HEADLINE: Conventions Are Ready, Primaries To Follow

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

 BODY:
SEVEN men and women have been campaigning to succeed Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. for months now, but except for occasional bursts of television advertising introducing their unfamiliar names to Connecticut, the candidates have focused on convention delegates rather than the public.
That ends in the next two weeks, as Democrats and Republicans meet in Hartford to choose their candidates for governor, and Mr. Weicker's A Connecticut Party convenes in Wallingford for a picnic at which Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark will be nominated by acclamation. 
 Both the Democratic and Republican conventions could result in voters getting an early say, in the September primaries, as to who they like. John G. Rowland, the former Congressman from Waterbury who nearly defeated Mr. Weicker in 1990, appears assured of the Republican convention's nomination a second time, but he may not be able to block Secretary of the State Pauline R. Kezer from winning enough delegates to qualify for a primary.
Among the Democrats, State Senator John Larson of East Hartford and State Comptroller William E. Curry Jr. both have enough delegates to file for a primary, and State Senator Richard J. Balducci of Newington is vowing to enter his name at the convention in an effort to qualify. Mr. Balducci has rejected overtures from the Curry and Larson campaigns, as well as party officials, to accept the lieutenant governor's nomination in the name of party unity. A fourth Democrat, Mayor Joseph P. Ganim of Bridgeport, pulled out of the race on Thursday and announced his support for Mr. Larson.
For Mr. Rowland and Mr. Larson, who have the greatest support from their party leaders and the largest war chests, the challenge in these last weeks before the conventions is to persuade delegates that they are best equipped to win an expensive general election in November, and that a primary can only weaken them.
Electability -- in large part defined by the ability to raise money -- is the only difference among the Democratic candidates, argued Senator Larson's campaign manager, Martha Carlson. "We are all Democrats, we are all pro-choice, we are all pro-family, we are all pro-worker," she said. "You could cover all of our positions with one derby hat."
But for candidates like Mrs. Kezer and Mr. Curry, their entire strategy is based on surviving the conventions so they can prove their appeal to voters in a primary.
"I think a primary is absolutely needed and absolutely helpful, because it offers voters a choice," Mrs. Kezer says, in asking Republican delegates to give her a chance to test her appeal against Mr. Rowland's. "Connecticut is basically a moderate state, and I'm a moderate Republican. John is a conservative Republican."
For many Democrats, the best argument against a primary is the experience of their last one, in 1990, when Representative Bruce Morrison defeated State Senator William Cibes, an open advocate of an income tax. His funds depleted, his campaign mired in the income-tax issue, Mr. Morrison staggered to a third-place finish that November, barely winning the 20 percent of the vote needed to preserve the Democrats' status as a major party. Mr. Cibes then left the party to join the victor, Mr. Weicker, as his budget chief.
"Once the primary ended, it was pretty much over for Bruce," said the state Democratic Party chairman, Edward Marcus. "It made it impossible for him to get his act back together and financially impossible for him to run the campaign."
Mr. Marcus's Republican counterpart, John Mastropietro, said, "I don't share the Democrats' hysteria about primaries," but he agreed that many primaries turn negative as candidates attack each other instead of debating the issues, just as in a general election.
 
The When of Conventions

 
 But while Mr. Marcus is hoping to use the Democratic convention (Friday and Saturday at the Hartford Civic Center) to settle on a consensus candidate, Mr. Mastropietro would just as soon eliminate conventions (the Republicans meet July 22 and 23 at the Bushnell) and decide nominations in direct primaries.
"Today people turn on their televisions, pick up their newspapers -- they know at least as much about the candidates as the delegates do," he said. "The need to rely on delegates to choose candidates for them is long gone."
The problem with Connecticut's system, he said, is that the primaries come so late -- this year's will be Sept. 13 -- that little time is left for candidates to soothe ruffled feathers and refocus on the general election, after spending months pursuing a relative handful of delegates.
"It seems to me an awfully, awfully long time and a lot of money to spend talking to 1,303 delegates instead of to the general public," Mr. Mastropietro said of the convention process. He would like to see direct primaries as early as May.
Among all candidates, Mr. Rowland, who is 36 years old, offers Republicans the best-known name, the result of his $3 million campaign in 1990. Like every other candidate, he has identified jobs and crime as the two most important issues, linking them to welfare reform and education as well.
His main proposal for improving the state's economy is to eliminate the personal income tax, making up for the loss of revenue by reducing state spending. A strong advocate of tougher sentencing laws for criminals, he criticizes the Weicker administration for spending lavishly on "Club Med" amenities in the state's new prisons.
Mrs. Kezer, a 51-year-old former teacher and state legislator, promotes herself as the only Republican to win statewide office since 1972. "I won my campaign four years ago," she says. "John didn't win his." She proposes to cut the income tax, but says it cannot be eliminated.
As Secretary of the State, she says, she has demonstrated that state government can be made to work more efficiently by cooperating with its employees. She would toughen criminal penalties by requiring felons to serve their full sentences.
 
Sizing Up the Democrats

 
 Among the Democrats, Mr. Larson, the 45-year-old Senate president, is most widely known, in part because of a recent television campaign. A former teacher and owner of an insurance agency, he stresses the state's need for a more focused economic development strategy and for improving its public schools. He is also concerned about family issues, and sponsored the first family-leave legislation in the country.
Mr. Curry, 42, speaks of his experience as comptroller and the need to reorganize the state bureaucracy. One way to make Connecticut a better place for business, he says, is to make its government work better. He favors community-policing strategies to curb violence in the state's cities, but also talks of making "prisons prisons again" by stripping inmates of privileges.
Mr. Balducci, who is 52, won praise as Speaker of the House in 1991 for holding together the coalition that enacted an income tax to end the state's immediate fiscal crisis. The owner of an auto salvage company, he says the state must improve its economy by aiding small businesses, controlling state spending and providing property-tax relief, as well as improving public schools.
 
The Weicker Candidate

 
 A Connecticut Party, meanwhile, has only one candidate, Mrs. Groark, who is closely identifying herself with the record of Mr. Weicker. At 56, her only political experience besides her term as lieutenant governor is four years as a Hartford councilwoman.
She pledges to continue the Weicker policies of making Connecticut more competitive by cutting business taxes and providing aid and loans to employers. Most of all, as an independent, she offers herself as an alternative to the politics-as-usual that voters rejected four years ago.

HEADLINE: Choir College May Get New Address

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG 

 BODY:
MOVING is nothing new at Westminster Choir College. Founded in Dayton, Ohio, in 1926, the institution moved to Ithaca, N.Y., in 1929. Three years later, the students and faculty packed up once again and relocated to Princeton, where the school still stands.
Now, Westminster, a renowned training ground for church musicians and music educators, may face the prospect of a third change of address -- this time to nearby Lawrenceville, home of the school's parent institution, Rider University. 
 No final decision has been made, but one thing is clear. Whether Westminster stays in Princeton or moves down the road, adjusting to changing times and economics will affect the school's environment, curriculum and mission.
The merger between Westminster and Rider (formerly Rider College) was one of necessity. The trustees of Westminster, which was heavily in debt, with deteriorating buildings and declining enrollment, began exploring the possibility of affiliating with a larger school in early 1991.
Though plagued by problems, Westminster was not without institutional suitors. Drew University, Yale University and the Juilliard School of the Performing Arts all expressed interest in acquiring the choir school.
In the end, Rider, a 129-year-old former business school, won out because of its proximity and solvency. On June 30, 1992, the merger became official, and Westminster Choir College affixed School of Music of Rider College to its name. When Rider gained its long-sought university status on April 13, 1994, Westminster became Westminster Choir College of Rider University.
But Westminster's new-found solvency and renovation failed to attract more young musicians to the college. The current enrollment of 343 students is almost the same as it was in 1991, the year before the merger.
Rising costs, combined with the static enrollment, have led to a deficit, which Dr. J. Barton Luedeke, Rider's president, estimated at $1.5 million a year. To compound the college's problems, buildings need further repairs and outmoded or undersized structures must be replaced.
 
Ran a Deficit
 Rider, which ran a deficit for the 1993-1994 school year, does not have deep enough pockets to meet these demands. Faced with an untenable financial situation, Rider's board, which includes two Westminster alumni, is investigating ways of preserving the choir college and returning it to fiscal health.
Among the cost-saving options under discussion is moving Westminster to the Rider campus, and that has created controversy. Rumors about a possible move began leaking out earlier this spring, and almost immediately what Dr. Luedeke calls "the anxiety meter" went up among students, faculty and alumni.
Concerned that the rumors were taking on a life of their own, Rider's president sent an explanatory letter to Westminster alumni in April. After outlining the school's problems, Dr. Luedeke encouraged alumni to continue contributing to the Westminster annual fund and referring prospective students. The letter ended with the line, "Together we can help Westminster move forward into a bright new future."
Though a move might improve the fiscal picture, Dr. Luedeke said that ultimately it would take a "combination of strategies" to keep Westminster in business. Increased enrollment is so crucial that he calls it the "driving force" behind Westminster's continued survival.
The primary responsibility for increasing enrollment will fall upon two newcomers to Princeton, Anne Meservey, director of admissions, and Westminster's dean, Robert Annis.
 
Turned a School Around
 Mr. Annis, who assumed his responsibilities on July 1, is no stranger to admissions problems. During his 11-year tenure as dean of enrollment services at the New England Conservatory of Music, Mr. Annis is credited with an admissions "turnaround" that included the recruiting of more Asian students to the Boston institution.
Mr. Annis, who visited Princeton during Westminster's alumni week, said the school's problems could not be solved easily. He said increased enrollment, strong fiscal management, new programs, more creative marketing and greater use of modern technology to spread Westminster's message would all play a role in the college's survival.
Westminster's affiliation with Rider is "crucial" to attracting new students, the new dean added. He said independent conservatories offering narrowly focused music programs were much less likely to survive than conservatories that offer students liberal arts courses as well.
While Mr. Annis, Ms. Meservey and others focus on increasing enrollment, trustees, administrators and consultants continue to explore the feasibility of consolidating the Westminster and Rider campuses. The Princeton campus, which was worth an estimated $20 million at the time of the merger, is being reappraised by an outside consultant.
At the same time, costs are being calculated for a building that might be erected to house the choir college on the Lawrenceville campus. Such a building would have to contain a concert hall of sufficient size to accommodate the Westminster population, plus soundproof practice rooms, office space, classrooms and a small recital hall.
The cost of construction together with the expense of moving large pipe organs and all the other choir college equipment will eventually be weighed against the cost of renovating and maintaining the buildings on the Princeton campus.
John Davis, president of the Westminster alumni association, said that he was "saddened by the possibility of the sale" of the Princeton campus, but that such a possibility was "the only feasible solution" to the school's problems.
He said that the school's chapel, which has not been able to accommodate the entire school population in years, needed enlarging or replacement, and that the costs of rehabilitating and maintaining the buildings on the Princeton campus would be high both now and in the future.
Though he is not optimistic, Mr. Davis has not given up all hope that the Princeton campus can be saved.
Dr. Luedeke remains undecided on the move. In mid-May, he said, he was in favor of consolidation. Now, he is not so sure.
Dr. Luedeke said of all the issues confronting Westminster, the financial ones are probably "the easiest to nail down." The emotional, educational and logistical problems will take longer to resolve. If the decision is made to move the campus, it cannot be accomplished for several years.

HEADLINE: DEATH OF A LEADER: THE OVERVIEW;
North Korea, Its Chief Dead, Leaves World Guessing

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Sunday, July 10

 BODY:
The sudden death of Kim Il Sung, North Korea's Communist leader, in the midst of negotiations with the United States has cast a pall of uncertainty over one of the world's least-known and most dangerous countries. But experts said that initial signs suggest the transition has been orderly so far.
Shortly after noon here Saturday, the official North Korean news media reported that Mr. Kim, 82, had died at 2 A.M. on Friday after suffering a heart attack. [Obituary, page 13.] 
 The Government appeared, on the surface at least, to be well prepared for the event. Pyongyang Radio issued a detailed funeral schedule, flags were flown at half-staff and foreigners living in Pyongyang reported that thousands of mourners in the otherwise quiet capital were flocking to a huge statue of Mr. Kim in central Pyongyang and weeping before this symbol of the personality cult he created.
Mr. Kim, who formed the Democratic People's Republic of Korea in 1948, was the only leader of his country in its brief history.
While there was speculation about a potentially violent struggle for succession, South Korean and American officials said they had detected no signs of such a conflict.
An edgy South Korean Government issued statements throughout the day Saturday that its military and police had been put on alert and that the Government was prepared for any developments. But the North Korean military was conspicuous for its lack of activity or unusual movements on both Saturday and today, several officials said.
Perhaps more important, Mr. Kim's anointed successor, his son, Kim Jong Il, was named head of the funeral committee and was referred to in official broadcasts as "outstanding leader," "his excellency," and a worthy successor to his father.
In a warm, rainy Seoul, the mood was calm today, with no noticeable police movements or concentrations of force. South Korean newspapers delivered mixed judgments on Mr. Kim's rule. Many condemned him for causing the nearly three million deaths during the Korean war and for subjugating North Korea's citizens under a despotic rule. But there was also concern that the hostile-edged stability he had come to represent might now be shattered.
While Sautrday's North Korean broadcasts created the appearance of a well-prepared plan being carried out smoothly, the developments raised as many questions as they answered and did little to ease fears about the threat posed to the region by North Korea, which has been locked in a tense dispute with the United States over its nuclear development program.
No explanation was given for the fact that it took the notoriously secretive Government 34 hours to announce Mr. Kim's death, and no foreign officials are being allowed into the country to attend the funeral or to confirm the accuracy of the reports.
It was unclear why the detailed medical report issued Saturday stated that Mr. Kim suffered the heart attack "owing to heavy mental strains." The source of the strains was not described and the mere mention of such a factor was a departure from the uncritical reverence generally shown Mr. Kim in the North Korean press.
In addition, the high-level negotiations that began in Geneva on Friday between American and North Korean officials have been suspended at the request of Pyongyang.
The talks, in which the United States is seeking to persuade North Korea to open its nuclear installations to international inspections, got off to a cordial start and offered some promise after the mounting tensions recently.
The negotiations came about after former President Jimmy Carter visited Pyongyang last month and sought to mediate the dispute. Mr. Carter delivered an upbeat assessment of his visit and said at the time that he had found Mr. Kim lively and engaged.
Just a few months ago, the United States threatened to impose economic sanctions if the North Koreans did not permit the inspections, and Pyongyang warned that sanctions could set off a war.
The suspension of the talks broke what might have proved the most useful link in years between the two countries, but President Clinton indicated at a news conference that they might resume later, another potentially hopeful sign.
"While they did ask that we suspend our talks with them, they asked that our representative stay in Geneva and we agreed to do that," President Clinton said in Naples.
Also, the first meeting between the leaders of North and South Korea, scheduled for July 25, has not yet been canceled, President Clinton said.
Nevertheless, Mr. Kim's death and the uncertainties it created hung heavily over the summit meeting of the leaders of the seven top industrial nations in Naples.
As a senior South Korean official put it Saturday, the best that could be said at this point was "there is no sense of crisis."
There are a number of reasons why other countries, especially South Korea, Japan and the United States, are likely to follow events in North Korea nervously.
Mr. Kim's death offers an opportunity for change and an easing of the hostility across the most heavily armed border in the world, the Demilitarized Zone separating North and South Korea.
It also creates an opportunity for turmoil in the most rapidly growing region of the world, East Asia.
For years analysts and government officials have feared the possible consequences of Mr. Kim's death. The most obvious potential problem is an outbreak of violence within North Korea if a power struggle gets out of hand. The country has a standing army of well over one million, and possibly a few nuclear bombs, so such a conflict could easily spill across the border and threaten South Korea.
A civil war, or even a lesser conflict, could also cause the flight of thousands of refugees, a thought that worries South Korea and Japan.
A more practical concern is North Korea's poorly developed economy, which was heavily dependent on barter arrangements with the old Soviet Union and China. Only China continues to provide essential raw materials, like oil, on favorable terms.
North Korea conducts very little foreign trade, its industrial base is believed to be falling apart, agricultural production has been declining and the economy has been shrinking for years. In 1992, the South Korean central bank estimates, the North Korean economy shrank by 8 percent and had a per capita output of just $943. That compares with $6,790 in South Korea.
Thus the concern is that political turmoil could cause the already shaky economy in the North to collapse, setting off a major economic crisis in South Korea and other countries in the region.
West Germany had the strength to support a collapsing East Germany after the fall of the Berlin wall. But few experts believe South Korea could do the same for a stumbling North Korea; several recent studies have estimated that it would cost more than $1 trillion to rescue the North Korean economy.
A new regime, less experienced in economic affairs, thus worries many analysts.
Those fears were behind a quiet shift in policy toward reunification by the South Korean Government's several years ago. It began to moderate its calls for rapid reunification of the peninsula, the common stated goal of both countries.
Many in South Korea now believe the process should be stretched out, perhaps over 10 years or more, to give the North more time to catch up economically. Indeed, many in South Korea and elsewhere in Asia would like to see North Korea adopt an open economic policy similar to that of China, its last close ally, to accelerate the integration.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE OVERVIEW;
On the Stump, Not Much Talk Of Health Care

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., July 9

 BODY:
Health care may be at the top of President Clinton's agenda, but at least for now it has sunk near the bottom as an issue on the campaign trail.
With voters saying they consider crime and the economy more pressing, and with Congressional debate mired in complicated and contradictory health insurance bills, most incumbents surveyed around the country barely gave health care a nod as they campaigned back home this week during the Fourth of July recess. Virtually no Democrats made a point of publicly embracing Mr. Clinton's embattled proposal. And even some of the physicians running for office have abandoned health care as their driving issue. 
 Here in California, the state with the second-highest ratio of uninsured to total population, Senator Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat seeking re-election, spent her time not on health care but on events geared to the crime issue, which carries little of health care's political risks.
"Violence is the No. 1 issue in the state of California today," Ms. Feinstein said in an interview on Friday after examining confiscated weapons at the San Bernardino County sheriff's office. "Next to that, I would have to say people are worried about whether they have a job today, and at the end of the year."
The current absence of any public passion on health care is bad news for the White House, threatening to diminish Mr. Clinton's ability to pressure lawmakers to meet his line-in-the-sand demand for universal coverage and his proposal for some form of requirement that employers pay for it. Beyond that, many advocates of a health care overhaul believe, the silence could jeopardize efforts to reach consensus on any compromise.
Backers of the President's proposal predict that interest will be rekindled when the issue advances to the House and Senate floors later this summer and the nation begins to focus on specific legislation. Their best hope, they say, is that incumbents of both parties will realize that health care's political risk is double-edged: that although they may be attacked for backing a given proposal, they are also liable to be blamed for gridlock if no substantial measure is enacted.
Many experts say Mr. Clinton has no one but himself to blame for the current lull. After creating a sense of urgency by linking health care to the larger notion of security for all Americans, they say, he allowed opponents of his plan to frighten much of the nation into thinking that it would cost too much or compromise care.
"Clinton squandered the salience of health care reform by his cockamamie nine-month task force," said Ted Marmor, a professor of public policy at the Yale School of Management who was an informal health care adviser to Clinton aides during the Presidential transition. "Over the past year, the public has become more rather than less confused about the link between the problems and the remedies. The choices now are between some Chinese-menu compromise, where they take a little bit from a lot of other things, or literally deadlock."
 
An Unenthusiastic Senator
 The inevitability of compromise or nothing at all seemed apparent among the campaigning lawmakers around the country this week, particularly in remarks by Ms. Feinstein.
An early supporter of the President's plan, she said she had withdrawn as a sponsor because of his proposal to require employers to pay for most worker coverage. That provision -- the employer mandate -- would be too damaging to business, she said.
"The people of our state want me to get it right," she said, "not to vote for something that's going to have an adverse impact on jobs and employment and small business in this state."
Ms. Feinstein was also unenthusiastic about the four health care bills that have emerged from Congressional committees. "It's like looking at a kaleidoscope," she said. "The more you look at it, the more the parts change."
One exception to the health care soft-pedaling on the stump this week was provided by Representative Michael Huffington, Ms. Feinstein's Republican challenger. In his kickoff television advertisement for the general election, Mr. Huffington, although himself no supporter of the Clinton plan, delivered a stinging rebuke to the Senator for backing away from it. "It's the only principle of a career politician," the narrator says. "Save your own skin."
Even some Democrats who still support the Clinton plan say they are concerned that universal coverage, although viewed by most Americans as a laudable goal, is not a particularly compelling message, given that most people already have some coverage. "We need a rallying cry about better coverage and lower costs," said George Burger, a Democratic strategist in Washington. "I don't think universal coverage gets it done."
The party is toying with other pitches. In a memorandum to Democratic candidates, Representative Vic Fazio of California, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, urged them to frame health coverage as a middle-class issue and to depict Republicans as protectors of big business.
"Health care will be the key to the '94 elections," he wrote. "It will play to our advantage only if we use every aspect of the debate to reinforce our key overall political/economic message: Democrats believe in linking work and reward; we're on the side of the hard-working middle class."
Nonetheless the candidates remain wary of embracing health care, since no one knows what will happen in Congress during the three months before adjournment or, more important, how the voters will react to whatever legislation evolves.
Another predicament for the White House is that perhaps the worst thing going for the President's proposal is its very name -- "the Clinton plan." Polls show that despite some nervousness over other elements, most Americans favor the proposal's cornerstones: universal insurance and employer mandates. But, the findings suggest, those same Americans have reservations about the author.
According to the latest Gallup poll, for instance, 77 percent support guaranteed coverage for all. And 52 percent say employers should pay either all or most of the insurance premiums. But in that same national poll, conducted June 25-28 with 1,019 adults, 49 percent said they opposed the "Clinton" proposal, compared with only 33 percent who opposed it a year ago. The poll's margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points.
Those results suggest that Mr. Clinton must somehow press his own proposal while at the same time distancing himself from it. Attacks from Republicans and others -- including Ross Perot, who plans a large-scale television effort -- are likely to make that difficult.
"The key to political success with health care reform this year is to escape the label of 'the Clinton plan,' " said Mark Mellman, a Democratic strategist. "What members of Congress need to do is say they are supporting a reform that's going to achieve the President's goal of universal coverage but will be different in significant ways."
Charles Rund, a Republican pollster in Northern California, said the White House should be learning a different lesson from what he describes as a lack of public interest. The Administration should ask itself, "Did we make an issue out of something that's not there?" said Mr. Rund, adding, "I don't hear any statement of what I would call populist America coming forward to get excited about the issue."
Senator Tom Daschle, a South Dakota Democrat who is a leading advocate of the President's proposal, said he was confident that the battle would turn in Mr. Clinton's favor.
"Nafta was a dormant issue until the last few weeks," the Senator said as he prepared to take the stage to lead a forum on health care in Sioux Falls this week. "Then, all of a sudden, the whole country came alive. I think you're going to see the country become very actively engaged in the coming weeks as this debate goes to the floor."
Other lawmakers are not so sure. Across town from Mr. Daschle's meeting, Senator Dave Durenberger, a Minnesota Republican who was one of a bipartisan group on the Senate Finance Committee that produced a health care compromise, told a gathering of health professionals that Mr. Clinton would have to bend on universal coverage.
"We can't do universal coverage unless we pay for it," he said. "And if the Finance Committee can't pay for it, nobody can."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Back home in California for the Fourth of July recess, Senator Dianne Feinstein spoke to schoolchildren about violence, a topic that has taken the spotlight away from health care, at least for now. (Marissa Roth for The New York Times) (pg. 18)
 
Chart: "DIARY: Health Care Developments"
 
WHAT HAPENED LAST WEEK
 
Members of Congress went back home over the Fourth of July recess, and President Clinton traveled to Europe for the G-7 summit. As a result, last week was a lull after the feverish conclusion of committee action. Seeking to drum up public support for Mr. Clinton's goal of universal coverage, members of the Cabinet traveled around the country for health care speeches. On Thursday, the Democratic National Committee made public a television advertisement poking fun at the insurance industry's "Harry and Louise" advertisements. In a nearly deserted Capitol, staff members worked on possible combinations of the four plans the committees left behind.
 
WHAT TO EXPECT THIS WEEK
 
Congress returns on Monday and begins work on Tuesday. The Democratic leadership will begin weighing what combination of the committee bills stands the best chance of winning approval in the House and Senate. The White House plans to step up its outside-Washington campaign.

HEADLINE: 7 NATIONS TO GIVE HIGHEST PRIORITY TO CREATING JOBS

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NAPLES, July 9

 BODY:
Describing the toll of unemployed in their countries as an "unacceptable waste," leaders of the seven major industrial democracies agreed today to pursue policies to keep a nascent economic recovery on track, encourage growth and create jobs.
Then, joined by President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, they turned to global political problems in a session overshadowed by the death of the President of North Korea, Kim Il Sung, and uncertainty about his country's plans to develop nuclear weapons. 
 The economic talks also produced a joint pledge by the leaders to "continue the momentum of trade liberalization." But President Clinton had to retreat from a proposal that finance, trade and commerce ministers of the seven nations immediately begin a review of trade barriers in the hope of presenting an agenda at the next annual meeting, in Halifax, Nova Scotia.
Mr. Clinton, who is trying to shore up his international policy credentials on his European trip, had committed his prestige just 10 days ago to acceptance of that proposal.
But France, supported by Britain and Germany, objected that new trade proposals would only make it more difficult for each country to ratify the sweeping accord reached in December under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Their goal of ratification by the end of this year will pose no particular difficulty in France, but it will require all the persuasive skill the Clinton Administration can muster in Congress.
Surprised and embarrassed, Administration officials said later that they had thought other countries would give more support to the proposal. France has not yet ratified the trade agreement; Germany did so on Friday.
Mr. Clinton said he felt good about the talks despite the setback, in part because the leaders had agreed to discuss next year what financial and political institutions were needed to meet the challenges of the next century. The Group of Seven consists of the United States, Japan, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Canada.
On the immediate problem of the decline of the dollar against the yen and the German mark, the leaders said not a word, perhaps out of fear of driving it down further, as President Clinton did when he talked about the dollar here on Friday.
Nor did they say anything to indicate whether central banks would buy large amounts of dollars to try to halt or reverse the dollar's slide, something the Europeans say would be futile anyway until nervousness in the capital markets fades.
"We shared the objective of a strong dollar," said Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen. But he said he refused to "telegraph" what the Federal Reserve Bank would do.
The seven men said they would encourage "stronger cooperation between our appropriate authorities to respond to the growing integration of the global capital markets" and insisted that nothing fundamental was wrong with their economies.
"Inflation is now at the lowest levels in over three decades and the conditions are in place for strong and lasting noninflationary growth," their communique proclaimed.
 
Finance Ministers Also Mum
 The seven finance ministers meeting here talked about the dollar at some length, officials said, but they did not issue a statement. The German Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, said the ministers "agreed the economic fundamentals are solid," with low inflation and the prospect of significant growth this year in both the United States and Europe.
In their communique, the seven heads of government reaffirmed that "unemployment remains far too high, with over 124 million unemployed in our countries alone."
"This is an unacceptable waste," the statement said. "We will build on the present recovery by accelerating reforms so as to improve the capacity of our economies to create jobs."
Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama of Japan was not among his colleagues today in the meetings at the 18th-century Royal Palace, across the blue bay from Mount Vesuvius. Summer heat was described as one reason he was taken to a hospital on Friday night, suffering from diarrhea and dehydration. His spokesmen said Mr. Murayama planned to join political discussions on Sunday, the final day of the summit talks.
 
Aid for Russia and Ukraine
 Before Mr. Yeltsin joined the group for dinner tonight, the leaders agreed to help Russia join the global trade agreement and to continue to provide financial underpinning for economic reform.
The seven nations offered Ukraine $200 million, in addition to $100 million previously offered by the European Union. They also offered an unspecified amount of loans to close the Chernobyl nuclear power plant, part of which exploded in 1986, and replace it with three safer reactors.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, which joined France in proposing the Chernobyl aid package, pronounced himself satisfied, calling the unsafe reactor "a ticking time bomb."
The seven leaders also offered Ukraine up to $4 billion of aid from international institutions over the next two years if it begins converting state-owned industries to private ownership, as Russia is doing.
 
All This and Soccer, Too
 For the most part, the leaders seemed to be in a self-congratulatory mood. Though their host, Prime Mininster Silvio Berlusconi, may have been upset by word today that his brother will stand trial on corruption charges, he seemed buoyant after Italy defeated Spain, 2-1, in today's World Cup match in Foxboro, Mass.
Though Neapolitans had been told not to stream into the streets to celebrate because of security measures, they disregarded the instruction with gusto, filling the streets on motor scooters and tooting air horns.
President Clinton was also upbeat. "I was struck by the degree to which the vision and the goals of the United States are shared by our partners," he said. One thing they agreed on, he said, was to discuss in Halifax "what we want the world to look like 20 years from now."
"We are still working with the institutions that we settled on at the end of World War II," Mr. Clinton said. "Are they adequate for the problems we face today and tomorrow? And if not, how do we need to change them?"
He made light of his disagreement with France on the trade review. "Every member of the G-7 except one affirmatively said they agreed with my trade proposal," he said. "One country said that this could complicate -- if we raise another trade issue now, that approval of GATT in his country was not a foregone conclusion."
President Francois Mitterrand, asked to explain France's position, said, "Instead of a too-rapid return to GATT issues, it would be prudent to wait for completion of the ratification process." But he said that France would be ready for further discussions next year, after ratification.

HEADLINE: Exxon Valdez Trial Focuses on Spill's Effects

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE, July 9

 BODY:
The second phase of a Federal trial on the Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1989 started this week with testimony about the life stages of herring and the intricacies of the wholesale fish markets as the oil company and the fishermen suing it battled over how the spill affected Alaskan waters.
For some jurors, who earlier found that the Exxon Corporation and the Valdez's skipper, Joseph J. Hazelwood, were reckless in causing the 11 million-gallon oil spill, the string of scientists and economists produced inadvertent catnaps. 
 "In a trial this long, where you have long stretches of technical and boring stuff, it would be strange if there weren't some of that," said James Neal, a lawyer from Nashville aiding Exxon's Federal case.
Other evidence concerned marine plants, life cycles of salmon, ocean temperatures and the price volatility of fishing permits. Closing arguments are scheduled for Monday.
Jurors in Federal District Court here intend to begin deliberations on Tuesday on a request by roughly 10,000 fishermen for $978 million in compensatory damages. The same jurors are set to consider punitive damages later this summer, which could expose Exxon to damages of up to $15 billion.
The jurors will examine loss estimates from several salmon fisheries in Cook Inlet, Kodiak and Prince William Sound, as well as alleged damage to the sound's once lucrative herring fishery. Commercial herring seasons failed in 1993 and 1994.
Exxon experts testified that there was no relationship between low prices paid to fishermen today and any consumer worry about tainted fish five years ago. Exxon says low fish prices are caused by market factors like the availability of farmed fish. Since the second phase of the trial began on June 20, the company has argued that the Alaska coastline has recovered from the spill.
At the same time, Exxon is defending itself against a lawsuit in state court. The plaintiffs in the second case include six Alaska native corporations and six Alaska municipalities. Claims were consolidated into four cases seeking $86 million.
Much of the state case involves alleged land damages. Plaintiffs concentrated their case last week on coastal-dwelling Alaska natives, who have relied on the sea for food.
Exxon lawyers say the claims are "greatly exaggerated," noting that one Alaska native corporation acknowledged that many of its 1,900 shareholders do not live on Prince William Sound.
The state trial is scheduled to last another month. The Federal case began on May 2, and no end is in sight.

HEADLINE: DEATH OF A LEADER;
Kim Il Sung, Enigmatic 'Great Leader' of North Korea for 5 Decades, Dies at 82

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sunday, July 10

 BODY:
By the time Kim Il Sung died on Friday at the age of 82, there was not one "Great Leader" running North Korea. There were three.
There was the man seen around the world as a Stalinist maniac, who 44 years ago sent his troops pouring over the 38th parallel to unify the Korean Peninsula on his own terms, and who four decades later burst again onto the front pages as a man in search of a nuclear bomb to save his regime. This was the Kim who intimidated his neighbors into silence, who used his unpredictability as a weapon. 
 There was the Kim Il Sung of North Korean myth, whose likeness dominates Pyongyang and every town square in the form of 30,000 statues, the man who was lionized in song as the "sun of the country" for single-handedly defeating two enemies in one generation: Japan and the United States.
And, in recent years, there was the grandfatherly Kim Il Sung, the smiling leader seeking respect for his economically disabled nation, the man who three weeks ago embraced Jimmy Carter and used him as a conduit to President Clinton, who was not yet born when Mr. Kim was installed as North Korea's leader. It was that incarnation of Mr. Kim that led the former President to declare, with little hint of skepticism, that a "miracle" had occurred. One of the world's most fearsome dictators actually sounded reasonable and eager to end his confrontation with the West.
They were all images that Mr. Kim, the peasants' son who went on to become the longest-surviving Communist leader of the cold war, knew how to exploit brilliantly. When his death came early Friday morning, he had been staging a remarkable international comeback, a shadow from the old newsreels of the Korean War who thrust himself into the atomic glare of the 1990's.
 
An Enduring Puzzle To the Outside World
 For those who met him, he was the incongruous dictator of a hard and unforgiving land. Former Representative Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn, who met Mr. Kim twice, said a few days ago:
"He has this avuncular persona that stands in stark contrast to the reality of the regime, which is without question the most ruthless and tyrannical anywhere in the world. It is like meeting Hitler at Berchtesgaden and commenting on how he got along with the dogs and the children. He has the blood of millions on his hands; he has a society based on Orwell's '1984.'
"So you expect someone who will act like Saddam Hussein, a forbidding, threatening presence. And he is just the opposite, always smiling, always speaking softly."
In fact, to step into Kim Il Sung's North Korea was to enter a laboratory from Orwell's wildest imaginings: a country that could not afford to keep the lights on at night, and yet which built -- but may never open -- Asia's tallest hotel, a country where the people seemed almost robotic in their praise of their leader and his son, Kim Jong Il, his presumed successor.
Millions of North Koreans, until this morning's news, have never lived in a country not run by Kim Il Sung.
During his rule North Koreans were urged to devote at least two hours a day, and four on Saturdays, to "Kim study," memorizing his sayings. His birthday was, for decades, the nation's greatest holiday, celebrated with "mass games" in which North Korean youth performed remarkable gymnastic feats.
It is a country of operas like "My Happy Country with a Great Leader," whose lyrics include:
O, Generalissimo, Kim Il Sung,
Our fatherly leader!
The people are unfailingly loyal to you!
Our party is the best in the world!
Socialism is the best in the world!
Let's defend Socialism,
Under the unfurled red banner!
Mr. Kim seemed, in every public utterance, to be nothing short of a god. Everything North Koreans received from the government -- clothes, rice, apartments -- were said to come directly from "the Great Leader" or "the Dear Leader," his son.
 Pyongyang considered 50,000 new apartments to be the Great Leader's birthday gifts to his people. But when a reporter toured these "gifts," no one discussed the fact that there was little heat and electricity.
"You have to remember that at home, President Kim Il Sung is treated as a combination of George Washington, Thomas Jefferson and Abe Lincoln," Mr. Carter said this week in Tokyo.
Mr. Kim's philosophy centered on the principle he called "juche," which he said meant "holding fast to the principle of solving for oneself all the problems of the revolution and construction of one's own efforts." This was to be accomplished, he added, while "applying the universal truth of Marxism-Leninism."
He held every important post in the country, including General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Workers' Party of Korea, its one party, and President of the country. And when he died, no one had yet really figured out his game: whether he was using the threat of an atomic weapon to get economic aid for his bankrupt country, or whether he was wielding it as a suicide pill to save his regime from absorption by the South.
"It is possible," one American official who has met Mr. Kim, said today, "that we will now never know."
 
From Humble Origins, A Steep Climb to Power
 Kim Il Sung was born to a peasant couple in a small, mud-walled house on the outskirts of Pyongyang on April 15, 1912, shortly after the Japanese began their formal occupation of Korea. For years that house has been visited daily by thousands of North Koreans.
Mr. Kim often used his simple birthplace to contrast his own early life with Pyongyang's American missionaries and Japanese residents. "In the 'Westerners village,' at the time inhabited by Americans and the Japanese settlers, brick houses, shops and churches increased in number," he recalled vividly many decades later, but across town "the slum quarters were getting bigger."
It is nearly impossible to separate truth and fiction in the state-sponsored mythology about Kim Il Sung's youth, but in all the stories there is a constant subtext: Mr. Kim's struggles against greater powers around him, particularly America and Japan.
Those two countries controlled the world in Mr. Kim's view, and it was the Kim family's destiny to battle them. In his memoirs, published two years ago, Mr. Kim maintained that his great-grandfather set fire to the General Sherman, a "U.S. imperialist aggressors' ship" because its crew went about "stealing the people's possessions and raping the women" while sailing up the Taedong River to Pyongyang in 1866. Mr. Kim's biographer at the University of Hawaii, Suh Dae Sook, calls these stories "politically motivated fabrications." but most of them seem impossible to verify or disprove.
Whether the stories are true or not, the myths have become the man.
Mr. Kim said he was a schoolchild when he committed his first act of rebellion against the Japanese occupiers, using a pocket knife to scratch off the title "Mother Tongue Reader" from the textbook issued by the Japanese colonial government, which required children to speak only Japanese. He said he wrote "Japanese Reader" on the cover, and from that moment, "whenever I saw children trying to learn Japanese, I told them Koreans must speak Korean."
Neither his memoirs nor official biographies dwell on the fact that he spent most of his youth in Manchuria, where he learned Chinese. That later turned out to be a crucial skill, as he joined China's communist guerrillas. And it was from China that Kim obtained the Communist philosophy that he combined with the nationalist mission his father bequeathed him -- along with two pistols -- on his deathbed in 1926: to free the peninsula from Japanese domination.
 
Images of Resistance, Masterfully Manipulated
 Mr. Kim served as an anti-Japanese guerrilla in Manchuria, Siberia and the North Korean border areas, but it is impossible to verify the claims of his astounding feats, including the killing of a unit of Japanese special police who were tracking him in 1940. The next year, he was forced to retreat to the Soviet Union for the remainder of the war. He makes no mention of that time, perhaps because it would be too obvious that his son, the "Dear Leader," was born there in February 1942, instead of on Korea's own soil. Mr. Kim was married to Kim Chong Suk, who died in 1949.
When he reappeared in Korea in late 1945, after the Soviet Union was already administering the area, it was in the uniform of a Soviet major. It was a ticket back home: At the war's end, the country was cut roughly in half at the 38th parallel, with the Soviet Union assuming the temporary occupation of the northern part and the United States the occupation of the southern zone. Reunification of the nation was the Allies' announced goal. Quickly, and with Stalin's apparent backing, he took control of the Korean Workers Party and called for a reunification under Communist control.
Of course, Mr. Kim's emergence was a far more complicated than the official accounts suggest. When he returned to Korea after 20 years' absence, his Communist party was tiny, outnumbered by other nationalist groups. But he rose to power by denouncing the "lackeys" of the Japanese and the Americans, and wiped out many of his enemies -- 60,000 people in his first purge.
The Democratic People's Republic of Korea was created in September 1948 after the United States organized the first government in the South, the Republic of Korea.
When Mr. Kim led an invading army into the South in June 1950 -- a scene of carnage that today seems a world away from modern Seoul -- the Truman Administration saw the takeover as the first step in a far broader Communist plot, directed from Moscow and Beijing, to seize much of Asia.
But a remarkable new study published earlier this year by Stanford University Press, one that is fairly chilling read in the context of the current nuclear standoff, shows that it was Kim Il Sung who did all the plotting. Documents recently made available in Russia, along with others that have slipped out of China, indicate that Mr. Kim was convinced he could take the South in three days.
His forces met little resistance in the first weeks, and by early September had driven the South Korean Army and its American allies to the Pusan area, at the southeastern tip of the Korean peninsula.
After a brilliant beginning, Mr. Kim's war plans went astray. He was surprised when, five days after his soldiers began streaming across the 38th parallel, President Harry S. Truman authorized American land, sea and air forces to go to South Korea's aid. Eventually 15 other nations responded to the United Nations call for help. Led by Gen. Douglas MacArthur, they reacted with a counteroffensive on Sept. 15, staging a large-scale invasion at Inchon, a conquered South Korean port on the west coast about 20 miles from Seoul. MacArthur's forces pursued them back over the parallel and, on Oct. 19, captured Pyongyang. By late November Mr. Kim and his troops had been driven almost to the Yalu River on the Chinese border.
But he was a wily strategist, and with "volunteers" from the Chinese Army and Air Force and some from the Soviet Union he recaptured Seoul in January 1951 and held it briefly. For the rest of the war bitter fighting was centered nearby and roughly along the 38th parallel.
MacArthur, who wanted to carry out another invasion of North Korea, advance beyond the Yalu into China and mount a full-scale assault on Communism, was relieved of his command by Truman.
As talks on a truce dragged on, battles continued. Finally an armistice was signed on July 27, 1953, ending the war that Mr. Kim had thought would reunite Korea under his control. It was a dream he never gave up.
According to official South Korean statistics, roughly 225,800 South Korean troops were killed in the war, along with 294,150 North Koreans, 184,000 Chinese and 57,440 United Nations troops, of whom more than 54,000 were Americans. In addition, 250,000 civilians are estimated to have been killed in combat, and millions were left homeless on both sides of the border.
 
Rivals Eliminated, Power Consolidated
 Mr. Kim emerged in a position to wipe out his remaining rivals. In later years he was to send his political enemies to work in the uranium mines, where the life expectancy was about two years. Those mines turned out to be critical assets. Years later he never forgot the threats issued by MacArthur and Truman, that the Americans might end the war with a mushroom cloud. The fear that the North could be subject to nuclear attack from the United States, to many minds, was the real start of North Korea's nuclear program.
At the end of the war, it seemed as if the North was destined to be the truly successful Korea. It had abundant natural resources, and with Chinese and Soviet help, Mr. Kim began an ambitious program of rehabilitation and industrialization with Soviet-model collective farms and heavy industry. A propaganda campaign led citizens to believe their country was an oasis of wealth and stability in a world impoverished by cruel capitalism. They had no way to see or hear about anything else: To this day there is no television from outside the country and no foreign publications allowed. The few foreign visitors are kept on a tight leash.
Mr. Kim courted his allies, but kept a measure of independence. In a single week in 1961, he signed treaties of friendship, cooperation and mutual military and economic assistance with both China and the Soviet Union. He continued to accept aid from both countries when the need arose. Through the years that need arose increasingly often.
The cost of the country's huge army took its toll on the economy. The DMZ, along the 38th parallel, became a eerie landscape of mines, tank traps and heavy artillery, and remains so to this day. Both sides built up enormous forces: Mr. Kim installed artillery that could shell Seoul from the North. But Mr. Kim also worried about his Communist allies. He was eager to maintain his slightly distant relationship with China and the Soviets, juggling them to keep from getting crushed.
In 1968, as the Vietnam War raged, North Korea and Mr. Kim surged into the headlines again. The North seized an American intelligence ship, the Pueblo, and its crew stayed in prison for 11 months. In 1972 there were the first gestures of peace to the South, called the Red Cross Talks, in which both sides talked of allowing families divided by the war to meet. But those negotiations broke off and were not resumed for 18 years.
The country began its slow spiral down in the 1970's. South Korea, with twice the population and a booming economy built on steel, cars, computer chips and other consumer goods, began to pull ahead: its economic growth was far faster, and the South's per capita income in 1990 was five times higher than the North's.
With the end of the cold war came the greatest blow of all: An end to the subsidies from Russia and, to some extent, from China that kept the North Korean economy going. Since 1989, by South Korean estimates, the North's gross domestic product has actually shrunk 2 or 3 percent a year.
For decades the Kims had been building a nuclear complex at Yongbyon, a mountainous area 60 miles north of the capital. Around 1980, construction began on a 25-megawatt reactor, that American intelligence agencies argued that the plant was designed for making plutonium, not for making electricity.
The cat-and-mouse game over the past few years has been all about the North's progress in building that technology, while denying it.
But every time there was talk of finally taking action regarding North Korea's nuclear development, the Asian allies fretted that Mr. Kim should not be provoked. The warning lights became impossible to ignore in March 1993, when the North announced it would pull out of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty rather than face continued pressure for disclosure and inspections. Their withdrawal was later suspended, but inspectors were kept out.
When North Korea began removing more fuel from its reactor this spring, potentially creating material for five more nuclear weapons, the United States moved for United Nations sanctions.
As fears of a confrontation grew, the United States sent more equipment to its bases in Japan and South Korea, from Patriot missiles to ammunition to laser-guided bombs.
In the last weeks of his life, Mr. Kim had one brilliant maneuver left. He let Mr. Carter, who was deeply opposed to sanctions, take up a two-year-old invitation to come visit Pyongyang as a private citizen. After the first night of talks, Mr. Carter went on television to announce that the Great Leader was ready to deal: He would freeze the country's nuclear program while the United States talked about a range of diplomatic and economic benefits that might end the North's isolation from the world. Meanwhile, international inspectors, who had been barred from parts of the nuclear sites, could stay there. The Clinton Administration was suspicious, but eventually dove through the opening. Mr Carter also emerged with an invitation from the South: A summit meeting between the Presidents of North and South Korea, a first since the peninsula was divided in 1945. Five decades after Asia's the war ended in a precarious stalemate, it would have been a symbolic melting of the last Cold War division. For many Koreans it would have undoubtedly raised a surge of nationalism that Kim Il Sung would have applauded: differences aside, we are all Koreans, our country divided only because we were pawns of the Cold War. He died 17 days before the meeting was to begin.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Kim Il Sung (Associated Press); Kim Il Sung embracing former President Jimmy Carter in Pyongyang last month after talks that led to a break in a dispute on North Korea's nuclear development program. (CNN via Associated Press); Kim Il Sung, pointing, with his son, heir and designated successor, Kim Jong Il, in front of Baegdu San mountain in North Korea in an undated photograph. HEADLINE: Jersey City Schools Audit Complicates State Control

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 7

 BODY:
When the State of New Jersey seized control of the Jersey City schools in 1989, officials cited fiscal corruption as a prime reason for the action. Now, five years later and just weeks before the state board is decide whether to extend the takeover, charges of financial mismanagement have again shaken the district.
Leo F. Klagholz, the Commissioner of Education, announced this week that an audit of the office of the Jersey City school business administrator had found a host of irregularities, inappropriate spending and weak controls. Two top officials have been dismissed over the findings that led to the audit. Elena Scambio, the Superintendent appointed by the state to run the district, has resigned. 
 But Dr. Klagholz says the turmoil does not mean that state takeover has failed in Jersey City, or that state control of local districts will not work.
"Takeover is a viable concept with great potential, partially when compared with what existed before," Dr. Klagholz said. "This is reflective not at all of the success of takeover. This is reflective of what can occur if we don't take our responsibility seriously in a state-operated district."
 
Leader Was on Leave
 The tumult over fiscal impropriety erupted in May, when Dr. Klagholz announced that his office had found irregularities in the awarding of a consulting contract to Child Study Team Associates of Bloomfield. He charged that two employees, Victor Demming and Elizabeth Guarino, altered documents, paid the firm $250,000 before it provided any services and processed payments without documentation.
Mr. Demming, the district's business administrator, served as acting superintendent during much of 1993, when Dr. Scambio was an assistant commissioner for urban schools in the state Education Department. Dr. Scambio returned to Jersey City last January. Ms. Guarino was executive assistant to the superintendent.
Dr. Klagholz said the audit found loose fiscal policies and weak internal controls. Among the irregularities were contracts that had not been signed by the right people; hand-written checks issued without proper requests or signed with a signature stamp; about $225,000 in incorrect or unnecessary payments made to various people and agencies; unauthorized travel advances; repairs of personal vehicles and salary increases of $15,000 to $22,000 awarded with no record of formal approval.
Dr. Klagholz said that the irregularities mostly occurred while Dr. Scambio was on leave. Because Dr. Scambio's Trenton position allowed her to continue overseeing Jersey City, she was essentially performing two jobs, and the Jersey City schools were being run by two people.
 
2 Employees Dismissed
 "I don't mean to criticize," he said. "But in retrospect I don't think it was a good idea."
After discovering the irregularities, Dr. Klagholz ordered the audit and called in the state Attorney General's office. He also called on Dr. Scambio to dismiss the two employees, but she refused. This week she resigned, saying she would not carry out his order. Dr. Klagholz appointed Peter Contini, an assistant commissioner, as acting superintendent, and he immediately dismissed the pair.
Dr. Scambio declined to be interviewed for this story.
The audit results come as the state is preparing to extend its takeover. State law on takeovers calls for keeping control for at least five years. State officials have hinted almost since the beginning that they would remain past 1994.
In the long, contentious process of getting into Jersey City, Dr. Klagholz said, state officials neglected to design a plan for getting out.
 
When to Go Home
 "In the future," he said, "we should go into the district with some sort of game plan, knowing how we'll decide when to turn back control.
"Here we are at the eleventh hour, absent a plan. I'm not sure what alternative we have but to extend it."
The question of when to declare victory and go home has broader implications. Paterson, the state's third-largest district, was seized in 1990. And the largest district, Newark, may be just months away from being seized.
On June 30, state officials received the findings of a 14-month investigation of the Newark school system, which has nearly 50,000 pupils. After reviewing the report, state officials are empowered to issue an order requiring Newark officials to prove why the district should not be seized. That order could come by the end of July.
Newark residents, many of them passionately opposed to state takeover, are watching the events in Jersey City.
 
Double Standard Is Seen
 "They're asking for two more years, but I wonder if they would give a district in trouble two more years to correct themselves," said Patricia Bradford, a Newark resident opposed to takeover in that city. "They still haven't answered the question, 'Can you teach children better?' "
When the state seized control of the Jersey City schools, more than 40 percent of the children entering high school failed to graduate. A state investigation found inept management, chronic disrepair, nepotism and an outmoded curriculum. The district's 30,000 students consistently scored near the bottom of standardized tests.
Several Jersey City residents said the change in leadership is a chance to test the takeover process and to begin restoring local control.
Robert Perry, a member of the school advisory board, said the board should have more authority than it has now. He suggested the state show good faith by giving board members a part in selecting the new superintendent.
"We are really the only official community voice," he said.
Raymond O'Brien, also a board member, said the district improved greatly under Dr. Scambio's leadership. Buildings were cleaned and repaired, principals given increased autonomy, curriculums rewritten and programs like full-day kindergarten extended throughout the system.
"I would hate to see anything halt that progress," he said.
 
Questions of Power
 But some see little improvement. In some schools, fewer than 25 percent of students pass the state high school proficiency test. Though absenteeism has improved, the dropout rate remains high -- the district continues to lose one of every six or seven high school students.
Dr. Klagholz said he would consider changes in the way the state controls a seized district. He has already told the state auditors that from now on, they will report to state officials and spend much of their time in Trenton.
"I have the feeling that Jersey City has been neither community-controlled nor state-controlled," he said. "The state hasn't paid a lot of attention."
The state must now create a plan for restoring local control. The 1990 corrective plan focused on specific problems, like the use of district vehicles. It includes no benchmarks for deciding when test scores have changed enough, or when enough financial safeguards are in place.
 
Need for Indicator
 Dr. Klagholz said one goal should be state certification. The district's inability to meet minimal state education standards was one reason for the takeover. But the district remains uncertified.
Dr. Klagholz says officials also need to find a student performance indicator they can agree upon, whether it be the state standardized tests, or national achievement tests.
"If you want to say there's been improvement, you can find the data," Dr. Klagholz said. "If you want to say there hasn't been improvement, you can find the data. If you want to say there's been regression, you can find the data. And people are doing all those things."
One of the biggest challenges is to insure, as far as possible, that patronage, mismanagement and abuse will not return when the state leaves. The irregularities found by the audit underscore how hard that task may be.
"It was politics and patronage which made this place an educational sewer in the first place," Mr. O'Brien said. "I could easily see it happening again tomorrow if the state leaves in October. With a $300 million budget, the wolves are circling."

HEADLINE: DEATH OF A LEADER: REACTION;
U.S. Unsure If Kim's Death Will Change Foreign Policy

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NAPLES, July 9

 BODY:
President Clinton and his aides said today that they had no real way of knowing how the death of Kim Il Sung would affect what remains the Administration's gravest foreign policy problem.
It was evident from their comments that the North Korean leader could not have died at a worse time for an Administration that only recently allowed itself to hope that the aging leader could prove instrumental in reducing tensions on the Korean Peninsula and ending a fierce dispute with the United States over nuclear weapons. 
 With Kim Il Sung having left his Government at the brink of parallel talks with the United States and South Korea, the question that could not be answered even by the high-ranking American officials who joined Mr. Clinton here for the summit of the leading industrial democracies was whether a successor might be prepared to order -- and have the clout to carry out -- the enormous policy changes the 82-year-old Communist dictator appeared to have been weighing in his final days.
At a news conference this afternoon, Mr. Clinton expressed reluctance to comment about the situation beyond a few known facts for fear of adding to "the sense of wariness and misunderstanding" that has poisoned relations between the United States and North Korea in the past.
With the high-level talks between American and North Korean officials that began in Geneva on Friday now postponed, Mr. Clinton urged gently that they be resumed "as appropriate."

 
 
Summit Plans Unchanged

 
 As one hopeful sign, the President cited news reports saying that the North has told the South that it intends, despite Kim Il Sung's death, to proceed with the summit between the countries that is scheduled for the end of this month. He also reported that the leader of the North Korean delegation in Geneva for the talks had asked their American counterparts to remain there until he received further instructions.
Mr. Clinton, who consulted earlier in the day with Defense Secretary William J. Perry and other top advisers, went on to emphasize that he had seen no need to put American forces in South Korea on military alert. But the uncertainties in dealing with the world's most isolated Government had clearly been enormously complicated.
"Because of the remoteness of this country, because of the suddenness of this change, it bears very careful watching," Secretary of State Warren Christopher said this afternoon.
 
The Most Likely Successor

 
 The most likely successor is widely thought to be Kim Jong Il, Kim Il Sung's 52-year-old son, who has been groomed as the heir apparent. American officials here said they had seen nothing to dispute the report from Pyongyang Radio that the death of the 82-year-old North Korean leader was a result of a heart attack. But they expressed a sense of unease that it had come just at the outset of the new round of high-level talks between the United States and North Korea.
That North Korea has also indicated that it does not intend to invite foreign leaders to attend Kim Il Sung's funeral also left American officials somewhat discomfited.
After offering "sincere condolences" to the people of North Korea, Mr. Clinton volunteered pointed praise today to the man who launched the Korean War for having shown "leadership" in the final months of his life by helping the talks to resume.
The President also said repeatedly that it was "in the interest of both countries" that the talks continue so the two countries might take further steps to resolve their dispute over North Korea's apparent efforts to build nuclear weapons.
That sentiment was echoed by Mr. Clinton's top national security advisers, who made clear that a willingness to proceed along the path set by Kim Il Sung would be regarded as a crucial test of good faith on the part of any new regime.

 
 
American Exasperation

 
 But as the gathering here was sent lurching by the need to grapple with that new challenge, officials also spoke with exasperation about the way events in Haiti, the currency markets and now North Korea had intruded on a setting they had envisioned as a showcase for American economic vitality.
Even more than questions about American policy toward Haiti dominated Mr. Clinton's first news conference here on Friday evening, questions about North Korea all but consumed the session this evening.
In looking ahead to what they said could be a fateful next few weeks, American officials expressed concern that even if North Korea does agree to the resumption of the Geneva talks, it could well harden its negotiating stand in a way that could fracture the fragile basis for talks.
They said it might be important for International Atomic Energy Agency officials to confirm that North Korea intends to abide its pledge, first made to former President Jimmy Carter last month, to freeze its nuclear program.
The American delegation here was first informed of the announcement of Mr. Kim's death at 5:13 A.M. in a telephone call from the White House Situation Room. Mr. Christopher was awakened almost immediately, while Mr. Clinton was not told of the news until he arose after 6:30 A.M because "there was no immediate decision to be made," a senior Administration official said.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
China Praises Kim
 BEIJING, July 9 (Special to The New York Times) -- China, a longtime ally of North Korea, reported the death of Kim Il Sung in a straightforward account today by the official New China News Agency.
Statements from Deng Xiaoping, the paramount leader, other high-ranking Chinese officials and the Foreign Ministry praised Mr. Kim, expressed sorrow and cited Chinese-Korean friendship.
Mr. Deng's statement, according to the news agency, said in part: "The life of comrade Kim Il Sung was one devoted to the national liberation of Korean and the happiness of the Korean people, and one dedicated to the forging and development of Sino-Korean friendship. with the passing away of comrade Kim Il Sung, the Korean people lost a great leader and I, a close comrade in arms and comrade."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Russia Reacts Cautiously
 MOSCOW, July 9 (Special to The New York Times) -- Russia reacted cautiously to Mr. Kim's death, with President Boris N. Yeltsin issuing a statement of "deepfelt condolences."
A Russian Foreign Ministry official said that Mr. Kim's death "should not worsen Russian-Korean relations."
