HEADLINE: River That Yielded Oysters May Harvest Tourism

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MAURICETOWN, N.J., July 7

 BODY:
As a river, the Maurice doesn't look like much at first -- broad and flat, snaking in lazy oxbows through the tidal marshland and sandy uplands of southern New Jersey to the shallow, shimmering Delaware Bay.
Yet the Maurice was a river to reckon with in New Jersey long before words like "suburbs" and "split level" and "turnpike" came to define the state. It was a highway for cotton for the mills of Millville, for bricks and hay, for sand headed for local glass factories. Above all it was host to the once-huge fleet of oyster boats, the shallow-draft schooners that raked the river and bay bottom for oysters once so plentiful that the Central New Jersey Railroad built a spur down the river to the packing plants at Bivalve and Shellpile to haul the oysters out to the tables of the world. 
 Now the oyster harvest is all but gone, a casualty of successive parasitic blights that wiped out the native oysters and clams after World War II. Yet the Maurice -- locally pronounced "Morris" -- has won a new distinction, one that says something about how the world has changed, and how it hasn't changed.
In December, President Clinton signed the law to designate 37 miles of the Maurice and its main tributaries, the Menantico and the Manumuskin, as the country's only river system whose banks are largely in private ownership to be designated for Federal protection under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act.
 
Fishermen Become Allies
 "This was precedent-setting for us, because these are private land rivers, and we went into the management study explicitly saying that the Federal Government was not going to acquire any land to protect these resource values," said Chuck Barscz, a planner in the National Park Service's Philadelphia office who specializes in wild and scenic river designations.
"We worked with local people so they could develop their own management plans, and one of the allies of the study were the fishermen, who were trying to protect the river because it is their livelihood."
Recreational and commercial fin fishing in the river and in Delaware Bay continues, as well as a limited version of oyster farming, which involves planting seed oysters and harvesting them when they mature.
New Jersey has one other river in the Wild and Scenic program, the Great Egg Harbor River. Because most of the Great Egg's area is already protected within the 1.1 million-acre Pinelands National Preserve, its designation was less a milestone for the Park Service, which administers the Federal program, Mr. Barscz said.
 
Big Brother Stays Out
 Under the Federal rules, all three townships containing the rivers, Commercial, Millville, and Maurice River, not only had to assent to the designation but also had to adopt matching land-use plans for the river areas. The local leaders overcame concerns about inviting new Federal regulations into one of the state's poorest regions. They agreed to the newfangled idea of a wild and scenic designation in hopes that restraints on shoreline development would help restore some of the wealth the river once produced, this time as a natural attraction in the nation's most densely populated state.
"We were for preserving the river, but we were concerned about Big Brother coming in with new regulations," said George Garrison, the Mayor of Commercial Township, who had at first held out against the designation. "Our township is financially depressed, there is very little economic basis here, and we had to make sure we weren't going to hurt the people who make their economic livelihood on the river and the bay."
Local boosters are talking about restoring one of the old fishing villages as a tourist draw to a part of the state that most people hardly know exists, perhaps creating a restoration yard for wooden ships, an oystering museum and other attractions.
 
'Those Rich Bird Watchers'
 "Eco-tourism, that's the answer," said Donald L. Fauerbach, who spent two decades with an oystering and ship-building concern on the Maurice before becoming executive director of the New Jersey Conference of Mayors. He helped found the group that spearheaded the designation drive, Citizens United to Preserve the Maurice and Its Tributaries.
"There were people who called us those rich bird watchers up on the river who wanted to keep the river to ourselves," he said, "but most of them came around to seeing this was a good plan for everyone."
Good also for the multifarious wildlife on the rivers and wetlands now under Federal protection. Good for the bald eagles that perch on snaggle-toothed pines, drawing bird watchers on silent paddle to the upper reaches of the Menantico, and ospreys, once nearly wiped out in the Maurice watershed by the DDT that farmers spread on their diked and drained tidewater fields.
Today, Mr. Fauerbach says there are 21 nesting pairs of ospreys up and down the river, their fledgling chicks ducking dutifully down into twiggy nests each time a parent squawks the warning of approaching humans.
 
Moral Support From Cedar
 In arrow arum and pickerelweed of the marshland, red-winged blackbirds, abundant as pigeons in Central Park, flash their improbably red chevrons against inky feathers. In the fall, the wild rice will turn brown and draw mobs of arctic wildfowl winging southward along the great Atlantic flyway.
At low tide, the slowly rotting skeletons of abandoned oyster boats can be seen resting in the mud, only their cedar wood frames for their dagger-board keels resisting decay, as if holding out for the new life the river's keepers hope will come with a Wild and Scenic designation.
"When the oysters died out, the captains were told to sail their boats up on the bank, strip them and leave them," Mr. Fauerbach said. "Think how they must have felt, rowing away. Now maybe we have a chance to bring some new activity back to this river."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "There were people who called us those rich bird watchers up on the river who wanted to keep the river to ourselves," said Donald L. HEADLINE: The Year in Albany: Results of the 217th Session of the Legislature

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 9

 BODY:
In an election year when the governorship and all 211 legislative seats are up for grabs, the New York State Legislature recessed its 217th session last Sunday at 11:20 A.M. with a number of major issues unaddressed. After failing to pass a budget until 69 days after the start of the fiscal year, the session ended in such disarray that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo immediately asked the Legislature to return later this summer.
Lawmakers were unable to reach agreements on creating a sentence of life without parole for third-time violent felons, on banning assault weapons, on a constitutional amendment to allow casino gambling, on finding ways to store low-level radioactive waste and on repealing the Wicks Law, which inflates government construction costs by requiring four separate subcontracts for each project. 
 The major accomplishments of the session were bills that would require the police to make arrests in domestic-violence cases, would toughen penalties for drunken driving, would ban smoking on school grounds and would expand the government's authority to compel mentally ill people into treatment.
The Assembly passed 1,565 of the 2,798 bills introduced in that house, while the Senate passed 1,514 of 2,585 bills introduced. A total of 792 bills passed both houses. Of those, Mr. Cuomo has as of today signed 286 and vetoed 7. As usual, many of the votes came in a last-minute flurry.
Following are the major actions of the session.
 
The Budget
 No one blinked when, for the 10th consecutive year, the Legislature missed the April 1 legal deadline for passing a budget. But few expected the battle to go on so long: the final plan was not adopted until June 8, making this the second-latest budget in state history.
In contrast to budget battles in recent years, when lawmakers disagreed over what cuts to make, the tussle this year was over how to spend a $1 billion surplus. In the end, the spending plan included $322 million for constructing and refurbishing sports stadiums and schools, $550 million in additional aid to school districts and $470 million in tax cuts, mostly for businesses.
The budget for the 1994-95 fiscal year, including all Federal money, totals $63.2 billion, an increase of 9.2 percent from the previous year. The general-fund budget, which includes most state tax and fee collections, is $34.2 billion, an increase of 7.3 percent.
The budget provided $44 million for prison programs, including the conversion of Gowanda Psychiatric Center near Buffalo into a 750-bed medium-security prison, the first expansion of the system since 1991.
In the course of budget negotiations, legislative leaders rejected two Cuomo ideas: creating a new keno lottery game and collecting $70 million each year in unclaimed bottle deposits to finance park improvements and environmental projects. The lawmakers also scaled back Mr. Cuomo's proposal to open boarding schools for gifted science and math high school students from across the state, agreeing only to a special school for students from the Albany area.
 
Crime and Justice
 
LEGISLATION VETOED
 Would have instituted the death penalty as a sentence for some murder convictions.
 
LEGISLATION SIGNED
 Requires police officers to arrest anyone suspected of seriously beating a spouse as part of a broad package to curb domestic violence.
Upgrades to a misdemeanor a third offense within 10 years of driving while impaired by drugs or alcohol.
Bans the sale of police uniforms to people not in law enforcement.
 
LEGISLATION PASSED
 Would establish a statewide DNA data base to store genetic samples from criminals convicted of murder, sex crimes and other serious offenses.
Would bar a victim's manner of dress as admissible evidence in rape trials.
Would allow judges to suspend licenses of people charged with drunken driving before conviction.
Would "flag" birth and school records of missing children to help track abductors who enroll the children in another area.
Would prohibit the sale of rolling papers and pipes to minors.
Would end a requirement that doctors predict whether terminally ill inmates will commit further crimes if they are paroled.
 
LEGISLATION FAILED
 Would have mandated life without parole for some criminals convicted of a third violent felony.
Would have banned two dozen military-style semiautomatic weapons and limited clip size for rifles and handguns.
Would have required fingerprinting for juvenile suspects charged in some felonies.
Would have made crimes motivated by bias a separate offense.
Would have allowed prosecutors not to specify exact dates in cases of continuing sexual abuse against children.
Would have required people convicted of sexual abuse against a child to register in their municipality upon release from prison.
Would have eliminated the requirement that prosecutors prove that suspected drug dealers knew the weight of the drugs they sold or possessed.
Would have expanded drug treatment and jobs programs as alternatives to prison for nonviolent offenders.
Would have placed restrictions on plea bargains for serious felonies.
Would have legalized Mace and other such chemicals for self-defense.
Would have suspended licenses of people under 21 convicted of drunken driving.
Would have allowed rape victims to request an H.I.V. test of their attackers.
Would have stiffened penalties for theft of a pet.
 
Health and Insurance
 
LEGISLATION SIGNED
 Includes 13- and 14-year-olds in the state's subsidized health insurance program for the children of the working poor.
Extends for one year the state's program for providing extra medical malpractice insurance to doctors.
Allows financing of life care communities for the elderly through industrial development agencies.
Allows insurance companies to offer policies covering expenses incurred by adopting parents when one or both of the birth parents withdraw consent for the adoption.
 
LEGISLATION PASSED
 Would create a pilot program in which the courts could compel hospitalization of a mentally ill person who fails to take medication or undergo counseling.
Would give police officers authority to detain a person apparently intoxicated by drugs or alcohol for up to 48 hours if the person demonstrates a danger to himself or others.
Would allow social workers, nurses and psychologists in state-authorized mobile psychiatric units to determine whether people who seem to be mentally ill should be hospitalized.
Would ban smoking on school grounds and other places used heavily by children and would prohibit the sale of individual cigarettes.
Would require hepatitis B immunizations for children born after 1993 before they enter kindergarten.
 
LEGISLATION FAILED
 Would have required health care providers to counsel pregnant women and new mothers about the benefits of testing for H.I.V.
Would have required doctors to notify parents of the results of H.I.V. tests now performed anonymously on their newborns.
Would have prohibited obstruction of anyone's entering or leaving any health care facility, including abortion clinics.
Would have required parental notification before abortions performed on minors.
Would have allowed family members and friends to make health care decisions, including terminating life support, for incapacitated patients who have not left specific instructions.
Would have allowed terminally ill patients the right to request and receive a physician's aid in dying.
Would have prohibited the genital mutilation of women.
 
Education
 
LEGISLATION SIGNED
 Would allow certain municipalities to create new school districts, a measure intended to allow the Satmar Hasidic village of Kiryas Joel in Orange County to have its own public school district.
 
LEGISLATION PASSED
 Would speed up the process of disciplining teachers and allow school districts to fire teachers as soon as they are convicted of certain crimes against children.
Would require the state's five largest cities to contribute a similar amount of aid to their school districts as in previous years.
Would give New York City until Feb. 1, 1995, to redraw community school district lines and allow the number of districts to increase to 37 from 32.
Would allow 60 schools with plans for innovative teaching programs to be exempted each year from state regulations.
Would require all schools to teach about the Holocaust, slavery and other human rights atrocities.
Would exempt the New York City School Construction Authority from the state Wicks Law for the next five years.
Would have prohibited most public school students from performing harmful experiments on live vertebrate animals.
 
LEGISLATION FAILED
 Would have taken most hiring responsibilities away from community school boards in New York City and given them to district superintendents.
Would have required elementary schools to notify parents within three hours of the start of the day if a child is absent without authorization.
Would have allowed New York City's schools chancellor and the state commissioner of education to take over failing schools.
Would have decentralized New York City's school system by creating a board of education in each of the five boroughs.
 
Business and Labor
 
LEGISLATION SIGNED
 Deregulates the setting of interest rates by banks on most forms of consumer credit.
Gives jockeys permission to wear advertisements on their clothing during horse races.
 
LEGISLATION PASSED
 Would create a new hybrid business entity, known as a limited-liability company, that has the liability protections of corporations and the lower tax rates of partnerships.
Would exempt most businesses, local governments and nonprofit organizations from state regulations regarding security guards.
Would require winter racing at Aqueduct Racetrack and provide an $8.5 million loan to the New York Racing Authority to cover the costs.
 
LEGISLATION FAILED
 Would have legalized casino gambling in the Catskills, on riverboats and at racetracks subject to approval by local voters.
Would have restricted suits brought by shareholders against corporate boards for misconduct.
Would have partly repealed a law that requires the hiring of at least four subcontractors on most public construction projects.
Would have increased the pensions of most public employees.
Would have given a state board jurisdiction over contract negotiations between New York City and its police union.
Would have expanded the types of public construction projects that must pay union wages.

 Permits the use of a name stamp for voting machine and paper ballot write-ins.
Authorizes the payment of the balance of Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin's 1994 salary, or $77,403.89, to his widow, Sylvia Weprin, following his death on Feb. 11.
 
LEGISLATION PASSED
 Would change New York's Presidential primary from the first Tuesday in April to the first Tuesday in March, except in 1996, when it would be on the first Thursday in March.
Would require the state to make voter registration applications available in motor-vehicle, social-service and other state offices.
Would expand the jury pool to include people on the welfare and unemployment rolls.
Would amend the State Constitution to ban the use of public authorities to issue debt for state capital projects and to place a cap on state debt.
Would require the Legislature to publish bill texts, vote tallies, bill memorandums and hearing notices on the Internet.
 
LEGISLATION FAILED
 Would have required the state to assume the share of Medicaid costs currently paid by local governments, in exchange for local governments' ceding some taxing authority to the state.
Would have authorized the secession of Staten Island from New York City.
Would have limited campaign contributions and expenditures, broadened financial-disclosure requirements and made it easier for insurgent candidates to get on the ballot.
Would have required fingerprinting of voters.
Would have allowed voting by mail and authorized the use of electronic cards to validate voters' identification.
Would have required the Legislature to vote on any bill if 50,000 residents sign a petition supporting it.
Would have extended the state law allowing cameras in the courts, which expires in January.
Would have required election-day expenses over $50 to be paid by check.
Would have required drug tests for legislative candidates.
 
Welfare and Families
 
LEGISLATION SIGNED
 Expands the state's electronic finger imaging of welfare recipients from 2 counties to 12.
Makes it a violation of the civil rights law to prohibit a woman from breast feeding in public.
 
LEGISLATION FAILED
 Would have eliminated increased welfare benefits on the birth of additional children.
Would have imposed harsher penalties on welfare recipients who fail to enroll in job training.
Would have placed a two-year limit on the state's welfare program for single males and childless couples..
Would have forced many unmarried welfare recipients under 21 to live with their parents.
Would have required welfare recipients who have not graduated from high school to enroll or risk a loss of benefits.
 
Energy and Environment
 
LEGISLATION SIGNED
 Authorizes the state to spend $19 million for acquiring environmentally sensitive land in the Pine Barrens of Long Island and Adirondack Park.
 
LEGISLATION PASSED
 Would require many state agencies to provide public information about the toxic chemicals they release into the atmosphere.
Would allow the state to swap land with three private landowners in Adirondack Park who want authorization to build on forest preserve land that is protected by the State Constitution.
 
LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have allowed storage of low-level radioactive waste at certain state-run nuclear power plants.
Would have required state and local agencies to consider whether minority and low-income communities are disproportionately affected by pollution before issuing various permits.
Would have allowed the owners of billboards near state highways and roads to clear trees that obscure their advertisements.
Would have prevented the dumping of incinerator ash in mines.
Would have required municipalities to meet state goals for recycling before they could receive state permits to build garbage incinerators.
Would have exempted large bakery ovens from state air pollution laws.
Would have required packaging sold in the state to be made from recycled or reusable materials, be easily recyclable or be smaller in size.

 Would have required state and local transportation agencies to study ways to encourage people to use mass transit before building or expanding highways.

HEADLINE: How a Shubert Fund Produces and Directs

SERIES: Backstage Drama: The Shubert Foundation -- First of two articles.

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
Along 44th Street west of the throb of Broadway, marquees trumpet the latest theatrical offerings and the din of voices animates the street. In the midst of this strip of theaters, out of cramped offices above Sardi's restaurant, the Shubert Foundation discharges its philanthropic glow, handing out grants: $100,000 to the Actors Theater of Louisville, $5,000 to the Indiana Repertory Theater and on and on, perpetuating its standing, in volume of grants and quantity of unrestricted money, as the country's largest private financial supporter of nonprofit theater.
But the Shubert Foundation has long been more than it appears, although keeps its operations purposely in the shadows. The foundation is not just an altruistic extension of the Shubert Organization, the country's most powerful owner and operator of legitimate theaters, home of hits ranging from "Oklahoma!" to "A Chorus Line" to "Cats." Thanks to a little-known and highly unusual tax arrangement, the foundation actually owns the Shubert Organization and dictates who runs it. 
 That arrangement, the result of a 1979 Internal Revenue Service ruling, is not simply an arcane matter. Without the ruling -- or an alternative remedy -- the Shubert empire would have had to be dismantled, in the way that the Kellogg Foundation had to relinquish control of the cereal company. Without it, the Shubert Foundation would undoubtedly not have grown and prospered so. Without it, the two rulers of the entire Shubert realm -- Gerald Schoenfeld and Bernard B. Jacobs -- would not have had their reign prolonged and preserved.
These days, the foundation is entering a pivotal stage. Mr. Schoenfeld and Mr. Jacobs are not young. Mr. Schoenfeld is 69. Mr. Jacobs is 78. Who their successors will be is a subject of intense speculation in the theater world. But Mr. Schoenfeld and Mr. Jacobs have no inclination to retire nor have they identified any succession plan. Lee J. Seidler, a Shubert Foundation director, said recently with total conviction, "Both of those guys are going to die in their chairs."
The two men sit atop a formidable cultural and real-estate empire whose fate has considerable bearing on the American theater and the civic health of New York City. Broadway theater alone generates an estimated $2.4 billion a year for the city's economy.
The Shubert empire owns or operates 16 Broadway theaters (and is co-owner of a 17th), half of the existing houses, as well as four theaters in other cities and additional plum Manhattan property. Thus, what happens to the dominion once the Gerry and Bernie show finally closes will affect a crucial section of New York -- Times Square -- which, after years of fits and starts, seems on the brink of extensive redevelopment. Any change in the enterprise -- particularly if it no longer remains fundamentally a theater business -- would also have a profound influence on the direction of the Broadway theater at a time of hand wringing over its well-being and, through Shubert Foundation grants, on the entire fragile infrastructure of the American theater. Everything, from what shows come to Broadway, to what stagehands make, to what price theatergoers pay for a ticket, is mightily affected by the Shubert kingdom.
The foundation's wealth, conservatively estimated at $149 million, makes it one of the nation's largest. The Foundation Center, which tracks charities, ranks it 169th in assets among the country's more than 35,000 foundations, though well below front-runners like the Ford Foundation, whose worth bulges into the billions. In May, the Shubert Foundation announced record 1994 grants of $6 million, $3.5 million of which benefited theater, most of the remainder going to dance groups and arts institutions.
But its greater significance lies in the iron-handed control it exerts over the Shubert theater empire. Such an arrangement, in which a sizable for-profit business, the Shubert theaters, belongs to a nonprofit private foundation, is extraordinarily rare and is almost always forbidden under Federal tax laws. Pamela Mann, the head of the charity division of the New York State Attorney General's office, said she knows of no similar setup. Neither does John Edie, legal counsel for the Council on Foundations, the foundation trade organization.
A simple relationship endures between the theater organization and the foundation. The board of the Shubert Foundation, the entity with the power to choose successors to Mr. Schoenfeld and Mr. Jacobs, is composed of six rather disparate men. These same individuals also constitute the board of the Shubert Organization. They faithfully re-elect one another year after year. Eight or nine times annually, they convene for their Shubert Foundation board meeting, then, without leaving their seats, reconvene for their Shubert Organization meeting.
For two decades Mr. Schoenfeld and Mr. Jacobs, collectively known as "the Shuberts," have perched at the helm of this integrated empire, serving as chairman and president, respectively, of both boards. They are said to earn $1 million each, plus bonuses that could approach their salaries, all paid directly by the Shubert Organization and not required to be disclosed in Shubert Foundation public filings.
The other board members are, surprisingly, not otherwise connected to the theater: John W. Kluge, is chairman of Metromedia Inc. and among the country's richest men; Irving M. Wall is a lawyer; Lee Seidler is a retired accounting expert, and Michael I. Sovern, the former president of Columbia University, is a law professor there.
Age and illness have figured significantly in Mr. Schoenfeld's and Mr. Jacobs's careers. They ultimately vaulted to the top of the theater empire in an unruly power struggle among irreconcilable directors of the foundation. In no small way, this was precipitated by the failure of the founding Shubert brothers -- Sam, Lee and J. J., who established their theatrical kingdom in the early 20th century -- to orchestrate an orderly transition. Now many in the theater community wonder if a similar untidy duel may someday be in the offing: dead hands of the past reaching into the future.
Asked about succession, Mr. Schoenfeld said: "That is a private matter. I won't talk about it." In an interview some years ago, Mr. Jacobs said: "Of all the things in the world I think the least about, it's what happens after you die. Dead is dead."
This is the story of the Shubert Foundation, not the theatrical organization, though one shapes the other. While Mr. Schoenfeld and Mr. Jacobs have talked volubly about their shows over the years, they have rarely spoken about the foundation. Since a fusillade of corruption charges battered the foundation in the 1970's, the two have been loath to raise its decidedly low profile. Recently, however, they agreed to discuss their role in it during extensive interviews at the resplendent Shubert offices, in Shubert Alley, across from the foundation headquarters, where exquisite wood paneling, French tapestries and Chinese screens overwhelm the eye.
The evolution of the foundation is a convoluted drama wrapped in the permutations of family, with untimely intermissions for scandal and legal encumbrances. The foundation started small and unheralded. Death, above all, made it something else entirely.
 
A Foundation Is Born
No Safer Place To Keep Money
 On June 28, 1945, Lee and J. J. Shubert quietly formed the Sam S. Shubert Foundation (its name was shortened in 1971), ostensibly to honor their deceased brother, Sam. They had waited 40 years past his death to extend the tribute, but then it is widely assumed that the true motivation, as with many foundations, was to lighten their income taxes and eventual estate taxes. In their wills, the brothers made it clear that they wanted the foundation ultimately to own the theaters. In short, they wished to stockpile their wealth where no one -- especially the Government -- could get it.
The foundation's stated mission was a broad one -- to carry on religious, scientific, literary and educational work, and to give away money for educational purposes. A press release at the time reported that it had assets of $500,000 and intended to contribute to religious charities. The original board consisted of Lee, J. J., John Shubert (J. J.'s son), Dora Wolf (Lee and J. J.'s sister) and three Shubert lawyers.
For quite a while, the foundation did not dispense much money -- nor did it have to. Before the Tax Reform Act of 1969, there were no enforceable requirements for how much foundations had to give away. As Mr. Seidler phrased it: "It was a wonderful way of putting money into limbo." (Today, foundations must distribute an average of 5 percent of their assets annually.)
For years, the Shubert Foundation remained a small arm of the brothers' theater business, its assets no more than a few million dollars. The deaths of Lee and J. J. Shubert changed that.
Lee, who was childless, died in 1953. Control of his stake in the various Shubert companies that made up the Shubert Organization passed to J. J., but Lee left the bulk of his estate to the foundation, more than doubling its worth, to around $7 million.
Lee's passing was the first of a parade of deaths that would provide exceptional opportunity to Gerald Schoenfeld and Bernard Jacobs. When Lee was alive, Shubert legal affairs had been handled by the firm of Klein & Weir. William Klein was the overseeing attorney and Milton Weir was the day-to-day man. However, J. J., the querulous sole surviving brother, disliked Mr. Weir. He anointed as the daily lawyer another member of the firm named Adolph Lund. The company of Klein & Lund was formed, and it set up shop in the Shubert offices.
Mr. Lund had two clients: Shubert and a hanger maker. He, in turn, enlisted help from a junior lawyer named Gerald Schoenfeld, a cherubic, earnest New Yorker whose father made fur coats. When Mr. Lund died on New Year's Day of 1957, at the age of 49, his premature death left Mr. Schoenfeld as the primary Shubert lawyer; he also took over the hanger maker.
For months, J. J. never paid Mr. Schoenfeld a cent. "He hadn't mentioned salary yet, and I couldn't ask him," Mr. Schoenfeld said. "The way things worked, you had to wait until J. J. brought the subject up."
After a few months, J. J. told Mr. Schoenfeld he ought to recruit another attorney. Mr. Schoenfeld mentioned the opening to Mr. Jacobs, a crusty, somber-looking lawyer who was in practice with his brother, largely handling jewelers. Both the Schoenfelds and the Jacobs lived on the West Side of Manhattan, and, despite the nine-year difference in their ages, the two men had known each other since they were young, for Mr. Jacobs was best friends with Mr. Schoenfeld's older brother.
Mr. Jacobs joined Shubert on St. Patrick's Day of 1958. As a welcoming gesture, J. J. made it clear to Mr. Schoenfeld that he would be held directly accountable for anything Mr. Jacobs did wrong.
By the early 1960's, J. J. was in such delicate health that direction of the Shubert operations had essentially passed to John Shubert, his only child, who was considered a fairly adept businessman. But John met an unexpected death from heart failure in late 1962, at the age of 53. The only relative of the Shuberts active in the business was Lawrence Shubert Lawrence, a grandnephew of the Shubert brothers and a man felt to have highly dubious managerial qualifications.
Mr. Schoenfeld and Mr. Jacobs said they contemplated seizing power themselves, but a lawyer advised them it would be unseemly. And so, Mr. Lawrence was anointed president of both the organization and the foundation.
In 1963, a catalytic moment arrived for the foundation. At 83, J. J. Shubert died. His will turned over the bulk of his estate, including the theaters, to the foundation. This meant that for the first time ownership of the vast theater network would pass from the family to the foundation and cause the theater organization to become subservient to the foundation. Henceforth, the foundation -- and those who led it -- would wield all the power.
 
A Weak Leader Reigns
The Empire Teeters
 The early 1970's were not merry times for the Shubert Foundation. They brought upheaval, scandal and many pilgrimages to court. In no small way did this evolve out of the soothing companionship of a liquor bottle.
Mr. Lawrence quickly demonstrated how ill suited he was to run the Shubert companies. Under his watch, the business foundered. He also had a major-league drinking problem. "He was not the most competent person in the world," Mr. Jacobs said. "And he suffered from the fact that 22 out of 24 hours a day he had more liquor in his system than he should have." Year after year, particularly after blockbuster hits like "Fiddler on the Roof" had run their course, the theater business lost money, propped up only by income from real-estate holdings.
The enterprise was teetering. The power structure was about to be rearranged.
By 1971, deaths had whittled the foundation board down to two directors: Mr. Lawrence and Kerttu (Ecky) Shubert, the widow of John Shubert. Mrs. Shubert did not much care for Mr. Lawrence, but she favored Mr. Schoenfeld and Mr. Jacobs.
Two directors was one fewer than required by the foundation's certificate of incorporation. According to statements Mr. Lawrence made in court papers (he died in 1992), he had a running dispute with Mrs. Shubert over appointing additional independent directors. Eventually, State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, who had regulatory authority over foundations, began to impose pressure of his own. New directors would be crucial choices because the foundation directors, for the first time, could choose who would run the entire theater and real estate enterprise.
After much discord, a bargain was struck. To satisfy Mrs. Shubert, Mr. Schoenfeld and Mr. Jacobs would be nominated to the board. Mr. Lawrence's nominees were his lawyer, Irving Wall, and Irving Goldman, a well-connected businessman who, as a boy selling paints used for scenery, had got to know J. J.
With the support of the other directors, Mr. Schoenfeld and Mr. Jacobs quickly revised the foundation's certificate of incorporation. One key change involved members' terms. The original certificate had bestowed life terms. Now, the six members as of Aug. 26, 1971, would serve for life, and those subsequently elected would have one-year terms. In a clarification added later, it was stated that the initial six directors could never be removed -- for any reason whatsoever.
Granting directors life terms is unusual among foundations, experts in the field say, and this action was subsequently pointedly criticized by the Attorney General's office.
 
Enter Irving Goldman
The Strategy Of a Takeover
 By now, Mr. Schoenfeld and Mr. Jacobs had concluded that the organization could no longer countenance Mr. Lawrence and his ineptness. So they made a Faustian pact involving Irving Goldman.
Mr. Jacobs said he never really cared for Mr. Goldman. Mr. Schoenfeld described him this way: "The Pope? He would know the Pope. The King of England? He would know the King of England. The truth is, you never knew if he knew anybody."
One thing they did know: the man had a thirst for power. And so the two lawyers offered him a deal too good to turn down: if he voted with them to oust Mr. Lawrence, he would share the power with them and become head of the Shubert Foundation.
In June 1972, the board deposed Mr. Lawrence as head of the organization and the foundation, although he remained a director. His power was invested in the triumverate -- Mr. Jacobs, Mr. Schoenfeld and Mr. Goldman. It was vaguely decided that Mr. Schoenfeld would reign over the nontheatrical real estate, most theater union negotiations and pensions, while theater operations and the selection of shows became largely the province of Mr. Jacobs. Mr. Goldman was put in charge of the foundation, vendors used by the theaters and theater maintenance.
Once in command, Mr. Jacobs and Mr. Schoenfeld said they found the Shubert operations more parlous than they had thought. There was no cash, the place was going broke, and half the Broadway houses were dark.
To resurrect the kingdom, they began investing in some shows to get them into their theaters. And they undertook a search for money-making productions. Within months, one came their way: "Pippin." Its rousing success gave them breathing room. In 1974 they booked "Equus," and more money poured in. They began refurbishing the theaters, then in deplorable shape, updated sales practices to allow tickets to be paid for by check or credit card and bought over the telephone, and spearheaded a reclamation effort of the seedy Times Square area.
Then, in July 1975, they had the great good fortune to put a musical named "A Chorus Line," which Joseph Papp had produced downtown, in the Shubert Theater. It blossomed into a remarkable money machine that spewed forth millions of dollars and solidified the Shubert empire.
Meanwhile, an incensed Mr. Lawrence had sued Mr. Schoenfeld, Mr. Jacobs and the other directors in State Supreme Court in January 1973 to regain control; he accused Mr. Schoenfeld and Mr. Jacobs of a conspiracy to seize power. The suit was dismissed because it had been filed too late.
But the Lawrence rumblings led Attorney General Lefkowitz to undertake an investigation of the foundation. In March 1974, he filed civil charges against the executors of J. J.'s estate as well as Mr. Schoenfeld, Mr. Jacobs and Mr. Lawrence, saying there had been millions of dollars of "grossly excessive, unjustified and unreasonable" claims. He charged the Shubert officials with conflicts of interest that he maintained had deprived the foundation of millions of dollars.
Once again, the consequences of sickness and death favored Mr. Schoenfeld and Mr. Jacobs. The assistant attorney general handling the case became ill and retired. Surrogate S. Samuel DiFalco, under whose jurisdiction the estate case fell, reached retirement age and soon died.
The merits of the Lefkowitz case were never judged in court, because several years later the Attorney General withdrew the charges in return for the executors and lawyers of J. J. Shubert's estate agreeing to reduce their claims by $2 million. That money then passed to the foundation.
So Mr. Schoenfeld and Mr. Jacobs had moved into power. "There was a weak king," said Foster Hirsch, the author of a forthcoming book on the Shuberts entitled "The Boys From Syracuse." "They took power away from the weak king. They did what anybody else would have done."
 
The Goldman Affair
Painting Himself Into a Corner
 Next on stage was the Goldman imbroglio.
Under Mr. Goldman's supervision, the Shubert Foundation gave out little money, and, according to people familiar with his tenure, quite a few of the grants were awarded to Mr. Goldman's pet interests. For example, he liked the City of Hope, a California medical institution, so it got handsome donations.
Along with serving as president of the Shubert Foundation, Mr. Goldman also, unexpectedly, became New York's cultural affairs commissioner under Mayor Beame. By early 1974, however, reports started to circulate about possibly illegal business dealings by Mr. Goldman, and the Attorney General began investigating him. Around this time, an article in The New York Times disclosed that a Shubert Foundation grant to the Yale School of Drama was sharply reduced after Mr. Goldman complained that Yale was not buying paint from a concern he owned. Chairmen at other drama departments also reported that Mr. Goldman had mentioned his paint company when discussing grants.
All of this brought considerable opprobrium to the Shubert Foundation. It needed new directors with unblemished reputations, and a search produced three people: Helen Hollerith, a trustee of the Kips Bay Boys' Club in the Bronx; John Kluge, then head of Metromedia but a few billion dollars short of what he's worth now, and Lee Seidler. They joined the board in January 1975.
Matters worsened for Mr. Goldman. In March 1975, he was indicted by a special state grand jury on grand larceny charges that he had defrauded the Transit Authority. In April 1975, he was indicted by a Federal grand jury on similar charges. In October 1975, he was indicted on charges that he had bribed a witness to disappear to avoid testifying before a grand jury investigating allegations that Mr. Goldman had improperly funneled money from the Shubert Foundation. The indictment also charged that Mr. Goldman had given $1 million in contracts to a Queens company to paint Shubert theaters and that the paint company had returned half the profits as kickbacks.
With three indictments hanging over him, Mr. Goldman was not an ideal foundation president. It was clear to Mr. Schoenfeld and Mr. Jacobs that he had to go. "The price of getting rid of Lawrence was Goldman," Mr. Jacobs said ruefully. "We didn't know how high the price would be."
Under pressure from Mr. Lefkowitz, the directors had in June 1974 amended the foundation's certificate of incorporation to specify that directors were to serve year to year, rather than for life. They also revised the rules so that one-third of the board -- or just two members -- would constitute a quorum and a majority vote of the directors present could transact business.
Although Mr. Goldman truculently refused to leave, he was without allies. The day after he was indicted for the third time, the Shubert board severed him from his duties. As it turned out, he was never convicted of any crimes. With the passage of time, Mr. Goldman's health unraveled steadily and prosecutors lost interest in bringing him to trial. He died in 1983 at the age of 73.
Tomorrow: The Favorable Tax Ruling
Pugnacious they were, but the Shubert brothers certainly had spunk. The boys from Syracuse, as they were called (even though they were actually born in Poland), were Sam, Jacob (known as J. J. or Jake) and Lee, sons of a Syracuse peddler named David Shubert. In the late 1800's, before they had entered their 20's, the brothers formed a stock company that blossomed into a mini-theater chain in upstate New York. In 1900, Sam descended on New York City and decided it suited him, and the brothers began operating theaters there. They were scampish, ruthless men of outsized ambition, and they quickly booked a string of hit shows.
 Sam was the first to die. On May 11, 1905, he boarded a train bound for Pittsburgh. It crashed, and the next day he was gone. He was believed to be 29.
 With Sam dead, the empire was led by Lee and J. J. The brothers bought sizable swaths of real estate and theaters in midtown Manhattan as well as in Boston and other cities. Virtually alone, they built New York's theater district. By 1927 they owned an astonishing 104 theaters and booked shows in 1,000 more. If you liked theater, you were beholden to the tastes of the Shuberts.
Their grip on theater was so absolute that in early 1950 the Federal Government filed an antitrust action asserting that the Shuberts monopolized their industry. The brothers eventually agreed to divest 12 theaters, depart the booking business and not buy any theaters without the Government's blessing. That was a lot to lose, but a lot was left. Indeed, Shubert steamed ahead as the most powerful theater organization in the country.
Lee Shubert died on Christmas Day 1953 at the age of 78, leaving J. J. as the sovereign. J. J. could be winsome and he could be vituperative -- often in the space of minutes. This was never lost on Bernard B. Jacobs and Gerald Schoenfeld, his lawyers and eventual successors. Once, J. J. called in Mr. Jacobs and told him to fire Mr. Schoenfeld. "Then I forgot about it and he forgot about it," Mr. Jacobs recalled. "You never knew if he was serious or if he was playing games." N.R.K.

HEADLINE: The World;
When Neighbors Aren't Friends

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

 BODY:
FOR nearly three years now, the United States has confronted a tide of Haitian refugees whose management has gone well beyond its considerable logistical challenges to become a sore on the conscience of a country that cherishes an image of itself as warm and welcoming to foreigners.
As scenes of Haitians being stockaded in sweltering tent cities have become commonplace, a moral question has arisen in Washington: Is it just the Haitians' blackness and poverty that causes them to be treated differently from, say, Vietnamese, Russians or Cubans? And one truth that gets lost in the heat and fog of debate is this: The question could just as easily be asked in the capitals of the Caribbean, albeit with different perspectives on race and racism. 
 Lost in the reflection and debate over the United States' handling of the more than 50,000 Haitians who have fled their country since the September 1991 military coup that overthrew the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide has been the cool treatment reserved for Haitians throughout the hemisphere.
Other nations have shown more rhetorical zeal than the United States in supporting Father Aristide, but 34 months into Haiti's crisis the United States, for all its perceived stinginess toward them, remains the only country that has willingly been host to sizable numbers of refugees who have fled what Haiti's President calls "a house on fire." Last week Panama provided the most dramatic example of the cold feet Haiti's other neighbors get when asked to help temporarily shoulder the burden of the crisis in Haiti. Just days after the outgoing President, Guillermo Endara, agreed to receive as many as 10,000 Haitians on Panamanian soil, he abruptly canceled the arrangement. Mr. Endara complained that the United States had sought to shift the terms of the agreement without prior consultation, but few could doubt that a political firestorm in Panama about the presence of large numbers of Haitians was a major factor in his decision.
Panama is far from alone in its ambivalence. Venezuela announced at a recent foreign ministers' meeting in Brazil that it would be willing to receive Haitian refugees, only to quietly withdraw the offer a few days later. More recently, Washington asked Jamaica to help out with the refugee problem. The best American diplomats were able to obtain was an agreement for a leased hospital ship, the Comfort, to process Haitian refugees in Kingston harbor. Even this raised hackles in Jamaica, with the opposition Labor Party objecting, saying that Haiti's refugees were "a U.S. problem."
"There was initially a wave of public concern that some of these people could jump ship and swim ashore," said Canute James, a Jamaican journalist, referring to the public aversion to the plan. "A lot of this, I believe is simply racist. Although Haiti is in the middle of the Caribbean, most people know very little about Haitians. They may as well be from the other side of the world." Implicit in Mr. James's remarks is that the term "racist" can apply not just to skin color but to peculiarities of culture, language and nationality as well.
Haitians, who have long thought of themselves as awkwardly fitting into Latin America, have themselves begun to recognize this cultural isolation as one of the most underrated elements in the country's seemingly perpetual political troubles.
Beyond the country's blackness and poverty, Haiti is the only French-speaking country in Latin America, and its Creole, the universal language of daily life, throws a further shroud of impenetrability over the land.
 
A Revolutionary History
 A proud revolutionary history, moreover, has made many Haitians scornful and prickly toward foreigners, particularly those Caribbean neighbors, also with dark skin, whose colonial status only began to end in the 1960's.
Told recently that soldiers from small neighboring islands might participate in a Haitian peacekeeping force, one Haitian intellectual cried, "Anything would be preferable to being subjected to people like those, without history, without souls."
Haitians realize that, as much as the continuing boat people crisis, it is because their fate has captured the attention of black America, whose political leaders have refused to allow the issue to die, that their troubles have remained on the political front-burner in the United States all these months. But if they are unaccustomed to solidarity like this, Haitians say they have quickly learned its lessons: As Haitians have settled in the United States in recent years, their country has become less and less a Latin, or even Caribbean nation, in its cultural identity.
Instead, Haitians have begun to tie their fates to the United States. And as Haitian-Americans grow in number, both returning to their country for visits and becoming politically active in the United States, they will increasingly determine the direction their homeland takes.
"The black American relationship has already proven to be extremely important to us," said Lionel Delatour, a Haitian political scientist who has written on the subject. "Now what we will increasingly see is the 300,000 Haitians born in the United States who are black Americans as well as Haitian-Americans serving as a vital bridge. That is our hope for modernizing, politically, culturally and economically."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Haitian refugees at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, were detained last week after being picked up at sea by the Coast Guard. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Word for Word/The Three Stooges;
Thoughts on the Social Significance Of Getting Hit With a Pie. Seriously.

BYLINE: By TOM KUNTZ 

 BODY:
THE Three Stooges never showed much respect for high-falutin' types like college professors. Funny, then, that the world of academe today is displaying serious deference to them, this trio of manic numbskulls who ran amok before the cameras from the 1930's to the 1960's and frequently made slapstick violence so hilarious it hurt.
Foremost among academic Stooge experts -- admittedly, there are not many -- is one Donald B. Morlan, Ph.D., professor of communications and a comedy film historian at the University of Dayton in Ohio, whose insights on the wider social and political significance of Moe, Larry and Curly (and Shemp, Curly Joe and Joe Besser) are such that he is once again a featured participant at the annual Three Stooges Convention, being held this weekend at the Ramada in Trevose, Pa., outside Philadelphia. 
 There, the 60th anniversary of the Stooges' first Columbia film shorts will be observed with requisite solemnity, and Dr. Morlan will hold forth on the Stooges' contributions to World War II film propaganda. But for those who can do without loitering in a hotel lobby with a bunch of barking Curly imitators and guys in Moe haircuts trying to poke their eyes out -- and for those who cannot -- here are excerpts from Dr. Morlan's scholarly research. TOM KUNTZ

 
Anti-Aristocratic
 From "A Pie in the Face: The Three Stooges' Anti-Aristocracy Theme in Depression-Era American Film," delivered to the Popular Culture Association, Bowling Green (Ohio) State University, April 1994:
The original intent of the current research was to examine the 190 Columbia Stooges' shorts to answer pertinent questions relating to the pie fights. Specifically, purposes were to determine the frequency of pie fights, to draw any conclusions evident as to the "victims" of the pies, and to search for any existent social themes . . .
Results of the search were quite surprising. This paper will answer the three questions posed; however, the most significant result of this effort was that the Three Stooges were major contributors to the anti-aristocracy/wealth theme so prevalent in Depression-era films. Just as the Stooges contributed to anti-Nazi sentiment in America in the late 30's and early 40's, they also made significant contributions to uplifting the morale of Americans during the economic crisis of the Great Depression.
Most likely surprising to many "Stoogemaniacs," bona fide pie fights occurred in only five of the 190 Columbia comedies. The first such battle appeared in "In the Sweet Pie and Pie" (1941), which found the boys marrying three society girls immediately prior to being hanged. When they are pardoned, the girls attempt to embarrass the boys at a high society party. Perennial supporting actress, Symona Boniface, who appeared in all the pie fight comedies, threw the very first pie in a Stooge short subject.
 Perhaps also surprising to many Stooge fans is that Curly appeared in only one pie fight -- the first. "Half Wits Holiday" (1947), which introduced the classic fight to be seen many more times (as stock footage in later pie-fight shorts), was Curly's final comedy with the team and the concluding pie fight scene was shot without him -- presumably following his stroke on the set.
 The victims of the pies, without exception, were the wealthy in "hoity-toity" social settings. As indicated earlier, Symona Boniface, one of the most popular short subject supporting actresses of the time, was involved in all the pie fights. Even though she was an active participant, she was always the clear victim of the melees. Her society friends and party guests were also victimized with a pie in the face.
 The recurring social theme in all the pie throwing comedies was that of anti-aristocracy and wealth which was so popular in Depression-era films. Plots were quite repetitive. Low-life ruffians were thrust into high-society settings and quickly made a shambles of the elitist climate. The result in each case was the same -- society matrons and patrons were quickly relegated to the level of the ruffians and made to look foolish.
The recurring theme in the pie fight comedies prompted a deeper and more analytical examination of all 190 films for thematic significance in the era of the Depression. The result of that search was that the Stooges -- amid their slapstick nonsense -- were making a meaningful and calculated contribution to the prevailing political climate of the time.
 
War Propaganda
 From "Slapstick Comedy Contributions to Pre-WWII Film Propaganda: The Three Stooges and Abbott & Costello," delivered to the American Culture Association and Popular Culture Association meeting in New Orleans, April 10, 1993:
The role of the motion picture industry in furthering the national interest in World War II has received heavy documentation in the past. Most attention, however, has been focused on the filmmakers' contributions to the war effort via celluloid propagandizing intended to build public morale in favor of America's involvement -- after that involvement was initiated.
 [Before the United States' entry into the war] persistent and heated attacks on the motion picture industry . . . came from the isolationists/America Firsters -- particularly those in the United States Senate. Perhaps having grown frustrated with the increasing failure of their attempts to curb interventionist sentiment in the Roosevelt Administration, the American press and the public at large, the motion picture industry became their focal target in mid-1941.
Senators Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota, Burton K. Wheeler of Montana and Bennet Clark of Missouri became leaders in a Congressional attack on the movie industry. On Aug. 1, 1941, Nye and Clark called on the Senate's Committee on Interstate Commerce to investigate the "sordid story of war propaganda in the film."
 Senators Nye and Clark's efforts were successful in the creation of a specially impaneled subcommittee of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee to investigate "war propaganda disseminated by the distribution, or exhibition of motion pictures." Senator Nye was the chief spokesperson for the isolationist cause and the lead-off witness. Heads of most major studios were called to appear to defend charges against the industry.
The committee targeted 39 motion pictures and nine episodes of the [newsreel] "The March of Time" as being the most offensive in their propagandistic content. None of the movies listed by the subcommittee were comedies; however, Charles Chaplin's "The Great Dictator" was among an additional list of offensive titles cited in Senator Nye's opening testimony.
 The apparent elitist attitude of the isolationist Senators in assessing propagandistic value of films by type, i.e., "quality" pictures as opposed to slapstick, etc., may have been a great mistake. Slapstick comedy was immensely popular as an art form in the late 30's and early 40's. . . . Three Stooges comedies played to far more patrons than a single film due to the practice of showing short subjects with a variety of feature films in multiple theaters in a single market.
The historical significance of the three Stooges' propagandistic war efforts cannot be fully appreciated until the comedies are placed in chronological perspective with other events occurring in the country at the time. The Stooges were virtually "getting away with murder" at a time when even the slightest hint of anti-Nazi sentiment in a feature film was sure to draw the wrath of the isolationists.
"You Nazty Spy," the 44th in the series of 190 Columbia Stooges shorts, was released to theaters on Jan. 19, 1940 -- nearly two years prior to the Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbor and at a time when any serious effort to pan Germany or Hitler would receive immediate opposition. "You Nazty Spy" beat Chaplin's "The Great Dictator" to the screen by nine months and, contrary to the belief of many film historians, it was Moe Howard who was the first film actor to ridicule Hitler on the screen and not the immortal Chaplin.

HEADLINE: Playing Poker: Clinton Says Economy Is All Aces

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NAPLES, July 9

 BODY:
President Clinton has often been accused of timidity in foreign policy, but the policy on the dollar that he articulated here at this year's economic summit meeting is about as gutsy as anything he could do these days short of invading Haiti.
When all the oratory is stripped away, the President has essentially looked the world's currency traders in the eye and said to them, "I dare you." 
 That dare is embodied in Mr. Clinton's argument that the United States economy is as healthy as ever, that inflation is well under control and that the currency markets have to some degree undervalued the dollar.
For those reasons, the President said, if at all possible he is not going to prop up the dollar.
 
What Clinton Doesn't Want
 He said he does not want to see the Federal Reserve Board raise interest rates to support the dollar because that would needlessly damp domestic growth, and he is counting on the markets to eventually recognize the fundamentals and stabilize the dollar at a reasonably strong value.
He is also betting that this process will take place without any serious long-term negative effects on the American economy.
As bets go, they don't get much bigger. If Mr. Clinton and his advisers are right, some speculators who have been dumping dollars by the bushel are going to lose money. If he is wrong, the dollar, and maybe stocks and bonds, are in for a very interesting ride.
The last world leader to take on the currency markets in such a brazen way was Prime Minister John Major, who declared in 1992 that the British pound would be devalued only "over my dead body." Currency traders took up the bet, hammered the pound down by 15 percent and left Mr. Major's body as roadkill on the global investment highway.
 
The Parallels That Aren't
 In fairness to Mr. Clinton, the pound was overvalued and the American economy today is in much better health than Britain's was then.
But how much better? Americans will soon find out as currency traders and the President engage in a fundamental test of wills over whose assessment is correct.
Many speculators have argued that a lot of fundamentals point to a weaker dollar: Japan and Germany are coming out of recession, which means interest rates there are likely to rise, making investments there more attractive and increasing demand for their currencies.
In the United States, strong employment numbers from the Labor Department suggest that inflation might soon rise. The trade deficit with Japan is heading for another record this year. And maybe most important, there is no sign of a Japanese Government that is ready or able to deal with the endemic trade surplus.
 
Good News and Bad News
 Most Clinton aides walked away from the President's meeting on Friday with Japan's new Prime Minister, Tomiichi Murayama, saying there was good news and bad news.
The good news, they said, was that the first Socialist Prime Minister of Japan in more than four decades seemed just like every other Japanese Prime Minister, despite his reputation as a radical pacifist with almost no foreign experience.
The bad news, the officials said, was that the first Socialist Prime Minister of Japan in more than four decades seemed just like every other Japanese Prime Minister -- with lots of vague promises about opening Japanese markets and deregulating Japan's economy but without any specifics that might make these happen.
In citing economic fundamentals that support the dollar, the President and his advisers say that $500 billion in budget cuts have finally brought the deficit under control, and that the United States economy has generated 3.8 million jobs in the last 17 months without any real sign of serious inflation.
With Japan coming out of recession, they add, demand for American products there should increase (presuming the markets open up), and the dollar should therefore strengthen against the yen. Moreover, while the dollar is losing ground against the yen and the mark, it is holding steady against other currencies.
 
And if Clinton Is Wrong?
 As Mr. Clinton said Friday: "Over the long run, the economic fundamentals will have to work themselves out. And I think that the best thing to do to stabilize the dollar and other currencies is to send a signal to the markets that we are working on the economic fundamentals. These things, it seems to me, together offer the promise of strengthening the dollar over the long run in a realistic way."
Anyway, the President hinted, if he is wrong and the fundamentals are not as strong as he thinks, no amount of intervention in the markets will be sufficient to hold up the currency.
Not surprisingly, many speculators interpreted these remarks as a definitive signal that there would be no market intervention or interest-rate increases unless markets really started gyrating. That is why the dollar fell again on Friday against the yen and the mark.
Over the long term, if the President is right, the economic fundamentals -- employment, inflation, interest rates -- will remain sound and the markets will stabilize the dollar at or above its current level.
If the traders are right, the dollar will continue to fall, foreign investors will pull more money out of United States stock and bond markets and things could get increasingly disorderly.
 
The Specter of Greenspan
 "The Administration is betting that they are right about the economic fundamentals, that the markets will adjust, and that this adjustment will be relatively painless for the American economy," said John P. Lipsky, chief economist for Salomon Brothers. "The risk, which we have seen in dollar weaknesses in the past, is that market adjustments can involve overshooting and overselling, which produces undesirable economic effects."
The key unknown element is the Federal Reserve and its chairman, Alan Greenspan. The Administration can think whatever it wants about the fundamentals, but if Mr. Greenspan thinks they are eroding, he can raise interest rates himself, independent of the Admnistration.
So that is the poker game: Bill Clinton at the table with the currency traders. Each has chips in the pot. The traders have a pretty good idea what the President has in his hand, since he is not a very good bluffer. But the wild card is that fellow Greenspan standing at the President's shoulder. He has the ultimate poker face and no one knows when he might put his chips into the game.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: News Analysis

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Behind Heavy Hitters, Offense Is Soaring Up, Up and Away

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
With all due respect to Ken Griffey Jr., Frank Thomas is the most remarkable player in baseball today. Thomas, more than Griffey, epitomizes the overall offensive developments that have dominated the first half of the season.
Home runs, both the massive total and the individual feats led by Griffey, have dominated talk in the first half of the season, but the season has featured more than just home runs, and a look at Thomas's production for the Chicago White Sox provides the most comprehensive picture. 
 The first baseman, the unanimous selection as the American League most valuable player last season, entered yesterday's games with a .380 batting average, 31 home runs and 73 runs batted in. That would be a terrific season for many players.
 
An Exceptional Season
 For Thomas, though, those numbers make him one of the players who is making this an exceptional season.
As the season reaches the All-Star break, the major leagues have an inordinate number of players hitting .350 or higher, players with 25 or more home runs and players who have driven in 70 or more runs.
Using last season and the 1987 season, the year in which a record number of home runs was hit, for comparison, 1994 has been remarkable.
Going into the final weekend before the break, seven players were hitting .350 or higher compared with four at the break last year and two in 1987. Five players had slugged 25 or more home runs compared with none last season and five in 1987, and 12 had knocked in 70 or more runs compared with four a year ago and five in 1987.
 
.330 and Beyond
 At this time last season, John Olerud and Andres Galarraga were flirting with .400, but Olerud (.395) was the only American Leaguer over .330, and Orlando Merced and John Kruk were the only National Leaguers besides Galarraga (.391) at .350 or higher. In 1987, Wade Boggs (.375) and Tony Gwynn (.370) -- who else? -- were the only players over .350.
This season's list includes Thomas, Paul O'Neill, Kenny Lofton, Albert Belle and Will Clark in the A.L. and Gwynn and Hal Morris in the N.L.
At the break a year ago, Barry Bonds and Mickey Tettleton led their respective leagues with 24 home runs each. In 1987, Mark McGwire's 33 topped a group of five players at 25 or higher. This season, Griffey and Matt Williams each has 33, Thomas 31, Jeff Bagwell 26 and Albert Belle 25.
Bonds, with 71, was the only National Leaguer with 70 or more runs batted in at the break last season while three A.L. players, including Cecil Fielder with 77, had reached that mark. In 1987, Jack Clark had a whopping 86 r.b.i. and was joined in the 70-or-over listing by two players from each league. Plagued by injuries, including a torn ankle ligament, Clark drove in only 20 runs after the break and finished with 106.
This season's 70-plus list is lengthy.
"We have two guys with 70 r.b.i.," Don Baylor, the Colorado Rockies' manager, said. "It's kind of scary to think at the All-Star break there's going be 10 or 12 guys who have a chance at the r.b.i. title."
Going into yesterday's games, Kirby Puckett, with 79, was the No. 1 man in a collection of eight A.L. players at the 70-or-higher plateau. Bagwell, also with 80, was the head man in a group of four National Leaguers.
"There are probably more runners on base," Baylor said. "Guys probably are walking more. Every time you walk someone, they seem to score."
 
Pitching Skill Declines
 At the break last year, pitchers had walked 8,031 batters. With two days of games left, pitchers had walked 8,401 this season. The decline in pitching ability -- or a shrinking strike zone -- has created more opportunities for batters to drive in runs.
A "juiced" ball, of course, does not create more walks. But the man holding the ball does. The shrinking talent pool of pitchers is a constant topic of conversation in baseball. Doug Melvin, assistant general manager of the Baltimore Orioles, cited one effect of that development.
"I think we rush young pitchers to the big leagues because of their stuff," Melvin said. "Maybe physically they have the best arms and the best ability, but they're not ready to perform in the major leagues. We bring them up too quickly and don't prepare them properly."
There is no shortcut to the majors, Melvin added. "We need to develop pitchers fully," he said. "We don't have the patience to keep them in the minors. They throw the ball 90 miles an hour and we rush them through Double A and Triple A."
But the opposite happens more often than not, and a year after expansion, when teams are still trying to fill pitching holes, they grasp at developing but unprepared youngsters like Rick Helling (Texas), Arthur Rhodes (Baltimore), Tim VanEgmond and Gar Finnvold (Boston), Salomon Torres (San Francisco), Darren Dreifort (Los Angeles) and Paul Shuey (Cleveland).
Perhaps the number of hitters with dazzling production totals grows in direct proportion to the number of ill-prepared pitchers who pitch to them.
 
No Levity in This Clubhouse
 If George Steinbrenner doesn't like the theory that his scare tactics have hurt attendance -- he keeps warning prospective customers that it's dangerous to go to Yankee Stadium -- here's another one. Although the Yankees are in first place after a 12-year absence from post-season play, they have become a dull, colorless team that has no appeal to the fans.
Gone are the days of George and Billy and Reggie. Steinbrenner doesn't even have Dave Winfield to kick around. Instead, the Yankees, under the stifling command of General Manager Gene Michael and Manager Buck Showalter, are permitted to say nothing or do nothing that might attract attention.
Luis Polonia, a wonderfully free-spirited personality who can inject humor into the serious game of baseball, learned last week what happens when a player goes beyond the line of propriety as drawn by the manager.
Polonia made some humorous remarks about the parade of pitchers staged by the Oakland Athletics, and he became the unnamed object lesson of a Showalter lecture to his team.
Individual players and personalities attract fans. But on this Yankee team, there can be no individuals, certainly none with a personality.
 
Pitcher Up! Batter Down!
 Tony La Russa, the Athletics' manager, does seem to be outdoing even himself with his use of relief pitchers. After using three pitchers to face three batters and get three outs in a game against the Yanks, he used eight pitchers in a game against Baltimore, including four who faced one batter each, three of them in one inning.
But as the general manager of another club said: "It's working. They're all no-names. By the time he brings them in, the players ask who are they and try to find out what they throw, they get them out."
The strategy has become contagious. Marcel Lachemann, the California manager, used three pitchers to get three outs against the Yankees Friday night. Platoon pitching has become as much a part of the game as platoon hitting.
 
What the Poll Left Out
 The commissioner's office commissioned a poll that featured questions tantamount to "when did you stop cheating on your wife?" The Gallup survey asked baseball fans if they thought player salaries were too high and if they favored a salary cap. Yes and yes, an overwhelming number responded, 72 percent for the former and 76 percent for the latter.
The answers came as no surprise, but other questions come to mind:
Why didn't Gallup ask if the fans thought the owners should have a cap on their profits?
If baseball's economy is so bad, why are the owners wasting money on something so meaningless and frivolous?
If the owners were sharing their revenue with the players this year, would the players have paid for 50 percent of the poll?
 
Hats Off to Piniella
 Lou Piniella has not been a happy manager this season because the Seattle Mariners have not played up to his expectations. His frustration emerged recently when he tossed his cap, second base and his gum onto the outfield grass. His action prompted Piniella to recall a similar incident when he managed the Yankees and disclosed that not all of his vehement arguments are spontaneous.
"George called me one day," Piniella related, "and said, 'I hired you to put on a show. Now get thrown out and put on a good show.' "
Picking his spot, Piniella walked toward the umpire and, along the way, carefully dropped his cap in the on-deck circle. The cap, he explained, was to be part of his finale. "I was going to kick the hat into the stands and the people would fight for it," he said.
"So I'm kicking the dirt -- it was real loose dirt," he recalled, "and I'm waving my arms and now it was time for the finale. I go for the hat, but when I get there, I find that the batboy had picked it up. 'Here's your hat, Mr. Piniella,' he said. I said, 'Put my prop down.' "

HEADLINE: Electricity Industry Needs Competition

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Electricity Shopping Can Be a Bad Deal" (Viewpoints, June 12), Ralph Cavanagh bases his argument against deregulation of the electricity industry on his erroneous assertion that electricity production "has a greater effect on the environment than any other economic activity." Like many environmentalists, Mr. Cavanagh prefers to find fault with utility companies rather than tell us that the transportation sector -- especially the cars we drive -- is the primary source of pollution in this country. Perhaps he has not read the current New York State Energy Plan, which found that 80 percent of toxic air emissions in this state come from the transportation sector. Until environmentalists focus their efforts on the transportation sector, we will have neither a cleaner environment nor the beneficial lower prices that deregulation of the electricity industry would produce.
 
RICHARD B. MILLER
Albany, June 14
 
The writer is an energy and environmental lawyer.
