HEADLINE: HOME CLINIC;
How a Wide Variety of Nails Holds Things Together

BYLINE: By JOHN WARDE 

 BODY:
SELECTING nails is challenging, even for professionals. One reason is the wide variety of building materials, as nearly all need nails with specific holding properties.
For an idea of how different nails function, consider their three parts, the point; the shank, or shaft, and the head. Nails with long sharp points wedge fibers apart and are easier to drive than nails with blunt points, which simply punch through wood. But sharper nails are more likely to cause splitting. 
 For that reason most nails for general use have diamond-shaped points, which combine elements of both kinds. Even so, carpenters often deliberately blunt the points of general-purpose nails to insure further against splitting. They do that before driving the nails near the ends of boards or into brittle wood.
A nail's grip, or resistance to withdrawal, is produced by the friction of wood fibers against the shank. The larger a shank's surface area, whether owing to its diameter or length, the greater the nail's holding power.
As a rule the correct length of a nail is three times the thickness of the piece through which it is driven. If the piece is very thin, as with asphalt shingles or hardboard paneling, the nail should enter the second piece, the one to which the first is fastened, by at least three-quarters of an inch. Engineers often rely on a different formula, namely that nails should enter the second piece by a distance equaling 12 times the nail's diameter.
Where a nail chosen by either rule would penetrate the second piece completely, as when nailing together two pieces of equal thickness, two or more nails, each somewhat shorter than the combined thickness of both pieces, are usually sufficient. Longer nails have to be used when fastening materials having little holding ability.
The nail head serves mostly to resist "pull-through," should the joined pieces be pressed away from the direction of the nail's point. Where appearance is important, nails may have small heads designed to be driven beneath the surface. But such nails have little resistance to being pulled through and should be used just where stresses are quite unlikely to occur.
Coatings, threads and rings found on some nails enhance their grips, in different ways. Cement-coated nails, dipped in a resinous adhesive that softens from friction when the nail is driven, initially bond tightly to wood, but lose strength after a few months. Carpenters use those nails primarily so that their work will withstand the rigors of house construction. By the time the adhesive weakens, the joints are reinforced by additional building materials.
Galvanized coatings, designed to prevent steel nails from rusting, also enhance grip by increasing surface area and roughness. Although using galvanized nails solely for their increased grip is seldom economical -- they usually cost more than cement-coated nails -- an advantage is that they do not lose their holding strength.
Threaded and ringed nails grip more strongly than coated or galvanized nails. When driven, both wedge apart wood fibers, which then spring back and lock into the spaces between the threads or rings. Unlike plain-shank nails -- coated or bright (smooth) -- threaded and ringed nails grip tightly even when the surrounding wood becomes wet or shrinks.
Threaded nails resist withdrawal even while being pulled or forced out. That makes them excellent for flooring, which often flexes. Sized correctly, the plain part of the shank above the threads should equal or exceed the thickness of the material that will contain it, assuring that the pieces will be drawn tightly together.
Ringed nails grip more strongly than threaded nails, but any force sufficient to draw or thrust them out breaks the fibers surrounding the shank. Such nails, if they loosen, do so suddenly and permanently.
Although many nails are still formally classified by penny size -- a number followed by the abbreviation "d" -- specifying nails by length is perfectly acceptable, even at the testiest of stores.
As length increases, so does diameter and head size. The length of nails whose heads are designed for sinking below the surface includes the thickness of the head. Other nails do not. Here is a guide to varieties:
Common Nails Probably the most familiar. They feature thick, flat heads, plain shanks (bright or galvanized) and have a larger diameter than others. Use for general-purpose heavy construction.
Box Nails Look like common nails, but have a smaller diameter. As a result they have less tendency to split boards when driven near their ends. Use them in thin wood and wherever boards have to be nailed close to their ends or edges.
Sinkers Cement-coated box nails. Because their coating increases their grip they are made one-eighth to a quarter-inch shorter than plain box nails having the same penny size. Sinkers have to be installed rapidly with just a few hammer blows. If you pause too long, the adhesive will harden and the nail will be difficult to drive farther.
Finishing Nails Probably the second most familiar type. They have a small nearly spherical head with a dimple in the center to accommodate a nail-set used to drive the nail below the surface. The diameters are the smallest of all conventional nails. They are plain shanked, bright or galvanized, and typically used for cabinetry, paneling and trim.
Casing Nails Resemble finishing nails, but are larger in diameter, stronger and have greater holding power. Their conical heads differ slightly from those of finishing nails, but are also meant to be concealed. Casing nails are intended for attaching window and door trim. They are also suitable for fastening large moldings like baseboard.

GRAPHIC: Diagrams: Finishing nails have semispherical heads. Casing nails are conical. Both are dimpled for nail sets.
 
Coated, threaded and ringed nails hold better than smooth shanks.
 
Length of finishing and casing nails includes thickness of head. Length of common and other flat-headed types does not. (Edward Lipinski)

HEADLINE: Mr. Kim's Death

 BODY:
Kim Il Sung's death comes at a critical moment, just days after he had personally eased mounting tensions over North Korea's nuclear program by moving to resume talks with the United States.
 President Clinton struck the right note, expressing appreciation for Mr. Kim's role in recent days and reassuring the North that he wants a continuing and "personal" dialogue with his successor after an appropriate hiatus to mark Mr. Kim's passing. A delay poses no risk, with international inspectors in place to assure that the North's nuclear freeze remains in force. 
 Washington can only hope that Mr. Kim's son and heir apparent, Kim Jong Il, or whoever winds up in power will follow in the father's footsteps and choose negotiation over confrontation.
 The legitimacy of North Korea's regime is critical to resolving the nuclear question. Founding father Kim had ruled longer than any other sitting world leader. After nearly a half-century in power, the elder Mr. Kim adopted a uniquely Korean form of succession, melding Communism with dynastic rule. He had begun to devolve day-to-day responsibilities to his son when the collapse of the Soviet empire and the Soviet Union itself called the legitimacy of Communism into question.
 North Korea remained somewhat insulated from these larger currents. Its doctrine of self-reliance made it impervious to the shifting ideological winds, even in neighboring China. And its economy relied on outsiders for only a few necessities like subsidized oil.
 But North Korea suffered grievously from the loss of its Soviet and East European trading partners. And its nuclear program made it an international outcast, only deepening economic distress.
 No succession is a sure thing and the younger Mr. Kim's impulses have worried some U.S. observers. Officials around him may be inclined to act tough: to rally domestic support they stress time-tested themes of self-reliance and the need to stand up to a hostile world, especially the U.S. With that posture, they might want the Bomb for protection.
 But the elder Mr. Kim seemed to recognize the limits of that posture and quietly resumed a larger role to assure a smooth succession. He realized that North Korea could not keep up with South Korea militarily. To try would risk economic collapse. And he knew the tough-it-out posture would give the military too much influence over a successor regime.
 He resolved to seek a peace treaty and diplomatic relations with the U.S., opening the way to security assurances and economic ties with the rest of the world. To achieve such a breakthrough, he was willing to put plutonium reprocessing on hold and allow international inspectors to verify that. Now the hope is that his successor will see the wisdom of his ways. Continued reassurance from Mr. Clinton could help.
 Hawks in Washington want to resolve the nuclear issue by destabilizing the Communist regime. But that risks a war that none of the North's neighbors want. The hawks' approach would likely revive the North's alliance with China. More important, it would risk an open breach with U.S. allies South Korea and Japan, which want both a stable and a non-nuclear Korean peninsula.
 Mr. Clinton is right to embrace those goals and reassure the new leader in the North that he wants to deal with him, not destabilize him.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Most Russians Know Violence and Starvation;
How to Help

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your June 29 article on philanthropy in Russia: It is remarkable (and encouraging) that despite serious economic and political chaos, the business community has made a commitment to support charities with private contributions on a grand and growing scale. And lest we get too smug about the dubious sources of some of the private wealth that supports charity in Russia, the selfish motivation of many donors and the existence of phony charities that steal contributions, it is important to remember that these can be found in our own philanthropic sector as well. 
 It is our familiarity with these problems that has led to caution by United States funders to making grants in Russia. Most United States foundations are used to exercising a high degree of accountability over their grantees, which they cannot easily do in a country where basic tax laws, financial and accounting systems, communications and respect for the rule of law do not yet exist. Groups like Interlegal are working to change this. It will take time, and they have limited resources.
Individual donors in the United States, especially those whose families came from Russia generations ago, have shown interest in supporting Russian causes. But because United States tax law does not permit deductions for contributions to foreign charities, it is difficult for them to have much impact without using United States charities as intermediaries -- complicated and difficult under United States and Russian law.
United States churches and religious organizations are active in religious and secular projects in Russia because they have the fewest legal restrictions and greatest motivation.
The United States Government, to its credit, has been a big supporter of the nonprofit sector in Russia. Neither a government nor the for-profit sector can provide all the services and mechanisms any democratic market economy needs to function well. Government policies that promote private charitable activity are therefore quite sensible.
The Russians are coming to understand the importance of a regulatory system that permits private charitable activity to flourish while insisting on strict accountability for the use of funds. As this system grows and develops, our partnership in global philanthropy can be expected to grow as well.
 
ALLEN R. BROMBERGER
Executive Director
Lawyers Alliance for New York
New York, July 1, 1994

HEADLINE: Christopher to Meet Hanoi Counterpart

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, July 9

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher is scheduled to meet with the Vietnamese Foreign Minister in Bangkok this month, senior Vietnamese officials disclosed today. The meeting would be the first between the foreign-policy chiefs of the former foes since the Communist victory in 1975.
Deputy Foreign Minister Le Mai, who oversees relations with the United States, declined to confirm formally that the meeting was set. But he said in an interview, "I think there is a high possibility." 
 Mr. Christopher and the Vietnamese Foreign Minister, Nguyen Manh Cam, will be in the Thai capital to attend consultations among 18 nations on security matters after the annual foreign ministers' meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.
The high-level Vietnamese-American meeting was arranged during a visit here earlier this month by Assistant Secretary of State Winston Lord and Hershel Gobel, the Deputy Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Their talks were part of a longstanding effort to normalize Vietnamese-American relations, which took a major step forward in February when President Clinton lifted the trade embargo that had been in force since the end of the Vietnam war.
 
Liason Offices to Open
 Mr. Mai said liaison offices -- the precursors of embassies - would be opened in Hanoi and Washington once American officials found a suitable building here.
The United States owns the building of its former consulate here in Hanoi. But Mr. Mai said "dozens of families" lived in the building now and it would take time to relocate them.
"We think there should be an interim solution," he said. United States officials here are looking for interim quarters.
The diplomat who has been named to head the American office, James H. Hall, is visiting. Now the director of the State Department's Office of Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia, he served as an adviser during military service in South Vietnam.
Vietnamese officials said they expected the liaison offices to open within a month or two but that they doubted Mr. Clinton would soon raise them to embassy status.
 
Americans Divided
 "The division in American society on the question of Vietnam remains deep," an official said, speaking on condition that he not be named. "It will take some time."
But he said Vietnam saw the difference between a liaison office and a full-fledged embassy largely as one of name, and that it was ready to give the top American representative here the same access to Government leaders he would have if he were an ambassador.
Mr. Mai said Mr. Lord and Mr. Gobel had come to Hanoi this month "to thank the Vietnamese people for their cooperation" in working to resolve the issue of the 2,231 Americans still listed as missing from the war in Indochina. Despite both officials expressing satisfaction with the continuing progress, leaders of American veterans organizations who accompanied them "had a different opinion."
The Deputy Minister said Vietnam had agreed to two requests made by the officials and the veterans' leaders. One was for greater unsolicited efforts by the Vietnamese, particularly in searching through the records of various ministries for clues to the fate of the missing. The Hanoi Government also agreed to appeal to its citizens to come forward with any information they might have on a missing serviceman's case.
 
Concerns Over Instability
 Mr. Mai said Vietnam was concerned about instability in Cambodia but was determined to remain "disinvolved." Vietnam invaded Cambodia in December 1978 and overthrew the regime of Pol Pot, the leader of the widely feared Khmer Rouge. It withdrew its last troops in 1989.
The Deputy Foreign Minister said that the agreements reached in 1991 on a transition to peace in Cambodia had committed all major and regional powers to preserving the country's stability, and Vietnam would adhere to the "multilateral approach" even in seeking protection of the ethnic Vietnamese there. Vietnamese are widely resented in Cambodia and have fallen victim to mass killings there since last year.
The Deputy Minister said that in discussing human rights, Mr. Lord had asked for information on the well-being of four Vietnamese imprisoned for political offenses. He toldthe Americans that the four were in good health.
Ten Americans are imprisoned here, some for political offenses. A European diplomat with connections to Vietnamese officials said the authorities were nervous about possible opposition activity by former Vietnamese citizens visiting from the West.
Mr. Mai said Vietnam would recognize as foreign nationals only those emigres who had taken legal steps to divest themselves of Vietnamese citizenship.
 
The American Presence

 
 Alluding to Vietnamese concern about American interest in human-rights cases here and possible linkage to trade privileges, the Deputy Foreign Minister said he considered Mr. Clinton's decision to extend most-favored-nation status to China as "suitable to international trends."
Mr. Mai disputed a widely held view that Vietnam's eagerness for an American presence here was based on a desire to use Washington as a counterbalance to China, Vietnam's historic enemy. He said it would be bad diplomacy to play off one big power against another now that the cold war is over.
"All major powers, without exception, should be able to play an active role in Southeast Asia, and none should have a feeling of being left out," he said.
Mr. Mai said Vietnam and the United States had agreed to recognize ownership of Government assets in each others' countries and that senior legal officials would meet in Bangkok on Aug. 1-3 to work out details.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 12, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article and a headline on Sunday about a meeting planned between Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Vietnam's Foreign Minister described it incorrectly. It would be the fifth between an American Secretary of State and a Vietnamese Foreign Minister since the country was unified, not the first.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CLINTON;
On Ninth Ave., A New Call For Help. . .

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
In its heyday in the 1930's, Paddy's Market thrived as an open-air pushcart bazaar that jammed Ninth Avenue below 42d Street. Vendors of all nations sold fresh produce that drew customers from across the city.
Now, after a half-century of setbacks, only a few merchants survive there. On several blocks, parking lots and boarded-up storefronts outnumber active shops. Along the west side of Ninth, from 35th to 38th, the only businesses operating are a parking lot and the Kam Hong restaurant. 
 Hoping to recapture the past, local merchants joined with Community Board 4 in December to win a rezoning for residential use, and now they are trying to enlist city and state agencies in revising a development and marketing strategy.
For aficionados of exotic foodstuffs and bargains, the remaining shops still provide a magnetic allure. Where better to find Jamaican Jerk Sauce, tropical yams, tamarind nectar, octopus, baby eels, shark, couscous, rabbit, venison, baguettes, Afghani flatbread, Turkish coffee beans, goat gouda cheese or dried Egyptian fava?
The merchants want to attract workers from midtown offices and the garment center and tourists from the theater, restaurant and hotel district and the nearby Circle Line, Intrepid Museum and Javits Convention Center. They hope to draw from transportation hubs like Penn Station, the Port Authority, Lincoln Tunnel, Times Square subways, the piers and the West Side Highway.
"We're really the western gateway to New York," said Susan Wilson, a consultant to the merchants.
 For decades, Paddy's Market served more as the city's battered back door. Tenements and factories were demolished to make way for the tunnel, rail yards, bus terminal and convention center, robbing the area of business and population. Manufacturing sank, the printing industry vanished and the garment industry shrunk. The recession hit hotels and restaurants hard, and some of them were wholesale clients on Ninth.
"Our area was decimated in years of abuse," said James Dell'Orto, owner of Manganero's Hero Boy. Even when the merchants dreamed up the Ninth Avenue food festival in the early 1970's, it became a success above 42d Street, with Paddy's Market as the straggling tail end.
 For decades the city imposed industrial zoning on the strip, which never attracted industry but did stymie loans to keep up the aging apartments above the stores. Ms. Wilson estimates that at least 600 apartments are vacant. Planners hope the new zoning, restoring residential use, will enliven the neighborhood.
Still, the vacant stores, the shadows cast by the bus terminal overpasses and the pockets of prostitutes, homeless people and squeegee wielders all make the strip uninviting, creating a barrier between Paddy's Market and Ninth's vibrant segment above 42d.
 Mr. Dell'Orto, who sold paper bags at the pushcarts as a young boy, said that the old Paddy's Market virtues of ethnic diversity, neighborhood ties, living near work and eating fresh, healthy food were in vogue again. "You know," he said, "they weren't so stupid a hundred years ago after all." BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;
A Tug-of-War Redux

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
It is a classic battle for space in a crowded city. A venerable private day school, bursting at the seams, wants to take over the recreation floor of an apartment building that houses its high school.
The building's tenants, for whom the floor has long served as a sort of town hall and community playground, become angry. They carry pickets at the school's commencement, send angry letters and enlist the help of politicians, including the Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger. 
 The dispute has been raging for a year and now Community Board 7, after months of soul searching, made a recommendation last week, deciding unanimously to oppose the plan by the 285-year-old Trinity School, unless the school offers the tenants comparable facilities.
The fate of the space now rests with the City Planning Commission, which will decide whether to allow the expansion by altering the urban renewal plan for the area, which governs how space in the building, at West 92d Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, can be used.
Trinity, which built the 29-story building and which occupies the first three floors, has said it must expand into the fourth-floor community rooms and recreation area because its 920 students are crammed into classrooms designed for only 600.
But the tenants who live above say the community space, which includes an outdoor loggia, was guaranteed to them when they moved into the building and was also part of the school's agreement with the city.
"These facilities have been very important to us," said James A. Paul, vice president of the tenants' association. "They've allowed us to have a life together as a community."
Residents have been made angrier in the dispute because the school has kept them locked out of the loggia area for more than a year while the fate of the space is being decided. School officials have said the area is padlocked because of concerns about the safety of the residents, but residents counter that they and their children have used the area for years without incident.
Gus Oliver, the president of the school's board, said the school was looking into building an equivalent community area for the tenants on the roof of the building and moving the laundry room to the basement, where some school employees now have offices. But the board's resolution opposing the plan said that the school had "failed to make any concrete proposal for roof-top space for the tenants' consideration."
Tenant leaders also say that the discussions have been hindered because school officials have been evasive about the nature of their plans from the beginning. The tenant association recently retained a lawyer, Jacqueline Bukowski, to help them with negotiations.
A meeting last week between the two sides ended with "little movement off of dead center," said James A. Paul, vice president of the tenants' association. R.K.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ASTORIA;
For Bosnians, Melting Pot Is a Myth

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
To most patrons, Steinway Cafe Billiards is a place to shoot some pool and guzzle a few beers afterward. But for one group of young men and women, it has much greater significance.
The pool hall on Steinway Street has become a gathering place for about 20 young Bosnian refugees who have been relocated in Queens by international agencies. Here, they speak Serbo-Croatian, which they now call "Bosnian," drink coffee, listen to Bosnian music on tape cassettes, gossip and giggle. When they have money, they even shoot pool. 
 "Things have been difficult," said Nadim Ridjanovic. "We don't really fit in here."
In Sarajevo, it was chic and simple "to act American, to be cool" -- listening to Bruce Springsteen and wearing sunglasses and jeans. But up close, they say, America is hard to fathom.
Their new neighborhoods, primarily in Astoria, Ridgewood and Flushing, are a hodge-podge of cultures. Salsa music blares on streets that are crowded with Chinese, Indian and Greek restaurants and Italian bakeries.
The youths see themselves as outcasts in this melting pot and among the older Bosnian immigrants and refugees, who resent them for not staying and fighting for their country. With little help from the organizations that helped bring them over and from Muslim organizations here, they are struggling to make ends meet.
To Mr. Ridjanovic and his friends, the melting pot is a myth -- at least in their case. They say ethnic prejudices run deep. Greeks in Astoria are pro-Serbian, the young men say, something that disturbs many of them who said they were tortured by Serbian soldiers during the war. Historically, Serbian and Greek Orthodox Christians shared a common hatred for the Ottoman Empire, making them de facto allies.
In a delicatessen near his home, Mr. Ridjanovic says, he hears its Greek owner wishing for a Serbian victory in the war. But Mr. Ridjanovic did get some satisfaction out of seeing Greece's defeat in the World Cup.
The young immigrants also are careful to keep their distance from clubs and bars that are known to be Croatian and Serbian turf. "We don't want to start a fight in this country," Mr. Ridjanovic said.
Many of the immigrants came from comfortable families and are well- educated. But because of language difficulties and different educational standards in America, they now have to accept unemployment or low-paying menial jobs.
Amir Deljanin, 19, was studying to be a computer technician in Sarajevo. He now works in a warehouse in Flushing.
Others have been victimized by unscrupulous employers. Mr. Ridjanovic said he spent nearly $300 responding to advertisements that promised jobs with big returns for a small investment up front. After spending $200 on photographs, he barely broke even, working two days as an extra on a movie set. He also spent money buying ice picks and other tools for a short-lived career as a door-to-door meat salesman. He now calls this country "the United Scams of America."
But the Ridjanovic family, like many Bosnian families, resisted applying for welfare.
"We don't need handouts!" declared Mr. Ridjanovic's father, Dr. Midhat Ridjanovic, a former professor of linguistics at the University of Sarajevo. "We need jobs that would pay us money. We're willing to work."
There is little emotional support for these youths from older Bosnians. On a recent Sunday, a group of middle-aged men sitting in a semicircle at the Bosnian Islamic Cultural Center stopped talking about the conflict back home when Mr. Ridjanovic appeared on the scene.
"Why are you here?" one man asked. "Why aren't you fighting for our country?"
Mr. Radjanovic quickly walked away.
Later, in the pool hall, he asked rhetorically, "Why can't he go and fight? He's still young."
Several young men chimed in, "They want us to die for them."
In the background, a tape of Dino Merlin, a Bosnian rock singer, blended with the cracking of the pool balls. "I always dream about going back to Bosnia," he sang. "Someone is waiting for me, somebody who loves me."JANE H. LII

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.

 BODY:
Bugs Bunny and Friends Arrive at Queens Mall. . .

The Warner Brothers Studio Store, which created a stir when it arrived in the high-style neighborhood of 57th Street near Fifth Avenue, has opened another store in a very different setting: the Queens Center mall in Elmhurst. 
 The stores sell clothing, toys and souvenirs emblazoned with animated cartoon characters like Bugs Bunny and Tweety Bird.
Casper Caldarola, a spokeswoman for the stores, said the company had been attracted to Queens Center because "it's a high-traffic mall and there's no other entertainment store out there." In addition to the 7,900-square-foot store, she said, the company will provide "Warner theming," including a 30-foot-high Bugs Bunny.
 
. . .While 57th Street Gets Another Unlikely Store
 Next year, the Warner Brothers Studio Store on 57th Street and the nearby high-fashion outlets like Chanel, Burberry and Hermes will have a new neighbor: an Original Levi's store.
Designs, Inc., based in Chestnut Hill, Mass., has signed a long-term lease for the 15,000 square feet of space now occupied by Ann Taylor, which caters to young businesswomen, at 3 East 57th Street, between Madison and Fifth Avenues. The Original Levi's operated by Designs Inc. sell Levi Strauss & Co. products exclusively, including jeans, baseball caps and leather coats.
 
Coming to the Bronx Hub, An Alexander's Replacement
 Bradlees, the discount retail chain, is planning to set up shop in a 170,000-square-foot store to be built in the Hub, the central business district in the Mott Haven section of the South Bronx.
"When Alexander's moved out two years ago we lost a lot of advertising that brought people to the neighborhood," said Bill Bollinger, director of commercial development for the South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation. "Bradlees will act as our new anchor and people will come and shop up and down the streets."
Bernard Rosenshein, who has developed 50 shopping centers around the country, will put up the building, which is expected to be completed by December 1995. He successfully bid for a lease on the city-owned retail lot as part of the city's effort to revitalize retail developments in distressed neighborhoods.
Bradlees has announced plans to open its first store in the city in November in Union Square and another soon after on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn, and more are in the works. "We looked at the map and realized there are 10 million people in the city and Long Island that we don't serve," said Sam Mandell, Bradlees' president. "Our bread and butter is in urban suburban settings, and that's where we are going to concentrate our growth."
 
Big European Clothing Chain Plans First New York Store
 MaxMara, a European producer of women's classic ready-to-wear clothes with a touch of high fashion, will be opening its first store in the Northeast in September at 813 Madison Avenue, at the corner of 68th street.
The company, which is based in Reggioemmilo, Italy, has 250 stores around Europe and the Far East, but only two in the United States, in Palm Beach, Fla., and San Francisco.
Donna Cristina, a spokeswoman for MaxMara, described the clothes as costlier than those at Brooks Brothers but less expensive than those at Giorgio Armani, with suits ranging from $500 to $800. The company has bought the building at Madison and 68th Street and is restoring its original limestone facade. The store will encompass 3,600 square feet and two floors.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE HEARTLAND;
A Moderate Democrat From Omaha Caught in the Middle on Health Care

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OMAHA, July 9

 BODY:
It scarcely had the feel of radical politics: church bells pealed in the distance and a soft breeze fluttered an American flag as some 40 Nebraskans, most of them elderly, sat in lawn chairs on a sultry evening, sipping lemonade and talking with Representative Peter Hoagland about health care.
 But on the sidewalk, a grimacing man in a baseball cap and T-shirt paced back and forth with a cardboard sign that declared, "Give me liberty, not socialism!" 
Long before Mr. Hoagland returned to his district for the Fourth of July recess, voters here had been deluged with television and radio advertisements that cast Democratic efforts to revamp health care as a dangerous, even sinister threat to free enterprise.
 And wherever the three-term Democratic Congressman appears these days --Omaha Optimists Club, B'nai B'rith, trade union halls -- he hears the plaintive questions of frightened constituents, often framed in the precise warnings of the advertisements sponsored by conservative groups.
 "Will I still be able to go to my own doctor?" a retired woman asked.
 "Are my taxes going to skyrocket?" a union electrician asked.
 "Am I going to lose my job?" an insurance agent asked.
 
A Vulnerable Democrat
 The advertising blitz in this district might be unmatched anywhere, largely because Mr. Hoagland, a Democrat who represents a relatively conservative district, is seen as vulnerable on the issue.
 Until his election six years ago, the Omaha district was represented by Republicans for 40 of 46 years. And in the 1992 Presidential election, George Bush outpolled Bill Clinton by 15 points. All three of Mr. Hoagland's victories have been squeakers, and he now faces a strong challenge from a candidate with support among fundamentalist Christians, a conservative who favors the teaching of creationism in public schools, opposes abortion even in cases of rape and incest and has been a fierce critic of Government involvement in health care.
 "We have blanketed the Omaha market," said Brent Bahler, the spokesman for a group called Citizens for a Sound Economy, a conservative group based in Washington that has spent more than $1 million on health care advertisements. "We go duck hunting where the ducks are. And if you look at the Omaha district, you'll find that it's conservative Middle America. And after our ads ran, the phones in Congressman Hoagland's office were ringing off the hook."
 One advertisement says the consequences of all the Democratic health care plans would be ruinous: "tax increases, job losses, less money in your pocket to spend the way you want to spend it."
 
Deep Skepticism Abounds
 Groups that support changes in health care, like the A.F.L.-C.I.O., have also run advertisements here, but they have been dwarfed by those opposing the kind of changes sought by President Clinton, especially his goal of coverage for all Americans.
 Whether the advertisements are shaping public opinion, or simply reflecting it, there appears to be deep skepticism here about almost any change in health care coverage. Coupled with what appears to be a general antipathy toward President Clinton and Congress, the mood of Omaha voters illustrates the predicament facing moderate Democrats like Mr. Hoagland on the health care issue.
"A lot of people are simply uneasy about anything Congress might do," Mr. Hoagland said as he climbed into the back seat of a mini-van and headed toward another stop. "If the House can come up with a bill that I can defend here --well, that would be great."
 But he made it clear that no plan has yet met the test. He has called for the creation of consumer pools that could negotiate affordable rates on medical plans.
 
Yes and No Votes
 Mr. Hoagland has voted in favor of requiring employers to pay for health care for workers, as long as small businesses and those with high worker turnover receive tax credits. But last week he voted against a plan that would enroll Americans without health care in the Medicare system, a measure that barely cleared the Ways and Means committee.
 And in response to voters' questions about universal coverage, he said flatly: "It's just not going to happen. Politically, it's just not possible."
 To be sure, not all voters here oppose efforts to expand health coverage. Rita Carroll, a young woman who looked the picture of health and prosperity, told the Congressman: "I have multiple sclerosis. There is new medication out now, but it costs $1,100 a month. If I was on welfare, it would be paid for. But I can't pay for it. No way -- none."
 
90% Have Health Insurance
 More than 90 percent of the people in Omaha, however, have health insurance, Mr. Hoagland said. And to them, fear of crime and dissatisfaction with the welfare system appear to have a much higher priority. This is also the home of the insurance giant the Mutual of Omaha, which favors requiring employers to pay for health benefits, but has been critical of other elements of many proposals.
 Even in talks with trade union members, whose national leaders have called for extending coverage to all Americans, Mr. Hoagland was warned against making any rash moves.
 "Now, I haven't read all 800 pages of the plan, mind you," said Jim Picconi, a 55-year-old union electrician. "But our coverage right now is pretty good. And I don't want that to change."
 Mr. Hoagland, whose style blends the manner of the self-effacing Midwesterner and the polished Yale law school graduate, emphasizes repeatedly that he is no left-wing liberal, and that market-oriented solutions are the key to improving health care coverage.
 He appears eager to distance himself from President Clinton, at least on health care, while his opponent, Jon Christensen, portrays him as a liberal out of step with his district. In a poll published in mid-June by The Omaha World Herald, Mr. Christensen, a 31-year-old insurance salesman, was leading by 11 points.
The Democrat has been the target of negative advertisements before, especially during the budget debate last year, and worries that they could doom his political career.
 "One man's reputation can stand just so many of these negative ads," Mr. Hoagland told an audience at B'nai B'rith.
 But few of the Omaha voters aimed any barbs at Mr. Hoagland as sharp as those in the advertisements.
 One woman, Mary Johnson, even said that if nothing was accomplished on health care, the voters were as much to blame as the politicians.
 "I hear these sad stories about people without coverage and I feel terrible," Ms. Johnson, a first-grade teacher, said after a neighborhood gathering with Mr. Hoagland on M Street. "But then I start to think about the money coming from my own pocketbook, and I get a little greedy. I guess I'm like everyone else. I want utopia. I want everybody to be covered for everything. And I don't want any of us to have to pay for any of it."

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 13; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: ENCOUNTERS;
'It Was All a Kind of Enchantment'

BYLINE: By ERIKA DUNCAN; Erika Duncan is an essayist and novelist who lives in Sag Harbor.

 BODY:
PINK and yellow. And each of the fullest intensity of their hue. As I sat on the sofa with Enez Whipple, the bright pink of her sweater was echoed by the pale pink of the tulips on the coffee table before us. Against the white walls, and the chairs and the sofas that I would remember as white, came yellow pillows and little yellow details. It was the time of the yellow outside. Through the large windows of this East Hampton house built around an old water tower, came the vista of yellows of daffodils, daisies, birds singing outside. On a table in the dining room, a distance away but connected in the wide open space, there were white china fruits, and somehow, in my memory -- although whether or not they were really there, I don't know -- I add white china flowers.
There were none of the paintings of the abstract expressionists on the expansive white walls, nor the photographs of the many trail blazers -- first showings of the photographs, for example, of the interior of the last office of Freud, nor echoes of Hans Namuth or Dorothy Norman or Arnold Genthe, the people whom Enez Whipple had repeatedly granted a safe space to show in their earlier, more volatile days, during her 40-year stint as director of East Hampton's Guild Hall. 
 Even the new glossy print book, just out, that Enez Whipple had put together to tell the story, "Guild Hall of East Hampton, An Adventure in the Arts," was absent from that friendly white and pink and yellow living room.
In the last 10 years, since Enez Whipple's retirement, Guild Hall has had four different directors, a fact not surprising considering the tensions and the complex meshings of conflicting agendas that has always marked this community, where repeatedly artists in all areas have come for the particular quality of the light. What was it about Enez Whipple that had allowed her to hold the position as coordinator of it all, creating, well before such a thing was in fashion, a home for "interrelating the arts"?
'Temple as a Museum'
"It was the original vision of a museum as a temple that you went to be educated in. You went to the theater, and during the intermission you went into the garden and saw outdoor sculpture. In the 30's, when Guild Hall was founded, only 2.9 percent of museums engaged in performing arts programs, so that by luck we were pioneers in the total art experience," she said with the modesty and simplicity that would be characteristic of her talking about her career, even as I asked her what about her had allowed her to take on that role.
Enez Whipple landed in Guild Hall more or less by accident. She came from a little upstate town about 15 miles from Syracuse, where she would eventually attend the university, a student in theater arts. There on the front porch she "did the usual things every child does, putting on little plays with the other children who felt the way I did, mostly farmer's children and children of the paper mill, undertakers' chairs and all the rest." Her mother, who had gone to Syracuse University before her, had trained to be an opera singer, but she had to give it up because of a disease of the vocal chords. Her father, a rather stormy soul, was an inventor.
Like her mother before her, her first interest was in music. She was a piano student from an early age, "although [she] didn't have what it took to be a concert pianist," she said without any particular sadness. "Still, I had a great love for it."
Ironically, in the beginning she didn't have any particular interest in the visual arts. "I just didn't think of it." But in college, her friends "all were in the school of fine arts," she said. There she was to develop the particular gift of coming to an understanding of new areas of art "purely through friendships," that was to deeply mark her subsequent career. There she continued to study the piano. "Since theater was my second love, and I didn't particularly want to teach, I started to do master's work in directing and theater arts."
 
Tie to Cultural Center
 Guild Hall opened in 1931. Enez Whipple came to East Hampton 10 years later. The era of the grand old summer colony was in its last radiance, already a bit tattered and becoming forlorn, when Enez Whipple first arrived in the Hamptons with her new husband, Whip, a cartoonist who was on Guild Hall's summer board of directors.
"When I saw the Rollins Dance Studio rehearsing a scene out of 'A Midsummer Night's Dream' in the garden, drifting around the courtyard in their long dresses, I felt I had never seen anything like it, that it was all a kind of enchantment," she recalled. "It was the end of the era of the great estate, and I was very glad to have been able to experience it."
She worked informally at first, assisting her husband who was really too busy to do very much for Guild Hall, until gradually the job became hers, until gradually, after three years, she became first, summer director, and then, at first unofficially, and later officially, the year-round director as well.
As Enez recapitulates the first wonderment of that long ago rehearsal on the grass, the surprise of those long floating dresses and the fairy tale quality of it all, even now, more than 50 years later, and with her four decades-long history of involvement behind her, one feels more the quality of that first child-like fascination, rather than the sense that it is she who has actually made a mark.
 
Which Came First?
 From the time of college onward, a certain enthusiasm for the makers of art had possessed her, so that it was as if the person, the creator had always come first, and the creation, the product, only second. And yet I was struck by the sense that in the face of the outspoken objections of the ultra-conservative board, only a woman like Enez would have been quite so open to allowing herself to be "taught" by the community of abstract artists, and to taking that teaching immediately back into the community.
In an area where the making of enemies goes almost without saying, she was, by all reports, to have very few enemies -- unafraid when Edward Albee deliberately went out to shock the board of directors, during the short time when he was theater director, unafraid when, in the middle of a showing of abstract art, someone decided to intrude a realistic painting.
Was it also her strange combination of nostalgia and realism, romanticism mixed with inclusiveness and fairness, that allowed her to cook up a brew of contradictory influences no one else would have been comfortable with?
As our talks weave back and forth between nostalgia for the estate era and early Guild Hall tales, she tells me the story of Albert Herter, of the family whose estate was "made of all white gardens, where everything was white," who had a painting of himself made in full Oriental regalia, and gifted to Guild Hall, so large that after he died Guild Hall didn't know what to do with it, although every day, up until his dying day, he used to come to stare at it.
It is with a certain sadness that she tell me how his son Christian had asked that the painting "be sent back up the creek," when finally, because it was so large it could not have been taken up to storage in its frame, they gave him the choice of having it rolled up, "which surely would have ruined it," or cutting it in half so that only the upper portion of the portrait could continue to be shown. It was only years later that they learned that the painting had never even been picked up, that when it finally was retrieved, it was cut up so that its back made many, many canvases.
 
Sadness and Humor
 There is a mixture of sadness and humor in her voice as she speaks, and as she tells me the story of the dreaming Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse, who, in this era when so many had lost their fortunes in the stock market crash and were just barely hanging on, would build the opulent Guild Hall, who was to become Enez Whipple's mentor and very close friend.
"By the time I arrived," she says almost wistfully, "instead of 20 gardeners, Mrs. Woodhouse was down to two or three."
The tale of Guild Hall begins, ironically, with Mrs. Woodhouse's decision to restore the Clinton Academy, an old school building on Main Street, East Hampton, to make it into a museum for housing local antiquities. As the dream of the museum filled her, in her desire for authenticity, she thought nothing about eliminating a later added wing where people used to come to play basketball, where amateur theater and community meetings would take place. Even as the museum filled up with the elegant woodwork and old furniture that it still houses today, the community for which it was supposedly built retreated.
It was once again in an effort to reinterest and reinvolve the community that Mrs. Woodhouse decided to build Guild Hall across the way, as a place where community theater would be combined with meeting spaces and there would even be a gallery for showing local art. However, once again her love of elegance and opulence got in the way. She couldn't resist making everything as elegant as possible, so that the theater became a sparkling architectural gem, in grand Elizabethan style. The galleries were crystalline and regal and forbidding. While the Rollins Company Dancers wafted across the manicured lawns, and while the very rich conservative painters showed their floor-to-ceiling self-portraits, once again the community stayed away.
 
Anm Auspicious Start
 It was into this scene that Enez Whipple entered in 1941, when all but Mrs. Woodhouse were engaged in the war effort and Mrs. Woodhouse felt herself increasingly alone with her grand enterprises. With the fading of attention to cultural pursuits and impractical dreams, here came the girl from the village of farmers and paper mill workers who would know how to talk to the potato farmers, who would know how to persuade whoever she found in the grocery store to try to be in a play.
As one sits with Enez in the realm of the pink and the yellow, and one shares her reminiscences of what Mrs. Woodhouse's parties meant to the young woman from the country, we must picture the older Mrs. Woodhouse taking the young Enez Whipple through the sparkling theater and through gilded rooms telling the tales of why she built Guild Hall. We must try to imagine what the two women meant to each other.
"What I noticed about her most was that she never spoke about her past," Enez says, "but it was always today or tomorrow she talked about, whether she was creating a garden or a playhouse for her daughter, or Guild Hall." And indeed it is this quality of always today or tomorrow that one feels in her own emanation as well.
Freely she moves from describing the "wonderful old carriage house on the Woodhouse estate which was the laboratory theater where plays were performed in a less formal way" to explaining that "in order to try to lure people into Guild Hall we had to do things that were not what most museums did, great books discussion groups, French classes and square dancing," describing the way they would bring short plays to the military bases that dotted Long Island, the more rustic winter exhibits that were her ideas: "Life Styles 1648-1976," "The Romance of Maritime Long Island," "The Long Island Indian" and "Early East End Crafts."
She laughs as she tells me about courses she took in museum management and box office management in which she "learned that pop corn and Coca-Cola made more money than plays did," how she would have to argue with funding agencies that "couldn't quite understand why they weren't showing de Kooning in January."
 
Coming to Terms
 But even as she tells me about Edward Albee's insistence that the conservatives on the board had mounted a telephone campaign to try to discourage people from coming to one of his more provocative plays, I try to imagine her coming to terms with the economic and cultural stratification that she admits rather freely both attracted and repelled her.
For the several decades, up until the late 70's and early 80's, despite that gift for friendship that I would find so prominent in her nature, she avoided trying to be too close to the artists, photographers, theater people and dancers who performed at Guild Hall. And yet so often her stories of how she discovered a particular artist or a particular body of work would begin with the tale of a friendship.
 
'Never Offended'
 "I didn't always understand a painting or a particular musical composition," she said with the strange combination of humility and daring that would mark the interview, and that would mark her openness to all varieties of absolute purity of intent, "but nothing ever startled me. I was never offended, whether by the language used in a play, or painting that was very erotic."
It was as if she had a strange instinct for the most absolutely pure -- purity indeed seemed to be one of her favorite words. The extremes, however contradictory one might be of another, never scared her. It was as if, through a rare kind of intuition, despite her open mindedness, she knew to avoid the middles.
"I was extremely fond of James Brooks's paintings, although I didn't always know why," she told me, for example. "And I loved Ibram Lassaw's expression with all the different metals. Alfonso Ossorio I like very much as a person. I liked his early work. I was not so fond of his later work, but I thought it was important to show them."
Then she broke into a story that she said made her very sad about "one particular painter who could do anything."
"It was because he was so able to do anything, and because he tried so desperately to please the group, that he was never to amount to anything," she said.
I don't know quite why, but I asked Enez about her very first friend. It turned out that she was a little girl who happened to play the harp. "Her mother was a harpist who had been in the theater, and I remember I was absolutely fascinated by them.
"That girl, who went into the theater after high school eventually came home and married a farmer boy and had eight children. Yet she still kept all those talents."
As our talk meanders, Enez feels suddenly compelled to tell me about an experience she had as a member of the one of the first American Youth Hostels in Germany and Austria, how she had lived with the German youth who were "being trained," and how terribly frightened she was of the build up of nationalism, fanaticism and anti-Semitism.
Perhaps this too contributed to her refusal to take any sort of a fanatical stand, to her insistence upon letting all things in. There is a sense of leisure as we talk, as if, no matter which way our conversation will go, there always will be more and more and more. We talk for a while about her father's inventions, which she insists didn't influence her much, since he was such a difficult man, about how he invented something called a snap gauge for measuring infinitesimal distances and also very large distances, as well as a new kind of toilet paper, patented by Scott Tissue, so that during the war when toilet paper was scarce the family always brought great rolls of toilet paper everywhere they went. We talk of the new kind of wax coating he invented for the cardboard containers of milk cartons.
And we talk of her mother who lived until she was 98 years old, and up until the time she died still wanted to go to every concert, to every exhibition.
"She lived right there in that swivel chair, you see," Enez says pointing out the chair to me, "which she adored, so that she could see everything that was going on, who went in the front door, who went out the back door."
And even as Enez continues to speak, I see her own eyes wandering, out front, out back, but always, always taking all things in.

HEADLINE: Reappraising Strict Gun-Control Bills

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
ARMED with two proposals to strengthen existing gun-control laws, county legislators last month held an open meeting to take the public's pulse on the issue. Few lawmakers were prepared for a turnout of 1,900 citizens at the County Center here, many of whom claimed angrily that the proposed changes would jeopardize residents' constitutional rights.
"Regulate Felons, Not Us," read one of the placards carried to the meeting. "Parole Control, Not Gun Control," another said. 
 Now lawmakers say community opposition to their plan has caused them to rethink the issue.
"We're revisiting the matter," said Ernest P. Davis, chairman of the Legislation Committee of the Board of Legislators.
"Some people go off the deep end when it comes to gun control, but most are reasonable," said Mr. Davis, a Democrat from Mount Vernon. "What we need to do now is approach this sanely and rethink things."
Michael J. Spano, a Republican representing parts of Yonkers, called the proposals "too harsh and not really crime-control measures."
"It's a lot of smoke and mirrors," he said. "If we do something, let's do it with real bite. Let's attack the criminals, not the law-abiding citizens."
At issue are two county gun-control proposals that would be among the nation's most stringent. One bill would bring the county in line with New York City laws requiring residents to register rifles and shotguns as well as handguns.
Another proposal calls for gun owners to renew their permits every three years and to take a gun-training and safety course. The measure would also increase permit fees from $60 to $200 or more.
Most legislators, regardless of their position on gun-control measures, agree that higher fees are an economic necessity. They point out that Westchester pays $250,000 a year to process handgun permits and conduct background checks, but charges only about $17,000 in fees.
Most also are in favor of renewable gun licenses instead of the present system of issuing handgun licenses for life.
The County Clerk's Office reported that there were 61,000 active handgun permits in the county. To obtain such a permit, an individual now applies through the offices of the County Clerk or the county police. The application is then referred to local police departments, which conduct criminal and mental background checks, said Dee Barbato, program administrator for the County Clerk.
The local procedure for obtaining a handgun permit, which sometimes takes up to six months to complete, was in effect before the Federal Brady gun-control law -- which also requires background checks -- went into effect.
But parts of the new national law have been challenged recently. For example, in Billings, Mont., on May 21, Judge Charles C. Lovell of United States District Court ruled that the Government was overreaching its powers by ordering local police to conduct background checks. The judge said, however, that checks were not in themselves illegal, and several Montana cities are continuing them.
In Westchester, where background checks were conducted long before the national law was passed, the county is likely to continue the process, independent of future District Court decisions, said Ms. Barbato.
Many who are opposed to stricter gun control measures -- including Willard E. Doughty, president of the New York State Rifle and Pistol Association -- say local proposals, like those put forth in Westchester, fail to address the root causes of illegal firearm ownership and gun violence. They point out that most licensed gun owners do not use their weapons for illegal acts.
Indeed, most guns used in burglaries and homicides are illegally owned -- "stolen or hot weapons" -- reports Robert M. Maccarone, Director of Criminal Justice Services for the county. And most illegal weapons, he said, are brought into Westchester from out-of-state sources, although some are acquired during burglaries and robberies.
Mr. Doughty called the County Board of Legislators' gun-control proposals "totally misdirected" and said: "They have nothing whatever to do with the problems they are trying to solve. The focus needs to be on violent crimes and drying up the sources of illegal weapons."
"The sponsors of these bills are being led down the garden path on the issue," he said, "and maybe this will help them win the next election, but the tragedy is that even with tighter controls, the violence will continue."
By contrast, advocates for tighter gun controls said the measures being proposed by the Board would go a long way toward reducing the number of gun deaths.
Gun control advocates point to F.B.I. Uniform Crime Report statistics showing that each year more than 24,000 Americans are killed with handguns in homicides, suicides and accidents. They also say that, according to the National Center for Health Statistics, 15 children, age 19 and younger, are killed with guns every day.
The Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms reports that there are more than 211 million firearms in the possession of private citizens in the United States, and 71 million of those are handguns.
New York State Attorney General G. Oliver Koppell, who addressed the Board at the meeting, said that while automobile deaths had fallen 30 percent over the last 20 years, gun deaths had "soared." Between 1973 and 1993, the number of Americans killed in gun-related death almost doubled to more than 38,000 a year. Mr. Koppell also said that while there was "no single cure for the gun epidemic," Westchester's proposals would at least "slow the tide" locally.
Ann Janiak, chairwoman of the Westchester County Women's Advisory Board, told the Board of Legislators during the meeting that homes with firearms and where incidents of domestic violence had occurred were more likely to become the scene of future homicides.
She also said her advisory board was worried about the National Rifle Association's recent campaign -- "Refuse to Be a Victim" -- encouraging more women to carry firearms. Ms. Janiak dismissed the campaign as a marketing ploy and said women were not being told that those guns could be taken during a struggle and used against them.
Of concern to Dorothy L. DeCintio of Scarsdale, co-founder of the newly formed Westchester Handgun Control organization, was the "unruly and impolite" tenor of exchanges between gun-control advocates and those opposed to stricter laws.
Ms. DeCintio, whose brother Representative Allard Lowenstein was killed in 1980 by a student carrying a handgun, said she aired her views against a crowd of "rude, crude people who characterized themselves as great Americans and cited their Second Amendment rights to bear arms."
"It's a good law, like Nassau's and Suffolk's," Ms. DeCintio said. "I agree that there is a problem with the illegal sale of firearms, but all of these attempts to control guns are for the good."
Amy Paulin, president of the Westchester chapter of the League of Women Voters, was also greeted with boos and catcalls when she stood up to read a statement favoring stronger gun-control measures.
"I had to yell into the microphone that I had come here for a dialogue," Ms. Paulin said. "And the crowd shouted back that you need a diaphragm, not a dialogue. I told them they should be ashamed of themselves."
The league supports the proposed resolutions asking the New York State Legislature to authorize Westchester to issue gun-control provisions, and it supports measures to limit accessibility and regulate ownership by private citizens.
Mr. Doughty said that although some people opposed to gun control measures were unruly at the meeting, most were not.
Thomas Verri, a police officer and owner of Westchester Police and Uniform Supply in Westchester, also attended the meeting. He said that "without a doubt, some people get carried away with this," but that his concern was making sure "private, law-abiding citizens should not have to pay the price for criminals who own or use guns for illegal purposes."
At the Sportsman's Den in Mahopac, the co-owner, Deborah LoPrimo, said she was worried that the laws would become so strict that the average citizen could not own a firearm and that the criminals would continue to circumvent the law, rendering individuals without guns defenseless.
In Washington, Representative Nita M. Lowey, a Democrat from the 18th Congressional District, said that gun control was an issue that had to be addressed by both local and Federal governments and that she supported the Board of Legislators' proposals. But she also said that she was worried about lax Federal licensing laws for dealers:
"There are more Federally licensed firearm dealers than gas stations in the U.S. They're selling them from the backs of their cars. It's easier to get a license to sell firearms than a driver's license."

HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: Howard Silverman;
A Financial Business Casts a Vote of Confidence for the Island

BYLINE: By SUSAN KONIG 

 BODY:
THE career of Howard Silverman, chairman of Gruntal & Company, the Wall Street brokerage house, has had a major theme -- Long Island.
Mr. Silverman has not only made Long Island his home, but also the site of three branch offices that are the fastest-growing for Gruntal. His latest endeavor is the Gruntal Financial Center in Hewlett, which is to be completed this year.
The company signed a 15-year lease on a two-story 13,500-square-foot building, double the size of its current office in Hewlett. The new office will have room for a staff of 75. Gruntal has also expanded its branches in Great Neck and Syosset. 
 "Now, we are looking at Suffolk County for further expansion," Mr. Silverman said.
Much of his faith in Long Island, he said, stems from an improved local economy, as recession-battered industries like manufacturing continue to reorganize. In short, he added, Long Islanders have shown a renewed confidence in the local and national economies, and that is translating into increased investing.
Founded in 1880, Gruntal has $2.5 billion in assets and $170 million in capital. The firm, which employs more than 2,000 people, has 35 offices in 10 states. In 1991 it was acquired by the Trygg Hansa SPP Group Inc. of Sweden, the largest insurer in Scandinavia, with $40 billion under management.
Mr. Silverman, 58, has worked for Gruntal for 34 years. He became managing partner in 1974 and chairman and chief executive in 1985, when Gruntal went public. He earned a master's in economics and finance at City College. He and his wife live in Great Neck, where they have raised three children.
Q. What is your projection for the stock market in the near future? Do you anticipate a dramatic correction or a "slow drip"?
A. We're not anticipating a dramatic correction. We think the economy is in far better shape than most people realize. We're seeing an economic recovery and a surge in corporate earnings, and all of this is coming without any substantial increase in inflation. What's more important, though, is that we're seeing the productivity of the U.S. employee increase dramatically, and that tends to increase corporate earnings and keep inflation down.
You will see fluctuations in the stock market, because of the interest-rate adjustments that are going on now. But we feel they'll end in a few months. As long as corporate earnings stay on track, and we think that they will for at least the next few years, the market is in good shape.
Q. How would you advise investors bewildered by the market's recent volatility?
A. I would tell them not to take a short-term outlook. That invariably leads to selling at the bottom and buying at the top. I'd advise taking a long-term outlook, because we feel the current economic recovery and change in business will be a longer-term phenomenon. If investors look at the long-term picture we think they'll do quite well.
I don't know of any area where you can get a higher rate of total return or more liquidity than in the equity market. The real-estate market is coming along, which is very important for Long Islanders. I think home prices on the Island will rise again. They've already risen in the city.
Q. Which investments are performing best?
A. Without naming individual companies, which I'd rather not do, I would say those that are tied to the economy will do quite well. Companies tied to consumer demand, heavy industry or resources that are used in the manufacturing cycle -- they are the best situated on a nearer-term basis.
I just read in the paper that the automobile industry is seeing a scarcity of certain models. The average car-manufacturer's inventory is down, and prices have just been increased. All of this is indicative of very good business, and it should continue to reflect itself in auto stocks.
We also think chemical companies are in good shape because of the increase in overall manufacturing.
On a longer-term basis it's the growth stocks -- those in the biotech industry, the electronics industry and software companies that we're recommending. We think they have a very bright future.
Q. Is now a good buying market?
A. I think there are many equities in the buying range now, especially since we've had the reaction in the marketplace. One should not be hesitant because prices have declined. One should become more aggressive when prices fall, not when they rise. I know it goes against human nature, but that's the way to make money.
Q. Do you anticipate another rise in interest rates?
A. Interest rates have risen dramatically with the 30-year Treasury, now yielding more than 7 percent. But I think they're very close to their high, and I would advise investors not to wait to place income-oriented investments. We think now is a good time for that.
Q. Will CD's have a revival?
A. The problem with CD's is that they're yielding far lower than other income instruments. You can't buy a five-year CD that is yielding anywhere near a five-year Treasury, for example. But there's no doubt in my mind that CD rates will come up to meet the yield of the other instruments.
One thing investors should consider are municipal issues, because their yields are quite high. If, for example, Long Island residents purchase New York municipals, they are triple tax free. Their yields are above the normal relationship between municipals and other income investments. So the time for municipal investing is right about now.
Q. Should investors pull their money out of bonds?
A. No, I would not pull money out of bonds at this level. If anything, I'd be inclined to place additional money into fixed income. The rates are stabilizing, and I think they are good rates right now.
Q. What do you feel constitutes a balanced portfolio, and are mutual funds a good way for the average investor to diversify?
A. Mutual funds are good for the average person, because I think the average person needs direction. A portion of the average growth should be managed professionally, and that's essentially what mutual funds are, professional management of money. They've also performed quite well over the years.
On balance I feel at least half of an investor's investable assets should be placed into equities or equity mutual funds, with the remainder in fixed-income or income-producing institutions.
Q. Why should such a large part of assets be in common stocks?
A. Over a period of time stocks have substantially outperformed all other investment media. And there is no reason to believe that that will change in the future.
In addition, securities are liquid. If a person's financial situation should change, he can convert the equities into cash assets. If you invest in real estate or art, for example, you won't have that kind of liquidity.
Q. Is there reason to worry about the brokerage industry in view of the recent problems at Kidder Peabody and Prudential?
A. The problems at these other firms are significant. But 95 percent of this industry has never had trouble like that. I believe that those were isolated incidents, and they should in no way taint the whole industry.
At the same time, though, I think the problems those firms have had are being corrected. They are still two very fine firms. And most large brokerage houses have insurance, so their clients are protected and not placed in jeopardy.
Q. What are your feelings about foreign investments through single-country funds?
A. Some areas of the world are growing faster than others. But I think investments in a number of single-country funds are very valid. Most of these countries are not as economically developed as the U.S., Great Britain or France, for example, and there is a higher degree of risk exposure when you invest in them. Nevertheless, as we look into the 21st century, we know that Mexico will have a substantial growth rate. Some of the Eastern Bloc nations, which were recently separated from their mother country, will have great growth potential. It's important to invest in these countries. But you need professional management. You can't do it yourself. It's too risky. With a single-country fund the risk is spread out among various issues, and you have people in that country directing that investment.
Q. Is there a way for Long Islanders to invest in Long Island?
A. If you want to play certain stocks or certain areas, you should look at some of the superstores that have opened here. One only need look at Old Country Road in Carle Place to see the volume of stores that are coming in. One should also look at the plant expansions.
Unfortunately, when people think of Long Island industry they think of Grumman and how many people they've had to lay off. People think Grumman symbolizes Long Island. But that's not true. There are many vibrant industries here, and many on the way.
