HEADLINE: How to Look Like a Million When You're Not

BYLINE: By DEBORAH L. JACOBS; Deborah L. Jacobs, an independent journalist based in New York, specializes in legal and business topics.

 BODY:
WHEN Deborah Watring started a business in her bedroom eight years ago, she wanted the giant telecommunications companies to whom she offered marketing advice to think she was running a much larger enterprise. Although pinched for money, she spent several thousand dollars on a "high-end image package" that included three-color professionally designed stationery and business cards printed on expensive paper.
Today her company, Watring & Associates, rings up $1.5 million in annual sales doing business for the likes of Nynex, MCI and AT&T. Ms. Watring credits her success in part to the big-company attributes that her business has adopted -- despite its structure as a small "virtual" corporation. Ms. Wat ring's "associates," it turns out, are 40 sole proprietors and small companies, most operating from home offices, spread over eight states. 
 To keep up the corporate image, Ms. Wat ring requires her associates to follow certain protocols. They must answer all telephone calls by stating their names or the company name; they must not let children pick up the phone, and they must never mention that they are doing the laundry. Watring & Associates has only two employees (an office manager and a part-time bookkeeper), but "we think like we're in a marble-atrium office building," Ms. Watring said.
Like many others working in small businesses, Ms. Watring faced a marketing hurdle: building credibility in an environment dominated by name brands and by a belief that bigger means better. To overcome that hurdle, small businesses are increasingly relying on ways -- some high-tech, most commonsensical -- to project larger images.
Some use business names that connote bigness (with terms like "associates" or "group") and titles ("president" or "chief executive officer") that make lone eagles sound as if they have company. Other tricks of the trade: large ads in the Yellow Pages, "800" phone numbers and addresses with "suite" numbers (which often turn out to be the president's apartment or mailbox).
The business needs of emerging enterprises have given a boost to other companies that serve them. Mail Boxes Etc., a franchise, supplies a mailroom of sorts for some of the newly created "suites." HQ Business Centers, another franchise, offers office space, conference rooms, reception areas and secretarial services.
Approximately one-third of HQ's 10,000 customers buy a "business identity" package that includes up to 32 hours a month of office space and support services, said Lisa Surman, director of marketing at the San Francisco-based company. Prices for the package range from $100 a month at a business center in San Francisco's airport to $325 a month at a choice New York address.
THE wave of corporate layoffs and downsizings in recent years has sent more people into self-employment and increased the demand for image-building services. Clients "don't want to feel they're writing a check to just some guy working out of his home," said Barry E. Maher, a consultant who advises businesses about advertising in the Yellow Pages and who works out of a bedroom in his Santa Barbara, Calif., apartment. Although he types most of his own correspondence, Mr. Maher includes the code "Bem:im" at the bottom of letters to make customers think he has a secretary. The first three letters are his initials. The second two are short for "IBM," his computer.
In a similar spirit, an exterminator's business card gives an office address in White Plains and lists "direct lines" in six other Westchester towns. In fact, the exterminator has just one office with all of the telephone numbers feeding into it.
For a number of years, Watring & Associates operated out of a mobile home next to Ms. Watring's house in Talladega, Ala. Its "associates" -- including a video production company, two graphics design firms, market researchers and technical writers -- communicated by phone and through an electronic mail system based in the mobile home.
This year, the company bought a 2,000-square-foot building in Decatur, Ga., an Atlanta suburb, to serve as an office for the two employees, E-mail system and files. But most of the associates -- along with Ms. Watring, who now lives two miles from the Decatur office -- will continue working from home. Much of the time Ms. Watring is on the road, keeping in touch by cellular phone.
Other new and increasingly affordable technologies are supplying a variety of high-tech tools for looking big. One such device is the Image Vox, an electronic secretary that is reminiscent of talking dolls. Phrases in its digitally recorded repertory include "Who's calling?" "Will he know what it's about?" and "Please hold."
The Image Vox is designed for people who are ready to talk with customers "but don't want to answer the phone themselves because they feel it reflects negatively on their professional image," said George Ferrara, the Scottsdale, Ariz., entrepreneur who invented the device. Instead, business owners can carry on the "secretary's" end of the conversation by pressing a series of buttons that engage the caller in conversation, said Mr. Ferrara, the "marketing director" of his company, Image Vox Communications. (The company has an automated demonstration line: 602 502-1718.)
What if the business owner becomes flustered or runs out of possible prerecorded responses (for instance with a chatty caller)? In that case, the person can push a general purpose "panic button." It triggers the hurried answer, "hold on just a second," as if the "secretary" needed to answer another call. The owner can then pick up, said Mr. Ferrara, who has offered the device ($300 to $450, depending on the number of custom-recorded phrases) for more than a year. He declined to say how many he has sold.
Home Automation Laboratories, a catalogue company based in Atlanta, sells other high-tech tools for looking big. These include Zany Phone Effects ($39), which makes sounds like an intercom, a ringing phone and a doorbell while the user is on the telephone, and Voice Manager (about $3,000), which can direct telephone calls to various voice mail boxes -- even if it is the same person who will get the message. Then there is Voice Changer ($89), which can alter a person's voice by 10 pitches up or down and "fool the other person into thinking there are more people there," said Barclay Brown, Home Automation's president.
For handling weekend phone calls in his own office, Mr. Brown favors a more low-tech approach. "Security," he says, impersonating a watchman as he answers the phone. Unless he knows callers, Mr. Brown asks them to call back during business hours.
Where do legitimate business purposes end and deceptions begin? Business consultants are reluctant to draw sharp distinctions. The larger that small offices and home offices look, "the more they are perceived to have credibility and the more business they are going to get," said Gene Fairbrother, who provides advice to those who call a telephone "hotline" (800 232-6273) operated by the National Association for the Self-Employed in Hurst, Tex. After getting a foot in the door, it's up to business owners to prove they are "just as capable as anyone else," he said.
One risk is that small businesses will sell products or services that they don't have the expertise or resources to deliver. In that case, they should seek out experts or subcontract for additional help, consultants say. When small businesses fail to follow through -- or worse yet, perpetuate a scam -- "it goes down as a black mark against all of us," said Sarah Edwards, a self-employment expert in Santa Monica, Calif., and co-author with her husband, Paul, of "Making It On Your Own" (G. P. Putnam's Sons) and other books.
Strategies that mislead the public can backfire, Ms. Edwards added. For instance, a sole proprietor who always uses the term "and associates" or speaks of business decisions using the editorial "we" could be embarrassed when a customer finds out that the business is a one-person operation.
On the other hand, she said, old stigmas against home-based businesses make it "counterproductive" to routinely disclose all the details. Nor is it usually relevant that a business is home-based. "Most of the services that people provide at home are not location-dependent," Ms. Edwards said.
ONCE they build credibility, small businesses can use size as a selling point, said Marilyn Ross, co-author with her husband, Tom, of "Big Ideas for Small Service Businesses," published by Communication Creativity, their Buena Vista, Colo., company. A small company "can react much more quickly than a large corporation that has to go through committees or layers of bureaucracy," she said.
Big businesses that rely on small companies and home offices seem to agree. As long as a business can "get the job done," size doesn't matter, said Peter E. Fernald, marketing manager at Northern Telecom Inc., a client of Watring & Associates. Steelcase Inc., a Grand Rapids, Mich., manufacturer of office furniture, recently named a small business that produces acoustical material for office cubicles as its supplier of the year.
The irony is that "you have to come across looking like a big company to get your clients, but keep your clients based on small-company values and services," said Karen Westerfield, whose tiny Omaha company, Wessan Interactive, offers computerized processing of "800" phone numbers. Many of Wessan's competitors are long-distance carriers like Sprint and AT&T, which can undercut the small company's prices. Ms. Westerfield, whose clients include Fortune 500 companies, emphasizes the higher level of service that she says she can offer.
Even as small businesses try to look bigger, big businesses are imitating some of their intimate touches.
Take handwritten notes of the variety that many insurance agents and stockbrokers now send. Several years ago, a small business would never send a handwritten letter for fear of looking "like a little guy," said Mr. Maher, the Yellow Pages consultant. "But now the big guys are doing it to show how they can give personal service."

HEADLINE: Dodge Foundation: Financing Initiatives

BYLINE: By GENE NEWMAN 

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN

 BODY:
AS government and corporate subsidies shrink in recession times, philanthropic organizations like the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation are sometimes the only hope for those seeking to finance projects.
Created in 1974 with a $60 million bequest from Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge, who died in 1973, the foundation occupies offices here, close to the Madison site of the former Giralda Farms estate of Mrs. Dodge, a niece of John D. Rockefeller. Assets have grown to $190 million while grants totaling $103 million have been invested in a wide variety of carefully investigated projects. 
 "Sometimes we take a problem and we find who can provide the leadership to solve it; then we get behind that person and help supply energy and focus," said Scott McVay, the executive director of the foundation since it began operations.
He said initiatives like a 10-year, $2.7 million project to teach Mandarin Chinese in 60 high schools across the country were created because of needs perceived by the foundation.
Speaking of the 20,000 students who have participated in the program, Mr. McVay said, "Those children who have learned the Chinese language and culture are the ones who will be shaping the nature of our relationship with China in the next century in business, education, diplomacy and the professions."
 
$11 Million Grant Budget
 The foundation's $11 million grant budget for 1994 ranks it in the top 1,000 of the approximately 34,000 foundations in the nation, according to the Foundation Center in New York, a clearinghouse for industry data.
Dodge program officers consider proposals from organizations meeting certain Internal Revenue Service guidelines, but, except for some of its initiatives, the foundation does not deal with individuals. Mr. McVay that only about 250 of the 2,500 applicant proposals received each year resulted in grant awards.
The three grant categories suggested in the will of Mrs. Dodge were: animal welfare, which had been one of her major pursuits; the arts and local projects in Morris County. To these, the nine-member board has added public issues and pre-collegiate education categories.
The high demand for foundation funds is shown by requests for public-issue program financing last year that totaled $12 million.
"We had a budget in that category of only $3.2 million," Mr. McVay said. "It was agonizing. There was a lot of hard work and careful screening. Eventually we came to a decision, and 35 organizations that we supported in the recent past were not funded last year."
This year, he said, with an educational budget of $3.5 million, the foundation has received proposals totaling $6 million. Sixty-two educational applications representing $4.8 million in grants have survived initial reviews and await a final arduous screening by a trustee committee.
"This represents a lot of work," Mr. McVay said. "I could spend an hour discussing any one of these 62 proposals. We really want to work with people who are trying to make things better and who operate in a selfless manner."
The foundation has searched New Jersey for what he called "master teachers" to support educational programs. He described these educators as having a zest for life and a boundless curiosity and as exemplars of good practice.
 
Project for Principals
 Elaine Pace, principal of the Littleton Elementary School in Parsippany, was 1 of 25 New Jersey principals selected for a new program in 1992. She was given a $5,000 grant to divide between a course at the Harvard University Principals' Center and a program of her choice at her school.
"That was a terrific support project for us," Mrs. Pace said. "No one had looked to principals before when they wanted to help schools."
The Parents Learning Night, which she began then, has continued every year, she said, and the principals have formed a self-help network. The foundation helped establish a Principals Center last November at the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching in Princeton, she said.
The Partnership for New Jersey, a community service organization of business leaders, has received public-issues grants to support a yearly leadership course for 50 young executives.
"We're in the eighth or ninth cycle now," Mr. McVay said. "The graduates of this program have formed an actively responsive network, and 15 of the alumni are in Governor Whitman's administration, some at cabinet level."
The foundation has given about 21 percent of its total grants to the arts, about three times the national average, Mr. McVay said. Recipients in 1992, the latest year of record, included giants like the Metropolitan Opera, Carnegie Hall and the New Jersey Symphony and smaller local groups like the Playwrights Theater in Madison.
In some programs the foundation has brought schoolteachers and the art world together. The Dodge Poetry Festival, held every other year since 1986 at Waterloo Village, attracts major poets from around the world like Octavio Paz of Mexico, a Nobel laureate.
 
Search for Poetic Talent
 An outspoken lover of poetry, who will recite a Shakespeare sonnet to illustrate a point and who has included verse in the margins of the foundation's annual reports, Mr. McVay spoke enthusiastically about a 1986 search for poetic talent in the state.
"We sent letters to every high school English teacher and asked eight questions on poetry," he said. "From all the responses we picked 20 and invited them to spend a Saturday at my home in Princeton explaining what they thought could be done to advance poetry."
Each teacher was asked to recite a favorite poem, and Mr. McVay said that "after an hour of listening I felt like I was in a balloon rising."
An initiative program in nonverbal arts brought in 120 applications from art teachers to receive $5,000 grants to pursue projects of their choice. "The energy, the imagination, the articulation of those proposals," Mr. McVay said, prompted the trustees to increase the number of grantees to 18 from 16.
A statewide competition among art teachers will culminate next fall in a juried exhibition at the Morris Museum with judging by a panel of renowned artists including the sculptor George Segal.
 
Improving Animal Welfare
 As for animal welfare, one of the first steps necessary to improve it is to change the attitudes of many humans, Mr. McVay said. "It's a staggering fact that 15 million to 16 million cats and dogs are put to death every year," he said. "Why? Part of the answer is that we're a consumer-oriented society of fewer and fewer long-term commitments."
The foundation supports groups across the country that actively oppose cruelty to animals and promote animal population control. Speaking of a grantee, Esther Mechler, project director of SPAY/USA, a Connecticut-based organization, Mr. McVay said: "There was something about Esther that was really worth betting on. She's become one of a dozen key leaders in humane efforts in the country."
Without a Dodge Foundation grant, the Southeast Morris chapter of the Red Cross in Madison would have no newsletter to inform the community of 60,000 that it serves, said Anne Babcock, executive director of the chapter. The newsletter advises on available services and has been instrumental in recruiting 700 volunteer workers. In today's economy, she said, "there's no other place to get this money; absolutely not."
Dodge Foundation grant recipients are required to file accountability reports after nine months. Evidence of effective use is necessary to make their next application competitive, but Mr. McVay said repeat grants should not be counted on. "We try to provide clear signals at every step along the way to lower expectations," he said.

HEADLINE: PRESSURE BY SERB ON ALLY IN BOSNIA

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 10

 BODY:
Maneuvering to bring an end to trade sanctions against his country, President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia has opened a campaign to discredit his erstwhile ally, the leader of the Bosnian Serbs, Radovan Karadzic.
The apparent aim is to force Dr. Karadzic to accept a settlement of the Bosnian war proposed last week by major powers including the United States. That would in turn lead the United Nations to ease the crippling trade embargo imposed two years ago against Yugoslavia to punish Serbia, its dominant republic, for its military support of the Bosnian Serbs. 
 In the last few weeks, Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party of Serbia has abruptly posed a direct challenge to Dr. Karadzic by opening branches in Serbian-controlled cities in Bosnia including Banja Luka and Pale.
The new offices carry photographs of Mr. Milosevic but none of Dr. Karadzic, whose Serbian Democratic Party had virtually monopolized the political scene in Serbian-held areas of Bosnia.
At the same time, Dr. Karadzic has disappeared from state-controlled television in Belgrade, the single most powerful vehicle of Mr. Milosevic's authority and long a trumpeter of Dr. Karadzic's accounts of the military victories of the Bosnian Serbs.
"I don't know how long Karadzic will endure," said Milorad Ekmecic, a Serbian historian who used to teach at Sarajevo University. "It seems that Milosevic now wants him out."
Aside from seeking an end to the trade sanctions, Mr. Milosevic seems to be trying to distance himself from Serbian war crimes committed in Bosnia early in the war by directing blame at others.
 
Gesture of Contempt
 When Dr. Karadzic returned to Belgrade on Wednesday from Geneva, where the United States, Russia and the European Union gave him and the Muslim-led Bosnian Government until July 19 to decide on a proposed settlement, his news conference was not televised and Mr. Milosevic declined to receive him.
The proposed settlement, ringingly endorsed today by the Group of Seven industrialized democracies and Russia at a summit meeting in Naples, offers 51 percent of Bosnia to a federation of Muslims and Croats there and 49 percent to the Serbs.
Although Dr. Karadzic has publicly described the map as a humiliation to the Serbs, who now hold 70 percent of Bosnia, most analysts here predict that he will sign the settlement.
Rather than report Dr. Karadzic's views on the proposal when he returned to Belgrade, state television and other media organizations close to Mr. Milosevic moved into high gear, depicting Dr. Karadzic's self-styled government as a venal and oligarchic regime bent on thievery and warmongering.
Dr. Karadzic's notorious gambling, his purchase of villas for his family in Belgrade and the theft by Bosnian Serbs of thousands of Volkswagen Golfs from a factory near Sarajevo have all become news, though they were once taboo subjects for most of the Serbian media.
Hadzi-Dragan Antic, the director of Politika, a newspaper close to Mr. Milosevic, scathingly criticized Dr. Karadzic and other Bosnian Serb politicians in an article last week.
 
War Profiteering Charged
 "There are those who wish to continue the war at any cost," he wrote, "because, among other things, it is their only opportunity to continue getting rich and living by war profiteering or maybe in order to cover up war crimes that might land them in court."
As those reports appeared, Mico Stanisic, an interior minister of the self-styled Serbian republic in Bosnia, accused the Bosnian Serbs' prime minister, Vladimir Lukic, of embezzling 3.5 million German marks, or about $2.3 million. Mr. Stanisic is known to be close to Mr. Milosevic, while Mr. Lukic is one of the politicians closest to Dr. Karadzic.
"The message seems clear," one Western diplomat said. "Milosevic now wants peace and sanctions lifted, and he wants Karadzic as a fall guy for what the Serbs did in Bosnia."
Even though most analysts here expect that Dr. Karadzic will sign the settlement, it is not yet clear that Mr. Milosevic will get his way. Important forces in Serbia -- including the Serbian Radical Party of Vojislav Seslj and the Orthodox Church -- have encouraged Dr. Karadzic to resist.
And since the settlement would require the Bosnian Serbs to withdraw from several important Bosnian cities, including Doboj and Jajce, Dr. Karadzic is likely to face strong resistance from his military leader, Gen. Ratko Mladic, and from local commanders.
Dr. Karadzic has said the latest proposal will be submitted to his self-styled parliament for a vote. In May 1993, the representatives of the Bosnian Serbs threw out an earlier plan prepared by Cyrus Vance and Lord Owen despite Mr. Milosevic's exhortation to accept it.
In that instance, the Serbian President's stand proved substantially hollow. Mr. Milosevic quickly resumed the active logistical and financial support that is essential to the Bosnian Serbs. Even now, analysts say it may be politically impossible for him to abandon his fellow Serbs in Bosnia if they reject the latest plan.
But there is an important difference today. A year ago, Dr. Karadzic had the strong support of the Bosnian Serbs. But their support is waning as they weary of war and progressive impoverishment. Mr. Milosevic, a deft politician, knows that this time he has a receptive audience.

Now, Mr. Milosevic is trying to wrest political power from Dr. Karadzic and force him to accept an international peace plan. (Associated Press)(pg. A2)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 2436 words

HEADLINE: The Uninsured: Who Are They? A special report.;
Frayed Nerves of People Without Health Coverage

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

 BODY:
At the age of 52, unemployed after an international career as a manager, Bob Hughes is astonished to find himself without health insurance and wishes Washington would do something about it.
"I don't want a dole from the Government," said Mr. Hughes, who lives with his wife next to a golf course near Houston and cannot afford the $568 monthly premiums they were quoted this year. "Just a little help, a little protection until I get re-employed." 
 Mark Elias, a 36-year-old self-employed woodworker in New Orleans, has plenty of business, but he and his wife think they would rather spend their money on private schools for their three children than on health insurance. Mr. Elias, who makes custom doors and windows to the sonorous voice of Rush Limbaugh, would rather live with risk than see the Government meddle with health care.
Lauren Bright, a 26-year-old actress, survives in New York City by waiting on tables. "I'm honestly thinking of giving up acting in search of a career with benefits," she said. "It's a sad thing."
In San Francisco, Trinidad Estrada, a 29-year-old mother of three who stands in a restaurant all day making burritos, wonders how she will come up with $1,000 for foot surgery; she resents the free coverage the state gives to people she regards as loafers.
These are some of the 39 million uninsured people, more than one in seven Americans, at the center of an epic political battle as Congress decides how far the country will go toward universal coverage. Their plight has been called a crisis and a non-crisis, their numbers called understated and overblown.
Whatever the politics, evidence points unequivocally to serious hardships for tens of millions of Americans. But this problem cannot be swept away, it is clear, without costly Government subsidies or painful mandates on employers and possibly both -- a predicament that goes a long way toward explaining the pitched combat that will resume this week in Congress.
"All the studies are finding the same numbers," said Drew E. Altman, president of the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation in Menlo Park, Calif. "The argument over the size and shape and seriousness of the problem is really a smokescreen for the more legitimate debate over how to solve it."
 
Profile of the Uninsured
 The burdens fall largely on working families with low-to-moderate incomes. In half of uninsured households, a person works full time and in another third of households a person works part time or part of the year, according to Federal data analyzed by the Employee Benefit Research Institute.
Many uninsured people work for small businesses offering no benefits, or in low-wage or contract jobs. A vast majority believe they simply cannot afford to pay hundreds of dollars a month in insurance premiums.
The uninsured do not include the group that would otherwise be most vulnerable, the elderly. Since the creation of Medicare in the looser fiscal climate of the 1960's, everyone 65 and over has basic coverage that is largely paid for by the public.
The uninsured also do not include many of the poorest Americans, who are often covered by Medicaid, the Federal-state program. Yet, fewer than half of Americans who live below the official poverty line -- an annual income of around $15,000 for a family of four this year -- are on Medicaid, leaving millions uncovered who live in stifling need.
Minority members with lower-than-average incomes are disproportionately uninsured. While 14 percent of white Americans under 65 were uncovered in 1992, 23 percent of blacks under 65 and 35 percent of Hispanic Americans under 65 were.
Disparities among the states are also striking. In much of the South and the West, where jobs without benefits are more common and Medicaid is often less generous, more than one in five people under 65 are uninsured. In many Northern and Midwestern states it is closer to 1 in 10.
People who are excluded by insurers because of pre-existing medical conditions -- a history of cancer or a chronic disease -- have provided heart-rending stories in the health care debate. Banning such exclusions is a goal of many bills in Congress. Yet, these account for only a small fraction of the uninsured, perhaps one million of them, studies suggest.
The commonly quoted figure of 39 million or so uninsured is a snapshot of the population at any point and includes a changing mix of people. Over the course of a year, 58 million people are uncovered at least temporarily, research shows, but many regain coverage when a family member finds a new job with benefits, just as Mr. Hughes in Texas hopes to do.
This turnover has been seized on by both sides in the health care debate. Seeking broad support from the middle class, the White House stresses how widely shared the insecurity is, noting that one in every four currently insured Americans will spend vulnerable months at some point over the next two years. Opponents, asserting that relatively small numbers are chronically uncovered, say the whole problem has been exaggerated.
 
Going Without Care
 But a closer reading of the statistics shows that despite the turnover, the long-term uninsured remain numerous. A new analysis by Timothy D. McBride, an economist at the University of Missouri, finds that three-fourths of those who are uninsured on a given day, or about 29 million people, remain uncovered for one year or more and more than half of them, or 21 million people, for at least two years.
Beyond anxiety, being uninsured takes a medical toll. Most people find ways to get care when it is vital, either paying out of pocket or finding charity care. But they tend to seek help less often and late.
"All the studies show that the uninsured get less care and end up sicker than people with insurance," Mr. Altman of the Kaiser Foundation said. "Insurance per se makes a huge difference."
Many younger, healthy people voluntarily forgo the expense of insurance. In a survey last year of 2,000 adults, conducted by Louis Harris and Associates for the Commonwealth Fund and the Kaiser Foundation, 7 percent of those who lacked insurance said they did not want it, though the reasons were not specified.
Owners of restaurants and other small businesses who have offered to help pay for premiums note that some employees choose to be uncovered rather than pay their share. But it is not clear whether this is more a reflection of lack of interest or the financial strains on many workers.
 
Between Jobs
Medical Insurance Or Their House
 The home of Bob and Susie Hughes, in Conroe, Tex., north of Houston, is filled with mementos of a career abroad: dolls from Shanghai, an incense burner from Indonesia, a painting from Vietnam. Mr. Hughes admits he never thought much about health costs during his years as an executive and sales manager with several companies. That changed after Mr. Hughes left his last job in early 1992 as Southeast Asian sales manager for a petroleum equipment supplier, just as the company was going under.
With no new job in sight, the couple bought a private insurance policy. "They kept raising the premiums and the deductibility to the point where we couldn't afford it," he said of the premiums that jumped this year to $568 a month with a $2,500 deductible. "Faced with the choice of a house or medical insurance, I chose my house," he said. Their coverage ended two months ago.
"I've never taken unemployment from the state or the Federal Government," he said. "I've gone though my savings and I've had to take money from my 401(k). All I want is a little parachute."
Mr. Hughes said his main focus was on finding a job, not on politics, and he is active in Forty Plus, a group that helps experienced professional people find work. Asked about the Washington debate, he chuckled heartily. "I'd like to get the same kind of coverage Bob Dole gets for the same premium," he said, referring to the Republican Senator who has called universal coverage too expensive.
"I think if the Federal Government has their employees on a master plan, they ought to offer it to everybody in career transition," Mr. Hughes said.
 
Out of Reach
No Funds for Care Or for Insurance
 Enrique and Trinidad Estrada of San Francisco, parents of children aged 9, 7 and 4, are struggling toward the middle class. Mr. Estrada, who is 31 and has lived in this country nearly all his life, works all night delivering tortillas; his wife, who came from Mexico to marry him at age 19, works all day making burritos in a restaurant. Neither receives health benefits.
For years they lived with Mr. Estrada's parents, saving to buy their small blue house in the Mission District. To meet the $1,800 monthly payments they rent out the bottom floor for $700, cramming themselves into the top floor, where they have one bedroom and a fold-out sofa on which all three children sleep. Between house payments and baby sitters, Mrs. Estrada said, buying health insurance would be unthinkable.
Mrs. Estrada has not paid much attention to the battles in Washington over health care, but she wonders about the fairness of things. Because of their jobs and home ownership, she said, her family did not qualify for MediCal, the California version of Medicaid. "The people who are working -- why shouldn't we have it?" she asked. "I see people who are as young as I am begging on the streets, and they get everything from the Government."
Still, the Estradas do not seem to dwell on the issue of health care. Mr. Estrada has never been to a doctor. Mrs. Estrada received free care under a public program when she was pregnant, but has not seen a gynecologist in the four years since she gave birth, she said with no sense of alarm.
The children get low-cost checkups at a publicly financed clinic. "They look so healthy," Mrs. Estrada said, "and I don't worry about it."
But a painful condition in her right foot has caused her concern and highlighted the family's vulnerability. She had one operation at a cost of $300, which she paid in monthly installments. But the operation did not cure her, and doctors say she needs another procedure, which will cost $1,000. "It's going to be very difficult for us to find the money," she said.
 
Out of Luck
Aspiring Actor Gets Pneumonia
 Milo Pacheco is a 26-year-old aspiring actor who has lived in New York City since 1991, working as a waiter or bartender to pay the bills. Like many of his friends in the arts and the restaurant world, he was last covered during college, when he stayed on his parents' policy, but now he has no money to spare for insurance.
Until March he was lucky, paying for doctors as he needed them. Then disaster struck, a severe pneumonia and infected fluid around the lungs. He had a chest tube inserted and spent 18 days in the hospital, racking up bills of more than $25,000.
Mr. Pacheco said he now owed several thousand dollars for doctor bills and a CAT scan, which he will slowly pay off. A thoracic surgeon near his parents' home in southern New Jersey, where he sought treatment, was a guardian angel, accepting a surfboard in lieu of a hefty fee. The hospital is chalking off his $20,000 bill to charity care and will recoup much of that from the state and the bills of the well-insured.
Mr. Pacheco's experience has only added to the fears of his girlfriend, Lauren Bright, who is also 26 and waits tables between acting jobs. "When you're paying rent and trying to save a little money, you just hope that you don't get sick," she said.
She has avoided going to the doctor but is grateful that gynecological care, at least, is available on a sliding scale through Planned Parenthood. But now, largely because of the threat of health costs, she said, she is rethinking her choice of careers.
Mr. Pacheco and Ms. Bright both scoffed at the suggestion, made by some economists, that many young adults were not worried about living uninsured. Among people working in restaurants, who seldom receive benefits, for example, "health care is a regular topic of discussion these days," Mr. Pacheco said. "It's always a concern."
He added that he believed that employers ought to contribute at least a share of the cost of worker coverage, as President Clinton proposed.
Ms. Bright said she would welcome Government health subsidies; if a plan with complete coverage were made available in the range of $100 a month, she would take it. But existing cut-rate plans, she said, are not worth it because of their limited benefits.
"I have friends who are Australian and Canadian, and I so envy the fact that they have national health care," she said. "They end up waiting to go home to see a doctor."
 
Against Principles
Business Owner Hates Regulation
 A talk with Mark Elias, the woodworker, suggests why the President's proposals for universal coverage have not drawn an irresistible groundswell of support. Running his own business in Slidell, La., a gritty town east of New Orleans, and making an annual income of about $40,000, he feels he cannot afford to buy insurance for his own family, including his wife, a 13-year-old and 11-year-old twins, let alone his three employees. But his sense of independence extends to his attitude about Government regulation of health care.
The family has been uninsured for two years, since Mrs. Elias left a job with an insurance agency. They looked into buying a policy but especially in light of their desire to send their children to private school, they believed they could not afford rates of $300 a month, with a $2,500 deductible.
"Fortunately, we haven't had any kind of doctor bills," said Mr. Elias, who admits to some worry. He guesses that someone in the family goes to a doctor about once a year, but he cannot remember the last time anybody went.
"I'm not one to run to the doctor for every ache and pain," he said. "Maybe if I was older I'd be more concerned."
At its income, the Elias family would not qualify for subsidies under the main health care plans being debated in Washington, although proposed changes in insurance rules might reduce the price of available policies. Mr. Elias is dubious in any case.
"Even if it was a good deal, I'd rather not have the Government give me something," he said. "I'd rather not have my taxes go for social programs."
But he also knows that if medical catastrophe strikes, he could get help. "I'd probably have to go to the clinic," he said, referring to a nearby public medical center. "We'd work something out. They couldn't leave us out on the street, at least that's the way I understand it."

HEADLINE: South Waits Calmly as North's Transition Begins

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Monday, July 11

 BODY:
The death of the North Korean leader, Kim Il Sung, has sent ripples of concern across the globe, but in this capital, just 30 miles from the border with the North, most people have responded with wariness and an enormous amount of curiosity.
South Korean officials have spent years and huge sums planning for precisely this moment, the death of their hard-line Communist nemesis, and they have constructed dozens of scenarios for taking advantage of any opportunities the transition might offer. 
 But the atmosphere here was noteworthy for its calm over the weekend, with the Government saying only that it was prepared to handle any unusual developments.
 
Party Leaders Summoned
 Reports from the isolated North depicted a nation deep in grief, but the transfer of power appeared to be proceeding without incident. Broadcasts from Pyongyang have been referring to Mr. Kim's son, Kim Jong Il, 52, as his father's rightful successor, and top members of the ruling Workers' Party have reportedly been summoned to the North Korean capital today, a step that some speculate could lead to Kim Jong Il's official election as party leader.
But here in Seoul on Sunday, the dusty parks were filled with a normal complement of families and strollers, the roads were knotted with afternoon traffic and there were no signs that the police had turned out in stronger numbers than usual.
Perhaps the only indication that this Sunday was unusual was the fact that most Government officials here could be reached in their offices, where they generally registered their satisfaction with the progress toward new leadership in the North so far.
The apparent calm speaks volumes about a subtle shift in South Korea's policy in recent years on reunification of the Korean Peninsula -- an issue that has cost more than 3 million lives, defined the political character of the region and at one time nearly brought the United States and China to war.
Only a few years ago, the Governments on either side of the Demilitarized Zone regarded the elimination of that barrier as an almost religious mission. If there was anything held in common by the two Koreas, one capitalist and one Communist, it was the shared passion for the swiftest possible reunification, although each wanted union on its own terms.
But that priority has changed, a fact highlighted by the markedly cautious response to Mr. Kim's death on Friday, reportedly from a heart attack, at the age of 82.
South Koreans still want the division bridged, but they now realize that anything that triggers a hasty, East German-style collapse of North Korea's faltering economy could wipe out the South's hard-won prosperity and lead to years of instability. That is a risk they no longer want to take, if it can be avoided.
The priority, in other words, is no longer removing a Government that South Korea regards as demonic and a barrier to reunification. The goal is to entice North Korea down the path of gradual economic reforms, even if that means the preservation for a time of the repressive, insulated and still dangerous leadership in Pyongyang.
This view has been bolstered in the last two years, as the old ideological divisions within South Korea have closed. The President, Kim Young Sam, is the first national leader in three decades who was not a general. The military's withdrawal from politics in South Korea has led to greater pragmatism here.
What is striking is that the South Koreans are sticking to this approach toward the North even if it means supporting the succession of Kim Jong Il. The younger Kim, referred to as "Dear Leader," is known as an erratic character and is suspected of having masterminded a number of terrorist attacks. Despite questions about his leadership, he appears to be smoothly consolidating his power.
He has been the designated heir for years, so he already controls several of the most powerful institutions in North Korea, including the military.
 
'Time for Keen Observation'
 "Our perception of Kim Jong Il is not favorable at all, that is true," said Kim Hak Joon, a political scientist who is chairman of the board of trustees at Dankook University and who was an adviser to the previous President, Roh Tae Woo. "But we realize our policy has to be realistic. It would be a mistake to show hostility toward Kim Jong Il. That is why this is a time for keen observation."
Of course, the calls for stability and calm reflect a desire to avoid any outbreak of violence at this unusually sensitive moment. At the least, the South Koreans are seeking to avoid a conflict at what is the most heavily armed border in the world.
Kim Young Sam, South Korea's reform-minded president, put his armed forces and police on alert after Kim Il Sung's death was announced, but he also instructed his troops to avoid provocations.
Government officials and experts at Government-controlled research centers say the low-key policy is also a result of a desire for drawing out the unification process.
 
Slow Approach Favored
 "Our best scenario is reunifying through dialogue and opening North Korea's economy, and that is a very slow process," said Kil Jeong Woo, Director of Policy Studies at the Research Institute for National Unification. "We need time to know each other and to narrow the gap between us economically. That is the optimum scenario.
"Our surveys show that an absolute majority of the people in South Korea favor gradualism. They don't want to threaten their prosperity."
In part, this shift in priorities is a product of South Korea's intensive analysis of German unification. That process, which happened with surprising speed after the fall of the Berlin Wall, was far more expensive than many had expected and left Germany with a heavy economic burden.
Researchers here say that the costs would be even greater in Korea, since the economic gulf between the Koreas is far wider than the one between East and West Germany. The per-capita output of North Korea is $943, one seventh that of South Korea.
 
Costs of Unification
 Estimates of the costs that South Korea would have to bear range from hundreds of billions of dollars to more than a trillion, spread out over a decade or so.
Those analyses have sobered the South Korean Government and pushed stability ahead of the emotional desire for reunification.
The focus is on easing military tensions on the peninsula and trying to defuse the crisis over North Korea's refusal to permit international inspections of its nuclear facilities, relying on negotiation rather than potentially destabilizing economic sanctions.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thousands of North Koreans in Pyongyang crowding around a statue of Kim Il Sung on Saturday after his death was announced. Across the border, military forces were on alert yesterday, but Seoul was quiet as the Government awaited the North's next move. (Reuters)

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 6; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1092 words

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rate Rise Is Widely Expected

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Interest rates, particularly those controlled by the Federal Reserve Board, are headed higher, many credit market analysts and traders seem certain. The only unresolved questions, they say, are the timing and the size of the next Fed increase.
What they had viewed as a likely increase in the overnight Federal funds rate turned Friday into a virtual certainty, when the Labor Department released a skein of new and revised employment figures for April, May and June that suggested the economy was boiling along in the second quarter. 
 "We have created one million jobs in the last three months alone," said Paul Mastroddi, a managing director at J. P. Morgan & Company. "And various surveys, from the one conducted by Manpower Inc. to a rapidly rising help-wanted index, tell us this is going to continue."
 
View From Chicago Bank
 The strength of the employment report "warrants some sort of tightening" response by the Fed, said Paul L. Kasriel, a vice president and monetary economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
"The economy certainly appears to be strong, we continue to eat up excess capacity in both the labor market and factory capacity utilization and we are starting to see consistent price increases at the input level, increases coming about because of strong demand," he said.
To most analysts, the timing of the new Fed move is not terribly important. It is likely to come, they said, sometime between now and Aug. 16, when the central bank's policy-making Open Market Committee is scheduled to hold its next meeting.
Between now and then, the traders as well as Fed governors will have had the opportunity to sift through more economic and inflation data, much of it to be released this week.
 
Greenspan Testimony
 The Fed governors will presumably have to decide if they want to raise rates before Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, goes to Congress on July 20 to deliver his semiannual testimony on the Fed's outlook for the economy.
Given the past performance of the Greenspan Fed, a rise of one-quarter of a percentage point in the Federal funds rate, currently at 4.25 percent, would seem the most likely course.
But some analysts noted that the gradualist approach was not well received by financial markets in the first quarter. Rather than risk another period of market turbulence, during which questions about the Fed's resolve to fight inflation would again be raised, the analysts said, the Fed might choose to raise the Federal funds rate by half a percentage point and lift the discount rate, now at 3.50 percent, by a similar amount.
It is far from certain that even a half-point rise, which would mean the funds rate has gone up 1.75 percentage points in slightly more than six months, would preclude further tightening moves by the Fed this year.
Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities Inc., said he expected growth to moderate in the second half of the year. A half-point increase later this month or in August might be sufficient, he said.
 
Economy's Growing Strength
 But others said they were surprised by the underlying strength implied by the employment numbers. To ratchet down growth, higher interest rates will be needed, they said.
"At this point in the cycle, I think growth is fairly insensitive to interest rates," Joseph Liro, chief economist at S. G. Warburg & Company, said. "We are at the part of the business cycle where things are buoyant, and I think it will take a long time to slow it down."
Until Friday, Mr. Liro said he had been expecting a second-half rally in the bond market. No longer.
"The economy has enough self-sustaining momentum to drive it at above potential growth for the next year or so," he said. "I think the Fed will be driving short rates higher, and I think long rates will follow."
After looking at the employment numbers, one money manager said he agreed that the Fed would tighten policy again.
But William H. Gross, a managing director at the Pacific Investment Management Company, which has more than $53 billion in fixed-income assets under management, said he believed the worst of the selloff in the bond market was over.
"We are not expecting an imminent return to a bull market," Mr. Gross said, "but the employment number probably represents a peak in all of the bearishness we have seen since early this year."
"I think we will move toward weaker " economic numbers in the second half of the year, he said.
Mr. Gross said he expected the yield on the 30-year bond, which ended Friday at 7.69 percent, its highest since early November 1992, to trade in a range of 7 percent to 8 percent during the next three months to six months.
Further tightening by the Fed would doubtless meet with at least some oratorical resistance from the Clinton Administration.
Indeed, on Friday, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said at the Group of Seven economic summit meeting in Naples that no interest rate increase by the Fed was immediately justified.
But analysts said such objections would be based on politics, not on real concern about what higher rates might do to the economic expansion.
"As long as the economy shows good growth, I don't think the Administration will fight another increase of one-quarter, one-half or even three-quarters" of a percentage point in the Federal funds rate, Allen Sinai, chief economist at Lehman Brothers, said.
"The moment the economy show some signs of recession, the Administration would be on a conflict path with the Fed," Mr. Sinai continued. "And interest rate increases of the sort I talked about would not do in the economy."
 
Dollar's Continued Influence
 The Administration -- and the bond market -- will probably continue to be pestered by a weak dollar, analysts said, even after the Fed raises interest rates.
"I think the dollar will continue to be a problem for the bond market, even though the employment data make a Fed tightening move more likely," John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said.
Offsetting an increase in short-term interest rates, Mr. Lipsky said, is the Administration's continued proclivity to change positions on its exchange rate policy.
In the days before the Naples meeting, Secretary Bentsen, the Administration's chief spokesman concerning the dollar, said the Administration vigorously supported a strong dollar. But Mr. Lipsky said that stance seemed to evaporate.
And Mr. Liro said, "I think the dollar will be one of the negatives weighing on the market."

HEADLINE: Unclimbed Summit;
The Talks Begin With Modest Aims And Indeed End With Much Undone

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NAPLES, July 10

 BODY:
Last year's economic summit conference, President Clinton said on Saturday, ended by "not accomplishing very much." This year, he suggested, "there was a real sense of confidence," and the achievements would therefore be greater.
If so, they were subtle, incremental and not very easy for most people to discern. 
 The really important thing about such meetings is not, in any case, what kinds of headlines or initiatives they produce, but whether they carry forward, from year to year, the process of cooperation among the world's strongest nations, which so often in the past have been such deadly rivals.
Politicians, journalists and the gala atmosphere surrounding these conferences often raise unreasonable expectations. The issue is not whether summit conferences change the world but whether they keep happening and keep providing a forum where leaders can schmooze.
"You need to step back," Secretary of State Warren Christopher said in an interview, "and consider how remarkable it is that all the great powers in the world meet with each other and have good relations with each other and do business with each other."
 
Much Unfinished Business
 From that perspective, Naples was a success, even if the agenda of unfinished business remains long, even if Mr. Clinton had several very unsteady moments.
The President told his fellow leaders just before the conference opened that he opposed any early effort to prop up the dollar, because the American economy was healthier than the markets thought. The markets promptly battered the dollar further.He put forward a trade initiative and then, opposed by the French, pulled it back.
This afternoon, he expressed hope that his diplomacy had paved the way for the completion of Russian troop withdrawals from all the Baltic nations, including Estonia, by Aug. 31. President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, standing next to him, said a few minutes later that he could "say no" to withdrawal from Estonia by that date.
In each case, Mr. Clinton seemed to have gone just a bit beyond his brief, opening himself to embarrassment. On Estonia, for example, his aides said that while the outcome was far from clear, Mr. Yeltsin's agreement to discuss the issue personally with President Lennart Meri of Estonia for the first time was a hopeful sign.
 
A More Informal Approach
 On the other hand, Mr. Clinton succeeded in many of his aims, including the adoption of a more informal approach this year, with less predigestion of thorny issues by aides. He also persuaded his fellow leaders to focus on Iran as a sponsor of terrorism and to make specific promises of aid to Ukraine when some of them favored a more general approach. And he got the Russians to join in urging an end to the Arab boycott of Israel.
As the leaders of the seven principal industrialized nations concluded their annual talks, marked this year by the inclusion of President Yeltsin as a full participant in the political discourse, the words were optimistic, the body language cordial (handshakes all around, with a few bearhugs thrown in) and the weather stunning.
Even the smog lifted, giving the visiting big shots a postcard-perfect view of Vesuvius, Sorrento and Capri.
But for the most part the meeting followed its modest script, producing the expected endorsement of the Bosnian peace efforts; a pledge by all to ratify the new General Agreement on Tarrifs and Trade, though it is unclear whether all the leaders can deliver on their promises; and an agreement to provide more money to Ukraine, some of it to pay for the initial stages of shutting down the dangerous Chernobyl nuclear reactors.
It is easy enough to enumerate things that were not done.
Caught by surprise like everyone else by the death of Kim Il Sung, the North Korean leader, the leaders could take no new steps on the crisis in that country. With the new Japanese Prime Minister, Tomiichi Murayama, weakened both by his politically perilous position and a bout of intestinal illness, even less progress than anticipated was possible on the problems that result from his country's trade policies.
 
France Labors Alone
 None of the other six nations represented here stepped forward to offer to help France in its lonely effort to bring order to Rwanda through the dispatch of 2,500 troops to central Africa. Wider philosophical questions of peacekeeping and peacemaking -- when and where it should be undertaken, and by whom -- were notably absent.
One senior American official said that there was no agreement on what should be done if the Serbs fail to accept the terms of the current Bosnian peace proposals. Another said there was. The Europeans disagreed among themselves.
There were no notable initiatives intended to solve the most pressing problems of all. Mr. Clinton and his colleagues spoke of the cyclical recoveries that most of their nations are experiencing but they had few answers to the stubborn structural unemployment that has accompanied the rise of computers and mass communications. Compared with the fluctuations of the business cycle, long-term joblessness presents far tougher social, political and economic challenges.
Nor did the Naples summit do much to advance the process of creating a grand post-cold-war plan with institutions comparable to those that were put together in the 1950's. In the years since the Berlin wall came down and Communism collapsed in the Soviet Union, the leaders of the West have fiddled with the idea of a new world order, talked about reforming their institutions, but stopped there.
 
The How-To Is Not Addressed
 For the most part, they temporized again here. The final communique was marked mainly by expressions of good intentions, like this, "We are conscious of our responsibility to renew and revitalize these institutions and to take on the challenge of integrating the newly emerging market democracies." It was short on how-to.
Mr. Yeltsin, who came to power three years ago today, was clearly pleased to be included in the political talks. He promised that "the Russian bear is not going to try to break its way through an open door" to full G-7 membership, but there is still sharp disagreement among the seven on inviting him to play a bigger role in the group and on the future status of Eastern European nations.
It is no doubt true that the Group of Seven is an imperfect vehicle for making many of the decisions that must ultimately be made.
It is no doubt true, as Mr. Christopher and others have repeatedly said, that it is harder for the United States to lead in the increasingly multipolar world than it used to be, and that international organization is more difficult without a goal like the containment of Communism.
 
An Opportunity Missed
 But those explanations (or excuses) will last only for so long. All the presidents and prime ministers and officials and diplomats gathered here sense that they have only a limited time to realign the geopolitical pieces that have been scattered in the last few years, and that the longer they wait, the greater the chance of one or more explosions that will close the current window of opportunity.
To quote Mr. Clinton again, this is a "moment of historic economic, political and social change" that must be mastered. From that perspective, each summit meeting that passes without major progress on the broad questions facing the industrialized world is an opportunity dangerously missed.

HEADLINE: Bankers Competing to Lend In New York's Poorer Areas

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
When Robert Cohen wanted to buy two Tudor-style buildings at the corner of Cruger Avenue and Pelham Parkway in the Bronx in 1991, he had trouble finding a bank that would lend him the money. Taking the one loan he could find at the time, he purchased the buildings and renovated everything from the boilers to the elevators to the mortar holding the rust-red bricks together.
Now, as Mr. Cohen tries to refinance the buildings, he has four or five banks competing for his business. His next-door neighbor has also been able to borrow enough money to renovate his building. They are among many landlords benefiting from new sources of money streaming into working-class neighborhoods like theirs in the Bronx and the city as a whole. 
 Over the last two years, borrowers in such neighborhoods who used to go begging for mortgages are finding that more and more banks are willing to lend them money. The increased lending in these areas is having a ripple effect, improving the housing stock and generally helping stabilize neighborhoods that had been teetering on the edge of decline.
With the economic downturn and the banking crisis of the late 1980's and early 90's behind them, banks and thrift institutions are better equipped to lend. But the real-estate market for commercial and larger residential properties still has not rebounded, so lenders are looking beyond their traditional investments to smaller loans -- under $1 million -- in what they used to consider risky neighborhoods.
"There is too much competition for the markets in the better areas of Manhattan, and even in places like Riverdale," said Jeffrey Denler, vice-president for multifamily lending at First Federal Savings and Loan of Rochester. "A lot of lenders are looking to other areas and finding that loans in neighborhoods they never looked at are just as safe."
The new wave of loans has not yet reached the city's most troubled areas but instead solid working-class neighborhoods where landlords can count on receiving their rent. Landlords in Mott Haven and Morrisania in the Bronx and East New York in Brooklyn still have to jump through an extraordinary series of hoops to get loans. But their counterparts in Pelham Parkway and Fordham, Crown Heights and Fort Greene now have more access to money to renovate their buildings and revitalize their immediate areas.
The turnaround is most striking in the Bronx, where whole neighborhoods in the late 1960's and 70's succumbed to abandonment or arson. In that atmosphere of decline, private lending all but stopped and never reached more than a trickle thereafter, primarily in the northwest of the borough.
Now some buildings in these neighborhoods, typically four- or five-story buildings with 50 to 100 apartments, lacking elevators but solidly built in the years before World War II, are being refurbished.
Although most of the loans in the Bronx are in the neighborhoods bordering Fordham Road and Pelham Parkway, the borough's version of the proverbial tracks, some lenders are now financing buildings in the South Bronx, near Yankee Stadium and the courthouse.
 
Loans Create Ripples
 The lending is already having a visible effect on these neighborhoods, helping to draw in even more money.
"As a lender you're surprised, but you do see some transformation in the way the buildings have been maintained," Sam Giarrusso, vice-president of East New York Savings Bank, said of a trip he recently took to see some buildings along the Grand Concourse and Jerome Avenue in the South Bronx. "I think there's a bit of a stigma there, but we will look at buildings selectively for owners that have a proven track record."
A strong demand from families searching for affordable apartments has encouraged both bankers and building owners to consider investing in neighborhoods they used to consider somewhat risky, such as those in the mid-Bronx, mid-Brooklyn and upper Manhattan. Low interest rates over the last two years have also made it more feasible for owners to borrow money.
A few banks lent money in the Bronx through the 1980's, and their programs are expanding. Since January, First Federal has financed 15 mortgages, worth $12.5 million, in the Bronx as compared to eight loans worth $5.5 million in all of 1993. Fourth Federal Savings Bank, which lent about $2 million a year in the Bronx in 1990 and 1991, closed on $11 million worth of loans in 1993. Lenders also say there is more competition to lend money in the Bronx.
 
Freddie Mac Is Back
 In addition, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, has begun lending money for multifamily buildings again after a three-year hiatus. Freddie Mac was the city's largest mortgage lender for apartment buildings in the 1980's, but canceled its lending program in 1991 because of a high default rate. The agency resumed lending to landlords in December, and wants to commit $600 million in the northeast region by the end of 1994, said H. L. Van Varick, director of production and product development for multifamily lending in this region.
But Freddie Mac has had trouble meeting that goal, and has only committed $50 million so far. Mr. Van Varick said the agency needed time to let borrowers know it was back in the market, but also is up against many more competitors than before.
There are two explanations for the growing interest in lending, and most bankers and building owners offer a combination of them. The first is internal: banks are stronger.
"The city's economy hasn't changed," said Robert Chambrey, a mortgage broker who is active in the Bronx. "The banking industry is healthier. Of the six banks I work with in the Bronx, three weren't in the market three years ago."
 
City Changes, Too
 But others say bankers are responding to changes in the city itself, particularly in the Bronx, where city and neighborhood development groups have helped rejuvenate many neighborhoods over the last decade. When lenders visit potential borrowers' buildings in the South Bronx now, they are as likely to see a block filled with viable, working buildings as a set of burned-out shells.
"The economy is stronger and the city's programs have given the Bronx a shot in the arm," said Richard Pergolis, another mortgage broker who grew up in the Bronx and has worked with building owners there for 14 years. "They weren't just putting fancy pictures in the windows of burned out buildings. There are real people in those buildings now. That's massive progress."
Public progress has led to private gains, as bankers are more willing to gamble on new neighborhoods. For example, Mr. Pergolis's firm, Pergolis Swartz, has helped finance 115 properties in the Bronx in the last two years, worth $100 million, about 10 times greater than their volume of business in the previous two years.
While banks are increasingly willing to lend, they are nonetheless careful about whom they lend to. They say they are most comfortable with professional owner-managers, who have a history with the bank and in the borough, and who have the resources to screen tenants and press for rent payments, two keys to success in lower-income neighborhoods.
 
Professional Landlords
 More lending, then, has given rise to more large-scale ownership, with landlords holding 30, 40 or even 100 buildings in the Bronx. Many of these owners have expanded their holdings by buying buildings that earlier Freddie Mac borrowers defaulted on.
These professional owners, in turn, are able to convince their banks to support ventures in other Bronx neighborhoods, ever farther south.
"The lenders kind of follow major building owners into those areas," said Mr. Denler of First Federal. "There had been a period of deterioration in those neighborhoods but now we have gotten to the point where lenders and managers are no longer afraid to invest there."
Jeffrey Levine has seen a new spurt of interest in the work buildings he renovates in the Bronx, in Harlem and in Flatbush, just south of Prospect Park. He said that until two years ago, he had difficulty finding private lenders outside of the Community Preservation Corporation, which pools public and private money for real-estate deals in poor neighborhoods, and Chemical Bank's community investment group.
 
Interest and Credit
 "All of a sudden there is a flurry of banks that were not familiar with these areas before that are now looking to lend in them," Mr. Levine said. "Banks are anxious to lend money where the economics are good, and even more in communities where they can get credit for their loans."
Banks must meet Community Reinvestment Act requirements, investing a certain percentage in neighborhoods where they have branches. These loans can help meet those requirements and also helps them boost their community relations credit. Whether the lending trend will continue depends on the economy, and extending it to poorer neighborhoods may require government subsidies to bring banks into the market.
Still, owners are optimistic. David Ribler held onto four buildings in the Bronx through the 1970's, but sold three others in the South Bronx when they were the only thing standing in the rubble of their neighborhoods.
"I think it's beneficial for the borough," Mr. Ribler, who grew up in Kingsbridge Heights, said of the new money for owners. "I'm not the only one who stayed. Hopefully the people who did will reap the rewards now."

LENGTH: 1369 words

HEADLINE: For United Pilots, 2 Views of Buyout

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
They fly the same type of plane, a Boeing 737, and they have worked for the same airline, United, for at least 25 years. And since 1985 Roger D. Hall and George T. Lenormand have been players in one of Corporate America's longest-running soap operas.
The finale may come tomorrow, when United shareholders will vote on whether to approve the employees' offer of wage and work-rule concessions in return for 55 percent of the UAL Corporation, the airline's parent. 
 If the deal is approved, UAL will become the nation's largest employee-owned company, and Mr. Hall, leader of the pilots union, will have prevailed. But such a move would be cause for apprehension for Mr. Le-normand, who worked through the pilots strike in 1985, is an active lobbyist against the buyout effort and has done financial analyses on the buyout for a group of United pilots who want a new vote by all the pilots, rather than by their representatives.
"The world is changing and we're trying to address that change," said Mr. Hall, 55, the chairman of the United division of the Air Line Pilots Association. "We have come up with a very creative approach, one that is going to provide a lot of benefit."
Mr. Hall, a native of Peoria, Ill., who now lives in Los Altos, Calif., added, "We're on the leading edge of labor-management relations."
But Mr. Lenormand, 50, worries that the leading edge might be on the face of a cliff. "To buy the airline just because you want to have some sense of control doesn't make any sense," he said. "I hope I'm wrong, but this is a lose-lose proposition."
Mr. Lenormand, a Manhattan native who currently lives in Denver, said he believed the employee buyout would hamstring the company financially and would not by itself help change the corporate culture so that employees think more as owners do, particularly since so many employees are either not involved or are opposed to the buyout.
"A business isn't a great social experiment," said Mr. Lenormand, who received a master's degree in business administration from Fairleigh Dickinson University. "I went through all these stupid management courses, and when it comes down to it, the only time this stuff works is when you are doing well."
UAL's operating losses during the last three years totaled $769 million. Its net losses over the same period were $1.34 billion.
Under the proposal that shareholders will vote on tomorrow, employees would receive 55 percent of UAL in exchange for $4.9 billion in wage and work-rule concessions over six years. Stockholders would receive $84.81 in cash for each share they own, and would continue to own 45 percent of UAL.
To be sure, the employees who may soon own most of United are not united themselves. Flight attendants, who have the most contact with passengers, are not part of the deal. And many pilots, machinists and nonunion workers oppose it.
A survey commissioned by a group of United pilots after the union's 28-member council ratified the buyout proposal found that of the 1,750 pilots who responded, 1,200 said they opposed the buyout. UAL's law firm, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, sent a letter to the pilots containing a thinly veiled threat that if they publicized the results, the company would sue them.
The story of the United buyout effort began in 1985, when the union waged its only strike against United over pay and over how long newly hired pilots could be paid less than longtime pilots. The company had asked for concessions from the pilots, who disagreed with the airline company's diversification into hotels and rental car businesses.
Mr. Hall, who was chairman of the United pilots' union at the time, recalls sitting in a meeting during the 29-day strike with the lawyer F. Lee Bailey, who suggested that the union acquire a majority stake in the company so that it could have a say in blocking other strategies it considered misguided.
 
Earlier Buyout Attempts
 "About the only way you're ever going to solve these long-term problems," Mr. Hall recalled Mr. Bailey saying at the time, "is to buy the company."
On several occasions, the pilots tried, in concert with various partners, to acquire United. One notable failure occurred in 1989, when financing for a buyout collapsed, setting off a case of market jitters that led to a 190-point one-day drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. During several days before and after the buyout collapsed, the value of UAL's stock fell by more than a third, as arbitragers saw the value of their investments drop by more than $500 million.
The latest proposal took root in 1992, when Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman of United, approached the union and reiterated his concern about United's high labor costs and the need for wage and productivity concessions. Without them, he said, United would have to sell assets and pull out of unprofitable routes.
The pilots suggested that they and other employees consider concessions in return for majority control of United, and United's management responded with interest. Over the next year, negotiations broke off and revived several times before United's board approved a proposal in late December. The machinists and pilots unions approved it earlier this year, setting the stage for tomorrow's vote.
If the deal goes through, the pilots will have one seat on the company's 12-person board, as will the machinists union and the company's nonunion workers.
In addition to a 15.7 percent wage cut, the pilots agreed to more flexible work rules that would enable the company to set up a no-frills shuttle service fashioned after Southwest Airlines. The machinists agreed to a 9.7 percent wage cut, and the other employees agreed to an 8.25 percent cut. One goal of the deal is to stem United's heavy losses on many shorter domestic routes.
Besides giving the employees equity in the company, the buyout agreement would provide some protection by restricting the company's ability to lay off unionized employees, subcontract work and sell major assets.
 
Weakened Balance Sheet
 The company's balance sheet would be weakened immediately by the transaction, with the removal of about $1 billion from cash reserves and the addition of about $1.15 billion in debt and preferred stock. Newly issued shares would be worth 45 percent of the company, and would trade considerably below the current value of UAL stock, which closed Friday at $129.50, down 75 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The prospect of increased control by labor over United's strategic decisions is illusory, Mr. Lenormand said. With one seat on the board, the pilots would not hold much sway over company strategy, particularly if industry economics demanded that cuts be made.
"It's a nice thought, but in practice it is not going to work," he said. "In the long run, the economics rule."
Mr. Lenormand, who believes a less sweeping solution to some of United's problems could be worked out between the union and United's current management, said he was mainly concerned about the addition of debt and stripping out $1 billion from the company's cash reserves, most of which is going to shareholders.
In an unpredictable business where competitors are forced to match one other's prices, the airline with the strongest balance sheet will always win, he said.
"The cash is the blood of any company, and without blood, what happens?" he said, quoting one of his former business professors.
But United said that it would still have $1.5 billion in cash reserves after the buyout, among the richest reserves of any airline.
While the additional debt is significant, it is still small relative to UAL's current $16 billion in debt and leases, said Philip Baggaley, a transportation industry analyst for the Standard & Poor's credit rating agency.
Mr. Baggaley said he harbored greater concerns for the company's creditworthiness if the deal failed than if it went through, because the unions promised to retaliate fiercely if the company started selling assets.
"There are some large positives and large negatives associated with the buyout," Mr. Baggaley said. "Depending on which you choose to focus on, you can spin out a very optimistic or pessimistic story."
