HEADLINE: A Vision for an Asbury Park Hotel

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ASBURY PARK, N.J.

 BODY:
Bruce Springsteen crooned tributes to this beach town in the 1970's, but it has long since fallen from grace. Years of economic decline have left the Palace Amusements building dilapidated and the souvenir shops deserted. On most days, gulls share the weathered boardwalk with sad-faced wanderers.
Now an unlikely champion -- the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi -- has offered the city hope, not just for the comeback of its tourism business but, his followers say, for a revival in more ethereal ways as well. 
 The Maharishi, 83, a former Hindu monk and spiritual adviser to the Beatles, recently opened two transcendental meditation schools and a holistic health center in Asbury Park's oldest hotel, the elegant Berkeley-Carteret. His nonprofit company, World Plan Executive Council, bought the building in March for $1.85 million.
 
'Little Seaside Haven'
 "We chose Asbury because we wanted to be near the ocean," said Richard Quinn, who manages the hotel with his wife, Linda. "If enough people come here and meditate, it will become an idyllic little seaside haven."
Mayor Patricia Candiano said she is optimistic that the town will profit from the Maharishi's venture. "In order for people to visit Asbury, there has to be a viable hotel," she said. "They seem to be a very good group, and they seem to be making money."
While the Quinns will continue to operate the 250-room Berkeley-Carteret as a hotel and conference center, they expect the meditation schools will be equally important in attracting guests. The schools will teach "Vedic knowledge," theories of nature from sacred Hindu texts. They will offer courses in architecture, business and other subjects from the Vedic point of view -- that of a single reality underlying all things. Daily introductory courses are usually attended by only a handful of people, but Mr. Quinn said the schools' first weekend conference, in April, drew 160 people.
If enough people meditate at the hotel, the owners say, positive energy will nourish the troubled town.
Asbury Park, a working-class community 60 miles from New York City, has struggled for years to reclaim its status as a popular vacation spot. It has been in decline since the 1950's, when the Garden State Parkway opened and tourists started visiting shore towns further south.
Race riots in the early 1970's caused more flight, and many of the town's Victorian homes have become boarding houses for former psychiatric patients, further diminishing its tax base.
The Maharishi is not the first investor with high hopes for Asbury Park, which has a population of 16,800. A group of businessmen tried to transform the town in the 1980's with a $500 million redevelopment project, including an $18 million renovation of the Berkeley-Carteret. But bankruptcies and litigation delayed the project indefinitely.
Meanwhile, other problems have gnawed at the town's dignity, including the resignation of Mayor Dennis Buckley in March after he was arrested for cocaine possession.
 
Seeking 'Pure Consciousness'
 None of this fazes the Maharishi's followers, who assert that transcendental meditation can reduce crime and drug abuse. When a large group of people meditate together, he says, they reach a state of "pure consciousness" that can affect entire communities. His followers have meditated en masse in Washington and Los Angeles, hoping to cure urban blight.
"We like having a positive influence on an oppressed area," Mr. Quinn said. "When your activities create an air of freshness, they refresh the environment."
For Asbury Park, the Maharishi's purchase has already brought financial relief: the $1.85 million price tag for the 69-year-old hotel included $1.25 million in back taxes and liens, Mr. Quinn said. In 1991, the former owners of the hotel defaulted on bank loans, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation took over.
The Maharishi, who lives in the Netherlands, where his company is based, has never been to Asbury Park and rarely visits the United States. The Berkeley-Carteret is his first East Coast hotel. Mr. Quinn said the World Plan Executive Council has bought 15 hotels in this country to house meditation schools, and plans to have one in every state.
The corporate headquarters for the Maharishi's hotel chain has been relocated from Houston to Asbury Park, as well as the administrative offices for his university system, which includes an accredited school in Fairfield, Iowa.
"It's a popular town, a beautiful hotel and the price was right," Mr. Quinn said. "A lot of people won't invest in a place like this, but we've never been afraid."
Mayor Candiano said she supported the new owners' plans. "We're just happy that the hotel is open for business, and that the Quinns are abiding by the rules," she said. "We don't mind them offering classes there. If anything, it's good for business."
Mr. Quinn said a seven-session meditation course costs $1,000. Tuition fees support research on transcendental meditation, he said.
The Quinns say they will keep the decor -- which includes terrazzo floors, arched windows and three ornate ballrooms -- but are making other changes. A vegetarian restaurant will open in the hotel this summer, and the gift shop will feature New Age merchandise, including the Maharishi's line of vitamins.
So far, the changes have not deterred non-meditating customers; the Berkeley-Carteret was booked solid for the July 4 weekend, and several dozen banquets, conferences and weddings are planned for this summer, Mr. Quinn said.
If local interest grows, Mr. Quinn said his staff might offer meditation classes in schools, hospitals and community centers. If the schools are a success, he added, World Plan will buy more property in Asbury Park.
The group is considering the nearby, vacant Convention Hall for a "Veda Vision" theater, which would use special effects to explain Vedic knowledge, Mr. Quinn said. Mayor Candiano insisted, however, that city landmarks like the Convention Hall would never be sold. "The citizens would never stand for it," she said.
But Danielle Richards, a waitress who lives near the hotel, said the Maharishi and his followers should buy more property if it will help Asbury Park.
"If they believe meditation will save this town, let them do it wherever they want," she said, squinting at the hotel as she walked her dog. "Asbury has tried everything else, so why not give these Maharishi guys a chance?"

HEADLINE: For This Court Choice, Policy Is Passion

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
When the Senate Judiciary Committee takes up the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Stephen G. Breyer on Tuesday, the focus of the discussion will probably be profoundly different from confirmation proceedings of recent years.
The issues expected to be considered most intensively with Judge Breyer are not emotion-laden subjects like abortion, the death penalty and freedom of speech. Rather, the focus will most likely be on economic regulation: the authority of the Government to affect the marketplace, the responsibilities of corporations and the choices available to citizens. 
 That change is due, in part, to how much the Supreme Court has receded for the time being as the stage upon which the nation's most pressing social problems are played out. But it is also a reflection of the man President Clinton has selected to be the nation's 108th justice of the Supreme Court.
Judge Breyer, who has written extensively and provocatively about government regulation, is regularly described as a "technocrat lawyer," someone enamored of the intricacies of public policy rather than the more traditional elements of constitutional law.
As the Supreme Court prepares to enter the 21st century, many scholars predict that its workload and its most heated debates will involve just such issues of government regulation.
 
Policy Disputes on the Docket
 In the past, courts were infrequently involved in those kinds of public policy disputes. But such questions are increasingly coming before the court as Congress passes more statutes that the executive branch interprets into regulations -- and a dissatisfied person challenges in a lawsuit.
In this manner, the Court may find itself refereeing tangled questions like how much should the Government spend on AIDS research as compared with cancer research? When Congress orders the cleanup of toxic dumps, should the Government spend large sums to make them squeaky clean or just the amount needed to make them clean enough to be reasonably safe?
Those are exactly the kinds of questions with which Judge Breyer has occupied himself.
Judge Breyer, who is the Chief Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Boston, has outlined his theories of regulation in two books, the most recent published last year. And as a senior Congressional aide in the 1970's he was able to see his theories put into practice when he was the principal architect of deregulating the nation's airlines. Airline deregulation was a bold policy experiment that continues to provoke heated debate, both from scholars and from ordinary air travelers befuddled by ever-changing and incomprehensible fare schedules.
In his 1993 book, "Breaking the Vicious Circle, Toward Effective Risk Regulation" (Harvard University Press), Judge Breyer painted a portrait of Federal regulators and Congress continually wasting resources because of distorted priorities in areas like toxic dumps and dangerous food additives. The regulators and lawmakers devote resources to the wrong problems, Judge Breyer wrote, because they are too sensitive to public opinion.
Many of the situations he cites in his book are from court cases in which judges ruled on Federal agencies' regulations. Judge Breyer argued that exaggerated public fears about the potential damage of breathing asbestos, for example, have produced an unwise and costly rush to clean up asbestos in buildings.
In a 1992 case he cites with approval, the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals struck down an ambitious plan by the Environmental Protection Agency to remove asbestos. The agency wanted to spend a quarter billion dollars in hopes of saving an estimated seven or eight lives over a 13-year period. The court said the nation could expect that many deaths from individuals swallowing toothpicks.
Regulators, he wrote, will pay extra attention to risks that come to the public's attention and, he noted, "Study after study shows that the public's evaluation of risk problems differs radically from any consensus of experts."
Ralph Nader, the public interest lobbyist, who is one of Judge Breyer's most vocal critics, has depicted him as instinctively distrustful of all government regulation and a servant of corporate interests.
Mr. Nader said in an interview that Judge Breyer was a compilation of "bad scholarship, bad analysis and an extremely corporatist outlook." He said the 1993 Breyer book relied heavily on corporate-financed studies to discredit regulation.
But Joel Klein, the deputy White House counsel, who has long followed the Supreme Court, disputed that characterization. He described Judge Breyer's views as an effort to make rational the Government's efforts to deal with competing demands.
"The debate has been miscast by Judge Breyer's critics," Mr. Klein said. "He is hardly an unalloyed critic of the regulatory process. His whole point is that when you have so many competing demands, the regulatory dollar has to be carefully scrutinized. A marginal cleanup of pollution, for example, could be better used on child health care."
But Mr. Nader, who is expected to testify against the Breyer nomination, said that such reasoning falsely pitted one need against another. "That is drawing the line far too tightly," he said, arguing that reducing corporate subsidies would give Government regulators the money to accomplish both goals.
Despite Judge Breyer's critics, there is little doubt that he will be easily confirmed to replace Justice Harry A. Blackmun, who has retired, and that he will take his seat in time for the Court's opening in October.
Nonetheless, Judge Breyer has intensively prepared for the hearings, sitting for several days in Room 145 of the Old Executive Office Building as White House lawyers and others pepper him with questions he is likely to be asked by the Judiciary Committee. He has also watched videotapes of recent confirmation hearings.
 
Amending an Image
 As the confirmation process has come to resemble a political campaign, most of the recent Supreme Court nominees have arrived at the confirmation hearings with carefully tailored images to present. Justice Clarence Thomas spoke at length in 1991 about his impoverished childhood in Pinpoint, Ga., a theme that came to be known as the "Pinpoint confirmation strategy." Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, a native of Brooklyn, similarly dwelt on her childhood last year, and her story was labeled "the Flatbush strategy."
Even Justice David H. Souter, the ascetic New Hampshire judge, apparently felt a need to present a warm, personal side when he said at his 1990 hearing that he had suddenly recalled the anguish of a student he once counseled over whether the student should help his girlfriend get an abortion.
In what appears to be an effort to retouch his image as an elite lawyer-philosopher, Judge Breyer has recently sought to describe himself as a populist. When he met with Mr. Clinton in the Rose Garden after his nomination, he described himself as a people's lawyer.
As a pillar of the Eastern academic-government axis, Judge Breyer, a former professor at Harvard Law School, had not generally been thought of that way. In his writings about regulation, for example, his solution to the problems of misplaced regulatory resources is decidedly elitist: he has proposed the creation of a corps of highly knowledgeable super-bureaucrats that would have the authority to override popular sentiment and Congressional directives.
In addition, apparently to counter the image of someone who has never gotten his hands dirty from contact with the workaday world, Judge Breyer listed on his Supreme Court application a summer job he once held as a "ditch digger" for a San Francisco utility. Other judicial nominees do not typically include their high school summer jobs, but the Breyer entry, with its Jack Kerouac touch, seems designed to show a broad range of experience.

HEADLINE: Buildings Department Irks Niche Professionals

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Can't fight City Hall? Try the New York City Department of Buildings.
"They are trying to prevent me from earning a living," said Carlos Burbano, owner of CCBS Consulting, as he stood in line the other day at the department's fortresslike headquarters in lower Manhattan, his arms filled with paperwork and his voice rising in anger. 
 Judith Faulkner, standing in the same line, complained: "I have one little specialty that is very useful to the city. Now they are trying to shut me down."
That specialty is the arcane business of "expediting" building permits, blueprint inspections and code applications through what may be the nation's most complicated big-city construction regulations. And for 1,600 registered expediters doing business with the Department of Buildings, a regulatory gauntlet has been thrown down.
No one denies that the expediters perform a necessary and probably permanent job. Much of their work is standing in line -- or adroitly jumping from line to line -- as representatives of architects, engineers and building owners who have neither the time nor patience to deal with the department's regulatory maze.
But in what may result in a court battle, the city's Commissioner of Buildings, Charles A. Miele, is threatening to bar the expediters from technical discussions with the department's assorted plan examiners, borough superintendents and technical personnel.
 
Crossing the Line?
 "I'm not trying to put anybody out of business," said Mr. Miele, who left his practice in February as a partner in a Queens architecture and engineering firm to take over the department. No stranger to the business of expediting, Mr. Miele, a licensed engineer, got his start in the 1950's working as an expediter himself.
Still, he said, "a clear line has been crossed from expediting into architecture and engineering." In official memos, distributed among the expediters in April and May, he said he would prohibit them from engaging in "architectural and engineering discussions" with his staff.
The discussions might involve such questions as whether the city's minimum requirement for apartment room size, 150 square feet, can be slightly amended in a homeless shelter or whether requirements for the placement of smoke detectors can be altered if additional detectors are installed.
Only people who are licensed as architects or engineers, or who are employed full time by architects or engineers, would be allowed to take part, according to Mr. Miele's dictate.
"This is purely and simply a legal issue," he said in an interview in his 14th-floor office at the Department of Buildings, citing the New York State Education Law. In part, that law says that people must be licensed as architects or engineers to engage in "consultation" or "evaluation" in architectural or engineering work.
Nine floors below, where the legion of expediters make their daily rounds, few people found his position either pure or simple.
 
Raw Nerves
 "My theory is that this rule change is intended to allow architects and engineers to recapture some income," said David Trachtenberg, owner of Novation, an expediting firm, and president of the New York Association of Code Consultants, an expediting industry group. He said the group would fight Mr. Miele in court.
In the face of virulent opposition, Mr. Miele has delayed the new rule, which he once announced would be in place by July 1.
"This issue has touched a very raw nerve," he said, adding that some letters to his office on the proposed rule had been "appalling in their filth." Now, although it may take until the end of the year and a court ruling, he said, "I believe the legal issue is clear and I intend to see this resolved."
Whatever the outcome, the battle has underscored the importance of an industry that operates largely behind the scenes in the huge bureaucratic theater of New York, and serves as a reminder of how government regulation creates both added costs for industry and profitable opportunities for those who can smooth the system's bureaucratic edges.
Although expediters ply their trade in the corridors of several regulatory agencies, including the Department of Transportation and the Department of Environmental Protection, the Department of Buildings has always been their reason for being.
That is because of the vast layers of building regulations that must be met: separate codes for buildings that went up before and after 1968, fire safety codes, zoning ordinances, asbestos removal requirements, a law mandating access for the handicapped and dozens of other legal strictures.
The result is big business for expediters, who, according to Mr. Trachtenberg's group, take in $30 million a year. Typically, an expediter will charge $2,000 to handle a building permit application, even if it is routinely approved. Mr. Burbano said he charged $90 an hour for his services.
 
From Line to Line
 By far the biggest part of an expediter's job -- at least as measured in time -- is moving from line to line, and from application to application, at Department of Buildings offices in all five boroughs.
Many people in the business are inexperienced college students or others who are hired simply to stand in line and deliver papers. Indeed, the most highly paid expediters, like Mr. Burbano, sometimes hire expediters of their own for the most tedious waits.
All adhere to long-standing rules of conduct -- sometimes mystifying to outsiders -- that are intended to speed the passage through bureaucratic red tape. In some corridors of the department, the expediters arrive early each morning and leave their briefcases or stacks of documents lined up on the floor in what appear to be small ceremonial mounds, but are in fact intended to hold their places for appointments hours later in the day.
Both Mr. Miele and the expediters say that less than 5 percent of the work includes technical discussions with Department of Buildings personnel, and those tasks are usually reserved for expediters with years of experience in reading the fine print of building regulations.
But it is those discussions that many claim to be the most critical service the expediters perform, since they relieve licensed architects and engineers of the need to spend hours or days waiting for appointments with department inspectors.
The expediters are already prohibited from signing applications on behalf of their clients or making any changes in the blueprints or other paperwork they submit for their clients. They say the discussions that would be barred by Mr. Miele simply enable them to act as liaisons and messengers between the architects and engineers who pay their fees and the inspectors who want more-detailed information on a blueprint or permit application.
"We are not practicing architecture, but negotiating over procedure," said Mr. Trachtenberg, who, like many expediters, often represents five or more clients in a single visit to the department. If Mr. Miele succeeds in imposing his new rule, "there will be architects and engineers lined up way down the halls," he added.
 
Support Is Lukewarm
 Among architects, engineers and building owners, Mr. Miele's proposal has drawn mixed reviews. Although some say it would increase their costs and professional aggravations by forcing them to assign their own staff members to the Department of Buildings, or hire additional workers, others maintain that it would increase the level of professionalism.
Some also acknowledged that the city's weak economy and construction downturn had left many architectural and engineering firms with little work and ample time to take on a larger part of the burden in dealing with city regulations.
Under the new rule, "we would be doing more of the job we were licensed to do," said Michael Zenreich, a Manhattan architect and chairman of the code committee of the New York City chapter of the American Institute of Architecture. He said some architects, particularly those with small firms, would welcome any new work, even if it meant dealing with the Department of Buildings bureaucracy.
Mr. Zenreich's committee sent a letter to Mr. Miele last month, supporting his proposed restrictions on expediters. But the support is lukewarm.
"The Buildings Department feels strongly on this one, and we are willing to agree, even though it will inconvenience some of our people," Mr. Zenreich said. But he added that architects "will continue using a lot of expediters -- they are part of the team."

Miele, the Commissioner of Buildings, is threatening to bar expediters from technical discussions with officials on behalf of the architects, engineers and building owners they represent. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Ultrair Shutting Its Operations

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Ultrair Inc., which serves Florida and Alabama from Kennedy International Airport in New York, will shut down after Wednesday.
The airline, which made the announcement on Friday, promised full refunds for any passengers with tickets for flights after that date. Ultrair said a battle for market share on the East Coast made it economically impossible to continue as the large carriers cut their fares. 
 "While Ultrair has strong financial backing, we don't think it makes good business sense to keep flying in markets where there is so little prospect of making money," Ultrair's chief executive, J. Patrick Millinor Jr., said on Friday. The carrier will evaluate its options and opportunities over the coming months, he added.
This is Ultrair's second incarnation. It flew for six months starting in January 1993 as a luxury airline based in Houston. It shut down last summer, blaming price wars with larger carriers, particularly Continental Airlines.
It was reborn in November, offering service from Kennedy airport to Miami, Orlando, West Palm Beach and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Later, the carrier added service to Birmingham and Mobile, Ala.

HEADLINE: COLLEGES;
Notre Dame Draws Big East's Approval

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN 

 BODY:
Four months after Notre Dame's interest in the Big East was said to have lessened considerably, the Fighting Irish have been approved as the 13th member of the conference. A person familiar with the discussions between the university and the league, speaking on the condition of anonymity, confirmed reports published over the weekend that a commitment was imminent and added that announcements were planned for today.
Notre Dame joins the league after what is believed to be a unanimous vote of the 12 members, including Rutgers and West Virginia, who were admitted last March 9. According to the source, Notre Dame's participation will take effect during the 1995-96 season for all sports except football, in which the Irish will remain an independent. 
The struggle in recent years of Notre Dame's men's basketball program has fueled speculation that the school would eventually have to abandon its status as an independent in the sport to gain the benefits of a high-profile league. That speculation reached its peak late last winter, as differences between football and basketball interests within the Big East created what Commissioner Mike Tranghese called the most serious threat in the history of the conference.
Notre Dame was interested in the possibility of a new, scaled-down Big East that would have resulted had those schools with major college football commitments carried through with their threat to form a separate all-sports conference. The Irish were one of several teams that could have been added to the schools without major football commitments: Connecticut, Georgetown, St. John's, Seton Hall, Providence and Villanova.
But the league saved itself with the compromise admission of Rutgers and West Virginia, a move that secured the continued full-time membership of Boston College, Miami, Pittsburgh and Syracuse. The financial prospect of splitting revenues with at least 12 other members in an enlarged Big East was seen as being less appealing to the Irish.
Dick Rosenthal, the Notre Dame athletic director, said at the time that while campus leaders were considering future commitments, he continued to feel that joining a conference was not essential. He was confident that the university could succeed in men's basketball while maintaining its independent status. Attempts to reach several Notre Dame officials yesterday were unsuccessful.
 
'Changed Its Mind'
 Those less appealing economic benefits of a large league, added to the the logistical wrestling Big East officials have undergone to create an expanded format for regular-season play and its conference tournament, seemed to make both sides less likely come together.
Until now. "Notre Dame changed its mind," the source said.
The new alliance will create a marriage between the Fighting Irish and Miami, which ended a hostile football series in the 1989 season. One longterm effect of Notre Dame's addition could be to strengthen the relationship to the point that the football rivalry could be resumed as a nonconference game for Miami.

HEADLINE: The Harm in a Budget Ideology

 BODY:
The House plans to vote soon on proposals that would amend procedures for passing the budget. The sponsors say their goal is to cut out fat and reduce the deficit. But the unstated, and ominous, impact would be to stop Congress from switching money from low-priority to high-priority programs. President Clinton's pledge to retilt spending toward long-term investments would be destroyed.
Representatives Charles Stenholm of Texas, Tim Penny of Minnesota and John Kasich of Ohio have proposed a number of harmful new rules. Among them is a proposal to alter the way Congress compares year-to-year changes in discretionary programs. Under current procedures, Congress compares future spending levels to current spending adjusted upward by inflation. That way Congress can instantly see if benefits under a program will expand or shrink. 
 But this procedure rankles conservatives because Congress can claim it is cutting a program even though it is adding money (though by less than inflation). The Congressmen want to compare future spending to current spending with no inflation adjustment. The proposal makes little sense. Responsible lawmakers need to know what would happen to services and benefits their constituents are used to receiving. The only purpose of the proposal is to make it easier for conservatives to bash "tax-and-spenders" even if they vote to raise spending only enough to keep pace with inflation.
The Congressmen propose a similar comparison for entitlements -- programs, like Social Security, that set spending by formula rather than annual appropriations. They would have Congress compare future spending to current levels without, for example, adjusting for increases in the number of eligible beneficiaries.
The Congressmen will bring to the floor an even worse gimmick, called a lock box, allowing members who propose spending cuts to specify that the savings be used only for deficit reduction. This is a dagger aimed at the President's economic program. He has proposed cutting hundreds of programs in part to free money for investment in infrastructure, education and training. The lock box would let members who propose the very same cuts siphon away the money for deficit reduction.
This week Mr. Stenholm and friends will also propose giving the President authority to force Congress to vote on any proposal he makes to rescind spending that Congress has already approved. The power to put individual programs up for vote would give the President an unprecedented weapon against recalcitrant members.
There is a misguided theme lurking behind every one of these benighted proposals: further deficit reduction is more important than anything else Congress can do with taxpayer money. This theme is ideology run amok. Deficit reduction is an important way to reduce public borrowing, thereby leaving more money in capital markets for private investors to borrow. But public investment -- in highways, mass transit, childhood education and worker training -- is also important for the economy's future. Congress ought not bury that good idea under the pretense of fiscal prudence.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Simpson Case Tells America About Itself

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The O. J. Simpson fracas has been debated enough from the pulpit, in the media and at the nation's barbershops and beauty salons. America will just have to wait as the wheels of justice grind to their conclusion. But because nothing takes place in a political vacuum, consider the following: 
 First, the issue of racism. As a black American, O. J. Simpson wears one mantle; but as a person of influence, prestige and wealth, he wears another, which has dictated his treatment by just about everyone involved. A cabal of high-powered lawyers has beaten a path to his doorstep. Ordinary black men accused of murder would have long been lost in our judicial and penal system.
Color is but the external device we use to determine the differences between peoples. Slavery, Jim Crowism and racism in general existed and still do to a certain extent because of a need for an economic underclass. It is affluence, rather than skin color, that decides your place in America's social stratum. Color is only a marker, albeit a valid demographic one.
Then there is the issue of violence, which is on all our minds as we are continually exposed to mass murder from a school tower, carnage on a commuter railroad train, a revenge killing in a post office by a disgruntled employee, an almost daily drug-related assassination and Federal Bureau of Investigation raids on religious conclaves.
If the Oval Office and Congress can glibly carry out nighttime bombing raids on urban civilian populations and suggest intercontinental ballistic missile attacks on another nation's alleged nuclear factories as part of our foreign policy, why can't a citizen take up the gauntlet and use bloodshed as a means of communication?
Justice Louis Brandeis said it all in a 1928 paper: Our Government is the teacher. It teaches by example. Crime is contagious. If the government is a lawbreaker, it breeds contempt for the law.
 
DON SLOAN
New York, July 1, 1994

HEADLINE: The New Military Order

BYLINE: By Barry M. Blechman; Barry M. Blechman is chairman of the Henry L. Stimson Center, a non-profit research and educational organization.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As the House and Senate prepare to confer on the Defense Authorization bill, Democrats and Republicans have largely set aside their conflicts and are sticking with the spending target of $252 billion -- a cut of 4 percent, adjusting for inflation, from last year. But a growing number of lawmakers and military commanders are arguing that the planned cuts go too deep and could endanger military readiness.
By the end of the decade, defense outlays are projected to decline in real terms by more than one-third from the highs of the 1980's. No complex organization can be reduced so quickly without incurring problems. And, as troubles from Haiti to the former Soviet republics underscore, the world remains an uncertain place. 
 The U.S. military should move gradually to adapt to the new world order. But when we peer into the next decade, can we see a way to reduce defense spending without risk to national security? The answer is yes, but not by further reducing the size of the military. The real promise of savings lies in simply making the armed forces more efficient.
Technology is transforming the U.S. economy. Corporations are increasingly taking advantage of emerging technologies to improve their product lines, slash payrolls and adopt cost-saving procedures. Military technology is also changing radically, and the Defense Department is taking advantage of it by improving its product lines. But unlike American corporations, the military has been slow to reorganize; the challenge facing Defense Secretary William Perry is to accelerate the reform.
Two kinds of reform in particular need bipartisan support from Congress. First, the U.S. needs to change the way it buys military equipment. The complicated process through which we develop and purchase weapons and equipment includes perverse incentives that drive up costs. Mr. Perry knows very well what needs to be done, having had hands-on experience in the defense industry, and he has begun to make concrete improvements, like issuing an executive order last month mandating wide-ranging changes in the Defense Department's business practices.
One reform he is advocating is especially promising: eliminating special military requirements, making it possible to purchase equipment more cheaply. Military commanders need not shop at their local Wal-Mart, but hundreds of thousands of weapon components could be purchased more cheaply if the military accepted commercial standards of performance. These standards are quite stringent, particularly in the highly competitive field of electronics. Yet military specifications, even ordinary pieces of equipment, often run dozens of pages and demand absurd levels of performance that drive costs sky-high.
The shift to commercial standards will also mean that our armed forces could expand more quickly in an emergency. The fewer military requirements there are, the easier it would be for the Pentagon to piggyback on commercial industries.
No one knows exactly how much money could be saved eventually through this and other procurement reforms, but Mr. Perry has estimated that they could reap $5 billion to $10 billion a year beginning in 1999. Last year, the Defense Science Board, which advises the Pentagon on technological issues, put the figure at $20 billion. Certainly, the high end of Mr. Perry's range is a reasonable target.
Another area that needs significant improvement: how the military uses its personnel. We must do more to reduce duplication in the support staffs of the armed services, a move singled out by Gen. Colin L. Powell Jr., the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, in his 1993 report on the services' roles and missions.
Because the Army, the Navy and the Air Force have each historically tried to remain as autonomous as possible, they often replicate one another in such areas as training of electronics technicians, providing medical care and maintaining vehicles and aircraft. If a single service could be named executive agent for each of these functions, fewer people would have to be kept in uniform to support combat-ready troops. And eliminating duplication also would mean fewer civilians working for the Defense Department and fewer military bases.
A second way to reduce personnel would be to review the way that manpower requirements are calculated. Before Richard Nixon abolished the draft in 1972, it was cheap to hire servicemen and women. Now personnel are paid competitive wages, but they continue to be used inefficiently as if they were still inexpensive.
Congress should undertake a comparison of military schools, hospitals, supply centers, administrative headquarters and repair depots with their civilian counterparts to assess how serious the problem is. American corporations have found their greatest savings by streamlining middle management; this would be a good place for the armed services to look as well.
If the Pentagon reduced its civilian work force and uniformed personnel assigned to supporting roles by 20 percent -- in line with the cuts now being made by many U.S. companies -- annual savings could reach $12 billion over the next decade.
Adding these savings to those from procurement reform would bring the Defense Department budget down from the $230 billion (in today's dollars) planned for fiscal 1999 to below $210 billion. These cuts would be made without reducing the size of the combat forces, risking their technological edge or compromising their readiness.
Of course, it is a great deal easier to theorize about these potential savings than to pocket them. The Defense Secretary must initiate the changes and his staff must follow up aggressively, but only the services can take action on the thousands of individual steps that are required to nail down the cost reductions.
Twenty years ago, as the nation's armed forces wound down after the Vietnam War, then Secretary of Defense James Schlesinger offered the services additional combat units if they were able to make deeper reductions. This kind of creative management is worth another look as the services recover from the cold war.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Dell Computer to Abandon Retail Store Sales

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
Seeking to play to its strengths, the Dell Computer Corporation said yesterday that it would stop selling computers in stores and concentrate instead on direct sales to consumers.
The move is expected to have little overall impact on Dell. The company has already pared its retail business to roughly 2 percent of its annual sales of $3.5 billion, and the operation is not profitable, Michael S. Dell, chairman and chief executive, said in a telephone interview. 
 And Dell computers will still be readily available, he said, adding, "There are 180 million telephones in the United States, and anyone can reach us."
The main reason for eliminating retail sales is to reduce costs and pricing risk, Mr. Dell said. Conventional retailing is too slow for a product like computers, which have a short shelf life, he said.
 
Intel Lowers Chip Prices
 "Intel just announced that prices of chips are going down," he said. "If you've got chips sitting on the shelf from 30 days ago, or if the manufacturer has 70 days of inventory, you can't respond as quickly to changes," he said. With no inventory in warehouses, Dell can adjust prices faster, he said.
Dell ranks sixth in personal computer sales in the United States, behind Gateway 2000, which also specializes in direct sales. A year ago it was ahead of Gateway, according to Richard Zwetchkenbaum, of the International Data Group, a consulting firm in Framingham, Mass. The leaders, Compaq Computer, Packard Bell, Apple Computer and I.B.M., all sell their machines primarily in stores.
Mr. Zwetchkenbaum and other analysts said that at least in the short term Dell's move was probably a good one, but that the company would forsake some brand identity, and thus, some future sales.
"In some respects it is a good solution for Dell," he said. "They were out of their league, in a sense," he said, adding that direct-channel sales are Dell's strong point.
But in the long term, he said, not having retail sales means not having a strong brand image, and closing off some potential buyers. About 35 percent of households in this country have a personal computer, Mr. Zwetchkenbaum said, but the others, "the great unwashed," will not buy their first machine by calling an "800" number, he said.
"The novice and the first-time buyer generally are going to want to touch and feel," he said. "They want the in-store experience. They want to hear the multimedia, with different speakers, see the different sized monitors and graphics resolutions, and talk to somebody interactively, and bring the kids along with them on the second trip."
Fred Gardner, the hardware editor of Computer Reseller News, a weekly in Manhasset, L.I., said: "They'll be getting more experienced customers, but maybe that's what they want. It's a lot less trouble for them."
Wall Street seemed to favor the move. Dell's shares gained 81.25 cents yesterday to close at $28.875 in Nasdaq trading.
Dell and other direct-sales companies offer what Dell calls "mass customization," which means letting the buyer mix-and-match components, like the central processor, the size of the storage disk, the amount of working memory and the software installed. Experienced computer users usually have detailed preferences.
 
Sales to Resellers
 The company will continue to sell personal computers to "value added resellers," or companies that install additional hardware into the computers, or link them together into networks with special software, and then resell them as packages to client companies. Mr. Dell said yesterday that such sales accounted for less than 10 percent of his volume.
At BIS Strategic Decisions, a market research and consulting firm in Norwood, Mass., Raymond L. Boggs, a personal computer analyst, said, "It's certainly not the doom of retailing, but it underscores how difficult it is to build a retail franchise and make money at the same time."
Making money in retailing is hard because margins are thin, he said, 15 to 20 percent at computer stores and as little as 7 to 9 percent at warehouse stores. One reason markups are so small, he said, is that Dell and others are putting pressure on prices by direct sales.
Computer companies have had varied experiences with direct sales. Apple gave them up last year, Mr. Zwetchkenbaum said. I.B.M., on the other hand, is now emphasizing direct sales.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Eli Lilly said it would buy PCS Health Systems, the country's largest manager of drug benefits, from McKesson for $4 billion in cash. The deal will give Lilly better access to the insurers and employer health plans that buy billions of dollars' worth of drugs a year. [Page A1.] Lilly's deal to buy PCS is essentially two transactions that would occur almost simultaneously. [D2.] 
 Spurred by the success of computer on-line services, developers are racing to build new electronic communities in cyberspace. But even the developers say the rush could lead to a glut of services overwhelming a relatively small market. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Dollar Falls Sharply Vs. Mark

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
The dollar posted one of its largest one-day drops today against the German mark and edged down to another low against the Japanese yen, as the Clinton Administration took no substantive steps to brake the dollar's monthlong fall and after the Federal Reserve left short-term interest rates unchanged.
Without action by the Federal Reserve, traders and Wall Street economists predicted, the dollar could fall much further. "The dollar can go down wherever the markets want, and frankly it can go down anywhere," said Allen Sinai, chief economist at Lehman Brothers. "I wouldn't even try to foresee where the dollar will be in a week or two." 
 The dollar plummeted to 1.5280 German marks in New York trading today, from 1.5617 marks on Friday, after being as low as 1.5202 marks during the day.
 
Tough Day All Around
 It also touched another post-World War II low of 96.96 yen before edging back to 97.73 yen, its previous low, down from 98.10 on Friday. The dollar fell, too, against the Canadian dollar, British pound and some other European currencies.
Stock and bond markets were down as the dollar's drop was taken as a lack of international interest in holding dollar-denominated assets.
President Clinton said in Bonn today that the lack of American action should not be interpreted as an effort to make American goods cheaper and more salable in foreign markets. "We will not use the dollar as an instrument of trade," he said. "We take this issue seriously."
 
A Loud Silence
 But the President said nothing about whether interest rates should be raised to protect the currency, nor did he signal any further interventions in currency markets to prop up the dollar.
By saying nothing about interest rates, Mr. Clinton left in place Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen's comment in Naples on Friday that he saw no need for the Federal Reserve to raise rates "at this point." Many traders contend that the dollar is unlikely to stop dropping soon without higher rates to make American bonds more attractive to international investors.
Mr. Bentsen's remarks Friday were made after Mr. Clinton had set off a plunge in the dollar earlier in the day by saying he opposed quick action to help the currency. He said the dollar would rebound on its own, once investors realized the American economy's fundamental strength.
Treasury Department officials in Naples also raised the possibility that central banks might eventually intervene on the dollar's behalf. But central banks around the world have had little success lately in propping up the dollar by selling billions of marks and yen in exchange for dollars.
The Federal Reserve is independent of the executive branch and has defied Administrations over the years by raising interest rates to fight inflation. But the central bank has tended to respect the wishes of recent Administrations when it came to dollar policy.
Fed officials have long avoided citing the dollar as the sole reason for rate increases, preferring instead to mention the dollar as one of many reasons.
Yet top Fed officials are known to be reluctant to defy the Administration now, given contradictory evidence about whether the domestic economy is growing fast enough to feed inflation.
"It's my feeling that they'll want to wait until they can point to a domestic reason" for any further short-term interest rate increases, said Robert D. Hormats, a vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, who has been an economic-affairs official in the Reagan and Carter Administrations.
The central bank might find such reasons later this week. The Labor Department is scheduled to release figures on Tuesday for producer prices in June, and on Wednesday for consumer prices, and some economists expect these figures to show slightly higher inflation.
 
Fear of Too Much Demand
 Commerce Department figures on Thursday for retail sales in June and the Federal Reserve's figures Friday for industrial production would provide further ammunition for another interest-rate increase if they show that the economy is growing so quickly that companies may start to bid up the prices of scarce materials and the wages of workers with sought-after skills.
Last Friday the Labor Department reported a surge in jobs. But other recent economic indicators, like new home sales and orders for factory equipment, have suggested a slowing of economic growth.
The Federal Reserve does not focus only on the dollar's relationship against the yen and the mark. When the central bank's board meets every Monday morning to review interest rates, its members look at an index of the dollar's value in terms of 10 other currencies. The index is weighted by the volume of American trade with the countries issuing each of these currencies.
The overall index dropped only slightly last week, to 89.06 from 89.98, as the American dollar's strength against the Canadian dollar and the pound offset weakness against the yen and the mark, according to Federal Reserve figures released today.
But the dollar was weak across the board today, pushing the British pound up sharply to $1.5720 in late New York trading, from $1.5500 on Friday.
It fell to 5.2545 French francs from 5.3700 francs, and weakened to 1.2905 Swiss francs, a 20-month low, from 1.3175. It also tumbled to 1,524 Italian lire from 1,555. The Canadian dollar rose to 72.13 United States cents from 71.96 cents.
Fed officials have been impressed that the overall index had virtually the same average in June as in June 1993. This suggests that while importers of German cars or Japanese cameras may be raising their prices soon because of currency-market fluctuations, importers of Canadian pork or British antique furniture might not do so, with little if any overall effect on inflation.
Some Federal Reserve officials and Wall Street economists worry that the United States depends heavily on Japan for investment capital. They fear a lack of demand for American corporate and Treasury bonds, and higher long-term interest rates as a result, if Japanese investors stop putting up money for fear of exchange-rate losses.
Mr. Hormats said the Fed might also be reluctant to set a precedent for propping up the dollar with interest-rate increases, noting that Britain had raised rates several percentage points in stages two years ago in an unsuccessful effort to bolster the pound.
The Fed operates by controlling the overnight interest rates at which commercial banks borrow money from each other or from it. By raising these overnight rates, the Fed induces commercial banks to cut back on lending, which can prevent the economy from overheating.
Higher short-term rates tend to push up long-term rates for a while, but eventually hold down long-term rates as investors conclude that inflation is less likely to erode their returns from long-term investments.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Dollar Drops in Tokyo
 TOKYO, Tuesday, July 12 (By Bloomberg business News) -- The dollar continued to drop against the yen, though less steeply, in Tokyo trading today.
In afternoon trading, the dollar fell to 97.38 yen, compared with 97.73 late Monday in New York.
Stock prices were lower in sluggish trading. The yen's strength against the dollar was discouraging buying, traders said. An hour before the close of the market, the Nikkei index of 225 leading issues was down 81.51 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,391.58. On Monday, the Nikkei fell 53.42 points.
The dollar also continued to slip against the German mark. The dollar was quoted at 1.5274 marks this afternoon, off slightly from 1.5280 marks in New York on Monday.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE DOCTORS;
Doctors Are Sparring With Insurers Over Right to Join Health Networks

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
In a battle that will profoundly shape the way American medical care is delivered, doctors across the country are pressing for state and Federal laws to make it harder for insurance companies and health maintenance organizations to exclude doctors from health care networks.
These managed-care networks generally have lists of doctors who agree to work for discounted fees; patients must choose from among these doctors to receive insurance reimbursement. 
 As more Americans sign up with networks or H.M.O.'s in the search for lower medical costs, doctors who are not aligned with the plans lose patients.
Insurers say legislation to forcibly broaden doctor enrollment threatens to eviscerate H.M.O.'s and discount medical networks, which now provide coverage for at least 90 million Americans. The insurers say they need to limit the number of doctors to keep administrative costs down and maintain standards of care, even if it means rejecting qualified doctors.
But the doctors, thousands of whom have tried to join such networks over the last year only to be excluded because insurers have all the doctors they need, say they are unfairly being shut out.
Joseph White, a researcher at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said the conflict was over raw economic power. "The forms of managed care that work at all do so by holding some hammer over the doctors," he said. "The ability to exclude people is fundamental in those systems."
Doctors also assert that patients are being deprived of access to longtime family practitioners who can be relied on to place health concerns ahead of economics.
Charlene Culpepper, a telephone service representative for Southwestern Bell in Houston, is one patient upset about having to change her doctor. She said her longstanding physician, Dr. Robert Maidenberg, was dropped from her health plan when her employer switched from the Prudential Insurance Company to another insurer last year.
 
'I Don't Feel Comfortable'
 Dr. Maidenberg "saved my life" when he identified what she said was a "precancerous tumor" that was then removed from her right kidney. "Now I have to go to another doctor," she said. "I don't feel comfortable with him. I feel I wouldn't get as good care."
Eight states have enacted doctor-sponsored measures, called "any willing provider" bills, and legislative committees in at least eight more, including New York and New Jersey, are considering similar proposals. Five states defeated such proposals this year.
Dick Hegner, a senior research associate of the Intergovernmental Health Policy Project at George Washington University, said, "The issue forces legislators onto a battlefield of basic American values, where providers' freedom to contract conflicts with insurers' free-enterprise rights."
Independent pharmacists have also been scoring lobbying victories. Laws in 15 states make it difficult for managed-care networks to exclude any pharmacy.
 
Insurers Look to Congress
 Critics in the insurance industry hope the state laws will be killed by Congress. That could happen under pre-empting provisions of the health care bills recently approved in the Senate by the Finance Committee and by the Labor and Human Resources Committee and in the House by the Education and Labor Committee.
But Congressional aides said that support for the pre-emption was precarious. They said it only made it into the Finance Committee's bill after the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, who opposed the measure, changed his vote to break a 10-to-10 tie that was threatening to block action on the entire bill.
Moreover, the insurance industry is further concerned because the bills endorsed by the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee and by the House Ways and Means Committee include any-willing-provider provisions.
If Congress fails to pass sweeping changes in the way Americans receive health care this year, the growing number of state laws will command the field and may determine the future of health care financing. State legislators do not necessarily welcome that prospect, and governors in a number of states, including California, Colorado, Florida and Minnesota have threatened to veto the legislation.
 
Patients' Right to Choose
 The state laws "compel insurers to admit to their networks any provider" of health care who is "willing to abide by the terms and conditions of the contract," according to a survey by the Washington office of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, which strongly opposes such measures.
Spokesmen for doctors groups emphasize the patients' right to choose. The executive vice president of the American Medical Association, Dr. James S. Todd, said, "What we are trying to do is preserve the ability of physicians to care for patients who want to go to those physicians."
Insurance executives concede that the doctors' tactics have been effective. "We are on the defensive, trying to explain that we are not anti-choice," said Barbara Hill, vice president for health care policy at Prudential. "We prefer to call it a debate over quality and standards."
Karen Ignagni, president of the Group Health Association of America, a trade group of health maintenance organizations, said the willing-provider measures "gut the essence of what H.M.O.'s do: determine the complement of physicians, hospitals and other health care practitioners that best meet the needs of members."
Many employers, who pay for a large share of the country's health insurance and are increasingly turning to managed care to curb costs, also oppose the doctors' legislative efforts. In a letter on May 16 to members of Congress, 60 large employers and business coalitions called for rejection of proposals that would force health plans to contract with any willing provider and with teaching hospitals, in particular.
Helen Darling, manager of health care strategy for the Xerox Corporation, said, "The advantages we might get in being more selective, both in quality and cost, go away" if employers have to accept unwanted doctors.
Many doctors are furious at insurers like Blue Cross and Blue Shield of the National Capital Area, which left out a third of the 8,000 doctors in its other health plans when it started a new network in the Washington, D.C., area last year. It covers 485,000 Federal employees and their families, including a third of the members of Congress and their staffs.
"My patients say to me, 'Why do we have to pay more money to see you, when you're willing to participate and they won't let you in?' " said Dr. Mark Whitten, a Washington ophthalmologist. He is chairman of the District of Columbia Medical Society, which is seeking a court order to force Blue Cross to let doctors who were excluded join the network.
Indeed, doctors and hospitals are challenging managed-care exclusions in a number of lawsuits across the country. In Houston, doctors dismissed from managed-care networks have sued divisions of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company and Prudential in a case that is still unresolved.
 
Exclusions Questioned
 As it stands now, there is a patchwork of rules and laws that vary by the places where patients live and doctors practice. In Washington, for example, doctors contend that the new Blue Cross network violates a willing-provider law in Virginia, where Dr. Whitten also practices. The District of Columbia City Council recently heard testimony on a proposal similar to Virginia's law. And Maryland was one of the states that rejected a doctor-supported bill earlier this year.
The Washington doctors also said Blue Cross had discriminated against doctors who served low-income neighborhoods, where patients more often delayed seeking care until they were seriously ill and needed expensive treatment.
Dr. Robert Blythe, a Washington urologist who was not taken into the network, said his practice had been hurt at his office next to Southeast Community Hospital, which serves many low-income, minority patients. He said the new network had excluded a disproportionate number of doctors in that part of town, leaving fewer family doctors on the list who would refer patients to specialists like him.
Barbara Exstrum, a spokeswoman for Blue Cross and Blue Shield of the National Capital Area, said invitations to join the network were partly based on a computer system "that allows us to compare the resources that different physicians used in treating the same degree of illness." She said the comparisons were adjusted to reflect differences in the severity of the illness treated, and she disputed the accusation that the new network discriminated against doctors who treat the sickest patients.
The insurers and H.M.O.'s say the outcome of the battle will affect their costs, which may be passed along to members of their health plans. Profits may also be affected, said Ira S. Loss, a Washington health care analyst with Natwest Securities Corporation. He is not sanguine about the chances of defeating the willing-provider legislation in Congress because, he said, "There are more doctors and pharmacists and patients than there are H.M.O.'s."

HEADLINE: Auto Finance Charges Jumped in Spring

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 11

 BODY:
Finance charges for buying new cars and trucks spiked upward this spring at a pace not seen since 1988, a Labor Department economist said today.
After declining steadily for three years, the charges moved up in April, after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates. 
 "You had the biggest increase in finance charges that we've had in quite a few years," said Patrick C. Jackman, a senior economist at the Labor Department who tracks consumer price data. "It's pretty obvious that in June they'll be up, too."
 
 
Index Up 6% in 2 Months
 The department's index of finance charges jumped 2.3 percent in April and another 3.7 percent in May, he said.
Because of special incentives and other marketing ploys, actual finance charges to customers vary widely, and Mr. Jackman said he had no average figures.
Finance charges have a direct impact on prices of new vehicles, since the higher the interest rate on a car loan the more a buyer has to pay each month. Despite the rising interest rates, however, new vehicle sales were healthy in June, posting a 6.8 percent increase over strong sales a year earlier.
Dealers said finance charges had not risen enough to begin scaring away buyers. At the Thomason Auto Group in Milwaukie, Ore., for example, finance rates have climbed to 7.75 percent, from 7.25 percent, in the last three months, said J. A. Justice, the finance manager. On a $15,000 car, Mr. Justice said, that change raised the monthly payment by less than $4 a month, to $303.92 from $300 on a five-year loan with no money down.
"People aren't going to balk over $3 or $4," he said. "Once you start getting up over 10 percent, people start thinking twice about it."
Mr. Jackman said he could not predict whether rising finance charges would depress sales. "It really depends on how the growth in the economy continues," he said. Robust growth and strong consumer confidence could offset the effects of finance rate increases.
While rising interest rates might not restrain total vehicle sales, they could convince consumers to lower their sights, settling for a cheaper new vehicle with fewer options than they would otherwise have bought. Sales of such cars and trucks are less profitable for the auto makers, since the markups on options like compact disk players are higher than the markup of the basic car. Further, some buyers may elect to purchase a used car, rather than a new one.
One worry for some Wall Street analysts has been that consumers would begin to pre-buy -- that is, to purchase vehicles sooner than they had planned in hopes of locking in lower rates. Such behavior could cause the auto cycle to peak sooner than 1996 or 1997, as most analysts have projected.
Rising rates do appear to be motivating some buyers. "People are coming in and saying, 'I might want to think about getting a car,' " said Liz Scanlan, business manager at Koons Ford in Baltimore. "They want to beat the rates."
Ms. Scanlan came to the same conclusion herself. "I was looking in March and thought, 'I'll just hang on,' " she said. "But then the rates went up." Ms. Scanlan bought a used car, a 1992 Volkswagen Cabriolet.

HEADLINE: Most Cities Raising Taxes and Fees, Survey Finds

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
Despite an improving economy, most American cities and towns are raising taxes and fees or reducing spending this year to keep their budgets in the black.
The National League of Cities said its annual survey of 551 municipalities showed that 70 percent planned to increase taxes or fees and 63 percent expected to reduce spending. 
 One in four cities and towns increased property tax rates during the past year, the survey found. The cities with the most such increases were in the Northeast, where nearly 50 percent of the municipalities raised property taxes, followed by the Midwest, with 31 percent; the South with 28 percent, and the West with less than 8 percent.
And half increased user fees and charges while 25 percent added new ones. There was little variation in cities of different size or in different regions, the league said.
The league said 1994 would be the second successive year that a majority of municipal budgets ended in the black after three years of widespread fiscal problems during the recession and early recovery.
The survey found 54 percent of the municipalities expecting to take in more in taxes and other income than they spend for services. That would be down from two-thirds in 1993.
"The signs of a turnaround are encouraging," said Donald J. Borut, the league's executive director, "but caution signals are still flashing."
Health care costs for city employees, spending required by Federal or state governments and infrastructure needs were the biggest problems for local budgets, the league found.
Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, the league president, said the cost of health care for municipal employees grew by 250 percent from 1980 to 1994 and was cited by 42 percent of the cities as a problem.
"Local government is labor-intensive," Mr. James said. "It's where the work gets done, and that's what makes this such a big factor in local budgets."
The league also found that 38 percent of the respondents complained about spending required by Federal and state governments.
"If something is important enough to require a state or Federal mandate, we should have a voice in deciding how to do it," Mr. James said. "And if it's important enough to require a mandate, it should be important enough to have state or Federal funding to help carry out the mandates."

HEADLINE: Flood Brings Danger Now, Worry Later For Georgia

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 11

 BODY:
Long after the muddy waters go down in Albany, after the stench of human waste and 300,000 dead chickens disappears from Montezuma, after workers start repairing 1,700 roads, 600 bridges and 100 dams damaged by last week's flooding, the Southeast's answer to last year's Midwestern flooding will continue to haunt this battered state.
The waters were still rising today in the southwest corner of Georgia, and officials in Bainbridge worked to move residents out of danger as they awaited the Flint River's record crest later this week. But from Atlanta south, the area battered by the rains brought by Tropical Storm Alberto, residents and officials were beginning to ponder the long-term effects of the worst flooding in Georgia history. 
 The death toll is already heavy: 28 killed since the rain began a week ago, compared with 48 deaths attributed to the summerlong flood in the Middle West last year. And, as residents of the Middle West learned, the damage in terms of economics, environment and emotions is also certain to be severe.
Worries include industries likely to be crippled for months, freight rail lines shut down by washed-out bridges that could take months to repair and up to 1,300 hazardous-chemical sites that are in the flooded area and have the potential to cause significant environmental problems.
"You know, I would like to be optimistic and say we'll get over this by spring," said Mayor Tommy Olmstead of Macon, "but that's not the case. This is going to have years of effects on us. We have never had a disaster like this in Macon."
 
Immediate Concerns
 In the areas still inundated or where water was still rising, the present, not the future, was the main concern today. In Albany, the Flint River, which drove a quarter of the city's 80,000 residents from their homes, finally crested today, two days later than officials had expected.
Downstream, the small town of Newton was almost completely inundated. Still waiting for the worst is Bainbridge, a community of 10,000 that is the last major town in the Flint's path. The river there is expected to crest Wednesday at 48 feet, 3 feet higher than had been expected earlier and a record 23 feet above flood level.
At the Vigoro Industries fertilizer plant in Bainbridge, the National Guard worked to build a 10-foot dike around a 200-foot tank that holds 9 million pounds of toxic ammonia. If the plant was to flood, toxic gas could be released. Officials said they were confident the dike would hold off the water but were prepared to evacuate remaining residents if it did not.
In much of the state, people were beginning to dry out and get their first vivid glimpses of how long-lived the effects of the flooding will be. Officials at the Georgia Emergency Management Agency command post in Atlanta got help from someone well-versed in flooding: Ellen Gordon, director of the Iowa Emergency Management Agency.
"From what I can see, Georgia looks a lot like Iowa did last year," she said.
 
After the Water Goes
 In Montezuma, a town of 4,500 about 110 miles south of Atlanta, much of the water that flooded the downtown last week was gone today. But officials said they did not know how long it would be before the town was habitable.
"One of the farmers in our county lost 17 houses and 300,000 chickens," said Joyce Middlebrooks, the city clerk. "You can't get within a mile of it because of the smell. They're having to get all this gear to go in there and remove those chickens. It's a disease problem, too. We have a biohazard downtown from all the water and two gasoline tanks that popped right out of the ground, with gas spewing everywhere. It's an environmental disaster here."
Even when the town is livable, residents must cope with the loss of the town's biggest employer, the Southern Frozen Foods factory, which had employed 550 people full time and an additional 150 during the summer.
"There are bridges that have to be replaced, there are streets that have eroded; these are long-term things," Ms. Middlebrooks said. "You won't have any trouble finding us. Just follow your nose."
 
Restoring the Rails
 Among the biggest worries is disruption of rail service, the main avenue for many industries and farmers to get their products to market.
Not all the news is bad. CSX Transportation, which operates 1,700 route miles of track in Georgia, said it had already repaired the damage that caused it to reroute 170 trains around the flooded area last week.
But for smaller freight lines, like the Georgia Southwestern Railroad, which covers 300 miles from Columbus to Bainbridge, the problems could linger for months.
Jim Davis, general manger for the company, which handles 17,000 carloads a year for farmers, paper mills and manufacturers, said that in the area near Americus three bridges had washed away, as had track beds as long as 200 feet. Some of the damage could take as long as two months to repair, he said.
If roads are repaired promptly, some of the freight traffic can be handled by trucks, Mr. Davis said. Timing is particularly critical for farmers and grain elevators.
"But you can't do that in all cases," Mr. Davis said. "It's really going to put some of them in a critical situation."
 
Hope and Pessimism
 In some places, there was optimism that the damage would not be crippling.
"To me it was amazing, in 24 hours, how much people got done," said John Cary Pittick, sheriff of Monroe County, where the tourist town of Juliette, largely underwater last week, was drying out today. "I really believe everything is going to wind up opened back up just like it was in just a few days."
But in harder-hit cities, and in bigger ones like Macon and Albany, there was far less confidence.
"Our Public Works Department was completely covered," said Ms. Middlebrooks, Montezuma's city clerk. "We had 17 pieces of heavy equipment, and we lost all but six."
In Macon, where it is expected to be a week before water service is restored, Mayor Olmstead fears the flooding will batter the summer tourism business and hurt small businesses for years. "I was a small businessman myself, and I know when you have a major loss, it takes years for you to get back up to financial strength," he said.
Another worry is environmental damage. Bert Langley, emergency response coordinator for the state's Environmental Protection Agency, said the flooded area included more than 1,300 locations, half of them service stations, storing about 10,000 pounds each of gasoline and other hazardous materials. But Ms. Gordon said Midwestern officials found last year that so much water was diluting the chemicals that little damage was apparent.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Bainbridge, Ga., National Guardsmen climbed a 10-foot earthen dam yesterday after placing sheets of plastic to shore up the dam, which is being built around a 200-foot tank that holds anhydrous ammonia at a fertilizer plant. Townspeople feared that rising flood waters would release toxic fumes. (Associated Press)
