HEADLINE: Mayor Agrees To 2 Advisers On Bond Sales

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Settling for now a major dispute with the city's Comptroller, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the city would retain two financial advisers for its forthcoming bond sales, including the black-owned company that the Giuliani administration sought to remove as a cost-cutting measure.
By backing down on its demand that only one company be hired, the administration can go forward with two important bond sales that are estimated to provide $225 million that the Mayor has counted on to close the budget gap and to help improve the city's cash flow. 
 As described by the Mayor and Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, the agreement means that each side will have one company advising it during the bond sales over the next three months. The two sides agreed to evaluate the issue again after that.
The administration had originally sought to use only one financial adviser to help it select underwriters for the bond sales, saying that the system of using two firms, which former Mayor David N. Dinkins had instituted, was too costly. But Mr. Hevesi insisted that the city's bond business was so large that the expertise of two firms was needed.
 
Racial Overtones to Dispute
 Although both sides had agreed to retain one of the firms the city has used, Public Resources Advisory Group of New York, Mr. Hevesi wanted also wanted to retain P. G. Corbin & Company of Philadelphia, which is owned by a black woman.
Two weeks ago the dispute took on racial overtones when Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson suggested that racial preference had been the basis of Mr. Hevesi's desire to retain P. G. Corbin.
The issue became more highly charged when Mr. Dyson, disputing Mr. Hevesi's contention that the cost would be the same whether the city used one financial adviser or two, said that Mr. Hevesi "ought to know the difference between a bid and a watermelon."
That comment drew the wrath of several elected officials, some of whom called on Mr. Dyson to resign. Mr. Dyson later apologized for his remarks, saying that he did not mean them as a racial slur.
Despite yesterday's agreement, there was apparently some tension, as the two sides disagreed sharply on how the firms would be paid. During a news conference this afternoon, Mr. Hevesi, with Mr. Giuliani at his side, said the two companies would be paid separately: the Corbin firm would be paid out of Mr. Hevesi's budget, while Public Resources would be paid out of the Mayor's budget.
But later in the day, Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers called reporters to say that Public Resources would be paid from the proceeds of the bond sales and that P.G. Corbin would be paid out of the Comptroller's budget.
Public Resources, he said, "was the company the Mayor selected as financial adviser and they will be paid from the proceeds of the bond sales."
Jack Chartier, the Deputy Comptroller for intergovernmental affairs, said that arrangement contradicted the agreement reached between the two officials on Sunday night. He said that the two sides had agreed to pay the companies out of their respective budgets.
"Now we're being told by the press that they are being paid by the bond proceeds," Mr. Chartier said. "If P.R.A.G. is going to be paid by the bond proceeds, then Corbin will be paid by the bond proceeds, too."
 
Seeking Long-Term Solution
 Speaking to reporters earlier, Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Hevesi said that the three-month period would enable them to resolve the issue entirely. "We're very hopeful that, with our staffs working together, we can come to a long-term resolution," the Mayor said. "Sometimes, after people work together, they can figure out long-term solutions that early on they can't figure out."
Mr. Hevesi said that the two companies, which have been acting as advisers for the city since 1990, would continue to work together. Mr. Hevesi said that, under the arrangement, the two companies would be paid at the same rate as they were in the last fiscal year, an annual amount of $770,000, to be split between the two.
The Mayor has steadfastly maintained that hiring a second company would cost the city at least $400,000 more a year. Mr. Hevesi countered that hiring two companies was no more costly than hiring one.
A financial adviser manages and advises the entire debt-management program for the city, helping to select underwriters and to insure that the city gets the most value for the dollars it spends.
The Mayor and the Comptroller spoke with reporters after a meeting of the State Financial Control Board at which Mr. Giuliani received a sobering assessment of the city's fiscal condition. Several members of the state monitoring body, including Mr. Hevesi, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and Allen J. Proctor, the executive director of the board, criticized Mr. Giuliani's budget plan, saying it relied heavily on revenues that were uncertain.
"The city faces more than $1 billion in current-year budget risk," Mr. Proctor said. "The possibility of enactment of increased city pension benefits by the State Legislature is another significant risk. This much risk, this early in the year is unprecedented and very worrisome."
To address those risks, Mr. Giuliani said that he would cut spending by $100 million in the first three months of the fiscal year -- a period ending Oct. 1. Holding back those funds would raise the city's financial reserve to a total of $250 million, the Mayor said.
"I will ask my commissioners to go through their agencies with a fine-tooth comb," Mr. Giuliani said. He added that he had asked all of the city's departments to decrease their spending by 2 to 2.5 percent -- including the Police Department, which had been largely spared from cuts under the Mayor's budget plan. "This is a holdback in spending," Mr. Giuliani said. "If things work out and we don't have to face these risks or the economy improves by the second quarter or third quarter we can reverse it."

HEADLINE: Israeli-Palestinian Talks Start

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Egypt, July 11

 BODY:
Israeli and Palestinian negotiators began talks today in Cairo on expanding Palestinian autonomy in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and settling outstanding security issues in the self-rule areas.
The talks marked a new phase in the Middle East peace effort. They opened as Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, landed in Cairo after leaving Tunisia, home to the P.L.O. for the last 12 years. On Tuesday, he will travel to his new home in the self-rule areas of Gaza and Jericho. 
 The two sides began the first detailed negotiations on "early empowerment," the formal term for widening Palestinian autonomy in the West Bank beyond the town of Jericho. Dr. Nabil Shaath, the chief Palestinian negotiator, said the talks would focus on giving Palestinians responsibility for education, tourism, health and economic and social affairs in the West Bank beyond Jericho.
The negotiators will not grapple with the issue of elections for a Palestinian council until the early empowerment issues are resolved, Dr. Shaath said. But he predicted the talks could be concluded quickly.
The Palestinian council will be charged with governing the West Bank and Gaza Strip for an interim period of five years, during which Israel and the P.L.O. will negotiate a permanent settlement.
A separate team of negotiators returned to the table to settle issues left over from the self-rule agreement that was signed by Mr. Arafat and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel on May 4, includingthe boundaries of Palestinian self-rule in the Jericho area.

HEADLINE: Facing Limit on Spending, House Reduces Clinton's Requests

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
Squeezed by the rigid spending ceilings that were enacted last year to lower the budget deficit, the House of Representatives has approved only a fraction of the new money President Clinton sought this year for his main domestic initiatives.
In the appropriations bills it passed last month, the House voted, for example, to give the President only 30 percent of the increase he wanted for Head Start, only half the increase he requested for the main Federal education program for poor children and less than half of the additional money he wanted for his national service program. 
 Administration officials said they hoped that more of the extra money for what Mr. Clinton calls investments would be approved when the Senate this month takes up the appropriations bills for the fiscal year 1995, which begins Oct. 1. But the officials conceded that any improvements would be slight.
The House did about as well as could be expected, said Leon E. Panetta, the budget director and the new White House chief of staff, given "the very difficult circumstances including the freeze on discretionary spending."
 
Appropriations Process
 Barry J. Toiv, the chief spokesman for the Office of Management and Budget, calculated that the House approved about 60 percent of the $14 billion in investment priorities the President proposed in his budget last winter. Mr. Clinton uses the term "investment" to describe any domestic program for which he wants an increase in spending.
About one-third of the Federal budget is controlled by the appropriations process. It involves what is known as discretionary spending, money that Congress allots every year for items ranging from air conditioners to aircraft carriers, from parks to paper clips.
Half of the $1.5 trillion Federal budget goes to entitlement programs, in which money is automatically allocated to everyone who meets the qualifications. Nearly 85 percent of the entitlement money is spent for Social Security, pensions for Federal workers, Medicare and Medicaid. The rest of the Federal budget is spent for interest payments on the national debt.
The deficit-reduction legislation that Congress approved and Mr. Clinton signed last year specifies that spending on discretionary programs will remain steady at $540 billion to $550 billion a year through the fiscal year 1998. In fact, discretionary spending will drop in the next fiscal year to $541 billion from $547 billion this year, the first time there has been a decrease from one year to the next since President Lyndon B. Johnson's last budget.
 
Cuts and Other Cuts
 That means that too little money exists for programs even to keep pace with inflation. So every additional penny that Mr. Clinton wants for one of his investments like Head Start, the preschool program for poor children, must be offset by cuts in other discretionary programs. Almost all the other discretionary programs, like air traffic control and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, are considered essential or, like the space station and Amtrak, have strong political constituencies.
For several years, the problem was eased somewhat because money was taken from the military to finance domestic programs. But Mr. Clinton and most lawmakers now believe that the Pentagon budget cannot safely be shrunk much more. "We must not cut defense further," the President said in his State of the Union Message.
So Mr. Clinton had to look elsewhere for money to pay for his investments, and the House was not always willing to go along.
He asked for a $745 million cut in the program giving assistance for home heating to the elderly poor. The House approved a reduction of only $250 million.
He wanted to cut several public housing programs by $1.3 billion, and the House voted a $300 million increase.
He wanted to reduce operating subsidies for local mass transit systems by $202 million. The House approved a cut of only $102 million.
 
Crime-Control MoneyFunds
 Crime control was one area where the House gave the President most of what he wanted. The House approved more than three-quarters of the $1.7 million in new financing Mr. Clinton sought for community policing and almost all of the $300 million he requested for border security.
But even in the case of crime-fighting, Mr. Clinton was denied. The House did not approve any of the $100 million he wanted to enforce the law enacted last year setting a five-day waiting period before a handgun can be bought to give the police time to check the buyer's background. The House also approved only one-fifth of the $257 million increase in spending the President wanted for drug treatment.
The President and Congress are not willing to commit nearly as much money to fight crime as it might appear when they are considering legislation like the anti-crime bill now before a House-Senate conference committee. The bill passed by the Senate last fall was widely described as a $22.3 billion measure, and the one approved by the House was said to carry a price tag of $28 billion.
In fact, those figures were largely for show. They are simply the maximum that could be spent under the legislation over the rest of the decade. They bear little resemblance to what Congress will appropriate this year or is likely to appropriate in the years ahead.

HEADLINE: Clinton Calls On Germany To Be Partner

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BERLIN, July 11

 BODY:
Acknowledging that a united Germany is now the powerhouse of Europe, President Clinton urged the Germans today to become America's main partners in integrating the former Communist nations of Eastern Europe with the economic and military institutions of the West.
Mr. Clinton's message was that the German-American military alliance must be replaced with a less lopsided partnership focused on economics and the unification of Europe. As Mr. Clinton noted, "Trade, as much as troops, will increasingly define the ties that bind nations in the 21st century." 
 American officials make clear that they consider the other European countries, like Britain and France, either too economically weak or too inward looking to play a leadership role in Europe these days. The "special relationship" is increasingly with Germany. The German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, said after his talks with President Clinton that his nation, now that it is reunified, was ready to assume the more assertive posture Washington is seeking.
 
Dollar Not Discussed
 "The excuse that we had for the past 40 years was that as a divided country we were unable to take certain decisions," Mr. Kohl said. "That is something that is no longer valid. One cannot be a reunified country with 80 million people with the kind of economic strength that we have, with the kind of prestige we claim for ourselves, if we do not fully assume our responsibilities and fulfill our obligations."
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kohl said they did not discuss the state of the American dollar, which fell one full percent today against the German mark -- a huge amount for one day -- closing in Frankfurt at 1.5495 marks.
Mr. Clinton, the first American President to visit a united Germany, is touring Bonn and Berlin at a critical hinge of history. On Tuesday the President is to preside over the deactivation of the last American military unit in Berlin, where there has been an American troop presence for 50 years.
By coincidence, on the same day the German high court is expected to rule, probably in the affirmative, on the constitutionality of German troop participation in military operations, including peacekeeping missions, beyond the country's borders. And again by coincidence, Germany is finally coming out of the recession created by the economic demands of absorbing the former East Germany.
 
Integrating the East
 All have combined to make the long-anticipated debate about Germany's proper leadership role in Europe an immediate reality, and President Clinton timed his trip here to put America firmly on the side of an assertive German leadership posture.
After talks on this theme between President Clinton and Chancellor Kohl at the German leader's office in Bonn, Mr. Clinton said at a news conference: "We know from our experience how half of Europe was integrated through NATO and other institutions that built stability after World War II. At the heart of our discussion today was what we have to do to integrate Europe's other half, the new independent nations: Poland, the Baltic countries, Russia, Ukraine, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovak Republic and others."
While all the attention in the past year seems to have focused on when Poland, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Russia and other former Warsaw Pact nations will be absorbed into the NATO military structure, the really more pressing question is when they are going to be integrated into the Western European economic structures, which have been shutting them out even more than NATO.
"The Chancellor and I," Mr. Clinton continued, "will do everything we can to integrate the newly independent countries of Europe into shared security with their neighbors, helping them to reform their economies, attract new investment, claim their place at the table with free and friendly nations of like mind. To imagine any of these things working out over the long run, the German American partnership will have to be maintained and strengthened."
Asked to comment on the pending German court decision about sending troops abroad, Mr. Clinton said, "I think anything that can be done to enable Germany to fulfill the leadership responsibilities that it is plainly capable of fulfilling is a positive thing."
 
A Vision Is Shared
 Mr. Clinton's trip here was meant to affirm the partnership with Bonn and to give a subtle boost to Mr. Kohl, whom the Americans are quietly backing in the German elections set for Oct. 16. Mr. Kohl, who has been Chancellor since 1982, has become Mr. Clinton's closest friend among foreign leaders. They share a common vision of Europe, a love of eating and a basically optimistic view of the world.
So as not to be accused of interfering in German politics, Mr. Clinton also met in Bonn with Rudolf Scharping, the Social Democratic Party leader and Mr. Kohl's chief opponent.
Late today, Mr. Clinton flew from Bonn to Berlin, with a brief stopover at Ramstein Air Force Base to visit with American troops.

HEADLINE: Galway Journal;
Defining 'Quality of Life' on the Crisp Celtic Coast

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GALWAY, Ireland

 BODY:
While many of Ireland's cities are trying to fight their way out of economic recession with ambitious urban development, this clean, windy city of 55,000 on the Atlantic Coast has decided that it has gone about as far as it should go with bricks and mortar.
The Galwegians, the residents of this 500-year-old city, say that they have enough new buildings pushing against the ancient gray walls of the port, and that a high quality of life does not require more construction. 
 They have relatively little street crime and a lot of history, a university, good theaters and the frequent sound of Gaelic spoken in public.
But perhaps most important, Galway has a lot of water. The River Corrib rushes through the city out to the ocean in swirls of white water. Salmon are there for the catching right in the city center. Swans glide along the river banks. Quiet, rubbish-free canals lead inland to the salmon weir and the domed Roman Catholic cathedral.
Any development plans here have a largely liquid center. They range from attracting more visitors for salmon-fishing and swan-watching to selling river water in container-ship loads to thirsty Arab nations. Tourists are coming in increasing numbers, particularly Americans no longer afraid to fly because of the threat of terrorism, which hurt business after the Persian Gulf war.
"There is a good buzz in Galway," said the Lord Mayor, Henry O'Connor. "We've expanded rapidly. In the 1980's we were the fastest growing city in Western Europe. The population went from 35,000 to 50,000 in about 10 years. But in the old days you could walk down the street and know everybody's name. Not now. I wouldn't like to see Galway going much further."
A new, bright red five-story apartment-office building in the old port, he said, has dwarfed the Spanish Parade area, where Columbus attended Mass in a local church, then set sail on one of his journeys. A monument to Columbus was recently defaced with the word "Choctaw" in black paint. Officials suspect it was the work of American visitors who feel Columbus had ravaged American Indians.
Although Galway's unemployment rate is 18 percent, about the same as the rest of the country, Mayor O'Connor said, "Galway hasn't suffered too much" in three years of recession because "we have a lot of tourism and a lot of students" who spend money.
The City Manager, Joe Gavin, said the loss of revenue and jobs due to layoffs last year at the local Digital plant would be more than offset by tourism and the opening of two United States technology companies, Boston Scientific and American Power.
Mayor O'Connor is in favor of making the canals navigable for fishermen. Only last year, he said, Ireland's most beloved Englishman, Jack Charlton, the coach of the national soccer team, was fishing there and drew such a crowd of admirers that their cars caused a traffic jam and the coach was asked to reel in.
But Mr. O'Connor, 48, a real estate agent, said he is against the proposal by an American company to sell water to Middle Eastern countries. "It's a danger if you get a dry spell," he said. "You'd expose harmful weeds, block navigation. And fishing is important here."
Mr. Gavin said that selling water was still under consideration and that it would bring Galway about $750,000 a year. "Our water is pristine -- clean, clean, clean, immaculate," he said.
To attract American tourists, Galway has a genealogical center. Jean Kennedy Smith, the United States Ambassador, spoke in June at the introduction of a genealogical magazine at a castle outside Galway. She recalled that she had once looked up her great-grandfather, Patrick Joseph Kennedy, on an Irish genealogy computer service and found out he was 28 and illiterate when he left this country in the 1840's.
The Ambassador was received as a celebrity, and several dozen people asked for her autograph.
Although crime rates are low, four residents were killed recently, including a mother and baby whose bodies were found in a wooded area and a Catholic priest whose body was found in the same area. No one has been charged.
The killings have revived calls for police officers to get out of their radio cars and to patrol, if not on bicycles as in the old days, then on foot.
There is also a debate over the traditional itinerants, once known as tinkers and now called travelers, who have lived a nomadic life for centuries. National and local officials want to settle them in towns or in specially equipped parking areas. But Galwegians are resisting such such settlements; many say the travelers bring crime.
Mr. Gavin said such fears are unfounded. But Mr. O'Connor said of the travelers, "Galway has been good to them, but we're probably getting to a stage where we say, 'Enough is enough.' "
Many other people here think that change would not be good for the city. Sheila O'Donnellan, a professional reciter of the works of Yeats and Joyce who has lived here for 40 years, summed it up: "My fear would be that in this unique place, the modern would take over and submerge the old traditional Galway. As it is now, Galway is the most livable city in Ireland."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Where the River Corrib flows past the Spanish Arch in Galway, Ireland, Columbus once set sail for the Americas. Now, Galwegians picnic there, and the city hopes more tourists will come from the Americas. (James F. Clarity/The New York Times)
 
Map of Ireland showing location of Galway.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bonds Continue to Fall

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury bonds fell for a fifth day amid expectations that this week's economic reports will show faster growth and rising inflation and lead to higher interest rates.
A decline in the dollar against the Japanese yen and German mark -- as well as higher commodity prices -- also helped drag down bonds, traders said. 
 Government reports this week on June producer and consumer prices, as well as retail sales, follow a report on Friday that the economy added far more jobs than expected in June. The economy grew at an annual rate of 3.4 percent during the first quarter.
David Duerson, head trader at BA Securities in San Francisco, said traders confronted an economy building momentum as well as a currency in "desperate" shape. "There's not a lot to look forward to," he said.
The benchmark 30-year bond closed down 10/32 , or $3.13 for each $1,000 of bonds, to yield 7.72 percent. Earlier, the bond was down as much as 1/2 point to yield 7.74 percent.
The closing yield, up three basis points, was at its highest since President Clinton's election in November 1992. The two-year note yield was 6.25 percent, also up three basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Investors will not buy Treasury bonds unless the Federal Reserve signals whether it plans to raise interest rates again, said Alfred Jordan, who helps manage a $150 million government bond portfolio at Commerce Capital Management in Memphis.
"One aspect of this whole thing that's scary is the real lack of buyers out there," Mr. Jordan said. "It doesn't matter what kind of statistics come out. If there aren't any buyers, it's impossible for the market to do better."
The Federal Reserve is expected to raise overnight bank loan rates by as much as 50 basis points during the next month to head off inflation as the economy expands, analysts said. Since February, the Fed has raised the overnight rate four times, to 4.25 percent from 3 percent.
Wayne D. Angell, a former Fed governor who is now chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company, said yesterday that the Fed needed to raise rates by 100 basis points to forestall a recession in 1996 or 1997. Otherwise, long-term interest rates would surge so far and so fast that the economy would stall, he said.
"The Fed's got to be concerned that any growth slowdown we've seen has been temporary," Jerry Zukowski, an economist at Paine Webber, said. "The economy hasn't responded by slowing to the higher rates."
Economic growth hasn't caused inflation to jump yet. During the first five months of the year, inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index was running at an annual rate of 2.3 percent in May, down from 3.2 percent for the first five months of 1993 and 2.7 percent during all of last year.
 
Labor Department Report on Jobs
 Still, Friday's report by the Labor Department that the economy added 379,000 jobs in June added to concern about inflation, which diminishes the value of bonds' fixed payments.
This week, the Government reports on June wholesale prices today, June consumer prices tomorrow, June retail sales on Thursday and June industrial production on Friday. Unexpected gains in those reports could touch off another round of Fed rate increases, traders and investors said.
To be sure, some investors said the Fed would not raise rates out of concern that higher rates would drive the economy into a recession.
"We've taken a lot of the spending power out of the public's hands with the rate increases we've already had," said Michael Link, who helps manage about $242 million in fixed-income investments at the Gradison-McDonald Government Income Fund.
"It's getting close to the straw that broke the camel's back," Mr. Link said, adding that if the Fed raised rates by 50 basis points, "I think the economy would collapse."
Bond yields were 6.3 percent before the Fed began raising rates in February. The record low yield is 5.77 percent, reached on Oct. 15. Changes in Treasury yields are important to the economy because they are the basis for rates for housing and auto loans.
The yield on the 30-year bond has climbed to more than 7.7 percent this year from 6.3 percent in February.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
After a selloff, the auto stocks may hold new promise.

BYLINE: By James Bennet 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
THROUGH the spring and into the summer, the auto makers and almost all financial analysts who cover them firmly predicted robust sales and earnings for the industry well into 1996. But the auto makers' stocks kept falling.
"The stock market has been saying for months now, 'We don't believe any of you guys,' " said Harvey Heinbach, an auto industry analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York. Then, after an upbeat report on June sales last week, investors shed their doubts and aggressively bid up the stocks on Thursday. Although they have retreated a bit since then, General Motors, Ford and Chrysler have held on to most of their recent gains. 
 Yesterday, G.M.'s shares closed at $51, off 37.5 cents, while Ford ended at $30.375, down 25 cents, and Chrysler was at $48.25, down 62.5 cents.
So has the sector bottomed out for the year? Ultimately, the answer depends on whether investors continue to have faith that the recovery is on track. "Who knows?" said Mr. Heinbach, who has recommended buying the stocks of the Big Three since before the selloff began early this year.
As interest rates began to rise earlier this year, investors fled many of the cyclical stocks on the theory that higher rates would choke the economic recovery. Over the last five months, the Big Three auto stocks lost about 18 percent of their value.
"This has been a very typical correction," said John Casesa, the auto industry analyst for Wertheim Schroder & Company in New York. He pointed out that during the last recovery, from 1983 to 1987, there were three similar corrections.
After each one, the stocks resumed their upward march, passing their old pre-correction peaks until the auto recovery itself hit new heights.
"You don't have to be worried about it as an investor," Mr. Casesa said. "There's a lot of appreciation in these stocks -- if you believe the recovery will continue."
Ah, the big "if."
This has been a peculiar recovery, particularly in the auto market. The fundamentals -- strong consumer confidence and a high average age for vehicles on the road -- remain in place. But sales have not been as strong as past recoveries would indicate. The reason, the optimists believe, is too little production capacity.
With most factories running flat-out, dealer inventories of hot-selling models like the Ford Explorer sport utility vehicle are nevertheless abnormally low, restraining sales. And production shutdowns by the Big Three, as they shift to 1995 models, have virtually cut off supplies of some big-volume products, like the Chevrolet Lumina sedan.
But it is no simple matter to measure how many unmade vehicles are going unbought. "We're all reaching for straws in the wind to tell us what's happening with demand," Mr. Heinbach said.
The auto makers continue to insist that the demand is there. "The market is still quite strong," J. Michael Losh, G.M.'s new chief financial officer, said in presenting the company's midyear sales figures. G.M., making one of the industry's most conservative projections, estimates that sales of cars and light trucks will total 15.3 million this year, 10 percent above the 1993 level.
One clear measure of demand, and hence the durability of the recovery, is the auto makers' earnings. As they raise prices and slash rebates in the face of strong demand, the auto makers make more money from each sale.
 So it is a further demonstration of their optimism that auto industry analysts are predicting that the Big Three will report combined second-quarter earnings of up to $4.33 billion, close to double what they were a year ago.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
MOTOROLA INC. (MOT,N)

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Motorola Inc. reported yesterday that second-quarter revenues and earnings were sharply higher, led by a 75 percent gain in sales of telecommunications equipment.
Motorola, the electronics manufacturer, said net income surged 63.8 percent, to $367 million, or 63 cents a share. The earnings were 5 cents higher than a mean estimate of 58 cents a share by 18 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. 
 Motorola's robust earnings increase is expected to forestall a repeat of last quarter, when its stock fell 5 percent after it missed analysts' earnings estimates by a penny a share. The results, however, were released after the stock market closed.
The company, which is based in Schaumburg, Ill., also said sales increased 32.9 percent, to $5.4 billion.
"The U.S. markets have been doing very well," said Gary L. Tooker, the company's vice chairman and chief executive, "although increases in interest rates could moderate the rate of growth later in the year."
Motorola reported the greatest growth in its General Systems unit, where sales rose 75 percent, to $2.1 billion. The company cited strong increases in sales of cellular telephones and transmitting equipment in China and Japan.
Semiconductor products sales rose 23 percent, to $1.7 billion, while its communications segment, which includes pagers, posted a 26 percent gain in sales, to $1.4 billion.

HEADLINE: A Boom for On-Line Services

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
Spurred by the success of America Online, Prodigy and other consumer information services that together are attracting more than a million new customers a year from home computer users, developers ranging from giant corporations to tiny start-ups are racing to build electronic communities in cyberspace.
In the last year the consumer response translated into a 25 percent annual growth rate, bringing total consumer subscriptions to on-line services to more than 5 million. 
 But while industry optimists expect such growth to continue, noting that the number of personal computer users, now 60 million, is steadily increasingly, others have concluded that there may not be enough gold in cyberspace to justify all the money that the prospectors are spending.
 
Glut Is Foreseen
 Analysts and even the developers themselves say the rush to cyberspace could lead to a glut of services that will overwhelm the relatively small market for consumer data. The 10 largest revenue producers among the on-line consumer services brought in only slightly more than $500 million last year.
"There's a shakeout on the horizon," said Rusty Williams, vice president and general manager of Delphi Internet Services of Cambridge, Mass., an on-line service provider owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation. "The numbers are growing rapidly, but they won't be high enough to accommodate all the companies who are coming into the market."
Delphi sees room for itself, however. Currently the nation's fifth-largest general-interest on-line service for consumers, with close to 100,000 subscribers, Delphi expects its clientele to double over the next year.
Unlike the on-line information systems that evolved in the early years of the computer industry, which catered to business customers willing to pay handsomely for archived documents and raw data, the new interactive services are being developed for consumers who use home computers to supplement other information systems: the postal service, newspapers, magazines, television, telephones, books and backyard fences.
Aficionados might be willing to spend endless hours and hundreds of dollars each month on line, but most people are likely to devote far less time and money to this aspect of their busy lives. For service providers, the trick will be to distinguish themselves as either fun or functional enough to attract and keep customers.
"The different services are now challenging themselves to come up with creative ways to present information and find new sources of information," said Lisa Johnson, an analyst with the market research firm Link Resources in New York City.
"But what appears to be lacking is the compelling content that is going to sustain the subscriber base and generate usage dollars," she said.
Consumer on-line systems, which typically charge fees of $10 to $30 a month, use point-and-click computer-mouse software to give users relatively simple and immediate access over phone lines to a variety of services. These typically include news, on-line shopping, financial and stock market data, electronic mail, libraries of software and technical information, entertainment listings, games, advertising and discussion groups.
Some of these consumer services already offer, and others plan to offer, access to the Internet, a worldwide network of some 2.2 million host computers that provide information and services to an estimated 25 million people.
 
A Dozen Services
 The consumer category at present consists of about a dozen large, general-interest services led by Prodigy Information Services of White Plains, which claims 2 million members; Compuserve Inc. of Columbus, Ohio, with 1.7 million subscribers; America Online Inc. of Reston, Va., 900,000; General Electric's Genie, 350,000, and the News Corporation's Delphi Internet Services Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., with 100,000.
Adding in other, smaller services, the total number of consumer subscriptions is estimated at 5.5 million. However, the market is believed to be smaller than the sum of its parts because of the different ways that services count members, because a household may subscribe to more than one service and because many accounts are inactive.
"At end of 1993 the market was no bigger than 3.7 or 4 million subscribers," said Lisa Thorell, principal analyst with the International Data Corporation in San Jose. "Those are not the kind of numbers that are going to get the attention of national television advertisers or even the cable TV advertisers."
Yet Ms. Thorell and other analysts say the economics of the consumer services will demand that they find a way to attract advertisers to subsidize the cost of doing business -- just as advertising subsidizes television, newspapers and magazines. But some services, especially the newer ones, may find it necessary to operate with little or no profit to attract enough customers to make themselves attractive to advertisers.
Lorraine Sileo, an analyst with Simba Information Inc., a market researcher in Wilton, Conn., said that unless prices for the services fell below $10 a month, the market would be limited to an estimated 1.5 million to 1.8 million new users each year for several years.
And yet, some billion-dollar companies are trying to create or expand their own on-line services to appeal to broad audiences of PC users around the world. The big players include AT&T, Apple Computer, Microsoft and I.B.M. -- as well as cable television, telephone, Internet service provider and publishing companies.
The newest among them is Apple Computer's eWorld, which made its debut late last month for users of Macintosh computers.
Soon to come is an AT&T system called Personal Link Services that employs sophisticated software "agents" that automatically gather and process information for the user. An investor in gold bullion, for example, might program a software agent to search the news data base each night and present a compilation in the morning of all gold market news.
The Microsoft Corporation, whose DOS-Windows operating system software is included with a majority of personal computers sold in the Western world, is developing its own on-line service, code-named Marvel. By early next year, the software for Marvel is expected to be included with every new copy of Windows.
Apple is including its eWorld software with all new Macintosh computers, so if Microsoft can persuade other computer makers to bundle Marvel with the machines they sell, it would mean that virtually every personal computer sold in North America would come equipped to receive an on-line service.
For smaller competitors, such moves by the industry giants could pose a threat. But many hope the trend could also stimulate the market by creating a large enough on-line consumer market to support the dozens of small companies and start-ups that offer specialized services aimed at specific groups of consumers.
 
'Niche' Services Gain
 There are, or will be soon, "niche" on-line systems that appeal to women (Women's Wire and Echo), the digitally hip (Transom, Pipeline and @Wired), older hipsters (Senior Net), homosexuals (Digital Queers and Eye Contact), sports buffs (USA Today Information Center)), game players (The Imagination Network and Novalink) and computer buffs (Interchange and Applelink).
"We have a tremendous capacity for growth in two directions: more users and multiple services per user," said Michael Kolowich, president of Ziff-Davis Interactive of Cambridge, Mass., whose Interchange service for personal computer users, is expected to be available nationally by the end of the year.
Mr. Kolowich predicted the on-line market would follow the evolutionary pattern of magazines -- except much faster. "It took decades for print magazines to go from general-interest publications like Life and Look and The Saturday Evening Post to special interest media," he said. "The on-line world has compressed the normal development of a medium tenfold."
But Ms. Sileo of Simba Information is not convinced that the consumer market can support an abundance of of narrowly targeted on-line services. "I don't think the on-line market is quite ready to be sliced and diced that way," she said. "They don't have the audience yet."
 
An Optimistic Upstart
 But at least one upstart says does not intend to wait until the current lineup attracts a large audience.
 "The services today -- Prodigy, Compuserve and America Online -- are like the Big Three television networks before Fox," said Michael Collins, a 26-year-old former advertising director for Spy magazine who is starting a service called Transom. "They try to get something for everybody, games for 6-year-olds, stock quotes and everything in between, so it turns out that not too much information has an edge."
Mr. Collins is managing director of Reach Media Inc., which later this year plans to begin operating Transom from a loft in the SoHo district of Manhattan. Transom will be "younger, hipper, and a lot more fun" than mainstream consumer services, he said.
Aimed at the 18-to-34-year-old market and conceived as a sort of MTV for the digital generation, Transom will offer electronic forums for the young and restless, as well as information and entertainment by writers from Rolling Stone and the Comedy Central cable channel, for example. There may also be music, news and audio samples digitized for downloading onto subscribers' computers.
Mr. Collins says he is not worried by talk of an on-line industry shakeout and the number of competitors crowding the field. "If this was television, right now we're still in the era of staring at fuzzy black-and-white screens," he said. "This is just the beginning. It makes it that much more exciting and challenging."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
It's Called Targeted Stock; Shun It, Some Experts Say

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
If some of Wall Street's financial engineers have their way, an exotic corporate financing tool known as targeted stock will be coming soon to a company near you.
When it does, some experts advise, run for the hills. 
 That is what many shareholders of the Kmart Corporation did when they voted down a proposal by the ailing retail company to issue targeted stock -- shares whose dividends would be linked to the performance of its specialty-store units but would have no guaranteed claim on their assets.
And based on the experience of a handful of earlier targeted-stock plans, the Kmart shareholders may have acted wisely, because the benefits of this technique are dubious.
"There really is no excuse for targeted stock," said Bruce Greenwald, professor of finance and economics at the Columbia University business school. "It is absolutely the purest form of financial engineering, and it yields no benefit at all."
Championed by investment bankers, targeted stock has gained a lot more attention in recent years. The most popular argument in favor of the mechanism is that it increases shareholders' value. And unlike spinoffs, targeted stocks help the parent company duck a potentially huge tax bill for capital gains.
Also known as alphabet or letter stock, targeted stock trades just like plain vanilla stock. It has its own stock symbol and may or may not pay a dividend, just like regular stock.
But it is not regular stock.
Targeted shares give their holders nothing more than a reason to believe they have a financial stake in a subsidiary of the company that issued the shares. If the subsidiary performs, the company delivers on its promise to pay out a souped-up dividend.
But because the subsidiary's assets and liabilities are mingled with those of the parent company, that dividend could vanish and the stock's price could fall the moment the parent company decides to divert the unit's earnings to satisfy its own liabilities.
Large institutional shareholders are snubbing such deals. They like to look at a company's underlying collateral to calculate what their investment might fetch in a worst-case situation. That analysis is impossible on targeted stocks because the corporate parent has first rights to any assets should financial problems arise, even if those problems crop up in a distant unit.
"It's sort of viewed as a mongrel that makes the valuation analysis quite difficult, so the technique is suspect with many large shareholders, including this one," said Kurt Schact, director of the State of Wisconsin Investment Board, which has led the shareholder revolt at Kmart. "We don't own any targeted stock."
Misconceptions arise because targeted stocks bear a striking but deceptive resemblance to shares that are often issued by subsidiaries that have made a clean break from their former parents. These spinoffs, brand-new companies whose shares are backed by their own assets and liabilities, offer investors "pure plays" on some industry or niche -- that is, an oil company stock or a steel company stock but not a combination of both in one stock.
The class E stock of General Motors, the granddaddy of all targeted stocks, is the most frequently cited example of a letter stock that has greatly maximized shareholders' value. In that 1984 deal, G.M. issued special shares intended to reflect the fortunes of the newly purchased Electronic Data Systems unit, primarily as a way of giving the founder of E.D.S., Ross Perot, a continuing stake in that business, and that business alone. The price of class E shares has increased by more than 200 percent in the decade since they were issued.
How much of that increase was related to the novel structure is anyone's guess. What many shareholders fail to grasp is that the class E shares are ultimately an investment in G.M. The auto maker, not E.D.S. or its class E shareholders, owns the assets of the computer services subsidiary. In the unlikely event that G.M. ever slid into serious financial trouble, it would be free to raid the assets of E.D.S.
Thus, owning class E shares is not really a pure play on E.D.S. And analysts and investors say that being a targeted stock was one of the things that scotched a merger between E.D.S. and Sprint earlier this year.
At least two recent targeted stock proposals -- one to separate RJR Nabisco's food group from its tobacco business, and the other to segregate Kmart's specialty-store earnings -- have been tabled indefinitely.
Other targeted stock offerings, including those of Ralston-Purina and USX, were done with another purpose in mind -- as a way to apply a tourniquet to a troubled business. They have generally not fared as well as the E.D.S. deal.
 
Two Plans Tabled
 That was the case, for example, when the USX Corporation's languishing steel business seemed to be obscuring the value of the company's healthy oil subsidiary. For each of their shares in the steel and oil conglomerate, USX's investors received one share of stock tied to the performance of the company's Marathon Oil unit and one-fifth of a share of stock that represented its steel operations.
Before the swap, USX shares traded at about $28. Now, the combined package of targeted stocks that shareholders received trades at about $23.50.
Last year, Ralston-Purina segregated its faltering Continental Baking unit from its basic food business using targeted stock instead of a spinoff. Though Ralston-Purina declined to comment, Nomi Ghez, an analyst for Goldman, Sachs who follows the company, said Ralston-Purina had chosen a targeted stock offering instead of a spinoff because it was concerned that the baking subsidiary would not fetch a high enough price to offset the taxes its parent would have paid on the sale.
Before the plan was announced, shares of Ralston-Purina traded at about $42 each. In the months after the deal, the combined package of original Ralston-Purina shares plus targeted stock in Continental Baking languished at about $37, at a time when food stocks were generally flat.
Ralston-Purina's decision in January to spin off its cereals businesses, rather than issue another targeted stock, seems to speak volumes about how companies increasingly view targeted stock. "The second time around, they did a spinoff because Continental Baking didn't work out," Ms. Ghez said. "The market just didn't receive the targeted stock all that well."
Philip Morris, Tenneco and Sears, Roebuck are three other companies that have politely declined the targeted-stock pitches of investment bankers.
 
Roller Coaster Ride
 Even G.M. had trouble replicating the success it enjoyed with E.D.S. when in 1985 the auto maker availed itself of the technique with its Hughes aerospace division. G.M.'s class H shares have given shareholders a roller coaster ride over the years.
Shareholders have fared better in Pittston, a mining company with interests in air freight and security services that was facing huge retiree medical liabilities from its coal operations. The package of targeted securities they received last year in the separated coal and services businesses has roughly doubled, in part because of a rebound in the steel industry.
But that deal was misunderstood by many investors, including at least one analyst for Lehman Brothers, Jeff Kessler, who was touting the service company's stock on the theory that this unit had escaped responsibility for the medical costs of retired coal miners.
To be sure, targeted stock deals confer some benefits. In addition to the tax advantages, they can help companies that want to stop short of a complete spinoff so that a subsidiary can retain access to a prized corporate asset like a companywide health care package or planning department.
Advocates of the technique also emphasize an increase in shareholders' value. Bankers contend that analysts, who usually specialize in one industry, fail to realize the value of a conglomerate because they do not understand all its businesses. By unbundling the businesses with targeted stocks, the thinking goes, each will gain the following of analysts who understand it.
Another argument for creating targeted stock is that the market prefers a pure play. Consultants also contend that targeted stocks make better incentives for the managers of subsidiaries because those shares are linked to the performances of those executives. "It's very effective in designing an appropriate incentive compensation system so managers can be rewarded in terms of something they can directly affect," said Joel M. Stern, a managing partner at Stern, Stewart & Company, a corporate finance advisory firm.
These arguments have some merit, critics of targeted stock say, but they are better addressed by going a step further and spinning off a subsidiary, which is much more straightforward and easier for investors to understand. "After hearing all of this, you have to ask yourself why you'd go to all that trouble when you could just do a spinoff," Professor Greenwald of Columbia said.
 
Advantage of Spinoffs
 Even Brian Finn, co-head of mergers and acquisitions at CS First Boston who worked on two such deals for USX, conceded that spinoffs were often optimal. "Most of the time, a spinoff is the better answer so you can eliminate any debate about valuation," he said. But, he argued, because spinoffs are not always possible because of tax and credit-rating consequences, targeted stock is the next best thing.
Mr. Finn and other proponents of the technique say some of the big disappointments are commentaries on those companies or their industries, and not on the technique. The package of securities that shareholders received from USX, for instance, is "not down because it's a targeted stock," Mr. Finn said. "It's down because Marathon is down, and Marathon is down because all oil companies are down right now."

HEADLINE: Taxpayers May Be Paying Twice for Some Drugs

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
Americans often pay for their medicine twice once through taxes and again at the pharmacy -- because the Government is not keeping tabs on the way private industry uses taxpayer-financed research, a new investigation concludes.
Under law, the Government has rights to any drug or medical device developed through Federally financed research. Among other things, the Government is entitled to lower the price of an excessively expensive treatment. 
 But it can only do so if it can prove that Government-financed research was used to develop the drug, and the National Institutes of Health have lost track of how its money is spent, concludes an investigation by the inspector general of the Department Health and Human Services.
 
One Person Keeping Track
 "N.I.H. needs to do a better job," Assistant Inspector General Michael Hill said at a Congressional hearing today. One employee is supposed to track the $8 billion the N.I.H. annually awards to outside scientists and find out how many medical discoveries result, he said.
"One person is watchdogging this $8 billion program? Unbelievable," said Representative Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon and the chairman of the House small-business regulation subcommittee, which requested the inquiry.
When scientists receive patents even partially financed by the Government, they must report them to N.I.H., which then has certain rights. If the agency thinks the drug is priced too high, it can license the product to a competitor. It can also make sure that companies do not refrain from developing cheaper treatments, and it can make sure that Government-financed drugs are available in the United States, not just abroad.
Such steps can be effective. The N.I.H.'s threat to step in when an AIDS drug, AZT, hit the market is credited with halving its price.
But Mr. Hill discovered one agency, the Scripps Research Institute in California, that has reported only 51 federally financed patents since 1979. The institute has been awarded at least 94 federally financed patents in that time and receives $70 million a year from the National Institutes of Health
A cursory look at 25 other institutions that get N.I.H. financing showed similarly low reporting rates, leading Mr. Hill to believe that underreporting is rampant, he said.
 
Cost to N.I.H. and Consumers
 Since the N.I.H. can buy Federally financed treatments without paying royalties, it may be paying too much for the drugs it buys for use at its campus in Bethesda, Md. And those drugs may be priced too high for the consumer, critics contend.
"There has got to be some sort of commensurate recognition of the taxpayers' investment when those drugs are priced," Representative Wyden said. "What we're looking at is, what's the best way to do that?"
The N.I.H. is studying the problem, said a spokeswoman, Anne Thomas. Scripps says it "regrets these past failures" and has corrected its reporting system.
But critics say the government must insure that drug price tags reflect taxpayer investments. "Taxpayers are funding an awful lot of work out there, said Peter Arno, a health economist at the Albert Einstein School of Medicine, "but if they create a product that's too expensive, that's as good as no product at all."
Government-financed drugs cost three times as much as drugs developed solely by pharmaceutical companies, according to a study by the Taxpayers Assets Foundation in Washington.
From 1987 to 1991, the Food and Drug Administration approved 10 significant new drugs for severe illnesses, and seven were financed by taxpayers, that study concluded. Of the 37 cancer drugs approved since 1955, 34 were financed by the Government. Yet the median wholesale price for company-financed drugs was $1,485, while drugs financed by the Government cost $4,480.
The N.I.H. is "this Federal Santa Claus," said a foundation officer, James Love. "It's really a ripoff for the taxpayers to have to buy the super-expensive drug" when they have already paid to develop the medicine, he said.

HEADLINE: Opponents of Haiti's Military Urge Rights Monitors to Stay

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 12

 BODY:
Supporters of the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, urged international human rights monitors today to remain in the country and continue investigating increasing reports of abuses.
The monitors, a joint civilian mission of the United Nations and the Organization of American States, were ordered Monday by the military-backed Government to leave. They are to go Wednesday. 
 The group decided to leave because the army said it could not guarantee the security of the 104 members, said Colin Granderson, executive director of the mission.
The Government of Emile Jonassaint accused the monitors of disturbing public order and threatening the security of the state.
 
Departure Draws Criticism
 "This is a setback to the Haitian people," said a top aide to Prime Minister Robert Malval, who was appointed by Father Aristide. The aide said the United Nations and the O.A.S. were tacitly approving the military Government. "We are the legitimate Government and we were not consulted," he added.
Today, tensions increased after radio reports that at least a dozen people had been killed in Leogane, about 20 miles south of here.
Foreign journalists who went to Leogane to investigate said the bodies were covered, but residents said they appeared to have been killed somewhere else and dropped in Leogane because no one there had reported missing relatives.
Charles David, Foreign Minister of the Jonassaint Government, defended the expulsion, saying the mission's mandate was "illegal and irregular." Mr. David said at a news conference that members of the mission were carrying guns and hand-held radios without permits.
"I want to remind you that Haiti is not at war with anyone," Mr. David said. "Haiti is not threatening anyone. We are put under an embargo, so therefore the Government will do what it thinks is its duty."
 
The Last Monitors
 Today during a news conference at the monitors' headquarters in Montagne Noire, a well-to-do suburb, Mr. Granderson said, "The de facto authorities have chosen to take on a heavy responsibility in ordering us, under threat, to leave the country."
The departure of the mission will leave a void in the monitoring of human rights abuses, which diplomats say have been rising steadily. Various organizations estimate that four Haitians are killed daily as a result of political repression.
The mission came to Haiti last year as part of an accord whose aim was to pave the way for the return of Father Aristide. Last October the mission left abruptly after armed thugs prevented a United States Navy ship, the Harland County, from unloading about 300 American and Canadian soldiers who were to rebuild roads and other facilities in Haiti.
The monitors moved to the neighboring Dominican Republic, returning to Haiti about two months later. Mr. Granderson said that this time, too, the group would return.
"It was tedious work, sometimes a thankless task, which has profoundly affected them," Mr. Granderson said, referring to the monitoring of reports of violence. "In forcing us to leave, the military officials and the de facto Government have implicity recognized the importance of the mandate with which the mission has been entrusted."
As the mission prepared to leave on an Air France flight, United States Coast Guard cutters continued to repatriate Haitian refugees, returning 747 boat people today. Refugee advocates say the Clinton Administration should not be returning any Haitians because of the worsening human rights conditions here.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
The Last Line Out
 UNITED NATIONS, July 12 (Special to The New York Times) -- The rights monitors are to leave Haiti on a scheduled flight by Air France, the only international airline serving Port-au-Prince, United Nations officials said today. Air France has three flights a week to Guadeloupe, a French island in the Caribbean.
The monitors have been confined to Port-au-Prince since last week because of threats they received when they tried to travel to investigate human rights abuses.
The Security Council said today that "this provocative behavior directly affects the peace and security of the region." The statement, initiated by the United States, called the expulsion "a serious escalation in the defiant stance of Haiti's illegal de facto regime towards the international community."
On May 6, when it tightened its economic sanctions against Haiti, the Security Council voted to ban all flights in and out of Haiti to cut off drug trafficking, which is believed to be a major source of foreign currency for the military Government. Only Air France still has flights, but United States officials said today that they expected these to end soon.

HEADLINE: Death of Kim: An Edgy Reappraisal

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, July 12

 BODY:
For more than four decades, ever since the North Korean dictator Kim Il Sung launched the Korean War, leaving hundreds of thousands dead and the peninsula in ruins, many South Koreans and Americans have been awaiting the death of this dangerous leader as a moment to rejoice.
But something strange has happened since Mr. Kim died on Friday at 82, reportedly of a heart attack. Not only have many people here failed to applaud his passing but, as a Government official put it today, there is even some disappointment among top policy makers. 
 More important, this restrained response would probably have been quite different if Mr. Kim had died just a few weeks earlier, before he suddenly took a conciliatory line in relations with South Korea and the United States.
 
An Heir Sires Uncertainty
 "We are confused," the South Korean official acknowledged. And a Western diplomat said, "There is a sense of letdown here."
Of course, there are plenty of reasons for finding the future more worrying than the past.
The uncertainty over the new policies of the hard-line Communist Government are an important source of apprehension. Mr. Kim's son, Kim Jong Il, a reclusive man who once ordered the kidnapping of a South Korean film director to enliven his country's cinema, appears to be consolidating his position, and that has left many here nervous.
In addition, there is speculation that the younger Mr. Kim does not have the charisma to maintain absolute power, as his father did. There is talk of coups and civil war.
But several officials and diplomats acknowledged that the unusual turn of events had led to a reassessment of the late Mr. Kim.
 
Nuclear Nervousness
 For the previous 18 months, Mr. Kim had been heading toward a collision with the United States and the United Nations over his refusal to allow international inspection of sites where North Korea was thought to be developing nuclear weapons.
There was fear that North Korea had produced some plutonium, the key component, and that it was about to extract more.
The war of nerves had reached the point where South Korea and the United States had decided to seek economic sanctions against the North, which North Korea warned could lead to war. Mr. Kim had seldom loomed so ominously.
And then suddenly, last month, after the mediation of former President Jimmy Carter, Mr. Kim softened his position. He agreed to hold the first summit meeting with the South Korean President, Kim Yong Sam, and to open high-level negotiations with the United States. In turn, the United States eased some of its demands.
 
Time for a Reassessment
 South Korean officials had gotten as far as working out details on security and communications for the meeting in Pyongyang, which had been scheduled to begin July 25. And the North Korean negotiator had just held the first meeting with his American counterpart in Geneva, with the mood described as amicable.
Both those diplomatic openings have been postponed. [The North Korea radio said Wednesday that officials would meet United States representatives on Sunday in New York to arrange a resumption of talks, Reuters reported from Tokyo, citing the monitoring service Radiopress.]
Still, these modestly hopeful signs appear to have had a big effect on the thinking of officials here and in Washington. There was even speculation that because the opening was so promising, hard-liners in North Korea had Mr. Kim killed to halt the progress, although the South Koreans and the Americans have said there is no evidence of this.
South Korean leaders, especially the President, have been conspicuous in saying little publicly. They have forgone an opportunity to articulate their judgments on Kim Il Sung's bitter legacy and the lessons to be drawn. Officials have said they do not want to poison the atmosphere, since many hope a new summit meeting can be arranged.
 
The Vitriol Fades
 Han Sung Chu, South Korea's Foreign Minister, said he hoped the new leadership would "keep alive the recently created momentum," as though the weight of history were already behind this new opening.
And in North Korea, too, there are signs of a change in attitude, however temporary.
The official North Korean news media have all but abandoned their acid forms of address toward Seoul and Washington. The huge speakers blaring anti-American propaganda at the Demilitarized Zone have stopped. The North Korean press even reported approvingly the expression of condolence from President Clinton, who was vilified in the past.
This change could be reversed, of course, when the period of mourning for Mr. Kim ends on Sunday. The fact that nobody knows what will happen, or feels any confidence in predictions, has only added to a surge of nostalgia for Mr. Kim.

HEADLINE: With a Few Strides, Clinton Celebrates Germany's Unity

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BERLIN, July 12

 BODY:
President Clinton paid tribute today to the end of Berlin's long and bitter schism, striding across the line that once divided the city and lowering for the last time the flag of the American forces whose vigil here began on July 4, 1945.
From the Brandenburg Gate, a symbol of a divided Europe, Mr. Clinton faced east in celebration and told some 50,000 Berliners who thronged Pariser Platz that he rejoiced with them that "Berlin ist frei!" 
 Coming nearly five years after the Berlin wall fell, this visit of a United States President seemed belated to many. But Mr. Clinton accommodated with exuberance. With American and German flags presenting a forest of color behind him, the President followed his idol, John F. Kennedy, in using the German language to proclaim an eternal bond.
"Amerika steht an Ihrer Seite, jetzt und fur immer," he declared, promising that "America stands on your side, now and forever."
 
A Symbolic Crossing
 Even more vivid was the scene when Mr. Clinton and Chancellor Helmut Kohl, accompanied only by their wives, passed beneath the gate's towering neo-Gothic columns, across the stretch of land where the Berlin wall stood and into the crowd that had gathered in the former East Berlin.
As the High Court ended the constitutional prohibition on a German role in combat operations abroad, Mr. Clinton's visit seemed truly to mark the end of an era. In helping to retire the colors of the Berlin Brigade, Mr. Clinton said farewell to an American unit that was dispatched at the height of Berlin wall crisis in 1961 to reinforce the units based here at the end of World War II.
By early September, the Russian, British and French forces will also be withdrawn.
In expectation of today's High Court decision, some of Germany's neighbors had expressed uneasiness at the prospect that German forces might once again mount military missions abroad. But Mr. Clinton has used his visit here to campaign for a more assertive Germany, and he proclaimed himself today to be "fully comfortable" with the decision.
 
Earlier Visitors
 In addressing Berliners from the Brandenburg Gate, Mr. Clinton joined a roster of Presidents who have chosen it as a symbol of their times.
When President Kennedy came in 1963, he tried to peer over the gate into East Berlin. But its openings had been blocked with giant banners, and it was from the West Berlin city hall that he delivered his famous speech identifying Americans with the plight of Berliners. In 1987, East German guards paced edgily near the gate as President Reagan, speaking from the Western side, challenged Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to "open this gate!" and "tear down this wall!"
But today, with the wall no more than a memory except in a few preserved places, President Clinton and Chancellor Kohl strode side by side from the Reichstag, the once and future seat of Government, through a gate that is again open to all.
 
Lots of Happy Germans
 Far from the tension that has racked past Presidential visits, the mood today was joyous, with a beating sun and strains of rock and military bands creating a festival scene. Some in the crowd seemed weary to be told once again that their city was free, but when Mr. Clinton put his college German to work, he was greeted with roars of approval.
"Nothing will stop us," he said in his hosts' language. "Everything is possible. Berlin is free!"
German police initally said the crowd numbered about 50,000, but the Secret Service later estimated it at 100,000. In either case, it was nothing like the swollen masses that turned out for an American President at the height of the cold war.
But it still spilled well beyond the East Berlin plaza, a no man's land under Communist rule, And after leaving the podium, Mr. Kohl proclaimed the event to have marked "an unforgettable hour."
 
Short and Sweet
 Even in its brevity -- the two leaders were the only ones to speak, and Mr. Clinton's speech lasted just eight and a half minutes -- the back-to-back appearances established an emotional high point in a week that took the President from Latvia to Poland to Italy to Germany. He left Berlin tonight. [The President arrived back in Washington late Tuesday.]
When the Berlin wall fell in the autumn of 1989, followed within months by Germany's reunification, President Bush initially seemed unnerved by the rapid pace of events, and although he attended an economic summit in Munich in 1992, he never paid the triumphal visit to Berlin that Mr. Clinton did today.
In some ways, Mr. Clinton's farewell to the Berlin Brigade was even more evocative, mostly because it foreshadowed the next stage of a Europe transformed. While tens of thousand of American soldiers remain elsewhere in Germany, the handing over of McNair Barracks, the brigade's base, underscored the extent of what has been a rapid American withdrawal.
At the afternoon ceremony, Mr. Clinton pledged once again to hold the line against military cuts sought by his fellow Democrats, saying he remained committed to maintaining 100,000 troops in Europe.
 
'America Salutes You'
 But in a setting in which he was his most Presidential, Mr. Clinton stood erect in the back of a jeep, grasping only a roll bar, as he and two Army generals reviewed the 4,000 soldiers on a parade ground.
Then, as an honor guard rolled the red and blue brigade flag around its staff and thrust it into its long case, Mr. Clinton reached out to hold it for a moment before handing it over to the unit's command sergeant major.
"With the cold war over, we gather to honor those Americans who helped bring it to an end," Mr. Clinton said to the unit. "America salutes you. Mission accomplished."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Five years after the Berlin wall fell, President Clinton visited the Brandenburg Gate yesterday, crossed into the old Communist sector and told Berliners, "America stands on your side, now and forever." (Associated Press)
 
Map shows the location of the Brandenburg Gate.
