HEADLINE: The Guard Takes On The Gangs

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R.

 BODY:
One day just before dawn a year ago, 500 police officers and National Guard troops descended on Las Gladiolas public housing project here, searching apartments, confiscating drugs and weapons, and making arrests.
Afterward, nearly 200 of them stayed on. They closed off a back entrance to the four buildings in the fenced-in project and built a bulletproof guard house with gates to control access to the property. Three months later, the Guard and most of the police officers withdrew, but 18 officers remained, quartered at a mini-station house. 
 Tenants say lives at Las Gladiolas changed drastically, beneficiaries of a Puerto Rican government crackdown that relies partly on the precedent-setting routine use of the National Guard to help fight crime in housing developments. Las Gladiolas, long known for its shootouts and drive-in drug transactions, the place where even ambulance and firefighting crews had refused to venture in, suddenly became one whose residents could venture out.
"Before, all you saw were lines of cars and people with arms," said Adela de Leon, the 43-year-old president of a new tenants council. "You don't see that anymore. We're more at peace."
 
Success and Reservations
 The experience of Ms. de Leon and her neighbors is mirrored by that of residents at other housing projects on the island. The authorities say that in the year since Puerto Rico decided to use the Guard to help the police seize control of residential developments rife with drug dealing, the crime rate has been cut by more than half in the 45 public projects and 5 private developments where the strategy has been applied.
Not that everyone is entirely sold on the effort, a showcase of Gov. Pedro Rossello's anti-crime program, Mano Dura, which is Spanish for Stern Hand. In addition to the complaints of civil rights lawyers that the crackdown has frequently been characterized by illegal searches and other transgressions, some critics remain unconvinced that the safer environment it has yielded will prove lasting or widespread.
For one thing, while the authorities' island-wide statistics show a sharp drop in crime as a whole during the last year -- rape, for instance, is down by 21.4 percent -- murder has risen, by 2.1 percent. The increase is attributed to drug gangs that, having been displaced from housing projects where the Guard has intervened, now find themselves fighting for control of new areas.
Further, the Guard typically remains at a raided project only two months or so, and there is already some evidence that once the soldiers move out, crime begins to move back in.
 
A First for the Military
 The introduction of Governor Rossello's anti-crime strategy drew immediate and vast attention last year because it marked the first time that American military units had been routinely deployed to help the police fight crime. Americans have been generally resistant to using the military for domestic police work -- when Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly of Washington suggested to President Clinton that the Guard could join anti-crime efforts in her city, the idea went nowhere -- and some of those reservations have been reflected here.
Civil rights lawyers say that although they have not yet filed lawsuits stemming from the joint Guard-police crackdown, they have received many complaints of abuse. And the legal issues, they say, intensify the social ones.
Judith Berkan, president of the Human Rights Commission of the Puerto Rican Bar Association, says the Guard's occupation of poor residential areas serves only to deepen class divisions. "You get people accustomed to state intervention and violation of civil rights," she said.
But if the critics refer to the program as the "militarization" of the housing projects, the Governor calls it their "liberation."
"What gives me the most satisfaction is that the civil rights of those who lived under the threat of drug trafficking have been re-established," Mr. Rossello said in an interview. "They've been liberated."
 
Praise From Washington
 The strategy, which at any given time involves as many as 300 of the island's 11,500 National Guard troops, has won praise from Federal officials who have followed it.
One of those officials, Lee P. Brown, the Director of National Drug Control Policy, visited some of the projects in May and said he believed that the crackdown had succeeded so far. "You break the link between the drug dealers and the drug consumers," Mr. Brown said in an interview. "The challenge is to keep them running, hopefully into the ocean."
The strategy entails three phases. First comes the raid. Then work crews build security fences and spruce up the property. Finally, representatives of 16 Puerto Rican government service agencies, collectively called the Quality of Life Congress, move in to address drug-spawning social problems like unemployment, poor heath care and lack of recreational programs.
Mr. Rossello said that when the program began, about half of the 250,000 tenants in Puerto Rico's 332 public housing projects lived "under the control of drug traffickers."
Now crime in the projects has dropped by more than 50 percent in only a year, says Police Superintendent Pedro A. Toledo; the Governor's office puts the figure at 85 percent. Either way, a drastic solution appears to have brought a dramatic result.
 
A Tinge of Disenchantment
 Still, concern lingers as to how long that result will last. Some tenants complain that the raids have been followed by laxity on the part of law-enforcement officials and social service agencies alike. Rafael Albarran, a political science professor at the University of Puerto Rico, said that in a series of surveys and interviews at 10 of the raided projects, many tenants told him and his students that some drug dealing continued, although more discreetly.
Several critics, like Representative David Noriega of the Puerto Rican Independence Party, the minority whip in the island's House of Representatives, say a greater emphasis on social programs and even some form of drug legalization would be better in the long run than the course Mr. Rossello has chosen.
But the Governor says he has just begun: He has committed about $75 million a year to his program through 1996, when his first term ends.
His administration acknowledges a need for diligent follow-through. Housing Secretary Carlos J. Vivoni says the challenge is to offer the projects' tenants, most of whom depend on welfare benefits, opportunities for education, jobs and "rebuilding" their communities.
"Our success," Mr. Vivoni said, "will depend on the continued importance subsequent administrations give the effort, and the level of involvement and commitment by the residents. If the residents don't become owners of their environment, the communities will rot again."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Virgilio Davila public housing project in Bayamon is one of 50 residential developments where the Puerto Rico National Guard has taken on an anti-crime role in the last year. (Phillippe Diederich for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Nations Envied for Schools Share Americans' Worries

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HONOLULU, July 12

 BODY:
When American officials embarked on efforts to improve public education a decade ago, the campaign was accompanied by hand-wringing over the well-run, results-oriented school systems of other nations. Why, American analysts asked, are schools in other countries seemingly better off than those in the United States?
The answer is that they are not, as American officials discovered in a rare meeting with high-ranking education leaders from Australia, Canada, New Zealand and seven other Pacific Rim nations here. The meeting ended over the weekend, but not before the foreign educators lamented problems that, to hard-pressed United States representatives, sounded reassuringly familiar. Students need to achieve at higher levels. they said; teacher training needs improvement; vocational education and school-to-work transition programs fall short, and the need for them will only grow. Finally, they said, there is too little money to overhaul schools. 
 "We're all in the same boat," said Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States, a nonprofit education research and policy organization based in Denver that was the host for the conference. "We're all moving toward each other, and I see that accelerating."
Even policy solutions instituted in Australia and Taiwan, including a commitment to strengthening student performance in math and science, sound strikingly similar to the eight goals in President Clinton's legislation, titled Education 2000, which was approved earlier this year.
 
Economy Fuels Convergence
 A broad spectrum of education officials here said this unity of purpose, if not approach, was being fueled by a world economy increasingly interdependent, competitive and service oriented. Without a skilled work force that can produce goods and, particularly, services that keep pace with the competition, they said, their nations will falter. Educational systems must be retooled to yield a work force that is multilingual, adept with computers and technology and able to engage in problem solving and other "higher-order" thinking skills.
Nowhere were common concerns more evident than in vocational education and school-to-work transition programs. Virtually every nation -- even those thought to possess highly skilled work forces -- said their programs, which resemble those in the United States, were failing students and, ultimately, their nation's needs.
South Korean and Japanese officials, for example, said that as in the United States, too few students enrolled in vocational education programs, primarily because parents preferred that their children enter college, not the work force after graduating from high school. "Parents don't want their children attending technical colleges," said Wang-Bok Kim, of South Korea's Ministry of Education. And inadequate financing has left most vocational programs without the state-of-the-art, computerized equipment needed to train the next generation of workers.
Indeed, Education Secretary Richard W. Riley said that in the United States, which has long struggled to upgrade and update job training, only Oregon and Wisconsin had produced work-to-school transition programs that aggressively addressed students' needs by allowing 10th graders to pursue job-training over college preparation and by incorporating advanced technology, visits to workplaces and business executives as instructors in those programs.
 
Deep Divisions Masked
 Such similar concerns and experiences masked deep international divisions over educational approaches, said Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching in Princeton, N.J. But they are differences, he and others suggested, from which all could learn.
Japanese students, for example, outperform American students in math and science because, Japanese officials here said, their schools are more structured and focus on drill and practice. But the officials acknowledged that educational rigidity bred a lack of creativity, an area in which American students excelled.
And the ability to develop new, innovative ideas, the representatives from Japan and other Asian countries said, is critical in service economies. "The East tends to be very traditional, very rigid," said Lee Yock Suan, the Minister of Education for Singapore. "In the West, there is a lot of emphasis on creativity, but not enough structure."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Little Changed After Losses Early in Day

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar cut its early losses late yesterday to end little changed against other leading currencies. Earlier in the day, the dollar fell to a new low against the yen for the third consecutive session.
The dollar fell sharply in early New York trading after the release of the Labor Department's report on producer prices. The absence of inflation at the producer level was seen as relieving the pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates soon. Many currency traders contend that a sharp increase in interest rates is needed to stabilize the dollar. 
 But the report that producer prices were unchanged in June from May was good news for the Treasury securities market, attracting money into notes and bonds. This, in turn, helped shore up the dollar.
 The dollar was quoted at 1.5280 German marks, unchanged from Monday's quote in New York. Earlier in London, the dollar settled at 1.5162 marks, down from 1.5382 on Monday. The dollar posted one of its sharpest one-day drops on Monday.
The dollar edged down to 97.40 yen, from 97.73 yen on Monday. Earlier, the dollar had fallen to a new intraday trading low of 96.60 yen, down from the previous record of 96.96 yen set on Monday. In Tokyo, the dollar settled at 97.20.
The British pound fell to $1.5685 in New York, from $1.5725 on Monday.
In other currency trading, the dollar rose to 1.2895 Swiss francs, from 1.2890. But it was at 5.2450 French francs, down from 5.2525; 1.3848 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3868, and 1,517 Italian lire, down from 1,525.
"The dollar continues to have a very negative tone," said Tom Benfer, a director at the Bank of Mon-treal. "The negative psychology about the dollar is still very strong in the market and we are wondering what is the development that will break that negative psychology."
The bearish sentiment on the dollar emerged after the Clinton Administration was seen as favoring a strong yen to put pressure on Japan to open up its markets to foreign products.
The Secretary of Commerce, Ronald H. Brown, reiterated yesterday that the Clinton Administration would continue "its aggressive, pro-active policy of doing everything we can to open those markets."
Talks between the United States and Japan are continuing, but Mr. Brown acknowledged that the Administration could not report "significant progress."
Mr. Benfer of the Bank of Montreal said, "Certainly if there is a trade agreement with Japan, even on one issue, this would be considered very positive for dollar-yen."

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL;
Judge Seeks N.B.A. Settlement

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
A Federal judge, wielding a prickly verbal scepter, warned the National Basketball Association and the players' union yesterday to settle their simmering labor impasse. He said that if they did not, he would make a decision that would please no one.
"All this should have been resolved at collective bargaining," United States District Court Judge Kevin Duffy said. "No two ways about it. Neither side is particularly well served by litigation." 
 At the conclusion of yesterday's contentious one-day trial in Manhattan Federal Court, Duffy ordered that each side submit final documents by noon today, but he did not say when he would actually rule. "Unless you want me meddling in your labor negotiations, you should go out and get it fixed now," Duffy said.
Jeffrey Mishkin, an N.B.A. lawyer, said: "Clearly, he was telling us to bargain it out. But whatever he decides, he can't write us a new collective bargaining agreement." Mishkin said that no talks with the union were scheduled.
The league sued the National Basketball Players Association last month to guarantee the continuation of the terms of their labor agreement, which expired June 23, until a new deal was negotiated. The union obtained a temporary restraining order last week that barred teams from signing players to new contracts.
 
Antitrust Law Is at Issue
 The heart of the dispute is whether the expiration of the agreement subjects the impasse to antitrust law. The league says no, but the union charges that three elements of past agreements it wants to end -- the revenue sharing/salary cap system, the college draft and teams' right of first refusal in the signing of free agents -- violate antitrust law.
The trial featured Duffy jousting with lawyers, especially Frank Rothman, one of the league's lawyers, who unsuccessfully defended the National Football League in its antitrust fight against the United States Football League. He also jousted with the N.B.A.'s commissioner, David J. Stern.
Early on, Duffy suggested that Rothman was engaged in delaying tactics. "Do you want to spend two and a half years on this, like the last one?" Duffy, asked, referring to the lengthy N.F.L. case.
"Your honor, I lost $1," Rothman said, referring to the fact that the jury awarded the U.S.F.L. damages of only $1.
"And all the attorney's fees, not a small matter," Duffy said.
 
League's Motives Questioned
 Duffy asked about the league's motives in seeking a judgment that the labor dispute was not an antitrust matter.
"Why not let it go to collective bargaining?" Duffy asked.
"I wanted to, but we were threatened with antitrust litigation," Rothman said, "We brought declaratory action. . . ."
"To diddle around for two and a half years," Duffy interjected. "You'd like the judge of the court to become czar of the N.B.A?"
At that, Stern smiled. Said Rothman: "It's the last thing we want."
 
Testimony From Grantham
 Charles Grantham, executive director of the players association, testified that the union accepted the salary cap, revenue-sharing and the draft in labor agreements reached in 1983 and 1988 as economic necessities. But by 1990, he said, "We decided the cap and the draft restricted movement of players, and they had to be ended."
Roger Noll, a Stanford economist, testified that the salary cap does not foster competitive balance in the league.
"Nearly all the teams are at the cap, and it's become anticompetitive," Noll said.
The contention that many teams were paying players all the money they are able to under the cap seemed to unsettle Duffy.
"The players are getting all the money they're promised and therefore it's anticompetitive?" he asked Noll. Yes, Noll said, "it becomes anticompetitive when a majority of the teams are at the cap."
A second economic expert called by the union, William Landes, was told to leave the jury box by Duffy when his background revealed no testimony or writings about sports. "Step down!" the judge ordered.
 
Stern Tells of Benefits
 In two hours of testimony, Stern portrayed the economic benefits of revenue-sharing and the salary cap, saying player salaries and benefits have risen from $79.6 million in the 1982-83 season to a projected $535 million in the season just ended. During the same period, Stern testified, league revenues subject to the cap rose from $135.2 million to a projected $945 million. The league assigns 53 percent of its designated gross revenues to player salaries.
He added that in previous agreements between the league and players, the provisions of past agreements stayed in place until a new pact was negotiated.
"Antitrust law has no place in a labor dispute," he said.
Toward the end of Stern's testimony, Duffy still seemed irked that the N.B.A., in essence, went to court to keep the dispute out of court.
"You expect everyone to roll over, say, 'Goody,' and do what you want?" Duffy asked Stern.
"We don't believe that," Stern said.

HEADLINE: Missed Chances in Europe

 BODY:
It is no secret that President Clinton is trying to demonstrate to the American public that he is capable of consistent, credible foreign policy leadership. On that score, the summit meeting of industrial democracies in Naples -- the centerpiece of his latest European tour -- was a missed opportunity.
It is also no secret that it is not as easy nowadays for an American President to dominate the world stage. Absent a common Soviet threat, America is seen as one more player in a complex and increasingly parochial post-cold war world. In the past, for example, Mr. Clinton's plea to the industrialized nations to open their markets to Eastern Europe might have commanded a respectful hearing; troubled by unemployment, the industrialized nations turned a deaf ear. 
 Unfortunately, Mr. Clinton and his team created problems of their own. The trip was marked by an informal clumsiness and lacked any theme or thread. He began inauspiciously with an odd, disengaged speech in Washington that seemed deliberately to ignore any foreign policy issues not directly related to trade and jobs -- even though subjects like Rwanda, Haiti, Bosnia and North Korea were sure to come up at the Naples meeting.
Later, in Naples, Mr. Clinton asserted that he saw no need to "overreact" to the dollar's decline; when the dollar immediately tumbled further, his staff, always on damage-control alert, hurried to explain that he had not ruled out measures to support it. At another point, he made a modest last-minute proposal for further trade liberalization. His surprised European colleagues rebuffed him. Mr. Clinton would have done better to consult them in advance, especially since an earlier, broader agreement has not yet been ratified.
But these bumbles and stumbles were not nearly as significant as his larger failure to see Naples as a chance to define -- for Americans as well as Europeans -- how today's tussles over exchange rates and trade agreements relate to the larger goals of reducing unemployment in the West and consolidating democracy and markets in the former Soviet empire. Moreover, Mr. Clinton might have used some of his time to coordinate with his allies on specific crises like Haiti and Rwanda, where there are sharp disagreements.
The issues Mr. Clinton tried to ignore forced their way onto the agenda anyway. On his first day in Europe, his own Pentagon upstaged him with leaks about commandos rehearsing to invade Haiti. Then Panama reneged on a plan to shelter refugees, forcing his traveling staff to scramble for explanations. The Naples gathering itself began under the shadow of the unexpected death of Kim Il Sung. And it closed with Boris Yeltsin sidestepping Mr. Clinton's calls to withdraw Russian troops from the Baltics by the end of next month.
So much for the illusion of an economics-oriented, photo-opportunity summit conference.
Elsewhere, the President got other issues just right, ably resisting the temptation to tell his hosts what they wanted to hear. In Riga, Latvia, he supported the sovereignty of the Baltic countries, while chiding their provocative treatment of Russians stranded inside their borders. In Warsaw, he made the most of NATO's newly formed Partnership for Peace, but rightly deferred the question of full NATO membership for Eastern Europe.
Overall, it was a journey of bits and pieces, none of which collected themselves into a satisfying whole. As such, it was another illustration of the discontinuity between policy and presentation that has plagued this Administration from the start.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Help the Poor Help Themselves

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As the founder and president of TechnoServe, a nonprofit, international development organization that has worked with the poor in the developing world for more than 25 years, I have learned some valuable lessons.
The lessons of a quarter-century of experience in Latin America and Africa helping the working poor establish and expand their own small businesses are the operating principles in what we call participatory development: helping people to help themselves. Here are the most important, which translate into any language and will work in America's cities as well as in the developing world. 
 First, never lead with money. The service or agency designed to help the poor through participatory development should not be in the business of giving away money, but sharing know-how and knowledge. The woman who styles hair out of her home, for example, needs not simply capital but business advice: a business plan, an advertising-marketing strategy and training in bookkeeping and accounting. She will then have the ability to manage her own business, as well as make it grow and prosper.
In addition, the relationship between the assisting agency and the beneficiary then becomes a partnership, rather than a handout. Both partners have a sense of pride in the relationship and the outcome.
Second, participants must show their commitment by having a stake in the project. As owners of the enterprise they must invest some of their own capital. This simple idea follows the principle that if people don't have a vested interest in something, they are less likely to see it through the often long and difficult road to success. TechnoServe will often wait months, even years, for the poor farmers of Africa and Latin America with whom we work to save the $10 or $20 required to start a new project.
Third, a new enterprise will have best results if owned by groups of people. People involved in a project share ideas, make up for individual weaknesses and support one another. By assisting a group of significant size, the development agency can also have the highest impact on the larger community. Such a venture will be more cost-effective, expand more readily, create more jobs and ultimately improve the lives of many more people in the neighborhood.
Empowering poor people overseas does not preclude helping the needy here at home. Both are necessary and possible. The key to success is fostering not dependency but a sense of participation and partnership between the agency and the poor. Once people have learned to run their own enterprise, they can go on by them
selves without further assistance. Those are the kind of success stories we'd like to see in Baltimore, as well as in Bolivia.
 
EDWARD P. BULLARD
Norwalk, Conn., July 5, 1994

HEADLINE: White House Says Growth Is Pushing the Deficit Down

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
Clinton Administration officials today reduced their forecast for this year's Federal budget deficit by $14.7 billion because stronger-than-expected economic growth has produced more than enough tax revenue to offset the cost to the Federal Government from higher interest rates.
But they cautioned that unless long-term interest rates fell to their levels of earlier this year, higher interest on the national debt would result in slightly higher deficits later in the decade. 
 Today's announcement of the revision was the latest in a series of estimates by Government and private economists that the Federal Government's finances are improving. The improvement is important because it means that the Federal Government can borrow less money, making it easier for businesses to borrow money instead to invest in new factories or offices.
Less deficit spending also means that the Federal Government is doing less to stimulate short-term economic growth. This in turn reduces the pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. The Federal Reserve has been worried that the economy is already growing so fast that it may overheat, fueling inflation, and it has responded by raising short-term interest rates four times this year.
 
White House Is Cautious
 Congressional Budget Office experts have been estimating for several weeks that the deficit for the current fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30, will fall as low as $200 billion.
But Leon E. Panetta, who remains the director of the White House Office of Management and Budget until Thursday, even though he has already taken his next job as White House chief of staff, was more cautious in announcing the Administration's new estimates at a White House press conference today. He predicted that the deficit for the current fiscal year would be $220.1 billion, compared with his February estimate of $234.8 billion.
Mr. Panetta suggested that the Administration should receive considerable credit for the shrinking deficit. But Republicans on Capitol Hill said underlying budget problems persisted and had merely been obscured by the extra tax revenue from economic growth.
"We have not solved any problems. We have temporary relief because of the business cycle," said Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, who is the ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee.
 
Deficit Could Rise
 Mr. Panetta also forecast today a deficit for the next fiscal year of $167.1 billion, down from his previous estimate of $176.1 billion. However, Office of Management and Budget documents distributed at the press conference, but not discussed in detail by Mr. Panetta, predicted that the deficit would rise to $207.4 billion by 1999, more than the office's previous estimate of $201.2 billion.
All these estimates excluded the budgetary effects of whatever health care legislation may emerge from Congress this year.
Alice M. Rivlin, the budget office's deputy director and Mr. Panetta's designated successor as director, said that in addition to extra tax revenue from higher than expected economic growth, the Administration had also benefited from lower than expected spending on Medicaid programs. The reasons for the lower spending are unclear, because the states, which run Medicaid programs using Federal money, have not reported why the cost of these programs is not rising quite as quickly as expected this year, she added.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alice M. Rivlin, the designated successor to the budget director, Leon E. Panetta, at left, helped present the Clinton Administration's cautious ly optimistic economic projections yesterday at a White House briefing. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE SUPREME COURT: THE NOMINEE;
Breyer Has Opportunity To Recount His Story Account Is Enthusiastic and Thorough

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
Judge Stephen G. Breyer today began the process of defining himself for the Senate Judiciary Committee and the public, neither of which is likely ever again to hear him discuss his life and thoughts at such length.
There is no doubt that Judge Breyer will be confirmed as a Supreme Court Justice, as senators of both parties emphasized in welcoming him to a confirmation hearing that was sometimes lighthearted, sometimes ponderous and occasionally revealing of the nominee's tastes and values. 
 "I know this isn't a classroom," Judge Breyer, a part-time Harvard law professor, said at one point. "I don't like to be professorial, frankly." But he was often very much the professor, plunging enthusiastically into discussions of doctrine and cases at the slightest hint of interest from a senator.
His description of one Supreme Court property-rights decision was so vivid and his pleasure in recounting it so evident that had the opinion not been written 72 years ago by Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes, it might well have been a case Judge Breyer himself had worked on during his days as a Supreme Court law clerk.
He was still the cautious nominee, however, keeping most answers at a level of generality that guarded against expressing a view on issues that might come before the Court.
Typically, he would give a general description of an area of law, followed by a description of the issues in that area on which there is general agreement, followed by a description of what he called the "gray areas" on which the Supreme Court might be asked to rule and about which he could say no more. Questions with broad potential implications got narrowly focused answers.
 
Raises Role of Congress
 Asked whether statistics could appropriately be used to attack the death penalty as racially discriminatory -- a subject of heated dispute in the crime bill now before Congress -- Judge Breyer said: "There are statistics and there are statistics. I don't think there's an absolute rule that bars the use of statistics where they are reliable and prove a legal point." He emphasized that the matter was a policy judgment for Congress to make and for the courts to enforce.
Judge Breyer was also well-schooled in the deferential tone expected of nominees who come before Senate committees -- even this nominee who once served as chief counsel of this very committee and who within minutes of taking his seat this morning heard himself praised for his academic accomplishments, his foreign language skills and his interest in cooking and bird-watching.
"If I am lucky and if you find me qualified," he began one answer, and none of the laudatory senators appeared to find that note of humility misplaced.
The realities of the modern confirmation hearing also required Judge Breyer, who has served since 1981 on the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Boston, to emphasize the less ethereal and intellectual sides of his personality.
"My ideas about people do not come from libraries," he said, recalling that his mother had tried to pry him from his books when he was a child. "Of course she was right."
 
Praise for His Labors
 And members of the Judiciary Committee appeared thrilled to have learned, from Judge Breyer's committee questionnaire, that he spent a summer during high school digging ditches for a California utility. Praise for the lawyer's son who sampled physical labor became a kind of mantra as the hearing progressed.
Senator Strom Thurmond, the 91-year-old South Carolina Republican, had an opening statement noting that "Judge Breyer has come a long way from the summer in 1958 he spent as a ditch digger." Even for Mr. Thurmond, who usually reads his prepared material verbatim, this was a bit much. He amended his statement to note simply that Judge Breyer had once worked as a ditch digger.
In his testimony, Judge Breyer offered a down-to-earth description of his judicial philosophy. The purpose of the Constitution, he said, is "to guarantee people the rights that will enable them to lead lives of dignity." When Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, the committee's ranking Republican, asked him to agree that a judge's only job was "applying the law," Judge Breyer would not accept that formula without a qualification.
"Of course that's true," he said. But it is not always so clear what the law is in the "vast, open areas" in which the Supreme Court operates, he said, adding, "There are such good arguments on both sides of such important policy issues." The purpose then, Judge Breyer said, was to "find the correct solution, the helpful solution consistent with the underlying human purpose."
"I'm in favor of moderate judges," he said at one point to Senator Thurmond in discussing membership on the United States Sentencing Commission.
Judge Breyer's humanistic description of his approach to antitrust law managed to pre-empt criticism from the one Senator, Howard M. Metzenbaum, who had expressed serious reservations in advance of the hearing. Even before Mr. Metzenbaum, an Ohio Democrat, began his questioning, Judge Breyer described antitrust law as "the policeman of the free enterprise system" with the primary mission of protecting consumers.
So Senator Metzenbaum's prepared statement, accusing Judge Breyer of seeing antitrust law only "in terms of abstract economics" in which "complicated charts and graphs replace individual justice," fell a bit flat by the time he read it. Senator Metzenbaum said he expected to vote for Judge Breyer in any event, urging the nominee to remember their colloquy once he sat on the Supreme Court. "Maybe the milk of human kindness will run through you and you won't be so technical," Senator Metzenbaum said.
 
Old Ties Important
 More important than any substantive issue was the personal relationship that Judge Breyer had established long ago with important committee members. Senator Alan K. Simpson, the sharp-tongued Wyoming Republican, said he remembered that Judge Breyer, in his role as counsel to the Judiciary Committee, was "courteous and fair to me as a freshman Senator, never judging or measuring things with a political yardstick."
Senator Simpson noted that Judge Breyer's son Michael, a Stanford University sophomore who sat behind his father in the hearing room, would he hiking through Wyoming later in the summer.
The Senator said he hoped Michael would enjoy himself, adding that while the son was hiking, "I'll be astride a horse."
"You'll be walking, I'll be riding," Senator Simpson said, leaving father and son looking a bit mystified.

A picture caption yesterday about Judge Stephen G. Breyer's testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee with a picture showing three members of the committee misidentified the Senator on the left in some editions. It was Senator Orrin G. Hatch, not Strom Thurmond.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bonds Show An Upturn

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Treasury bonds rose for the first time in a week yesterday as a Government report surprised investors with the news that inflation was nonexistent in June.
 The benchmark 30-year bond rose 13/32 , or $4.06 for each $1,000 bond, to yield 7.68 percent, four basis points lower than Monday. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. Bonds gained as much as 3/4 point after the inflation report. 
While there is now less pressure for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to contain inflation, many traders are concerned the falling dollar will discourage foreign investors from buying dollar-denominated assets such as bonds, limiting the market's advance.
 Earlier yesterday, the Labor Department said prices paid to producers in June were unchanged for the third month. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg Business News had predicted an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent for the month.
 Federal Reserve officials are "breathing a sigh of relief," said Alan McClymonds, a trader at CS First Boston, who added that he did not think the central bank's officials wanted to raise rates. "They're looking for a reason not to," he said.
 
Producer Prices Report
 The producer prices report is the first of four important reports on the economy scheduled for release this week. The June Consumer Price Index is due today, and tomorrow the Government is scheduled to release its report on June retail sales.
 The bond market's initial rally was reversed as the dollar tumbled to a post-World War II low against the Japanese yen. As the dollar recovered, the bond market advanced.
 The two-year note yield was 6.21 percent, down from 6.25 percent. The bond's yield was 6.3 percent when the Federal Reserve began raising rates Feb. 4. The record low yield is 5.77 percent, set on Oct. 15.
 As benign as the inflation report was, it was not enough to convince some bond investors, said Mr. McClymonds at CS First Boston. "We still go back to the reality of a weak dollar and the potential inflation pressures in the future," he said.
 The crumbling dollar makes it riskier to bet on which direction bonds will take, even in the face of economic reports that signal inflation is under control, said Steven Van Order, who helps manage $3.5 billion in fixed-income securities at Calvert Asset Management in Bethesda, Md.
 "If the dollar stays weak and people keep hiding from the 30-year bond, we could hit 8 percent by August," Mr. Van Order said. "It's the kind of summer that makes it difficult to take a vacation. It even makes it difficult to go down the hall to see someone." Even though the economy grew 3.4 percent in the first quarter and 7 percent in the last quarter of 1993, the Government's inflation statistics show little sign of rising prices, analysts said.
 Inflation "doesn't necessarily have to show up, because there's a lot of competitiveness out there" between businesses, said Kevin Flanagan, an economist at Dean Witter Reynolds. "Consumers are balking at higher prices."
 In another price report yesterday, the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta said its index of business activity rose to 18.1 in June, from 16.1 in May. Raw material prices paid fell to 29.4, from 33.6 in May, and the Atlanta Fed's index of prices received dropped to 4.5 last month, from 14.4 in May.

HEADLINE: Technology Issues Help Lift Stock Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Stock prices moved higher yesterday, fueled by a rally in high-technology issues, signs of a steadier dollar in Europe and a firmer bond market.
The rally in technology stocks was based largely on anticipation among investors of good quarterly earnings and by solid performances of stocks like the Chipcom Corporation and Seagate Technology, which both reported strong quarterly profits. Shares of Chipcom jumped up 7 1/8, to 46 1/2, while Seagate rose 1 1/4, to 24 5/8. Cisco Systems rose 1 1/4, to 24, and Intel was up 1 5/8, to 61 3/4. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.62 points, to 3,704.28, while the Nasdaq composite index gained 9.76 points, to 719.35.
John H. Shaughnessy, senior vice president and director of research for Advest Inc., attributed the buying to expectations of and, in some cases, already good second-quarter earnings by small-capitalization stocks that had been beaten down lately.
"These small-cap stocks in many cases have been oversold and are ripe for recovery as they respond to strong earnings," Mr. Shaughnessy said.
"Markets could be setting up for a summer rally," he added. "And among the reasons to be positive are the dollar is oversold, no interest-rate hike is imminent and earnings are good."
Volume on the Big Board was brisk, with 266.3 million shares traded, up from 252.3 million shares traded on Tuesday. The number of stocks posting gains for the day outpaced losing issues by 1,155 to 912.
Stock prices were strong early yesterday, speeding past a slowly recovering bond market, while responding to favorable inflation data and stronger European stock markets that were reacting to an improving dollar, amid rumors of a coming increase in United States interest rates.
The second leg of this week's inflation data, yesterday's Consumer Price Index, showed that the trend during the last several months of limited price increases remained intact. The June C.P.I. came close to expectations, with an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent, both overall and excluding food and energy.
Dave Cohen, an economist for MMS International in San Francisco, said, "Increases in the core have fluctuated in the narrow 0.2 percent to 0.3 percent range in recent months, thereby showing little evidence of acceleration in the underlying trend in final goods prices, despite the run-up in various commodity prices that have peridocally unnerved the credit markets."
Anthony Ludovici, a senior vice president and senior investment analyst at Tucker Anthony Inc., said he was impressed with the breadth of the market all day as measured by the advancers and decliners.
"The basic cyclical stocks were the vanguard of the advance, led by motors and autos parts," Mr. Ludovici said. "And today, too, we saw rails also lead the Dow transport index, with Kansas City Southern in the forefront."
According to some traders, the Illinois Central Corporation is thought to be ready to buy Kansas City Southern's rail operations.
Some analysts say railroads are thriving, and their success stems from an economy that continued to expand in the second quarter. Investors are expecting to see profits after years of cost cutting.
Santa Fe Pacific, which is spinning off its gold subsidiary as of Sept. 30 and plans to merge with Burlington Northern, was up 3/8, to 19 5/8, in Big Board trading.
CBS, which will not pursue a merger with QVC after a competing bid was made for QVC by Comcast, rose 8, to 308. QVC rose 6, to 42, in heavy Nasdaq trading, on news of Comcast's $2.2 billion takeover bid. Comcast fell 1 1/2, to 15 1/8, in Nasdaq trading.
Astoria Financial rose 1 5/8, to 33, on news that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Fidelity New York F.S.B. for $160 million, or $29 for each Fidelity share. Fidelity rose 227/32 , to 2627/32 .
Regency Health Services fell 5 3/8, to 8 3/4, the largest net loser on the New York Stock Exchange. The nursing-home operator said its earnings were hurt by recent acquisitions and would fall below analysts' expectations for the rest of 1994. The company also said it would take $10 million in charges for the quarter.

HEADLINE: With Persuasion and Muscle, Black Caucus Reshapes Haiti Policy

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
In March, the 39 members of the Congressional Black Caucus in the House introduced a bill to tighten the economic embargo against Haiti, sever its commercial air links to the United States, halt the summary repatriation of Haitian refugees picked up at sea and block financial assets held in America by Haitian nationals.
The measure has not yet come up for a vote in Congress. But now it hardly matters. Virtually all its provisions have been adopted as President Clinton's policy toward Haiti. 
 "It was a blueprint for what was done in the coming months," said a Congressional staffer who closely follows Haiti. "This is what they rallied around and pushed for. And they got almost everything."
 
Growth of Black Caucus
 The Administration's adoption of the group's ideas is indicative of the political influence of the black caucus, whose numbers in Congress rose to 40 from 26 after the 1992 election. But in pushing the Administration to take more robust action on behalf of the ousted Haitian President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the caucus, in the eyes of some in Congress and the State Department, is leading the United States inexorably toward military intervention -- an issue that has divided the caucus itself.
From the dismissal in May of Lawrence A. Pezzullo as the Administration's special adviser on Haiti and his replacement by William H. Gray 3d, a former member of the caucus, to the warmer embrace of Father Aristide and the new-found reluctance of his detractors in the Administration to make their private doubts public, the caucus has played a key role in steering Haiti policy in the Administration.
Members of the caucus tend to describe its contribution to the Administration's Haiti policy in modest terms and to stress that others have also played a role.
 
A Role in Policy Change
 "We've made legislative suggestions in a number of areas and have had limited success in a number of areas," said Representative Donald M. Payne, a New Jersey Democrat and the highest-ranking black lawmaker on the House Foreign Affairs Committee. "I think we certainly have played a role in the changing of the policy."
But others say the influence of the caucus is more profound.
"The basic components of the black caucus approach -- the military is the problem, Aristide is the solution; we shouldn't move away from him even two inches; we should do nothing that smacks of any kind of alternative to Aristide, like work with a prime minister -- all that has been adopted," said a State Department official who requested anonymity.
One lawmaker who follows Haiti grumbled that Administration officials consult more with key members of the black caucus about the crisis than they do with the chairmen and ranking members of House and Senate committees with jurisdiction over foreign policy or Caribbean affairs.
But the solicitation of the views of the caucus and the appointment of Mr. Gray have failed to silence criticism of the Administration's policy by some caucus members. Last week, Representative Kweisi Mfume, Democrat of Maryland, the caucus chairman, termed the Administration's efforts "a policy of anarchy, one that changes by the moment."
Representative Robert Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat, suggested that the black caucus, having gotten much of what it wanted, is simply keeping the heat on. "It has been a spiral of influence," he said. "The President has listened and the voices have been raised. The President has responded and the voices have been raised further."
 
Hunger Strike by Robinson
 To be sure, the group cannot take credit alone for having altered Administration policy. It was a 27-day hunger strike by Randall Robinson, the director of the TransAfrica lobbying organization, that galvanized the public and the black caucus to place more pressure on Mr. Clinton to change his Haiti policy. Florida lawmakers and groups advocating the rights of refugees also played a role.
Still, the caucus's interest in the issue kept it alive when many of the caucus members' colleagues in Congress and some in the Administration might have let it die. Its accusations of racism in the treatment of Haitian refugees got the attention of a Democratic President.
The caucus's 40 votes -- 39 in the House and one in the Senate -- are an unspoken part of the calculation. While there has been no explicit quid pro quo, some in Congress and the Administration are counting on the caucus to provide critical support for domestic initiatives like health care, welfare reform and the crime bill.
But while the caucus has helped push Mr. Clinton into a more confrontational stance against the military rulers who overthrew Father Aristide, the black lawmakers have yet to agree among themselves on the most critical question when it comes to Haiti: whether military force should be used to restore democracy.
Some, like Representatives Major Owens of New York and Maxine Waters of California, have advocated armed intervention to restore Father Aristide. Others, like Representative Ron Dellums of California, the chairman of the Armed Services Committee, have voiced strong reservations on the use of military force.
Indeed, the bill drafted by the caucus in March deliberately avoided taking a position on an armed invasion of Haiti because the caucus could not reach a consensus, Mr. Dellums acknowledged during a debate on the House floor in May.
"We have not been, generally speaking, a group that supported gun-barrel diplomacy," said Mr. Payne. "But we are seeing a changing world. I don't think any of the members of the caucus initially supported military intervention and there are still some who oppose it. But I do think the majority of the members are slowly moving toward the point where it might be the only solution at the present time."

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE HOSPITALS;
Drive Is Opened to Fight Cuts in Medicare

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
Hospital lobbyists today began what they described as an all-out fight to prevent Congress from making the kind of large cuts in the growth of Medicare that several committees have proposed as a way to finance health coverage for people who are uninsured.
Hospitals have generally supported President Clinton's effort to guarantee health insurance for all Americans, and they have endorsed many of his specific proposals to redesign the health care system. 
 But leaders of the American Hospital Association, the main lobby for the industry, said today that several Congressional panels, particularly the House Ways and Means Committee, had gone too far in tapping Medicare as a source of money to pay for new benefits and new coverage.
 
Mobilizing Hospital Workers
 Medicare finances health care for 36 million elderly and disabled people. The cost to the Government is $160 billion this year.
The lobbyists said they would mobilize hospital employees and trustees across the country, urging members of Congress to spare Medicare and find other sources of revenue. In many Congressional districts, hospitals are among the largest employers.
Richard J. Davidson, president of the American Hospital Association, said: "In its quest for universal coverage, Congress looks to Medicare as a huge source of money, a bottomless well. The Medicare cuts in the Ways and Committee bill are a farce. If Congress is serious enough to make a commitment to assure universal coverage, it should be serious enough to make the tough choices to pay for it.
 
Warning on Care
 "Members of Congress ought to quit kidding themselves. You cannot finance health care reform on the backs of hospitals and doctors who serve the elderly, or else you will harm the quality of care."
Representative Pete Stark, the chief architect of the Ways and Means Committee bill, rejected these complaints. "Hospitals," he said, "have always looked at Medicare as a bottomless pit to pay them.
"I'm dumbfounded by the hospitals' terribly narrow and parochial attitude," said Mr. Stark, a California Democrat who is chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health. "One would think they might have some interest in the health of the community at large and not just in their own self-interest. This bill is a good deal for hospitals that are well-managed. It's not too good a deal for hospitals that want to make a huge profit off sick people."
The Ways and Means Committee would slice $110 billion, or 10 percent, from projected Medicare spending over five years. Nearly two-thirds of the savings would come from Medicare payments to hospitals. President Clinton proposed Medicare savings of $103 billion, including $70 billion from hospitals. The Senate Finance Committee bill would cut about half that amount.
The House bill would set annual limits on Medicare spending, and it would gradually slow the growth of the program, so that after four or five years Medicare would not be allowed to grow any faster than the economy as a whole.
 
Shifts in Kinds of Care
 Despite strenuous efforts by Congress to rein in medical costs, limiting doctors' fees and payments to hospitals for specific procedures, Medicare now grows more than twice as fast as the economy. Part of the reason is that medical prices have been rising rapidly, and the type of care provided to elderly patients is more complex than it was just a few years ago.
The Ways and Means Committee bill sets Medicare spending limits for 10 separate categories of services. Thomas P. Nickels, a lobbyist for the hospital association, said these limits would perpetuate recent trends.
Services that have been growing fast in recent years, like home health care and nursing home care, would get a bigger and bigger share of Medicare spending, he said, while services like hospital care, which has been growing slowly, would get a dwindling share of the total.
Hospital lobbyists are telling members of Congress that under the Ways and Means Committee bill, Medicare would pay only 67 cents for every dollar of costs incurred in caring for patients admitted to hospitals, down sharply from 95 cents at present.
"Losses of this size cannot be made up through increased efficiency," said Mr. Davidson of the hospital association.
Clinton Administration officials and many Democrats in Congress say hospitals should be able to absorb cutbacks in Medicare because people who are now uninsured will have coverage in the future and can therefore pay their hospital bills.
Carmela S. Dyer, a vice president of the American Hospital Association, acknowledged that universal coverage would generate new revenue for hospitals. But, she said, the care provided free to people who are uninsured is much less significant than the proposed cutbacks in the Medicare program, which accounts for 40 percent of hospital revenue.
Moreover, she said, in the future, it will be difficult for hospitals to offset Medicare's underpayments by increasing charges to private patients, as they have done in the past.
 
Market Forces at Work
 "Market forces are already reducing our ability to shift costs," she said, and the Ways and Means Committee bill would virtually eliminate such cost-shifting because it would impose stringent new constraints on private health spending.
In the debate over health costs, hospitals have generally avoided the wrath of White House officials and members of Congress, who were more likely to criticize insurance companies and drug manufacturers. But if hospital lobbyists continue to mobilize their forces at the local level, they will immensely complicate the work of President Clinton and his allies in Congress, who want to squeeze large sums of money from Medicare.

HEADLINE: Berlin Journal;
Clinton at the Brandenburg Gate: Mixed Reviews

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BERLIN, July 13

 BODY:
Born 24 years ago in what was then Communist East Berlin, Oliver Blasing was standing on a street crossing just east of the Brandenburg Gate on Tuesday, cheering President Clinton. Mr. Blasing had taken a day off from his studies at western Berlin's Technical University, and braved a beating summer sun to listen to a speech by Mr. Clinton on his first visit to Berlin.
And yet somehow, Mr. Blasing said afterward, it was all so familiar. He said that seven years earlier, in June 1987, he had stood on the very same spot waiting for another American President to speak. 
 Mr. Blasing, then a young East German Army recruit, had defied the orders of the Communist leadership and, together with about 300 other East Germans, gathered on the eastern side of the gate to hear President Reagan, the nemesis of the Communist world, while he addressed Berliners from a podium that had been set up on the western side of the gate, facing east.
Mr. Blasing recalled how frustrated Communist police officials set up huge loudspeakers, blaring march tunes, to drown out the voice of Mr. Reagan as he appealed to the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev: "Mr. Gorbachev, open this gate! Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall!"
Mr. Blasing glanced toward Mr. Clinton's platform, and the opened gate behind it, that was once barred by the Berlin wall.
"Never in my life," he said, "did I think it would happen."
Now, he said, he had returned "to see another American President live."
"I like him," he said of Mr. Clinton. "Let's hope he can just continue what his predecessors started."
Many Berliners who sized up Mr. Clinton as he spent a hectic 24 hours in their city on Tuesday came away liking him -- the natural manners, the youthful freshness.
"Somehow he's friendlier than Reagan," said Klaus Diekmann, a 43-year-old tax official who turned out for the Brandenburg Gate event. "More youthful, less threatening."
Eastern Berliners especially, accustomed for decades to the gerontocracy of Communist rule, appeared particularly struck, at times even unsettled, by Mr. Clinton's boyishness. At the same time, many Berliners expressed a sense that the world Mr. Clinton governed in had grown more complicated, lacking the old simple delineations like the Berlin wall.
"He's very sympathetic, very natural," said Annamarie Mothsche, a schoolteacher in her 40's from eastern Berlin. "You know, we are used to a very different idea of politicians. Very stiff, and dignified."
"But somehow," she continued, "you think to yourself, can he ever achieve what he wants?"
Uwe Zimmermann, a 39-year-old insurance salesman, said approvingly that Mr. Clinton "sort of reminds you of Kennedy," and that he admired the President's exhortation to German youth for civil courage, against racism and religious hatred. But Mr. Zimmermann added critically that Mr. Clinton had been "very vague."
"I think a lot of people thought he'd be more specific," Mr. Zimmermann went on.
Peter Schneider, a well-known Berlin writer, said: "For Berliners, it's always fun to have an American President here. And surely they enjoyed it."
"But of course the historic role is different," said Mr. Schneider, the author of a best-selling book about the wall. "The wall is torn down, unification is taking place."
Throughout Berlin, remarkable symbols of reunification abound, and nowhere are they more evident than around the Brandenburg Gate. The subway stop on Pariser Platz, in front of the gate, is open again, and several stops up the line is Potsdamer Platz, where bulldozers are shaping what will soon be, arguably, Europe's biggest construction site, to revive what used to be the bustling crossroads of the city in its old imperial days, but was long cut in half by the wall. But there are also the signs of malaise.
A wave of violence against foreigners has not stopped. A deep economic divide splits east and west, driving many eastern Berliners to vote again in recent elections for the old Communists. The booing and hissing that met Chancellor Helmut Kohl as he introduced Mr. Clinton testifed to the political discord.
Thus, many Berliners met with skepticism the urgings of the President for a broader role for reunited Germany on the world stage.
The political scientist Arnulf Baring of Berlin's Free University cautioned that the Germans are too caught up in the ragged struggle to unify the nation politically, economically and psychologically to heed Mr. Clinton's call.
"Clinton is urging the Germans to take the peoples of East and Central Europe under their wing," Mr. Baring said. "But this does not fit the present frame of mind."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Turmoil in Television
The collapse of the CBS-QVC merger leaves CBS vulnerable to a possible takeover and ill-prepared to deal with pressing problems like restive affiliated stations and a program lineup in need of repair, television industry executives and analysts said. [Page A1.]
Comcast's Brian and Ralph Roberts tried to explain to Wall Street their buyout bid that scuttled the CBS-QVC deal. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Rose 0.3% in June

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
Consumer prices climbed three-tenths of 1 percent in June, as increases for cars, gasoline, air fares and clothing more than offset moderation in housing, the Labor Department reported today.
The rise, which closely matched expectations, meant that inflation as gauged by the Consumer Price Index ran at the same 2.5 percent pace during the spring quarter as it had during the first three months of the year. The rate for 1993, the third straight full year of diminished inflation, was 2.7 percent. 
 However, unlike Tuesday's surprisingly favorable report that prices at the producer level were unchanged last month, the C.P.I. data provided little comfort to the majority of analysts, who say that inflation -- higher in June than in either April or May -- has begun a gradual upswing, and that the Federal Reserve will need to raise short-term interest rates again by mid-August.
 
Upward Pressure Seen
 The bond market showed little reaction to today's consumer price report, and interest rates ended the day slightly lower. [Page D9.]
Characterizing the latest figures as "neither good nor bad, near-term," Allen Sinai of Lehman Brothers Global Economics, predicted inflation would quicken during the second half of the year. "Rising oil and energy prices, a still-firm economy settled in a 'full-employment zone,' rising industrial commodity prices and a lower dollar all will impart an upward tendency on inflation," he said.
Indeed, prices of new vehicles rose six-tenths of 1 percent last month, apparently because the sinking dollar led to higher prices for imports, and that, in turn, allowed domestic competitors to push up their own prices.
Prices in the metropolitan New York area rose by the same three-tenths of 1 percent that prevailed nationally in June and were 2.3 percent higher over the latest 12 months. The Philadelphia area posted a nine-tenths of 1 percent advance, mainly reflecting summer electricity rates and out-of-town lodging for residents on vacation.
In a related report, the department calculated that average weekly earnings, fell 1 percent in June following a five-tenths of 1 percent increase in May. This resulted from a six-tenths of 1 percent decline in average weekly hours coupled with a one-tenth of 1 percent decline in average hourly earnings and the loss of buying power from inflation.
The so-called core C.P.I., which excludes the volatile food and energy sectors, rose three-tenths of 1 percent for the second straight month, lifting the 12-month rate to 2.9 percent.
"Inflation really is fairly steady around 3 percent," said Patrick C. Jackman, a Labor Department official, noting that it had been the one-time villains of food and energy that had kept the index lower lately.
 
Commodities on Upswing
 Various analysts took note today of the fact that in contrast to the usual pattern, prices of commodities have risen faster than those of services for each of the last two months. Services rose more than commodities in 22 of the latest 25 full years.
Moreover, Joel Popkin, a Washington consultant and price specialist, said the gap between core commodities and core services other than energy had become unusually narrow during the first half of 1994, as goods accelerated and services decelerated. That development is particularly noteworthy because foreign competition is less a factor in holding down the price of services.
And while some analysts might be unnerved by quickened rises for commodities, the services component is twice as large and thus a larger force for price restraint, others said.
Mr. Popkin, in fact, expressing concern that the economy was not strong enough to withstand the combined contractionary effects of both fiscal and monetary policy, predicted that the next move by the Fed would be to cut interest rates, not to raise them.
 
Housing Edges Up
 Food prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month, the same as in May, while housing edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent with the aid of lower prices for natural gas and cable television.
The rise in apparel, six-tenths of 1 percent, was described as mainly a rebound from discounting that occurred earlier than usual this year.
Transportation provided many of the heftiest increases, with the cost of new vehicles up six-tenths of 1 percent, used cars up 1.2 percent, automobile finance charges up 3.4 percent and gasoline up five-tenths of 1 percent (2.4 percent before seasonal adjustment).
Airline fares rose 3 percent following a record 5.4 percent May drop that reflected Memorial Day promotions.
Medical costs rose four-tenths of 1 percent for the second straight month and now stand 4.6 percent above the level of June 1993, the report showed.
Before rounding, the C.P.I. for All Urban Consumers rose 0.2708192 in June, an increase that if maintained and compounded over 12 months would produce an annual inflation rate of 3.3 percent.
The index now stands at 148.0, meaning that an array of goods and services that cost $10 in the 1982-84 reference period now costs $14.80. The value of the 1982-84 dollar is now 67.6 cents.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Consumer Prices" track percent change, month to month, seasonally adjusted, from July 1993 though June 1994. Also shown in the Consumer Price Index in the U.S. for June 1994 along with the percent change from the previous month and year for the entire nation and ten major metropolitan areas. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics) (pg. D9)

HEADLINE: A New Report Suggests U.N. Consolidate

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 13

 BODY:
A new, privately commissioned report issued today suggests the United Nations should create a common headquarters for the General Assembly, the Secretariat and all its specialized agencies as the United Nations' founders originally envisaged.
The report, titled "Renewing the United Nations System," was financed by the Ford Foundation and written by two former senior United Nations officials, Sir Brian Urquhart and Erskine Childers. It also recommends radical reform of the International Monetary Fund and other aid organizations to mount an attack on the world's economic inequalities, which have left 80 percent of the world's wealth in the hands of 20 percent of its population. 
 The report recalls that the United Nations founders and the first meeting of the General Assembly both recommended that the United Nations group all its agencies in a common seat instead of spreading them around the world's capitals as it has done.
It suggests returning to this idea in the interests of efficiency and cutting costs with a single site for the United Nations Secretariat, the General Assembly and such agencies as the World Health Organization, the Food and Agricultural Organization, the International Labor Organization and the International Monetary Fund, which are currently in Geneva, Rome, Vienna and Washington.
 
Site Not Recommended
 While it does not say where such a headquarters should be, Geneva and Bonn, once the German Government moves to Berlin, are both mentioned as possibilities. But Sir Brian argued today that there is a strong case for grouping all United Nations agencies in New York to bolster American support for the organization.
The report, which concentrates on improving the United Nations economic and social activities and does not deal with peacekeeping or Security Council matters, says all United Nations development work, including Unicef and the United Nations Development Fund, should be consolidated into a single new United Nations Development Authority.
It also recommends abolishing the I.M.F.'s present voting system, which keeps control of the fund in the hands of the richest countries, and it calls for the creation of new low-interest lending to help the poorest countries.
Copies of the report are available for free from the Ford Foundation, 320 East 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10017. Telephone: (212) 573-5000.

HEADLINE: Hong Kong's Governor Says China Undermines Colony

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, July 13

 BODY:
At times battered by ferocious criticism from Beijing, and at times ignored, the Governor of Hong Kong vigorously defended his program of local democratization today and lashed out at the Chinese Government for undermining confidence in the colony in the three years before Britain surrenders sovereignty.
Mixing sarcasm with passion, anger with fervor, the Governor, Christopher Patten, placed blame for the growing nervousness among many people in Hong Kong about China's looming takeover squarely on Beijing's leaders. 
 In an interview in his spartan office in the grand Governor's residence on a hill overlooking the business district, the man who is probably Britain's last governor here said confidence in the colony could only be assured by Beijing.
"I have never sought to deny that they can come in and throw out the legislative council, the directly elected local government and bodies that have been created," Mr. Patten said. "I don't think that will be widely regarded as a very effective way of winning people's minds and hearts. And I think the rest of the world will inevitably see China's assumption of international responsibilities very much through the prism of how it deals with Hong Kong and how it behaves in Hong Kong."
 
Broader Democratic Rights
 Two weeks ago, Hong Kong's legislative council, the partly elected law-making body, approved the Governor's proposal to broaden democratic rights in the colony before China assumes control. His plan, loudly attacked by Beijing, will increase the number of directly elected seats on the council and expand electoral participation for those seats that are indirectly elected.
China has declared that it will dissolve the elected council, and Mr. Patten said such statements demonstrated Beijing's shortsightedness and ignorance of Hong Kong.
Referring to the document, signed by both Britain and China, that is to serve as a sort of constitution for Hong Kong after the assertion of Chinese rule, Mr. Patten said: "The Joint Declaration says we should have an executive who is accountable to the legislature and that the legislature should be composed through elections. It doesn't say fair elections because I don't think anyone seriously believed that we should sign up to elections which, as it were, were sculpted by Mayor Daley."
"It seems preposterous to argue you could have sham elections to the legislature which makes Hong Kong's laws and still have the fundamentals of the rule of law. And it's the rule of law which provides the unique spark in Hong Kong. We have spectacular economic success because of the combination of Shanghainese, Cantonese entrepreneurialism and the rule of law. Take away the rule of law and I think a great deal else unravels."
 
A Voice for the People
 Appointed Governor of Hong Kong in 1992 after losing his parliamentary seat, Mr. Patten, now 48, has alone among the colony's long line of governors insisted that the people be given a voice in their own future, a policy that has pitted him against the Beijing Government. In recent days, a series of articles and statements by Chinese officials have suggested that Beijing's rule here will be even more intrusive than many people have believed.
This week, a Chinese Communist Party propaganda official threatened the owner of a new newspaper here, The Eastern Express, for its critical coverage of China. The official, Huang Xinhua, declared that Hong Kong journalists should "be wise," and "act in line with the circumstances."
"Take these words to C. K. Ma," the owner of The Express, the official said. "Tell him to watch out."
Although confidence in Hong Kong is soaring among foreign investors, bankers and financial services groups, there are growing signs of anxiety among Hong Kong's citizens. This week, more than 42,000 people submitted applications for the last 13,000 British passports that are to be granted to Hong Kong residents. Even some of this colony's most prominent business executives, men who have publicly expressed support for China, have been quietly applying for British passports for themselves and their families, government officials said.
Mr. Patten said confidence in Hong Kong was not necessarily automatic.
"I think that a responsibility which China and this government have is to give people as much reassurance about the future as possible because inevitably from time to time people will be looking for it," the Governor said. "But the reassurance has above all to come from China's deeds."
For more than a year, talks between Britain and China over the terms of the colony's hand-over have been stalled, in part because of Mr. Patten's push toward democratization and in part because the Chinese Government found Hong Kong's approach to financing a new, $16.5 billion airport unacceptable. Those talks have now resumed, but with a warning by China that all of Mr. Patten's political reforms will be scrapped after it regains control of the colony.
 
A Down-to-Earth Style
 The Governor, who has wooed the people of Hong Kong with a down-to-earth style, lashed out at Beijing's threats and with Beijing's sympathizers in the colony, many of whom are leading lights in business.
"This is one of the most sophisticated economic communities in the world, well traveled, well educated, hugely successful economically," he said. "There are some people who think that it's outlandish that they want to decide how their kids should be educated, who should collect the dustbins, how much of their taxes should go on housing rather than the health service. I mean it's crazy."
"What we do have to do now," he concluded, "is to try to convince the business community that accountable government and the beginnings of democratization aren't a threat to 5 1/2 percent growth, low taxes, big surpluses and a pro-business ethic in government.
"I hope we will be able to make at least some progress in convincing Chinese leaders that this hugely precious community, representing as it does 23 percent of Chinese GNP, succeeds not just because of some capitalist equation but because its way of life helps to sustain its prosperity as well as its prosperity helping to sustain its way of life."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Christopher Patten, Governor of Hong Kong, defended his democratization plan, at the Governor's Mansion. (John Giannini for The New York Times)
