HEADLINE: THE SUPREME COURT: THE HEARING;
Cheerful Court Nominee And Cordial Senate Panel

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
Judge Stephen G. Breyer, who seems headed for easy confirmation to the Supreme Court, today painted a broad picture for the Senate Judiciary Committee of his views on the death penalty, freedom of religion and how he goes about the job of being a judge.
In his second day of testimony before the committee, Judge Breyer also elaborated on his earlier defense of his participation in pollution cases as a Federal judge. At the time, he faced great financial losses from his investment in an insurance syndicate suffering financial losses from pollution lawsuits. Judge Breyer, who on Tuesday sought to pre-empt any criticism of the issue with a statement to the committee, faced his first questioning on the subject today. 
 He told Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, that he was confident that he did not violate either the law or judicial ethics canons when he participated in eight pollution cases while he was a shareholder in a Lloyd's of London insurance syndicate.
Judge Breyer said he had an elaborate system in place to ward off potential conflicts. "I have three screening systems, now four, to make certain that I never sit on a case in which any firm in which I have an investment -- including Lloyd's, including that syndicate, including any part of Lloyd's -- is a party in that case," he said. The system he described involved having his cases screened by clerks and secretaries and finally himself, and if anything seems questionable, "bells go off in my mind."
 
More TV Urged for Court
 In a day of wide-ranging topics, Judge Breyer also said he was open to expanding the televising of Federal court proceedings to help educate the public about the law, but he declined to say whether he had watched any of the televised preliminary hearing for O. J. Simpson.
In a colloquy with Senator Hank Brown, Republican of Colorado, Judge Breyer seemed to be initially unaware that he was veering close to discussing the underlying legal issues in a sex-harassment suit brought against President Clinton. In discussing immunity for Government officials, he consulted a pocket-sized edition of the Constitution and joked about whether he could recall a precise quote from Judge Learned Hand about immunity.
But in the middle of the discussion with Senator Brown over whether a President is immune from a civil lawsuit for private behavior, Judge Breyer sat up in his chair, seeming to suddenly realize that the legal concepts he was cheerfully discussing might apply to the lawsuit brought against Mr. Clinton by Paula Corbin Jones.
Judge Breyer then, just as cheerfully, declined to go into the matter further.
Despite the debate over the Lloyd's issue, Judge Breyer, who is currently the chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Boston, faces no threat to his confirmation as the nation's 108th Justice of the Supreme Court. Several members of the Judiciary Committee spoke to him today as though he were about to be sworn in. Senator Paul Simon, an Illinois Democrat, for example, urged Judge Breyer to make certain that he stayed in contact with ordinary people after he joined the Supreme Court.
 
Link to Ordinary People
 When Judge Breyer said one way he did that was through his wife, Joanna Hare Breyer, who counsels children terminally ill with cancer and their families, Senator Simon urged him to do more. He told him to reach out "to people who are unemployed, who are hurting in our society."
Throughout the day, Judge Breyer offered his views on how emotional a judge should be in writing an opinion, when a judge should dissent and why it is important to achieve consensus on a judicial panel.
When asked if he would be a voice for the least fortunate in society, as was Justice Harry A. Blackmun, the man he would replace, Judge Breyer replied that he disliked emotional court opinions.
He said he had once received wise advice from Judge John Minor Wisdom, a renowned Federal appeals court judge. "He said if you feel you want to write a purple passage because you feel so strongly, write it and don't use it because people want your result and are not necessarily interested in your feelings," Judge Breyer said.
He said that consensus on a judicial panel like the Supreme Court is important because "law is a set of opinions and rules that lawyers have to understand, lower court judges have to understand, and eventually the labor union, the business, small business, everyone else in the country has to understand how they are supposed to act or not act according to law."
 
Seeker of Consensus
 For that reason, he said, he has discouraged dissents on his court unless they involved important points of principle.
Asked flatly by Senator Specter if he believed the death penalty might be imposed without violating the Constitution's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment, Judge Breyer replied: "Yes. I think that is settled law."
But he said, "That settled law is surrounded by what I think of as a cluster of less-settled matters," like what age a defendant must be for the death penalty to be imposed, the type of crime and the procedures of the case.
On the subject of freedom of religion, Judge Breyer's answers over the last two days seem to have caused mild consternation among some of the panel's conservative Republican members. He has talked about the wall of separation between church and state, a metaphor that some conservatives dislike because of its suggestion of a firm barrier.
He said the great religious wars of three centuries ago were fought over the right of people to pass on their beliefs to their children. It was therefore not surprising, he said, that controversy over the issue increased when it involved schools.
Judge Breyer is expected to complete his testimony before the committee on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Bosnian Serbs Confer With Britain and France on Peace Plan

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 13

 BODY:
The leader of Bosnia's Serbian nationalists said today that his faction's parliament would decide on Monday whether to accept an internationally backed proposal to end the Bosnian war, but the Serbian leader hinted that in his opinion the "take it or leave it" plan should be rejected.
The remarks by the nationalist leader, Radovan Karadzic, came after a meeting with the Foreign Ministers of Britain and France, Douglas Hurd and Alain Juppe. 
 The peace proposal was drawn up by diplomats from the so-called "contact group" countries -- the United States, Britain, France, Germany and Russia -- who set a deadline of Tuesday for the Bosnian Serbs and the Muslim-led Bosnian Government to accept or reject it. It would require the Bosnian Serbs to surrender about a third of the territory they have seized since the Bosnian war began in April 1992. The Serbs now hold 70 percent of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
More objectionable to the Serbs now, however, are elements of the plan that would legally preserve the existence of Bosnia and Herzegovina as a sovereign state.
In their 90-minute meeting at the Bosnian Serbs' headquarters in Pale, Mr. Hurd reportedly told Mr. Karadzic that rejection of the plan would be a "choice for war and disaster."
"We were faced with a terrifying image of an extended and intensified war that might spread beyond the borders," Mr. Karadzic said. "We listened to all this, but we also said that this war grew out of the Serbs' fear of Muslim and Croatian domination and because of our refusal to accept an independent state of Bosnia and Herzegovina. We did not accept that state and we will not accept it in the future.
"If we are in any kind of relationship with them," Mr. Karadzic said, referring to the Bosnian Muslims and Croats, "it will only be as an internationally recognized state, and with this it will be possible to make a compromise. The international community has to fear war more than us, because we are already at war."
Earlier this month, Mr. Karadzic called the proposal a "humiliation" for the Bosnian Serbs.
In a meeting with the two Foreign Ministers in Sarajevo earlier in the day, Bosnian Government officials said they would recommend that their parliament accept the plan when it meets on Monday, but only if provisions for recognizing Bosnia's sovereignty and territorial integrity remain.
"About this there can be no discussion," Bosnia's Muslim President, Alija Izetbegovic, said. "The plan is bad, but all the other options are worse. If the Serbs accept the plan, they recognize Bosnia and Herzegovina. If they don't, the war will continue under significantly better conditions for us."
The so-called contact Group countries have warned that if the Serbs reject the plan the international arms embargo against Bosnia might be lifted. But Western diplomats admit that there is no consensus over what action should be taken if any of the warring sides turn it down.
Mr. Karadzic has reportedly been under pressure from Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, to accept the peace plan. International economic sanctions have hurt the economy of the Yugoslav federation, in which Serbia is dominant.
Mr. Milosevic is clearly eager to have the sanctions lifted. But Mr. Hurd said the Serbian President also refrained from giving the peace plan a clear endorsement in a meeting this evening in Belgrade.
In the event the Bosnian Serbs reject the peace plan, Mr. Izetbegovic called on Mr. Milosevic and the federal Yugoslav Army to allow the United Nations to place troops along Serbia's border with Bosnia, across which Bosnian Serbs receive most of their supplies.
The United Nations force in Bosnia has had a mandate to police the border between Bosnia and Serbia since 1992, but Belgrade has not permitted it to deploy troops.

HEADLINE: Japan's Radical Plan: Self-Serve Gas

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 13

 BODY:
A motorist arriving at a service station here is usually greeted by a phalanx of uniformed attendants shouting welcomes. They guide the car into position, wipe the windows, empty the ashtray, and check the tire pressure. If necessary, they halt traffic to usher the car back onto the road.
This is the type of pampering for which Japan, land of the bowing elevator ladies, is known. But it comes at a price: it helps push gasoline costs to nearly $4.50 a gallon, four times as much as in the United States. But now, a radical notion is creeping into Japan. Why not let consumers pump their own gasoline?
 
Called Fire Hazards
 Self-service stations are prohibited on the ground that they are a fire hazard, a particular danger in congested Japan. But with the Government vowing to deregulate the economy drastically, the prohibition on consumers pumping their own gas has become a symbol of what critics say are thousands of needless restrictions that raise consumers' costs. 
 "It's just a very typical example -- America and many other countries can and Japan cannot," said Mitsuru Shinozaki, a spokesman for a business group pushing deregulation.
But the self-service debate is also symbolic of how difficult deregulation will be to achieve against the fierce resistance of vested interests. A package of 279 deregulatory steps recently announced by the Government recommended only that self-service be studied.
The step is often portrayed as in the interests of consumers, who would see lower prices, and of American companies, which would find it easier to penetrate the Japanese market.
But Japanese drivers have not been clamoring for the opportunity to fill their own tanks. This is partly because consumer groups here are not active -- but also because drivers don't know if they want to.
Sugao Morioka, a spokesman for the Japan Automobile Federation, the equivalent here of the American Automobile Association, said that many of the organization's 10.4 million members, 16 percent of licensed drivers in Japan, had not been calling for self-service and that many would find self-service too difficult. "To introduce the self-service system, we need to train the users, probably in drivers' schools," he said.
 
No Benefit for Americans
 Nor will American companies necessarily benefit. Indeed, companies like Mobil and Exxon, which are already well entrenched here, have been opposing a broader set of proposals to deregulate the oil market.
Rather, the push for self-service has come from Japanese big business. With the rising yen making Japanese companies less competitive, they are trying to cut costs.
The press has also taken up the cause because self-service gasoline is an example of deregulation that is easy to understand -- though perhaps not too easy. Recently, one evening news program treated its presumably bewildered viewers to a report from Los Angeles in which a reporter demonstrated step by step how to fill one's own tank.
Opponents of self-service -- mainly gas station owners and the national Fire Defense Agency -- say that letting drivers handle the hoses will lead to fires.
 
Fires and Inefficiency
 "In the West, buildings are made of stone," said Yoshio Sasano, head of the National Federation of Petroleum Commercial Associations, which represents gas stations. "But in Japan, buildings are made of more flammable materials." He said that only 10 fires started each year at gas stations in Japan, compared with 750 annually in the United States.
Efficiency would also suffer, Mr. Sasano argued. Since "gasoline stands," as they are called here, are far smaller than in the West, cars would be crashing into one another without attendants to guide them, and the time it takes to fill 'er up and pay the bill would double.
Nor, opponents say, would self-service reduce prices much. Even proponents of self-service say that the most that could be saved would be about 75 cents a gallon.
But perhaps the biggest argument of all against self-service is economic. There are 60,000 gasoline stands in Japan, many of them mom-and-pop operations that can ill afford the investment to convert to self-service.
And service stations employ 400,000 of those uniformed, bowing ashtray emptiers. While deregulation might indeed be necessary to stimulate the formation of new businesses in the long run, in the short run the impact might very well be an increase in unemployment at a time when Japan is trying to pull out of a three-year-long economic slump.
There is something to all the arguments. Even in the United States, a handful of states, including New Jersey, and municipalities, including some in the New York area, prohibit self-serve gas stations for safety reasons. And filling stations in Japan are indeed quite tiny. In many, motorists can't pull up alongside the pumps because there are none -- at least not on the ground. To save space, the hoses descend from the ceiling.
Still, advocates of self-service say that fears of a towering inferno are overblown.
 
'Why Not Tokyo?'
 "You can see many self-service stations in the center of Los Angeles, San Francisco or New York." said Mr. Shinozaki, the spokesman for Japan's most powerful business group. "The Government claims people are so stupid they might spread gasoline all over the place. Why are people going to commit suicide? The Japanese regulatory system is more or less like maternalism."
Proponents of self-service say that consumers are not actively demanding it because they don't know what they are missing. A few years ago, consumers were not asking for discount stores either, and the prevailing wisdom was that the Japanese preferred high prices and high levels of service. But now that some entrepreneurs have introduced no-frills stores with lower prices, consumers have been flocking to them.
But a bigger change may be looming for Japan's petroleum industry: the liberalization of gasoline imports.
For a long time, Japan resisted importing gasoline and other petroleum products, preferring to build its industry by importing crude oil and refining it.
In the mid-1980's, the Lions Petroleum Company, a Japanese company, tried to import inexpensive gasoline from Singapore but was stopped by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. In 1986, imports of refined products were allowed, but only by companies that already had refineries in Japan. A Government advisory panel recently recommended permitting other gasoline imports starting in April 1996.
Japanese refiners could easily be undercut by cheaper imports. Since the first oil shock of the early 1970's, the Government has kept prices of home heating oil and industrial fuels low while allowing prices of gasoline, viewed as a luxury, to rise. Even today, gasoline is the only profitable refined product for Japanese oil companies, said Lalita Gupta, an analyst with UBS Securities in Tokyo.
 
Deregulating Service Stations
 There is also a move to deregulate gasoline stations. A rice dealer in the Nagoya area recently opened one selling gas at 20 percent under the national average. The renegade company, Kanare Beikoku, has attracted huge media attention because it began operations without the required license. That is because the company, which is believed to be buying excess gasoline from one or more refiners, declined to disclose its suppliers.
Critics say that the requirement that service stations identify their supplier allows the Government to bring pressure on entitites that try to cut prices too much. Government officials contend that the incident had been blown out of proportion. In the last few days the retailer did file and was granted a license.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE;
Study Raises Serious Doubts About Commonly Used Methods of Treating Back Pain

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

 BODY:
A study that examined the spines of people without back pain is casting serious doubt on the methods used to diagnose and treat people whose backs ache.
The study, led by Dr. Michael N. Brant-Zawadzki, a radiologist at Hoag Memorial Hospital in Newport Beach, Calif., used magnetic resonance imaging, or M.R.I., to examine the spines of 98 men and women who had no back pain. The researchers found that nearly two-thirds of the subjects had spinal abnormalities, including bulging or protruding disks, herniated disks and degenerated disks. A third had more than one abnormal disk. 
 The investigators concluded that in many cases it may be sheer coincidence -- not cause and effect -- when a person with back pain is found to have an abnormal disk. Nevertheless, experts say, the use of M.R.I., a popular and sensitive imaging method, often leads to unnecessary surgery.
The study is being published today in The New England Journal of Medicine, accompanied by an editorial by Dr. Richard Deyo, a specialist in internal medicine at the University of Washington in Seattle.
"I hope this study is very influential," said Dr. Deyo, whose research focuses on the outcome of treatment for back pain. Many doctors routinely use M.R.I.'s to diagnose back pain, he said. Misuse of the results this imaging method "is a bigger problem than physicians or patients realize," he said, adding, "The opportunity to be misled is substantial."
Dr. Robert Boyd, an orthopedic surgeon at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, said researchers did not understand why most people with back pain had symptoms of abnormalities.
 
Cost Put at $8 Billion
 The new study follows others that showed that no matter what methods doctors used to diagnose disk problems, there seemed to be no correlation between back abnormalities and back pain. X-rays, CT scans and, in some other studies, M.R.I. scans all showed disk abnormalities in a large percentage of people with no back pain.
"Most back pain is never explained," Dr. Boyd said. But he added that most back pain also went away by itself. "If you take 100 people with back pain and look at them again three months later, 98 of them will be better," he said. "Anything you do to treat them in those three months will be given credit for healing. Treaters begin to believe that what they are doing is the reason for the improvement. And patients believe it, too."
Back pain is second only to the common cold as a reason Americans visit their doctors, Dr. Brant-Zawadzki said. As many as 80 percent of the nation's citizens complain of aching backs at some time in their lives, and nearly a third have back pain at any given moment.
The annual cost of medical care for people with back pain is more than $8 billion, he said.
Since M.R.I. scans cost about $1,000 each, their overuse and misuse wastes health care dollars, medical researchers said.
"Too often, people try to use the M.R.I to make a diagnosis," said Dr. John Froymeyer, director of the McClure Musculoskeletal Research Center at the University of Vermont. "It misleads you often enough that you perform unnecessary surgery, and the results are not very good."
 
'Temptation' for Doctors
 Moreover, Dr. Froymeyer said, Americans have almost 10 times more spinal disk operations than people in other Western countries. Perhaps not coincidentally, there also are far more neurosurgeons and orthopedic surgeons in the United States, and many times more M.R.I. machines. For example, he said, there are more M.R.I. machines in Boston than in all of Canada.
Dr. Boyd attributed overuse of M.R.I.'s to "insecurity, threat of lawsuits, inexperience and the potential for economic gain."
Dr. Brant-Zawadzki said: "Certain physicians like to be able to explain to their patients why they're feeling what they're feeling. The temptation is there for doctors who are not sophisticated to be glib about disk abnormalities and patients' symptoms."
In all the years that doctors have been operating on people with back pain, there has been only one randomized controlled clinical trial comparing surgery to conservative treatment like bed rest and exercises, and that was done 20 years ago in Norway.
The study included patients with ruptured disks, Dr. Boyd said, and found that a year after the patients' problems were diagnosed, about 80 percent of those who had surgery were better, compared with half of those who did not have surgery. But four years after the study began, the patients who had had surgery were no different from those who were treated without it -- about 80 percent of both groups were better.
"Surgery doesn't put new backs in and it doesn't give better long-term results," Dr. Boyd said. "It is indicated when pain doesn't respond to conservative treatment and is clearly associated with nerve root compression. Then the results of surgery are excellent. Instead of waiting a year or two or three to get better, you can wake up from the operation and that bad leg pain is gone or much better."
But he added that only about 5 percent of people with back pain fell into this category.
 
Tests Often Unnecessary
 Dr. Froymeyer said M.R.I. scans could not even tell a surgeon where to operate. "These tests are to confirm clinical judgment, not to make a diagnosis," he said. "People need to understand that most of the time these tests do not need to be done unless there is some definite reason."
Asked if more M.R.I.'s are done than are needed, Dr. Boyd said his answer was "an unqualified yes." He said that although he would recommend M.R.I. scans for very few of the patients referred to him, "I don't see many patients who haven't already had two or three M.R.I.'s."
He added: "Some physicians won't even see a patient without getting an M.R.I. They will say, 'Get an M.R.I., send it to me, and I'll tell you if I want to see you.' "

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Economic Data Cause Little Stir

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The bond market reacted indifferently yesterday to a Government report showing a modest increase in consumer prices last month, and interest rates slipped only slightly.
The Treasury's 30-year bond rose 3/32 of a point, or 94 cents per $1,000 bond, and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, slipped to 7.67 percent, from 7.68 percent on Tuesday. 
 Shorter- and intermediate-term Treasury issues also showed relatively little change.
The three-tenth of 1 percent rise in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index was in line with expectations. So far this year, inflation as measured by the C.P.I. is running at an annual rate of 2.5 percent, compared with 2.8 percent for the first six months of 1993 and 2.7 percent for all of last year.
That level of inflation is not enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates for the fifth time this year, some investors said.
The Fed "must be pretty happy with what they've got going here," said Warren Schmalenberger, who manages $2.3 billion in bonds at Transamerica Fund Management in Houston. "I don't think we're going to have another rate increase very soon. It will be in the fall of the year, if we have one."
A stronger dollar also helped lift bond prices, traders and investors said, because it makes short-term dollar-denominated investments more attractive to international investors.
Some of the dollar's gains came amid unconfirmed rumors in the currency market that the Fed was planning to raise short-term rates by half to a full percentage point. But several traders said the dollar was overdue for a technical bounce after its recent sharp slide and that the rumors were an excuse for the rebound.
Indeed, there were indications that many bond investors do not expect the Fed to raise soon, since yields on short-term Treasury securities fell.
Even so, some investors argued that the Fed was still planning to raise rates.
"We're steadily showing a modest upward drift in prices," said Harvey Hirschorn, director of fixed-income research at Stein, Roe & Farnham in Chicago, which has about $7 billion in government bond investments. "That will persist," he said. "The sooner it moves, the better for the market."
John Ryding, an economist at Bear, Stearns & Company, said the June consumer prices report should not reassure bond investors because "it's a rear-view mirror."
"The issue for the bond is what the C.P.I. is going to do next," he said.
Rising inflation means the Federal Reserve will have no choice but to keep raising interest rates this year, Mr. Ryding said. "The process of disinflation is over, and the Fed has a lot more work to do.,"
The Consumer Price Index was the second of four reports this week on the economy's performance in June. Bonds rose on Tuesday in a week after the Government said producer prices were unchanged in June, surprising analysts who had expected a three-tenths of 1 percent increase.
Today, the Commerce Department is to report on June retail sales. In a survey, economists forecast that sales rose seven-tenths of 1 percent.
And tomorrow, the Federal Reserve will issue its report on the productivity of the nation's industry in June. Economists are forecasting a a rise in factory capacity 83.7 percent, not far from the 84 to 85 percent capacity associated with increased inflation.

HEADLINE: Trust Started by Tree Lover Gives Botanical Garden $15 Million

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH 

 BODY:
As a young woman, Mary Flagler Cary had an enduring admiration for trees. She photographed them. She delighted in planting arbors on the family's 2,000-acre Dutchess County estate in Millbrook, N.Y.
Now, more than a quarter century after her death, the philanthropy she created is giving $15 million, its largest gift ever, to the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The money is to sustain plant research and help young scientists pursue botanical studies in this country and abroad. 
 The gift from the Mary Flagler Cary Charitable Trust, to be announced today at a City Hall meeting with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, is the single largest gift for the sciences received by the botanical garden in its 103-year history.
It comes at a critical time, when Federal financing for research on plant biodiversity has been scaled back, said Dr. Brian M. Boom, vice president for botanical science. He also said competition for grant money was intensifying "because private philanthropy is shifting toward sexier fields such as biomedical research."
 
Rare Specimens
 "The Cary gift is particularly significant because it sustains the nuts and bolts of plant sciences, such as the expansion of our collection of 5.7 million specimens, many of them rare and some probably extinct."
He said this collection of preserved specimens was amassed mainly by the 1,000 expeditions the botanical garden sent abroad. "With this money we can begin our second thousand expeditions by our 30 Ph.D. researchers, sending them throughout the world and especially the tropics of Latin America."
Most of the money will go into an endowment that helps finance these and other operations. The garden is about to begin a fund-raising drive with a $165 million goal. Over the years, it has had major support from Enid A. Haupt, the philanthropist.
The Mary Flagler Cary Trust was established by the benefactor's will. The Flagler family's fortune was made by Henry M. Flagler, an early business associate and friend of John D. Rockefeller in a partnership that began modestly in 1867 and developed into the Standard Oil company.
Mary Flagler, who was a granddaughter of the millionaire Henry Harkness, died childless in 1968 and left the Millbrook property she loved to the trust fund to be preserved for conservation. The property, now named the Mary Flagler Cary Arboretum, was dedicated to environmental research under the aegis of the New York Botanical Garden. The Institute of Ecosystem Studies is located on the Millbrook property.
The trust, originally valued at $50 million, has assets of more than $111 million. Substantial grants by the trust are made in the music field, for example, in support of music schools, performances and recordings.
 
Work in Conservation
 The trust is known principally for its work in conservation, preservation of the Atlantic and Gulf coastlines, wetlands and land acquisition. Other grants are used for community initiatives to work on environmental problems in low-income neighborhoods in New York City.
Edward A. Ames, one of the trust's three trustees, said the gift to the botanical garden recognized the increasing importance of the botanical sciences and the danger of losing species that could be of significant medical and economic importance.
"The funds will help support basic research by young and senior scientists, particularly in tropical areas, on identifying plants there and by supplying us with information to help us better manage the tropical forest environment," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
CPC INTERNATIONAL (CPC,N)

 BODY:
CPC International, a food company based in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., said Tuesday that its second-quarter net income increased 4.7 percent, excluding a restructuring charge announced in June.
Most notable were double-digit increases in sales and operating income from CPC's European operations, which account for 30 percent of the company's earnings. These were offset by a decline of 10.7 percent in operating income in Latin America, which the company attributed to the introduction of economic reforms in Brazil. 
 Charles R. Shoemate, chairman and chief executive of CPC, said "uncertainties related to the country's change in currency suddenly resurfaced, bringing customers' purchases of many consumer foods products to a virtual halt."
Though Brazil's currency shift went into effect on July 1, after the second quarter had ended, wholesalers were said to have reduced their purchases substantially in anticipation of the change. The situation could reduce the company's earnings by 3 cents to 4 cents a share for the year, Mr. Shoemate said.
But some analysts said they were heartened by CPC's turnaround in Europe, where recession has depressed earnings for food companies in recent years. "We haven't seen any good numbers in Europe for a long time," said Nomi Ghez, an analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company. "That's very encouraging."

HEADLINE: Boston Federal Reserve Selects New President

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston today named as its president a specialist in bank regulation and financial markets who has little background in interest-rate policy.
The selection of Cathy E. Minehan, who is 47 years old, the Boston Fed's chief operating officer and a career central banker, as the bank's president, holds special significance for two reasons. 
 One is that the Boston Fed president will vote next year on the Federal Reserve's interest-rate policy decisions, according to the rotation of Fed presidents who are members of the rate-setting committee. These rate decisions will be the biggest single influence on the American economy's health during the 1996 Presidential election, because interest rate changes typically take a year to affect the economy.
 
2d Woman to Run a Fed Bank
 The other is that Mrs. Minehan becomes only the second woman ever to lead one of the 12 regional banks of the Federal Reserve. The first was Karen N. Horn, who ran the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland from 1982 to 1987 and is now the chairwoman and chief executive of Bank One of Cleveland.
The Fed has been under strong pressure from Congressional Democrats to choose a more diverse group of regional Federal Reserve bank presidents. Regional bank presidents are not subject to Senate confirmation, a subject of periodic criticism.
They are picked by the nine-member boards of each regional bank. Three of the nine members are always local bankers, and the rest are community leaders.
Mrs. Minehan declined to discuss her views on monetary policy in a telephone interview today. The Federal Reserve has imposed a ban on such comments by its officials until Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, delivers his semiannual report to Congress next week on the economy.
Associates of Mrs. Minehan said that she had not staked out clear positions on economic issues but tended to share the mild reluctance of her colleagues at the Boston Fed to raise interest rates and curb economic growth when there was no clearly visible threat of inflation.
The selection of Mrs. Minehan had no effect on bond market trading today, Robert Giordano, a Goldman, Sachs economist, said. "She's a relatively unknown personage," he said.
 
Focus on Discriminatory Lending
 The Boston Fed is best known for its research into discriminatory lending practices by banks and savings and loans. Earlier this year, Mrs. Minehan helped oversee the production of a Federal Reserve videotape primer on how to comply with Federal fair lending statutes, and said today that she planned to continue the Boston Fed's emphasis on the issue.
Mrs. Minehan started work at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York right after graduating with a bachelor's degree in political science in 1968 from the University of Rochester. She worked in New York as a bank examiner and held a succession of vice president posts there, overseeing the accounting, check-processing and securities transfer divisions.
In her spare time, Mrs. Minehan earned a master's degree in business administration from New York University in 1977, with a concentration in economics. In 1987, she was the New York Fed's representative on an interagency panel that reviewed ways to prevent a recurrence of the stock market crash that year.
In 1991, she moved to the Boston Fed as first vice president and chief operating officer, the regional bank's No. 2 position. She became the bank's acting president after Richard F. Syron left the post in early April to become chairman of the American Stock Exchange.
Silas Keehn, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago since 1981, has announced his intention to retire on Aug. 31, and the reserve bank's board has retained an executive search firm to begin looking for his successor.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Finally Gains on Yen, But Traders Remain Wary

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar advanced broadly yesterday, ending higher against the Japanese yen for the first time in more than a week.
But currency analysts cautioned that the market remained negative on the dollar, which hit yet another record low against the yen on Tuesday, and that yesterday's gains could be short-lived. 
 "I don't think the bearish sentiment toward the dollar has evaporated," said Kevin Logan, chief United States economist for the Swiss Bank Corporation. "Nothing fundamental has changed."
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 98.30 yen, up from 97.40 yen on Tuesday. It also rose to 1.5422 German marks from 1.5280.
The dollar started rising in Asia and Europe early yesterday and continued to advance when trading shifted to the United States. Buying accelerated on rumors that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates by half a percentage point to a full point, traders said.
Higher rates could help the dollar by increasing the returns on short-term dollar-denominated investments and helping to stem the flow of money to Europe, where interest rates are higher.
The possibility of a large interest rate increase seems minimal, considering that inflation remains muted. Yesterday, the Government reported a rise of only three-tenths of a percent in consumer prices last month.
Still, many currency dealers who had bet against the dollar during its recent slide bought dollars for other currencies yesterday to cover their short positions and lock in any profits.
"People weren't willing to be short dollars with those rumors around," said Jack Griffin, a vice president at Fuji Bank Ltd. in New York. "A number of institutions bought dollars."
Several traders and analysts said the rumors about the potential Fed move were mainly an excuse for a technical bounce in the dollar, which has repeatedly hit new post-World War II lows in recent weeks and has fallen more than 4 percent against the mark this month.
They noted that yesterday's gains came despite a lack of market-moving news or economic data.
"Nothing crucial came out to lead the market this way," said Amy Smith, senior currency strategist for IDEA, an analytic service. "It's really just profit taking."
Some traders expect the dollar to fall further unless the Fed eventually raises interest rates or the Clinton Administration adopts a clear strong-dollar policy.
The dollar's gains yesterday extended to a number of currencies, pushing the British pound down to $1.5670 from $1.5725. But the Canadian dollar edged up to 72.41 United States cents from 72.24 cents.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Smoking's economic cost isn't a good argument for higher taxes.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
LAST week the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta confirmed what few had doubted. Smoking-related diseases have "an enormous economic impact," wrote the editors of the centers' Weekly Report -- the equivalent, they estimated, of $2 a pack in medical costs alone.
But the agency was careful not to link these remarkable numbers to the case for higher cigarette taxes, and perhaps wisely so: Few economists are convinced that the link is strong enough to bear the weight of the argument. For while the total costs of smoking are undoubtedly humungous, said Joseph Newhouse, an economist at Harvard, most are borne by the smokers themselves. "You just can't justify higher taxes on cigarettes by the damage done by cigarettes to nonsmokers," he said. 
 This latest Government report is by all accounts based on careful research. Sufficient data collected from some 35,000 adults allowed statisticians to untangle the effects of smoking from the myriad other influences on health: age, race, income, insurance coverage, education, obesity, even willingness to take risks as evidenced by seat belt use. When refigured at 1993 prices, estimated medical bills for smokers came to $50 billion a year, or $2.06 a pack. The costs borne by the public -- mostly Medicaid and Medicare -- came to 89 cents a pack.
That latter number is likely to figure in a suit by the State of Florida, which is attempting to recover medical outlays for treating smokers from the cigarette makers. And it is bound to turn heads among those looking for a palatable way to pay for health care reform. For as anyone who suffered through Econ 101 knows, taxes that offset "externalities" -- costs that aren't covered in prices -- actually increase the efficiency of markets.
The catch here is that a full accounting must also include the savings from smoking. Yes, savings: the reduced cost of private pensions, Social Security and nursing home care for smokers who die before their time. And probably the most complete estimate of the "benefits" as well as the costs was made in 1989 by a group of scholars under the auspices of the RAND Corporation.
The study, led by Willard Manning and published in the Journal of the American Medical Association, put the costs not borne by smokers themselves at about 15 cents a pack. Medical bills for smokers and nonsmokers alike have since risen sharply. So have estimates of the costs of passive smoking -- a classic case of a cost not borne by the buyer or seller. And even these newer estimates, said Ken Warner, an economist at the University of Michigan's School of Public Health, neglect the nuisance cost of coping with other people's smoke.
But by the same token, the avoided costs on the pensions and nursing home fees of smokers have risen, too. And Mr. Newhouse, one of the authors of the RAND study, argues that the conceivable magnitude of passive smoking is unlikely to exceed a few cents a pack. Hence it should not be surprising that Jane Gravelle and Dennis Zimmerman, economists at the Congressional Research Service, concluded that nonsmokers' costs of smoking were "too small to justify either current cigarette taxes (averaging 50 cents a pack) or the proposed tax increase."
That is not the end of the argument, however. "We are not talking about widgets," Mr. Warner said. "We're talking about an addiction formed in childhood" -- an addiction most smokers later come to regret. Thus the idea that the only justification for limiting the right to smoke is nonsmokers' costs seems strained.
Indeed, Mr. Newhouse sees a case for cigarette taxes unrelated to the harm suffered by others. A fat tax increase, he said, might deter young smokers -- a group inclined to puff first and think later. Yet it would have relatively little effect on the habits of older smokers, and would thus not distort free choice.
This latter point does not sit well with Mr. Zimmerman. Smokers, he notes, are on average poorer than nonsmokers. Hence, while the tax might not change consumption by confirmed addicts very much, it would certainly burden people who already bear more than their share of life's economic woes.
What, then, would Mr. Zimmerman do to prevent teen-agers from being hooked by Joe Camel? "If we were really serious about it," he says, "we'd stop sales of cigarettes from vending machines" where children have access. In general, he argues, "the biggest payoff at the lowest cost" would come through tough enforcement of laws against under-age smoking.
It is easy to understand why economists are not rushing to correct the impression that smokers are a burden to society. Most, after all, would like to combat addiction among teen-agers, and most would like to find a popular way to finance broader health care coverage.
In the end, though, one still has to wonder whether the ends justify the means. More pointedly, one might wonder whether the majority of Americans' enthusiasm for better health is so shallow that they would buy it only if a minority (smokers) is forced to foot the bill.

HEADLINE: From Pledge to Plan: The campaign to end welfare -- A special report.;
The Clinton Welfare Bill: A Long, Stormy Journey

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
With four days left before they were to present a plan to overhaul the welfare system, President Clinton's aides faced a painful question.
They were about to propose the strictest work requirements in welfare history, but were they really ready to cut off every penny to mothers who did not comply? 
 At a daylong meeting on Saturday, Feb. 26, Andrew M. Cuomo, an Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, warned that the very poor led chaotic lives and that failures would be frequent. Ending, rather than decreasing, payments would leave women and children on the streets. "Then what do we do?" he asked. "Watch them wither and die?"
But others stressed the need for dramatic change in a system that is almost universally reviled. They argued that only a no-work, no-pay plan would offer the dignity of a real paycheck. And they said that only a bold break with the past would satisfy the President's famous pledge -- not to reduce but to "end welfare as we know it."
Gene Sperling, a White House economics aide, summed up the group's decision. "This," he said, "has to be one of the things that defines us."
The debate illustrates the political forces that Mr. Clinton's welfare pledge has set into motion, and the stakes for 14.3 million of the poorest Americans, most of them women and children.
In three years, the promise to "end welfare as we know it" has grown from a snippet of campaign rhetoric, crafted by a volunteer one Saturday night, into a driving force in social policy.
That journey entered a new stage this week as Congress began debate on the 431-page bill that President Clinton unveiled last month, with all sides promising sweeping change.
The story of how the Administration arrived at that bill, pieced together from scores of interviews and internal documents, shows how politics and personalities intersected with academic theories and the realities of grinding poverty. Along the way, the idea at the heart of Mr. Clinton's plan, a two-year limit on benefits, underwent a telling change.
The idea was originally part of a much broader plan that, through services and cash supplements, would have lifted virtually all single mothers from poverty. But Mr. Clinton's proposal, while ambitious, makes no such promise. He hopes that the time limits, combined with billions of dollars in new training, work, child-care and tax-credit programs, will move recipients into private jobs. But he also offered a caution. "Let us be honest," he said. "None of this will be easy to accomplish."
Throughout the process, Mr. Clinton has struggled to keep pace with the expectations produced by his own, insistently bold rhetoric. As a candidate, for example, he rejected a complete cutoff for the non-compliant, saying in a 1992 interview he did not want to "punish the kids" for the mistakes of their parents. But as President he has embraced a set of escalating penalties that culminate in the denial of all cash to mothers who refuse to work.
As far as Mr. Clinton has moved, the political climate may have moved even further. It is his odd fate to propose the toughest work plan of any President, only to have most Republican denounce the measure as timid.
Fearful, perhaps, of ceding him the issue, some Republicans now want to go further, beyond work requirements to completely abolishing aid to some mothers.
Noting the stakes for indigent families, David T. Ellwood, one of the plan's main architects, recently took stock of the forces at play. "This," he said, "is the scariest thing I've ever done in my life."
 
The Pledge
A Concrete Call For Time Limits
 The pledge took shape in October 1991, after a phone call to the pollsters. Bruce Reed, the volunteer drafting the first major policy speech of Mr. Clinton's campaign, ran the welfare section past the political advisers, who agreed that the issue would sell with voters.
The welfare system was in genuine crisis. After remaining stable for two decades, the welfare rolls had grown by 25 percent in the recent recession, and the percentage of children born to single mothers was at a record high. Studies showed that as many as three-fourths of all black children would spend a year on welfare before reaching adulthood.
At the same time, the system offered less and less to those it was meant to support. States had let cash benefits erode so severely that some welfare families, no longer able to pay rent, were finding themselves in homeless shelters.
While President George Bush had scarcely mentioned welfare, Mr. Clinton had a record to run on. He had run experimental programs in Arkansas for a decade, and played a prominent role in convincing Congress to pass a 1988 law that requires some recipients to seek training.
In his announcement speech a month earlier, Mr. Clinton had offered a vague promise to move people "off welfare and onto work rolls," but his advisers now wanted something catchier.
"They said we should have concrete calls to make sure that people paid attention," Mr. Reed said. "And I suggested that we could call for 'an end to permanent welfare."'
The next day, a colleague supplied a paper by Mr. Ellwood, then a Harvard professor with an ambitious anti-poverty plan. Mr. Ellwood had called for a dramatic expansion of services and payments to the poor, but said that once they took place, the nation might limit welfare benefits to a period ranging from 18 to 36 months.
 
The Vision of Time Limits
 But Mr. Reed seized on the vision of time limits, picking a midpoint of two years. He forwarded the speech, along with Mr. Ellwood's paper, to Mr. Clinton, who made the pledge a few weeks later.
"In a Clinton Administration, we're going to put an end to welfare as we know it," he said at Georgetown University on Oct. 23, 1991. "We'll give them all the help they need for up to two years. But after that, if they're able to work, they'll have to take a job in the private sector, or start earning their way through community service."
George Stephanopoulos, then a top campaign aide, said Mr. Clinton read the Ellwood paper carefully, and was convinced on both policy and political grounds.
The concept of a time limit fit with the candidate's talk of balancing rights and responsibilities, Mr. Stephanopoulos said, and the clarity of the two-year pledge would help convince the public he meant what he said.
"They only believe if there's a definite end to it," Mr. Stephanopoulos said.
Upon entering the Administration, Mr. Reed taped the words "end welfare as we know it" to his office wall at the White House Domestic Policy Council, and quoted them like scripture when he sniffed the waning resolve of bureaucratic rivals. He calls the pledge "a guiding star."
 
The Professor
Father of the Idea Denies Paternity
 But among those made uneasy was Mr. Ellwood himself. "I don't think these are issues that are best discussed under the klieg lights and sound bites of a Presidential campaign," he said in a 1992 interview. Mr. Ellwood's 1988 book, "Poor Support," had indeed endorsed time limits, but only as part of a much broader anti-poverty program. To "make work pay," he wanted to give low-income workers sizable tax credits, a higher minimum wage, subsidized child care and universal health care.
And perhaps most important, he said the nation should guarantee that single mothers receive child support, with the Government making the payments itself if it failed to collect them from absent fathers. Only then would the Government place a time limit on the benefits, offering those still unemployed a public job as a last resort.
"I'm not truly in favor of time-limited welfare unless there are other supports in place," Mr. Ellwood said in 1992. He called guaranteed child support "the single most important" policy, and said of the time limits, "You can do that last."
When someone characterized him as the father of time limits at a meeting in December 1992, he quipped, "I deny paternity."
Though Mr. Ellwood was being recruited as a top human services official, he called for a series of state experiments rather than a national program of time limits.
"We simply do not have all the answers about how to transform the welfare system," he wrote in December 1992, adding that, "For me, the greatest fear is that desperately poor people will be cut off welfare and hurt."
But the nascent Administration was already heading in the opposite direction. Mr. Reed and other members of the transition team sent Mr. Clinton a briefing book arguing that only a nationwide program would meet his campaign pledge to put recipients to work.
"We don't need a demonstration to show us that's the thing the welfare system needs most," Mr. Reed said recently.
 
Getting Under Way
Visits to the Poor Bolster Beliefs
 By the summer of 1993, Mr. Ellwood and Mr. Reed were among the leaders of the task force that would draft Mr. Clinton's bill. While Mr. Ellwood would sometimes teasingly refer to Mr. Reed as a "right-wing hack," at a news conference in July he, too, was calling for the time limits that six months earlier had brought him visible angst.
"I was wearing a different hat in December," said Mr. Ellwood, now an Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services. "Now I work for the President."
His dream of guaranteed child support died a quick death. At the first welfare meeting in the spring of 1993, Mr. Ellwood gave a long account of the intellectual journey that had led him to embrace the policy. But Mr. Reed was unequivocal in response, calling the idea "welfare by another name," and reminding his rival that the President had never endorsed it.
Neither Mr. Ellwood, a lifelong academic, nor Mr. Reed, a speechwriter and campaign aide, could claim extensive contact with the poor. At the July news conference, Mr. Reed promised to "go out and talk to the real people."
Among the more memorable of the five trips was one about 30 miles outside of Memphis. "We saw a woman in a horrendous rural poverty situation," Mr. Ellwood said. "House with no windows. Broken down ceilings. No toilet. It was just absolute, total abject poverty."
For some in the 32-member group, the visits and public hearings brought doubts about ending welfare.
"Living in this shack, 15 miles from the nearest town, no public transportation -- what kind of program was really going to make her an independent, self-sufficient, tax-paying American?" asked one member of the task force.
But Mr. Ellwood said the visits sharpened his criticisms of the status quo. "It was a radicalizing experience, radicalizing because what we saw was really, really horrible," he said.
And the trips quickened Mr. Reed's faith that the group was on the right track. "No welfare recipients complained about the time limits," he said. "Quite the opposite: they all wanted to get off welfare as quickly as they could."
 
External Forces
The Debate Moves Far to the Right
 As they worked to reconcile internal differences, Mr. Clinton's aides were under assault from both friends and foes. The team had just assembled a first draft in early December when Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the House Speaker, asked Mr. Clinton to drop welfare from his 1994 agenda, warning that it would get in the way of the health care debate.
At the first Cabinet meeting this year, on Jan. 3, the President mused aloud: Could he send up a bill that created the appearance of progress even while quietly urging Congress to defer action?
But when an account was disclosed to the press, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan exploded. Mr. Clinton was cynically using the issue as "boob bait for the Bubbas," the New York Democrat said. Insisting that welfare was the true national crisis, Mr. Moynihan threatened to use his position as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee to "hold health care hostage" until the President delivered a welfare bill.
Mr. Moynihan's comments stunned his colleagues, since he himself had been critical of time limits, viewing Mr. Clinton's pledge as irresponsible campaign talk. "You let loose a lot of forces when you say 'end welfare as we know it,' which is why I never said any such thing," the Senator said later.
Mr. Moynihan quickly disavowed his health care threat and later conceded, "Sometimes I do talk too much." But the die was cast. The President vowed in his State of the Union Message in January to send Congress a bill "this spring."
As he struggled to keep the promise, however, the forces that Mr. Moynihan described were driving the debate fast and far to the right.
Professing to truly "end welfare," Jack F. Kemp, William J. Bennett and about a dozen Republican members of Congress proposed in April to deny all cash to single mothers under the age of 21. Those unable to support their children could send them to state-financed orphanages.
In May, a group of centrist Democrats displayed their impatience by announcing their own, sterner version of a two-year limit. Representative Nathan Deal, Democrat of Georgia, captured the political mood when he proclaimed welfare dead and said, "The stench from its decaying carcass has filled the nostrils of every American."
 
The Metamorphosis
Some Victories And Some Losses
 Against this backdrop, the Clinton plan continued its evolution.
Despite Mr. Ellwood's protests, for instance, the Clinton plan would allow states to deny extra money for extra children. Citing his own research, Mr. Ellwood argued that the cap would deprive needy children of extra money without deterring their parents. But in a meeting in the Oval Office on May 24, the President sided with Mr. Reed, saying that as a former Governor, he wanted to allow states to choose.
At the same time, Mr. Ellwood found himself fighting a battle he had never anticipated, fending off attempts to limit the work program itself. Such a move could potentially leave recipients with neither welfare nor jobs. Mr. Ellwood said it would violate a cherished principle: people who "play by the rules," as he would often say, should not lose the game.
But Mr. Reed worried that some recipients might cheat the system, turning down unpleasant private work to stay in subsidized jobs. While Mr. Clinton settled on a bill that would drop recipients only if they failed to make "a good faith effort" to find private jobs, debate on this fundamental point has certainly not ended. Democrats and Republicans in Congress have both put forward bills that allow time limits on the work program.
Mr. Ellwood did win important victories on some of the anti-poverty policies he advocated in "Poor Support." Mr. Clinton's plan would expand training programs, and the President continues to push for universal health insurance. The Administration says that is the key to reducing the welfare rolls, since some recipients stay in the program just to get health care for their children.
And Mr. Clinton says he has already won a dramatic welfare reform victory by expanding the tax credits that go to low-wage workers. Congress last year agreed to spend an additional $21 billion over five years on the credits, raising the income of a low-wage worker by as much as $3,300 a year. In pushing the expansion, Mr. Clinton even relied on Mr. Ellwood's catchy phrase: the credits, he said, will help recipients leave welfare because they will "make work pay."
While Mr. Ellwood lost the fight for child support guarantees, the plan contains new provisions intended to increase collections from absent fathers. Though past predictions have often proved rosy, the Administration hopes to improve such collections by as much as $11 billion a year. The Clinton plan also spends an additional $4.2 billion on child care, with $1.5 billion going to working-class families to help keep them off welfare.
Administration officials say the plan will do nothing less than restore work to the heart of social policy. Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said that the combination of "tax credits, health care and child care will make it possible for everyone who works to be better off than they were on welfare."
 
A Difficult Transition
 But universal health care is far from certain, and the tax credits would only help recipients who find private jobs. The Clinton plan denies the payments to people in the subsidized jobs program, to prod them to find private work. Most of those families would be no better off financially than they had been on welfare.
Mr. Ellwood argues that "the work program has never been seen as the ultimate resting point" for poor people. But how many of the nation's five million welfare families will be able to make the transition to private jobs? That is the biggest question about Mr. Clinton's plan, and there are no reliable answers. Over the last six months, the Administration has estimated that anywhere from 500,000 to 2.3 million families could be left in the work program, of the five million now receiving aid.
When all the provisions are tallied up, the distance Mr. Ellwood has traveled is substantial. While "Poor Support" pledged to lift a part-time worker out of poverty, the Clinton work program would leave the average mother of three about $4,000 below the poverty line of $11,300.
In a recent interview, Mr. Ellwood acknowledged the metamorphosis of his ideas, but said the plan remains a strong weapon against poverty. He said the increased emphasis on time limits was an attempt to fight a status quo that was even more cruel and entrenched than he had known.
"In 'Poor Support,' things like time limits were one item among many," he said. "In the end, I've come to believe that it's necessary, that the job of changing welfare is so hard that you really need something very clear. It's for the recipients, for the political process and for the welfare workers themselves."
"Don't forget, politics sometimes is information," he continued. "People are really frustrated and angry. The welfare system is collapsing under its own weight. We've got to do something.
"I'm really proud of what we've got," he added. "I really, really am."
 
The Money
Payment Becomes Biggest Headache
 While pledging to end welfare is one thing, paying for it is quite another, and financing emerged as the Administration's biggest headache.
The public hears the end-welfare talk as a cost-saving measure. But it is much cheaper to simply mail checks than to pay for the child care, training and wage subsidies needed to put the poor to work.
"It's the same debate we've always had about welfare reform," said Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff. "You have to make some up-front investments, so you immediately have a political problem."
Assuming that new taxes were out of the question, the leaders of the task force began by looking for other social programs to cut. In January, for example, the leaders of the task force suggested making food stamps, welfare benefits and housing assistance subject to taxation. Other benefits, like unemployment insurance, are taxed, and most recipients earn too little to cross the tax threshold anyway.
But the idea, leaked by opponents of the plan, drew fire from people as diverse as Jay Leno, the "Tonight" show host, and Bob Dole, the Senate minority leader, and Mr. Panetta killed it.
Mr. Ellwood and his deputy, Wendell E. Primus, followed with other suggested cuts, most of which proved equally unpopular. The ridicule they encountered was especially painful because they both pride themselves on their past advocacy for the poor.
Mr. Primus's world seemed especially upside down on March 19, when the working group took up a proposal to cut 250,000 children from the welfare rolls by tightening eligibility for families that take in extended relatives, like grandchildren.
A roomful of affluent officials, many earning six-figure salaries, then debated the difference that the average payments of $200 can make. What would the families be forced to surrender -- shoes? diapers? food?
 
Fiscal Choices
Cutting 'Welfare For the Wealthy'
 When Cabinet members considered the financing choices on March 21, they rejected the cut and urged a strategy that would raise some of the money from more affluent Americans. Mr. Stephanopoulos suggested that they could sell it as cutting "welfare for the wealthy."
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich agreed, and took the opportunity to press for a favorite cause: a cap on the tax deductions taken for mortgages on expensive homes.
But the Cabinet also began to talk of scaling back the plan, and so did Mr. Clinton when he joined the group the next day. "He did say, 'We do have a problem: the public doesn't think this should cost a lot of money,' " said one person who attended the meeting.
While the President had considered options that would spend as much as $16 billion over five years, he settled for a $9.3 billion plan, with much less child care for poor families who are working. To save money and bureaucratic chaos, the plan would phase in the work requirements slowly, applying them only to women born after 1971. That means only about one-third of the caseload is covered in the initial years.
But even the financing for a smaller package was far from complete. The life insurance industry drowned the White House in angry mailgrams when Mr. Panetta began exploring a cap on the tax-free interest that the wealthy could collect through large annuities.
Veterans swarmed over Capitol Hill when he began to contemplate minor cuts in veterans' benefits. And the Nevada delegation exploded over the possibility of a gambling tax.
In his book, Mr. Ellwood had been able to skip the question of finances, noting only that a Government that spends "over $1 trillion to protect us from Soviet missiles" could "spare a little for social policies."
 
A Political Death Threat
 Now he watched Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, issue a political death threat over a $3 billion tax that would hit that state's casinos. If Mr. Clinton went forward with that plan, Mr. Reid said, "I will become the most negative, the most irresponsible, the most obnoxious person of anyone in the Senate."
The President abandoned the tax, and two-thirds of the final financing comes from cuts in the anti-poverty budget, including $3.7 billion in programs for legal immigrants and $1.6 billion in an emergency program for people at risk of eviction.
Oddly, House Republicans now propose to spend twice as much on welfare reform as Mr. Clinton, which would allow them to put their program into effect much faster. But they would raise their $20 billion by eliminating virtually all Government aid to legal immigrants, a move Mr. Panetta likens to that of "a lynch mob."
Mr. Panetta got little enthusiasm from House leaders when he offered a preview of the package. "The cupboard is bare," said Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who stepped down recently as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. "There are few ways of funding that are palatable."
But Mr. Clinton professes optimism, insisting that his plan will establish the principle that "welfare ought to be a second chance, not a way of life." Unveiling his plan on June 14, he surrounded himself with recipients who had made the difficult transition to work, and reiterated his pledge to end welfare. "That is really what I ran for President to try to do," he said.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Photos: "LINEUP: Important Figures in Welfare Reform"
 
LEADERS OF THE PRESIDENT'S TASK FORCE ON WELFARE
 
David T. Ellwood
Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services
 The intellectual father of time limits on welfare, Mr. Ellwood proposed them in his 1988 book, Poor Support. A former Harvard professor, Mr. Ellwood coined many of the phases Mr. Clinton uses, including his calls to "make work pay," and protect people who "play by the rules."
 
Mary Jo Bane
Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services
 A former Harvard professor, Ms. Bane was Mr. Ellwood's co-author on several pioneering welfare studies in the 1980's. Before joining the Administration, she served as New York State's Commissioner of Social Services.
 
Bruce Reed
White House domestic policy aide
 A former campaign aide to Mr. Clinton, Mr. Reed is the most conservative of the three leaders, pushing for stricter work requirements. He wrote the 1991 speech in which Mr. Clinton first promised to "end welfare as we know it."
 
OTHER PIVOTAL PLAYERS
 
Leon E. Panetta
White House Budget Director
 As the attempt to raise billions of dollars flagged, Mr. Panetta took over the financing strategy. He blocked some deep cuts in anti-poverty programs, but failed in his attempt to raise money from wealthier Americans, inciting a battle from Washington lobbies.
 
Donna E. Shalala
Secretary of Health and Human Services
 Ms. Shalala once served as head of the Children's Defense Fund, an advocacy group skeptical of time limits on welfare. But she has now helped draft one of the toughest work requirements in history.
 
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan
Chairman of the Senate Finance Committee
 A pivotal but erratic player in social policy, Mr. Moynihan accused the President of abandoning his campaign pledge. His threats to block a health care plan prompted the White House to accelerate the drafting of the welfare plan.
 
President Clinton
 He prides himself on his commitment to overhauling welfare and his knowledge of the technical issues. As Governor of Arkansas, Mr. Clinton conducted experimental programs and helped Congress revise welfare laws in 1988. His famous campaign pledge to "end welfare as we know it," did much to reshape the national debate. (pg. A18)
 
Chart: "HIGHLIGHTS: Clinton Welfare Plan"
 Provides expanded training and child care for families on welfare.
 Requires those still unemployed after two years to join a work program at the minimum wage.
 Eliminates all cash payments to mothers who repeatedly fail to work.
 Phases in the program slowly, applying the time-limits only to mothers born after 1971.
 Toughens child support enforcement, by requiring paternity establish, tracking interstate cases, and regularly updating awards.
 Allows states to deny increased payments to women who have additional children.
 Provides $400 million in grants to fight teen-age pregnancy. (pg. A18)

HEADLINE: Optimism Ignites a Stock and Bond Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Stocks and bonds rallied yesterday in their best session in weeks, riding the crest of investor optimism brought on by low inflation data, a stabilizing dollar and some solid second-quarter corporate profits.
The bond market led stocks higher, beginning a surge yesterday morning after the Government reported that retail sales rose a modest six-tenths of 1 percent in June, providing more evidence that the economy was not overheating. This, combined with other reports this week that showed inflation to be under control, eased traders' concerns that the Federal Reserve would soon raise interest rates once again.
 
Bond Prices Rise
 As bond prices rose, interest rates fell, pushing the yield down to 7.53 percent, from 7.67 percent on Wednesday. Lower interest rates make stocks a more attractive investment. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average surged 34.97 points, to 3,739.25, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 4.68 points, to 453.41.
The other market barometers, which earlier were in line with the blue-chip indicators, fell off the pace at the end. The Nasdaq composite index shed half its gains in the afternoon after Cisco Systems plunged 4 1/4, to 19 3/4, dragging down other technology issues. Company officials said the company might face difficulty matching analysts' estimates for fourth quarter ended July 31. The Nasdaq composite finished up 2.21 points, to 721.56 percent.
On the New York Stock Exchange, advancing issues outpaced declining issues, 1,663 to 555. Volume was heavy at 322.3 million shares, up from 266.3 million on Wednesday.
Hugh A. Johnson, chief investment strategist at the First Albany Corporation, said it was the bond market's strong surge that gave the stock market the ability to make a strong run.
 
Optimism Is Cited
 "The drop in bond yields is tied to renewed market optimism about the currency and the belief that the worst is behind us," he said.
But, he cautioned that "the move by the bond market yesterday was much stronger than any of the fundamentals of the last three days have suggested."
Ricky Harrington, senior vice president and technical analyst with Interstate/Johnson Lane Inc., Charlotte, N.C., said he thought that over the longer term the stock market was still headed down.
"We saw economic reports this week that tended to reinforce the belief that inflation is not a problem, and the economy was moving along, " he said.
"Being oversold on a short term, it set the stage for a fairly significant rally in stocks."
Mr. Harrington said a poor earnings report could still puncture a rally in stocks, pointing to the impact of Cisco System's decline on other issues.
 
Chrysler Profit Rises
 Unexpectedly strong earnings from the Chrysler Corporation helped generate market optimism about corporate profits.
Chrysler, the No. 3 auto maker, reported yesterday that second-quarter earnings rose nearly 40 percent, to $2.35 a share. Analysts had expected the company to earn about $2.27 a share, according to a survey by Institutional Brokers Estimates System.
Elsewhere, shares of Microage Inc. plunged as much as 48 percent yesterday after the company forecast lower-than-expected third-quarter earnings, citing a margin decrease caused by pricing pressure and action taken to reduce inventory.
Cocensys Inc. rose 22/32 , to 3 24/32 , after the biotechnology company said it would introduce four psychiatric drugs on an accelerated schedule.
Digital Equipment, fell 1 1/4, to 20 1/8, after the computer maker said it would take a restructuring charge of $1.2 billion.
Kendall rose 3, to 54, after Tyco International said it would buy the company in a $1.4 billion stock swap. Tyco fell 1 3/4, to 45 5/8.

HEADLINE: White House Cuts Growth Forecasts

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
The White House said today that the economy was closer to operating at full capacity than it had previously thought, and so lowered slightly its forecasts for economic growth in 1996 and beyond.
Fearing that factories and other businesses were already close to operating at full speed and could run into production bottlenecks, fueling inflation, the Federal Reserve has raised short-term interest rates four times this year. 
 None of the officials at a White House news conference today discussed the Federal Reserve's actions. But their mention of full capacity suggested that they do not argue with the central bank's concerns, although Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen had reiterated as recently as last Friday that he saw no need for further increases.
 
 
Assumes Steady Rates
 Today's forecast assumed that the Federal Reserve would hold short-term interest rates steady until the end of this year and then raise them by half a percentage point. Like most prominent corporate economists, the Administration predicted an average interest rate on three-month Treasury bills of 4 percent this year. But the private economists are slightly more pessimistic, expecting a 4.8 percent average next year to the Administration's 4.7 percent.
The officials presenting the midyear economic review, which is part of a legally required midyear update of the Administration's budget proposals, reaffirmed their predictions for near-term growth. As in February, they predicted that the economy would grow 3 percent this year and 2.7 percent next year, and that inflation would remain moderate.
The consensus of blue-chip economists is for 3.1 percent growth this year, only a tenth of a percentage point higher than the Administration's estimate, and for 2.6 percent growth next year, only a tenth below the Administration's forecast. Private forecasters and the Administration agree in estimating growth in 1996 at 2.6 percent and in 1997 at 2.5 percent.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, who heads the President's Council of Economic Advisers, announced that faster than expected growth this year and next had forced the Administration to trim its growth forecasts for 1996, 1997 and 1998 by a tenth of a percentage point each year.
"The economy this year and at the end of last year actually grew faster than anticipated," Ms. Tyson explained, "in a sense using up more of the excess capacity in the economy than we anticipated and leaving less excess capacity to be used up in the future."
 
 
Strong Business Investment
 But Mr. Bentsen said that strong business investment now was helping to sustain economic growth at current levels. Business investment has risen at an annual rate of 18.4 percent since President Clinton took office, compared with an annual rate of 2.2 percent during the Bush Administration, he said.
During the Bush Administration, a prolonged economic slowdown reduced demand for goods and services and discouraged many businesses from expanding capacity.
Mr. Bentsen also repeated in strong terms his desire that the dollar hold its value in international currency markets, although he did not mention what the Treasury Department would do if the dollar resumed its fall of Monday and last week. "Let me state that obviously we are concerned and want a strong dollar, and that is important," Mr. Bentsen said.
John Lipsky, an ecnomist at Salomon Inc., said that it was standard Government practice to assume that short-term rates would stay unchanged in the short tun, but that he expected the central bank to tighten rates sooner. Administration officals "accept that there will be tightening, and my guess is that it will come sooner than they assume," he said.
