HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Price Surge Is Biggest Since May

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities surged yesterday in their biggest rally since May amid a rebounding dollar and expections that interest rates would remain stable.
When the Commerce Department reported that retail sales rose only six-tenths of 1 percent in June, less than anticipated, it was a signal "the economy isn't raging forward," said Patrick Retzer at the $77 million Heartland U.S. Government Fund in Milwaukee. 
 Combined with reports earlier this week that inflation was benign last month, the modest increase in sales signaled that the Federal Reserve did not need to raise interest rates. "Things look pretty good," Mr. Retzer said.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 113/32 , to 85. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, fell to 7.53 percent, from 7.67 percent on Wendesday and was the lowest since June 29, when it was 7.50 percent. It was the largest daily decline in yields since May 17.
 
Increase in Bond Prices
 Bond prices gained after the dollar rose against the German mark for a third day and the Japanese yen for a second day. A stronger dollar makes dollar-denominated assets like bonds more attractive to investors.
The yield on the long bond has fallen as much as 21 basis points since Monday, the most since a four-day rally lowered the yield 21 basis points, to 7.22 percent, on June 6. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
The retail sales report followed inflation reports this week that showed prices at the wholesale level were unchanged in June, while consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent, as expected. Given such reports, the Federal Reserve is less likely to raise short-term interest rates for the fifth time this year, traders said.
"The whole picture's fairly benign now," said Tim Heaton, a trader at Nikko Securities.
That view was underscored yesterday by a report from the Office of Management and Budget, which left its estimate of economic growth for 1994 unchanged at 3 percent, an indication it believes the Fed has succeeded in preventing runaway growth.
So far this year, inflation, as measured by the Consumer Price Index is running at an annual rate of 2.5 percent, down from 2.8 percent for the first six months of 1993 and 2.7 percent for all of last year.
Some investors, however, are skeptical that the rally will last. If anything, the gain in bonds is a chance to cash in on government bonds, said Richard Schlanger at Pioneering Management in Boston, which has $700 million in fixed-income assets. "If it runs much further, I sure intend to take some profits and sell," he said. A yield on the 30-year bond of less than 7.50 percent would mean it was time to consider selling, he added.
Some analysts warned that yesterday's retail sales report did not necessarily mean that consumers slowed their spending in the month. Consumer borrowing increased for the 14th consecutive month in May, implying that June sales were higher than reported in the sales survey, said Michael Strauss, chief economist at Yamaichi International (America). The annual rate of borrowing ran at 15.1 percent in May, up from 14.9 percent in April.
"Very possibly, what's happening is that the retail sales report may be understating the numbers," Mr. Strauss said. "The consumer credit numbers were so off the charts that they imply a lot more retail activity than we've seen in the last few months." If sales are actually rising faster than the Government reported, more inflation could be on the way, he said.

HEADLINE: Fund-Raiser Donated Office To Giuliani During Campaign

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
An East Side storefront donated for at least a month to Rudolph W. Giuliani's mayoral campaign by a real-estate executive was listed on campaign finance reports as a contribution worth $700, but the same space was recently rented to a pizza chain for $5,000 a month.
The storefront was donated by William W. Koeppel, the same real-estate executive who arranged apartments for 15 Giuliani administration and campaign officials, most of whom got their first two weeks to three months of occupancy without rent. 
 Mr. Koeppel, a major fund-raiser for the Mayor, also contributed an additional $5,000 to the campaign. If the storefront had been valued at or near the $5,000 it has now been rented for, instead of at $700, it would have put Mr. Koeppel over the $6,500 limit on individual donors set by the city's public finance law.
The storefront, at 941 First Avenue at 52d Street, was used as a neighborhood storage site for campaign literature and materials for four to six weeks, largely by Liberal Party campaign workers for Mr. Giuliani's mayoral campaign, according to Giuliani aides and campaign workers.
Gary Lewi, a spokesman for Mr. Koeppel, said the $700 evaluation was proper at the time because Mr. Koeppel had been unable to rent the space for months, in part because there was a homeless shelter nearby. "It had been vacant since June of last year and only recently has Mr. Koeppel engaged in lease negotiations with a pizza-parlor chain," he said.
Mr. Lewi said Domino's had recently agreed to a 10-year lease at $5,000 month, with the first four months of the lease free of rent.
 
'Apples and Oranges'
 Randy M. Mastro, Mr. Giuliani's chief of staff, said the $700 value was "comparable to the rental experiences the campaign had in many campaign storage sites in the city." He added that "it's comparing apples and oranges to try to draw a parallel between a short-term storage lease for a campaign and a long-term commercial lease to a viable commercial entity."
Nicole A. Gordon, executive director of the city's Campaign Finance Board, declined to discuss the storefront space donation. But she said that in determining the worth of an in-kind contribution, "you have to judge it by what fair market value is."
Ms. Gordon said earlier this week that the board was conducting routine audits of campaign filings and would look into any pertinent issues as it did so. Under the public finance law, a campaign that violates spending limits can be charged a penalty.
The administration and spokesmen for Mr. Koeppel have both said the apartment rental terms offered to the Giuliani aides were standard for the real-estate developer. They said the apartments, in four East Side buildings, were all rented at market value, thus amounting to neither in-kind campaign contributions or gifts. Other real-estate brokers have said that while one month of free rent was a standard incentive offered by real-estate dealers several years ago when the Manhattan rental market was soft, two to three months' free rent was highly unusual.
In addition, a previous tenant of one of the apartments rented by Marva L. Hammons, the Commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration, said she had been paying $500 more a month than the $2,500 Mr. Koeppel was charging Ms. Hammons. Ms. Hammons also was granted four months free in a studio apartment when her two-bedroom apartment was not vacated on time.
 
A Standard Incentive
 Mr. Lewi noted yesterday that the lease to Domino's also included a free-rent incentive of four months. Other realty executives said that in the commercial market, free-rent incentives were standard. "Owners always give free rent," said Ben Fox, executive vice president of New Spectrum, who said the usual free-rent period was at least 60 and sometimes 90 days.
Mr. Giuliani has said repeatedly this week that his aides' leases did not amount to free rent because he said the total rent paid over the term of the lease amounted to fair market value. At a City Hall news conference yesterday he refused three times to answer questions about the leases, saying he had already answered the questions over the last three days.
Mr. Giuliani said news accounts failed to report that some real-estate agents have told his aides that the arrangements were not unusual. "I have repeated the answers to this over and over again," the Mayor said. "And you insist on describing this as free rent. It is not free rent." The real-estate broker -- at the NRK Management Corporation -- cited by the administration as having told officials that 75 other tenants of Mr. Koeppel's have received similar rent arrangements has not returned repeated telephone calls from The New York Times seeking comment.
Mr. Giuliani added, "Anyone who understands economics and how it operates would understand you're paying for this by paying higher rents in the fourth and fifth and sixth month. It's the same $12,000 divided by 12 or 9."
"My repeated answers to your questions," he said, "are not going to clarify things any further. You continue to use what is in fact a misleading description."

HEADLINE: New Tactics by Unions Avoid Strikes

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Corporate America's legal right to hire people as permanent replacements for striking workers, a right reaffirmed by Congress this week, has led unions to shift tactics in recent labor disputes. Their goal, which has so far been less than successful, is to regain some of the bargaining power that a strike once conferred on unions.
In some cases, like the United Auto Workers strike against Caterpillar Inc., the unions have invoked legal provisions that hinder companies from exercising their right to replace strikers. 
 In other cases, like the recent six-week strike by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union against Leslie Fay Companies, a clothing manufacturer, the workers tried a consumer boycott and other pressure tactics.
"You have to wage the broadest struggle nowadays," said Susan Cowell, an I.L.G.W.U. vice president.
Leslie Fay had threatened early in the strike to bring in replacement workers, but did not do so. The strike came after the company sought union approval to close a Wilkes-Barre, Pa., factory employing 1,200 and move the work overseas. The settlement reached last month keeps 600 jobs in Wilkes-Barre, but only for the first year of a new three-year contract.
 
Union Tactics Altered
 Striker replacement has played a huge role in shaping the tactics of the United Auto Workers in the U.A.W.'s dispute with Caterpillar, which makes tractors, earth movers and other heavy construction equipment, mostly in Illinois. Two years ago, during a strike by 14,000 workers over the terms of a new three-year contract, Caterpillar threatened to hire replacements.
The company received hundreds of responses to its advertisement for workers. People who might have been unwilling in the past to cross a picket line had come to see a Caterpillar job, paying $15 an hour or more, as privileged employment at a time when high wages are hard to find. The U.A.W. promptly capitulated, calling off the strike, and the publicity made Caterpillar a national symbol of the striker replacement issue.
Now, in the U.A.W.'s second strike against Caterpillar, the issue is labor practices instead of a new contract, even though a contract has yet to be adopted. Under the law, if the U.A.W. were to strike again over contract terms, Caterpillar could once again hire, or threaten to hire, replacement workers.
But the company cannot hire replacements when the dispute is over labor practices. The union is striking over what is says are more than 90 unfair labor practices, which involve things like dismissing or suspending workers as a result of shop-floor disputes.
With the issue of striker replacements temporarily off the table, the Caterpillar-U.A.W. struggle has taken a different course. While the company continues to operate, it seeks to get as many strikers as possible to cross the picket lines and return to work.
Some 3,000 workers, or roughly 10 percent of the strikers, have gone back, the company says. The union says that whatever the number, its strike has greatly slowed production at several plants.
 
A Presidential Letter
 Whatever the truth, the Clinton Administration continues to link Caterpillar with the striker replacement issue.
On Tuesday, after the Senate killed a bill that would have outlawed striker replacement, President Clinton sent a pointed letter to Donald V. Fites, chairman of Caterpillar. The President told Mr. Fites that while the nature of the current dispute between the company and the union did not raise the striker replacement issue, the issue had a "poisonous effect" on labor-management relations. "I want to challenge companies like yours that have been split by this issue in the past to move forward to new chapters of cooperation and economic revitalization," the letter said.
In an interview, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich was blunter. "I cannot comment on the merit of the issues now pending, but Caterpillar has a very distrustful and angry labor force," he said. "Trust was squandered because of the use of striker replacement."
The company issued statements praising the Senate for its action and noting that Mr. Clinton was not taking sides in the labor dispute. But a U.A.W. statement hailed Mr. Clinton's letter as supporting its efforts "to get Cat back on track."
Corporate officials note that since 1938, they have had the right to replace workers on strike. They say this right has maintained a balance of power in contract negotiations.
The unions, however, argue that the balance has eroded in favor of management because companies have, in fact, made greater use of striker replacement since the early 1980's than they did in the past. Until the 80's, a decade when anti-union sentiment increased among corporations and in Washington, replacing strikers was considered unacceptable by both workers and managers.
Various independent studies support the claim that companies are hiring replacement workers more frequently, or threatening to do so. The result, the unions say, has been much greater strife and bitterness in contract disputes. Unions have also had more trouble organizing new chapters, they say, and the number of strikes that result in no contract being signed has risen. Government data supports some of those claims.
 
Affecting Current Strikes
 Certainly, the threat of hiring replacement workers is playing a role in several current strikes over new contract terms. Some 4,000 U.A.W. workers, for example, are on strike at General Dynamics plants that make tanks and other military vehicles. "The strike came at a point where delivery needs are relatively modest," said Ray Lewis, a company spokesman. He noted that nothing had been said about replacing strikers.
"But if it were absolutely necessary, I am sure we would consider replacement workers," he said. General Dynamics replaced workers during strikes in 1984 and 1990 involving other unions at other weapons plants.
The issue of striker replacement also hovers in the background of a strike that started on Monday and involves 4,000 workers at six plants of the Bridgestone-Firestone Company, which has Japanese owners. The company wants more control over working schedules, including authorization for some 12-hour shifts, and it wants the workers to pay part of the premiums for company-provided health insurance.
So far the United Rubber Workers has resisted the demands. If the resistance continues, might Bridge stone-Firestone hire replacement workers? "That would always be a possibility," said Richard Thomas, a company spokesman, "but we have not even discussed that yet, because we have not gotten to that point."

HEADLINE: Greyhound to Concentrate On Shorter Regional Routes

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DALLAS, July 14

 BODY:
In an announcement that marks the end of an era, Greyhound Lines Inc., unable to make money as the only nationwide bus system, said today that it would abandon most of its direct long-distance service and concentrate instead on regional routes of 400 miles or less.
What that means, said William Kula, a Greyhound spokesman, is "more New York-Boston, Dallas-Houston, Los Angeles-San Francisco, as opposed to Washington D.C. to Los Angeles or Chicago to Miami." 
 Long-haul passengers will still be able to get from here to there, but they will have to work at it. Frank J. Schmieder, the Greyhound chief executive, said they would have to make more transfers, in many cases to other bus lines.
"We're not abandoning the long-haul market," he said in an interview. "But we're not going to focus on it and we're not going to market it.'
And while the company plans some feeder service from smaller cities into its hubs, many places will lose their Greyhound stops altogether. The company hopes that smaller bus companies will fill the gaps.
Though Greyhound served 15 million riders last year, discount air fares had left fewer passengers willing to endure a bus trip of more than eight hours, Mr. Schmieder said, while low gasoline prices have more travelers relying on their cars.
The company announced that it had lost more than $45 million in the second quarter, compared with $5.6 million in the quarter a year earlier -- making it almost impossible for Greyhound to earn a profit for this year, Mr. Schmieder said.
Over all, the company plans to cut 100 to 200 buses from a fleet of 1,800. Other economies will include closing or consolidating some terminals, no longer keeping about 60 others open from midnight to 5 A.M. and eliminating free checked baggage.
Greyhound, which emerged from bankruptcy in 1991, remains in a vulnerable financial condition. In a statement, Mr. Schmieder said that the quarterly loss violated the conditions of the company's bank loans, but that these terms were being renegotiated.

HEADLINE: Gubernatorial Convention to Open

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 14

 BODY:
Three candidates for governor are coming to the Democratic convention that opens here Friday night, all pledging to unify the party, which finished last in 1990's three-way race won by Lowell P. Weicker Jr. But not one is pledged to accept their convention's decision, and a primary is all but certain.
The contest is a struggle to win back voters whose loyalties were weakened by a Governor allied with neither major party; by Ross Perot's 1992 campaign for President, and by the harsh actions that the Democratic-controlled Legislature took during the state's fiscal crisis. 
 Until 1990 a Democrat had governed Connecticut for 32 of the previous 36 years. Thirty-eight percent of the state's registered voters are Democrats.
 
Voting for Change Again
 "In 1994, people are going to vote for change again, in large part because they still don't think they got the change they ordered the last time out," said State Comptroller William E. Curry Jr., the candidate most directly challenging party leadership. "If the Democratic Party has the guts and vision to choose change first, then there's a chance they'll take our leadership in November."
The expected Republican candidate, John Rowland, a former United States Representative from Waterbury, outpolled the Democrat four years ago (and spent $3 million in doing so). Mr. Weicker is not seeking re-election, though his party, A Connecticut Party, supports Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark for governor.
 
Larson Is Best Known
 The Democratic leadership favors John B. Larson, president pro tem of the State Senate. Best known of the Democratic candidates and the best financed, he has raised $1.1 million so far, half a million more than Mr. Curry. Mr. Larson sounds traditional Democrat bywords, with an upward skew toward the middle class.
"I still think we're the party of hope," Mr. Larson said. "I represent the vast majority of the people who are in the middle being squeezed, the ones who are not so poor that they're on welfare, and not so wealthy as to be worry free."
Both Mr. Curry and a third candidate, State Senator Richard J. Balducci, are counting on proving, in a September primary, that they appeal to a broader group of voters than the party leaders.
 
Balducci Struggles
 Mr. Balducci has struggled to hold enough delegates to qualify for a primary. He needs 222, 15 percent of the 1,476 delegates, on any ballot. While Mr. Larson and his supporters worked to establish that he is the clear front runner, Mr. Curry appeared to be close.
Little separates the three men on issues. Many Democrats concede that any one would be acceptable to oppose Mr. Rowland.
"This is not a case where it should be Bill and it can't be John," said Thomas Carusello, the state A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s political director. His vote as a delegate will go to Mr. Curry, but as Waterbury's Democratic town chairman he is pledged to support the convention's choice in a primary.
Mr. Larson, 45 years old, has represented East Hartford in the Senate for 12 years. The owner of an insurance agency, a former teacher, he has focused on family issues, education and economic development.
A critic of Mr. Weicker's economic efforts, which include grants and loans to businesses, Mr. Larson says Connecticut needs an economic vision. He proposes making the state a leader in high-technology research.
He has supported bills to toughen criminal penalties, to expand the death penalty, to ban assault rifles and to restrict handgun purchases.
"The first initiative of the Governor, aside from establishing a jobs agenda, has to be to make the streets safe and the schools safe and to make people feel safe and secure in their homes," he said.
Mr. Curry, 42, was challenging the party establishment in the 1970's, pushing for campaign reform as a young State Senator from Farmington. In 1990 he won nomination for comptroller at the convention against an incumbent seeking a fifth term.
Mr. Curry is regarded as the race's intellectual, not always a compliment in Connecticut politics. He has released detailed plans for economic development and for fighting crime ("and its causes," he adds). He relishes radio talk shows as opportunities to administer civics lessons.
"People understand that fixing the bureaucracy and fixing the political system are related," Mr. Curry said. "They understand that the cornerstone of this political culture has become a kind of legalized bribery."
Mr. Balducci, 52, was elected to the Senate in 1992 after nine terms as a representative from Newington. He contends that economic development requires lower property taxes. He is best known for his role in 1991, as House speaker, in forming a coalition that enacted a personal income tax to ease the state's fiscal crisis.
"After years of opposing the income tax, he was convinced there was no good alternative," said Ellen Camhi, Stamford's town chairwoman. "It was a very difficult, wrenching session, and he kept people from destroying each other, the party, the state, and came up with the best possible solution."

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Tepid, Spurring the Markets

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
Consumers increased their spending at retail counters by a tepid six-tenths of 1 percent in June, a smaller rebound than expected from two straight months of decline and confirmation that this engine of economic growth is running low on steam.
"The consumer has backed off from the first-quarter buying binge," said Martin A. Regalia, chief economist for the United States Chamber of Commerce, referring to the Government's report on sales last month that also included a downward revision for May. 
 Except for last Friday's labor-market report, itself not without soft spots, today's results from the Commerce Department were the latest in a long series of statistics indicating slower economic growth and inflation still in check.
Most analysts take this to mean that the Federal Reserve is finding it progressively harder to find domestic reasons for another increase in short-term interest rates to head off any future revival of inflation. The Fed is thought unlikely to move solely to support the sagging dollar.
That outlook gave heart to the bond market, which rallied for its best session in weeks. Stocks followed suit, with the Dow Jones industrial average spurting by 34.97 points, spurred not only by bonds and falling interest rates but by investor optimism on inflation. [Pages D6 and D13.]
 Separately, the Labor Department reported that first-time claims for unemployment insurance jumped 19,000 last week to the highest level, 363,000, since mid-May. The figures were unusually hard to interpret, however, since they were muddied by the Fourth of July holiday. Holidays tend to depress claims despite adjustments for them.
In addition, the report reflected the first full week of a new quarter, and because benefits are based on recent quarterly earnings, many people with rising earnings defer filing so as to include a second quarter.
Jobless claims for the week ended July 2 were revised to show a 9,000 decline instead of the initially reported drop of 21,000, the figures also showed.
The retail sales report, though showing gains in seven of the nine principal categories, was robust in only a few areas, and in two of these -- department stores and stores selling apparel -- there are already signs of weakening in early July.
Today's results also seemed to shed light on the Federal Reserve's report on Tuesday of accelerating extensions of consumer installment credit. That implied that consumers were borrowing under duress rather than because they were confident about jobs and incomes, suggesting that even small spending increases -- retail sales account for one-third of economic activity -- might be hard to sustain.
"What's slowing down the economy is consumer spending -- it's already happening," said James E. Annable, chief economist the First National Bank of Chicago. He said the benefits of low interest rates and mortgage refinancing were "playing out" and that debt-to-income ratios had climbed back to their peaks of the 1980's.
Laurence H. Meyer, an economic consultant in St. Louis, told clients today that it would "be a stretch" for growth in gross domestic product to reach a rate of 3 1/2 percent for the April-June quarter.
 
Effect on the Fed
 This, however, would still be above the 2 1/2 percent or so that most economists regard as the economy's long-run capacity, one reason to think the Fed will not abandon thoughts of another tightening of monetary policy. Gross domestic product in the first quarter rose at a 3.4 percent rate.
Retail sales last month totaled $183.81 billion, 39 percent in durable goods like cars and furniture that posted a gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent. Merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes rang up a 2.7 percent gain, while sales at automotive dealers rose 1.3 percent and stores selling furniture and other equipment for the home showed a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent.
Excluding the automotive group, where shortages of some popular models have crimped sales, retail sales rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, the report also showed.
Among nondurables, 61 percent of the total, the only decline, six-tenths of 1 percent, was at food stores, offsetting a May advance.
The sales figures are seasonal, adjusted for holiday and trading differences but not for price changes.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Chrysler Has Record Profit Once Again

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich., July 14

 BODY:
With its profit margins widening on car and truck sales, the Chrysler Corporation reported today that its earnings jumped almost 40 percent in the second quarter, to $956 million, a company record for any quarter.
The auto maker said its profits increased because of an improved mix in its sales: a greater proportion of truck sales, which tend to be more profitable because trucks are in shorter supply, and a declining proportion of fleet sales, which are less profitable because fleets buy in bulk. 
 Chrysler's year-over-year improvement was stronger than the numbers would suggest, because earnings of $685 million in the comparable period a year ago included one-time gains of $109 million from the sale of stock in the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation and the sale of some plastics operations.
 "It was a very strong and clean quarter, just like the first quarter," said Michael P. Ward, an auto industry analyst for Kidder, Peabody.
Chrysler surpassed its previous earnings record of $938 million, set in the first quarter of this year. And the auto maker reached that peak on lower revenue: $13.1 billion, up 19.1 percent from revenue of $11 billion in the second quarter a year ago, but down from a record $13.2 billion in the first quarter of this year.
Earnings for the quarter, which ended on June 30, came to $2.61 a primary common share, slightly ahead of most analysts' expectations and well above last year's level of $1.86 a share. On a fully diluted basis, the earnings were $2.35 a share.
Retail sales rose 4.9 percent in the United States in the quarter, Chrysler said. But revenues declined slightly from the first quarter because of factory shutdowns to prepare for new models that restrained sales from factories to dealers.
 
 
15% Market Share
 Chrysler finished the quarter with about a 15 percent share of the United States vehicle market. That is unchanged from a year earlier, because the market has grown.
Investors appeared to have discounted the earnings report well in advance. In heavy trading today on the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Chrysler fell 75 cents each, to $49.375. It was the sixth most heavily traded stock on the Big Board.
After soaring for months, the stocks of all three domestic auto makers tumbled early this year, apparently because investors decided that rising interest rates would restrain sales and shorten the auto industry's recovery. But sales have remained strong.
"I think we're going to get another wave in the auto stocks," Mr. Ward said. "There's another two to three years in the cycle."
General Motors and Ford are expected to report earnings in two weeks.
With demand strong, Chrysler, the No. 3 auto maker in the United States, has been steadily shrinking its rebates and other customer incentives, raising its profit on each vehicle. The average incentive offered on each vehicle during the second quarter was $610, down from $1,050 a year earlier and $710 in the first quarter.
 
Older Models Are Cut
 In addition, Chrysler has discontinued some older models like its Acclaim and Spirit compact sedans. Mr. Ward said Chrysler's popular mini-vans, Jeep Grand Cherokee, Dodge Ram pickup truck, and LH midsize sedans accounted for 64 percent of the company's output in the second quarter, up from 53 percent in the first quarter.
 Further, the chief financial officer of Chrysler, Gary C. Valade, said fleet sales had declined as a percentage of total sales. For the second quarter, fleet sales accounted for 15 percent of sales, down from 17 percent a year earlier and 20 percent in the first quarter. Under pressure from Wall Street, the Big Three domestic auto makers have been reducing their reliance on sales to fleets.
Before taxes, Chrysler's average profit on each vehicle was $2,160 in the second quarter, compared with $1,350 in the comparable quarter a year earlier and $1,980 in the first quarter of this year.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Makes Strong Gains As the Bond Market Rallies

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar staged its biggest gain against the German mark in six weeks yesterday and rose against most other currencies as a bond market rally revived confidence in American assets.
"A little bit of the doom and gloom lifted today," said John McCarthy, foreign-exchange manager at ING Capital Markets. 
 The dollar was quoted at 1.5545 marks in late New York trading yesterday, up more than a pfennig from Wednesday. The dollar also rose to 98.60 yen from 98.30 in New York. The dollar is almost 4 pfennigs above its 20-month low against the mark and 2 yen above its post-World War II low, reached earlier this week.
Even so, many traders were not convinced the recent slump had ended. "The dollar isn't out of the woods yet," Mr. McCarthy said.
 
Retail Sales Slow
 The dollar began its climb when bonds rose on the Commerce Department's retail sales report for June. It indicated that the economy was not growing fast enough to revive inflation, which erodes the value of bonds and other fixed-income securities.
"The dollar fell too far, and the bonds became cheap, so people bought both," said Paul Farrell, manager of strategic currency trading at Chase Manhattan Bank.
Traders also drove the dollar higher after Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said the Treasury and the Federal Reserve agreed that the dollar must be stronger.
"We're going to continue to be in accord with the Federal Reserve and their objectives to see that we have sustained growth with low inflation and work toward a strong dollar," Mr. Bentsen said.
The Treasury Secretary's comments gave the dollar a lift because many traders interpreted them to mean that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates or buy dollars to bolster the American currency. Higher rates in the United States would make dollar-denominated investments more attractive.
Many traders said the dollar's three-day rally did not mean that it had halted its four-month slide against other currencies. "None of the underlying issues that caused the dollar to fall have changed," Mr. McCarthy at ING Capital said.
He expects the dollar to fall further against the yen unless the United States and Japan succeed in talks aimed at opening Japanese markets. Without such strides, the Japan's $60 billion annual trade surplus with the United States will persist, he said.
Jeffrey E. Garten, the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, said yesterday that progress in the trade talks was "very slow" and that negotiators faced "significant obstacles."
The dollar gained against most other currencies yesterday. It rose to 5.3320 French francs, from 5.2815 francs on Wednesday, and strengthened to 1.3117 Swiss francs from 1.3005 francs.
The British pound was quoted at $1.5600 late yesterday, down from $1.5640. The dollar rose to 1,548 Italian lire from 1,526 lire. The Canadian dollar was steady at 72.40 United States cents.

HEADLINE: Merchants See Modest Boom In Business From World Cup

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 14

 BODY:
They might not have known a header from a penalty kick, a Baggio from a Romario, but hotels, restaurants, souvenir stands and other businesses in the region apparently had no trouble recognizing the traveler's checks tendered by visitors to the World Cup.
Officials said today that the games at Giants Stadium, the last of which was played on Wednesday night, had pumped $450 million to $500 million into the area's economy, including nearly $200 million in New York City. Those figures landed in the middle of predictions made before the World Cup started here on June 18. 
 But not everyone was happy. Some executives said they had been so caught up in the pre-match hype -- "The most popular sport on the globe!" "Money is no object to these soccer fanatics!" -- that they had overstocked and overstaffed and finished with so-so revenues.
"It was not as significant as we thought, but it was better than we would have done without them," said Therese M. Lewis, director of sales at the 296-room Meadowlands Hilton. "It was not a huge, giant, sold-out-every-night situation, which is what we were told it was going to be two years ago."
 
Disappointment at Hotels
 Other hotel executives on both sides of the Hudson River agreed. They said they had expected most foreign visitors -- who held about one-third of the tickets for the Meadowlands games -- to make reservations. But many of these fans were from Italy and Ireland and were able to stay with relatives or friends in the large immigrant communities in the region.
Still, the hotel occupancy rate for New York City was projected at 74 percent for July, up from an average of 65 percent for that month from 1991 to 1993, the New York City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, said in a report on the economic benefits of the Cup released this week.
Mr. Hevesi said visitors to the Cup spent $63.8 million on food, entertainment and gifts in New York City. Total direct spending was $137.8 million, with an additional $69 million in indirect economic activity, meaning the ripple effect of the increased income earned by workers who provide goods or services to visitors. That produced $9.5 million in city taxes, he said. Altogether for the region, the Comptroller's Office estimated gains of $484 million.
New Jersey issued an early estimate of $460 million for the region, more than half of which was for the state. But officials said the figure might rise after more research was completed, perhaps to $550 million or $600 million. The state's tax coffers reaped $15 million to $20 million, they said.
 
A Lasting Effect
 Gualberto Medina, the New Jersey Commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development, said the impact might be greater than predicted before the World Cup because few officials had expected that all seven games in Giants Stadium would sell out, as they did. The stadium seats nearly 80,000.
And Mr. Medina said the Cup would have a lasting effect, noting that with many foreign dignitaries and executives visiting, the state had had an excellent opportunity to sell itself. "The contacts we made with officials from other countries were invaluable," he said.
In Hoboken, which is near the Meadowlands and has one of the highest concentration of bars and restaurants in New Jersey, Mayor Anthony Russo said business had been strong, even though the City Council recently passed some restrictions in an effort to clamp down on rowdy patrons.
"Just a look-see each evening showed most of our restaurants were filled to capacity," Mayor Russo said. "It was sort of atypical because these are the summer months and I don't think their business was that good last year. So it had to be attributable to the Cup."
At the Meadowlands this morning, in a fitting coda to an event that businesses of every sort tried to profit from, pieces of the Bermuda grass playing field were being sold, at $20 a square foot -- perhaps the perfect souvenir for people looking for a surface upon which to display their chunk of the Berlin Wall. The money was donated to the United States Soccer Federation.
 
A Sod Shrine
 One man said he would put the sod next to grass he plucked from the field of Shea Stadium after the Mets won the World Series in 1969. Another customer, Mike Martocci, 31, a firefighter from Fairlawn, N.J., said he would create a shrine by planting his sod (complete with chalk line) in his front yard, roping it off and sticking in some Italian and American flags.
"Right here on this turf Baggio walked and scored and even spit," he said of Roberto Baggio, the graceful Italian star who scored two goals on Wednesday night.
At Giants Stadium on Wednesday, as spectators milled around before the Italy-Bulgaria match, vendors like Warren Dischler, 44, and Joe Lucignano, 43, said they had done well. Mr. Dischler, a contractor from Secaucus, N.J., was so busy hawking soda for $2 a can that he barely had time to talk. "The heat helps you out," he said.
Mr. Lucignano, a bus driver from Hoboken, said he had few complaints, though he did say that he had fallen prey to overly optimistic expectations. He gave a brief lecture on the effect of nationalism on his sales, noting that the early exits of Colombia and Mexico had hurt revenues. There aren't many Bulgarian immigrants in the region, he pointed out.
 
The Local Hard Sell
 And then it was back to work for Mr. Lucignano, who earned about $500 a game, for 12 hours' work selling programs at $5 and $8 each.
"You going to read it or buy it?" he asked Pijush Sen, 45, a visitor from India who might have been unaccustomed to the local hard sell. "You've been looking for five minutes."
"You show me Romario's picture, I'll buy it," replied Mr. Sen, an engineer, referring to the Brazilian star.
"Ah, I got no time for this," Mr. Lucignano said. "I'm trying to make money here. If I talk to you, I don't make money. Come on, the ink's starting to come off that book!"

GRAPHIC: Photo: A vendor's tent at Giants Stadium appeared as if it had seen more action than the soccer field nearby. Although revenues produced by the World Cup matches disappointed some people in the metropolitan area, Jeff Schnarr of South Brunswick kept busy counting his intake. (Sam D'Amico for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
U S West Seen Near Deal

 BODY:
U S West is close to acquiring two cable systems in Atlanta from a partnership consisting of Robert M. Bass and Lehman Brothers for $1.2 billion, several people close to the transaction said yesterday. A spokesman for U S West declined to comment yesterday.
The planned sale, which was first reported by USA Today yesterday, would mark the transfer of ownership of systems with the largest single concentration of customers in one metropolitan area. The systems -- Wometco and Georgia Cable Television -- have 460,000 subscribers. While the Atlanta market is the country's ninth-largest metropolitan statistical area, it has the third-largest growth rate. 
 U S West, based in Englewood, Colo., would be entering a telephone market controlled by the BellSouth Corporation. The purchase would allow U S West to immediately begin offering cable services and the company is said to be hoping to offer telephony as well.
People close to the transaction said U S West hoped to create a large affiliated group of cable properties and to benefit from economies of scale because of its relationship with Time Warner. U S West owns 25 percent of Time Warner Entertainment, a division of Time Warner that holds Warner Brothers.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
J. P. Morgan's Net Fell 18.8% in 2d Quarter

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
J. P. Morgan & Company, the nation's third-largest banking company, said yesterday that its earnings declined 18.8 percent in the second quarter, below security analysts' projections, largely because of a big drop in trading revenues.
Net income fell to $350 million, or $1.73 a share, from $431 million, or $2.12 a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1993. For the first half of this year, profits dropped 4.3 percent, to $695 million, or $3.43 a share, from $726 million, or $4.27 a share, before the effect of an accounting change, in the comparable period a year ago. 
 Shares of J. P. Morgan fell 25 cents yesterday, to $60, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Trading revenues of $228 million in the second quarter were less than half the $520 million in revenues recorded a year earlier. The company attributed the decline in trading debt instruments, foreign exchange, swaps and other interest-rate contracts to the maintenance of smaller risk positions and "modest positioning losses" in some markets.
"Trading was at the lowest level since the fourth quarter of 1992," said George Salem, a banking analyst for Prudential Securities. "And if you add back the special loss they took that quarter, it would be the lowest since the first quarter of 1992."
 
'A Weak Quarter'
 Raphael Soifer, an analyst for Brown Brothers Harriman, said: "It was a weak quarter for Morgan. But I certainly wouldn't characterize it as falling out of bed."
The downturn at Morgan came on the same day that several regional banking companies -- including the First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., NBD Bancorp of Detroit and the Wachovia Corporation of Winston Salem, N.C. -- reported higher earnings. The Bank of New York Company also reported a large increase in net income for the quarter.
But on Wednesday the First Chicago Corporation announced that its profits from trading stocks and bonds in worldwide markets plummeted to $37 million, from $91 million in the second quarter of 1993. And other banks that depend on trading for much of their revenue could also report similar declines.
The J. P. Morgan earnings benefited from several nonrecurring gains. Net interest revenue in the second quarter advanced to $540 million from $424 million but included a gain of $35 million from past-due interest claims on Brazilian assets and $50 million from income-tax revenues.
In addition, the company gained $255 million from the sale of about one-third of its shares of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation. This represented the overwhelming bulk of the gains of $264 million in equity investment securities recorded in the quarter.
Some banking experts said J. P. Morgan's disappointing results stemmed more from the rising interest rates in the quarter, which caused the stock and bond markets to fall, than from any loss of trading prowess.
"It's indicative of the environment and the markets," said Diane B. Glossman, an analyst for Salomon Brothers. "I think it's just a transitory event."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
N.B.A.'s Ordeal in Court: Is Stern Losing His Touch at the Foul Line?

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
The courtroom is familiar territory to the National Basketball Association. The league is fighting for position against a diverse group of legal opponents: the players' union, the jilted buyer of the Minnesota Timberwolves, and the former three-time champions of the league, the Chicago Bulls.
On Tuesday, the league and the National Basketball Players Association, which have hit an impasse in collective bargaining, squabbled in Federal Court in Manhattan over thorny issues like the salary cap, which an emboldened union wants eliminated. The case could be decided today and may have a profound effect on the league's future if the union wins. 
 Meanwhile, a Louisiana state judge in New Orleans yesterday barred the league from printing its 1994-95 schedule until the dispute over the Timberwolves' sale ends. The ruling came despite the N.B.A.'s rejection of the $152 million purchase and proposed move of the team by Top Rank of Louisiana, and despite the fact that a Federal judge in Minneapolis had ordered the Louisiana court to halt all proceedings in the case. The league said it would publish the schedule regardless of the New Orleans ruling.
 
Bulls Ruling Next on Line
 The league is also awaiting a ruling from a Federal judge in Chicago on whether the N.B.A. can restrict or end Bulls broadcasts on WGN, a Chicago-based superstation whose telecasts can be seen on cable systems across the country.
Is the armor of David Stern, once the model of the modern-day sports commissioner, denting? In the post-Michael Jordan era, is Stern becoming vulnerable? Two of Stern's adversaries say no.
"He is still extremely powerful," said Jerry Reinsdorf, the Bulls' owner, who has criticized Stern before the other owners for spending too much of the league's money to fight him and WGN. "Within the league he's still king. He and I had a major disagreement that we can't work out. But it hasn't affected my relationship with him. He's in a position to make life miserable for me, but he doesn't."
Charles Grantham, the executive director of the players' union, said it is the success of the Stern-led N.B.A. that has led to the legal problems. To the list of the league's legal woes, Grantham added the N.B.A.'s failure in court last year to block the Portland Trail Blazers' signing of Chris Dudley to a contract the league believed to be a salary cap subterfuge.
 
'Success Breeding Conflict'
 "I'd characterize it more in light of success breeding arrogance and conflict," Grantham said. "The Chicago and Minnesota situations were cases of owners leaving the reservation. Same with Portland. It's the individual owners, who all used to scream 'we,' now screaming 'me.' I don't know if respect for Stern has changed, but it's individuals looking out for themselves."
Regarding his relationship with Stern, Grantham said: "We're cordial and contentious when need be."
Bad news for Stern, however, was the union's success in getting a temporary restraining order to halt all player signings. Not happy news, either, was Grantham's admission during the trial Tuesday that his idol was Marvin Miller, baseball's former union leader, who outmaneuvered club owners for two decades.
Jan Hubbard, an N.B.A. spokesman, said Stern was not available to discuss the ongoing litigation.
 
Never a Pushover
 Stern's N.B.A. has hardly backed down. The league launched the legal action against the union, believing that it had to do so before the union went to court first. The N.B.A. also sued to stop the Timberwolves' sale, as well as to keep Portland from signing Dudley to a contract whose first year's salary seemed to fit too perfectly into the team's final salary slot at a level well below his market value.
The league was sued by the Bulls and WGN in 1990, and the league has so far lost at every turn in that case.
 Stern himself is an aggressive witness. At Tuesday's one-day trial in the union case, he confidently defended as economic necessities the need to continue the salary cap, the college draft and the right of first refusal, which gives teams a chance to resign their own restricted free agents. He also pressed his belief that this was a labor dispute, not one for the courts to resolve.
 
'How Much Were You Paid?'
 He did not refrain from defending his right to a megasalary, which was awarded to him by owners, without any form of a cap.
Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr., a lawyer for the union, asked Stern: "In the year 1990, how much were you paid?"
The query caused two N.B.A. lawyers to leap, in unison, to object.
"I don't object to earning money," the commissioner said.
Schwarz: "How much in 1990? Wasn't it $13.5 million, a $10 million bonus and $3.5 million in salary?"
Stern: "Yes."
Schwarz: "Well, you're making a lot of money."
Stern: "More than I ever thought I would."
Schwarz: "I'm making more money than I thought."
Stern: "How much?"
Schwarz did not reply.

HEADLINE: WORLD CUP '94;
Coaches in Cup Final Do It Their Way

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif., July 14

 BODY:
Before Brazil faced Sweden on Wednesday, Coach Carlos Alberto Parreira was introduced to what should have been a friendly crowd at the Rose Bowl. Thousands of fans wore yellow shirts and waved the yellow and green flag of Brazil. Parreira was about to lead Brazil to its first World Cup final in 24 years. He would be hailed as a conquering hero, right?
Not a chance. 
 As his name was announced, Parreira was roundly booed. During the game, his face was flashed on the giant television screen at the Rose Bowl, and he was booed again.
At about the same time in Italy on Wednesday, after the Italian team had defeated Bulgaria to gain its first trip to the World Cup finals since 1982, the RAI television network conducted a poll regarding Coach Arrigo Sacchi. Sixty percent of the respondents said that Sacchi's success was based more on luck than skill.
"I don't care if we win or not, at least not like this," said Gennaro Suppa, an elementary school teacher from the southern region of Calabria. "This team hasn't shown me anything."
No two World Cup coaches have been more successful or less appreciated than Parreira of Brazil and Sacchi of Italy. Both have been vilified by the news media in their countries, ripped by fans, dismissed as ignorant in their choices of players and tactics. Parreira's lineup choices were questioned by his own mother.
Somehow, despite overwhelming pressure and skepticism, the coaches have ignored the critics and followed their own muse. In doing so, they have achieved a personal deliverance, accomplishing the very goal their detractors asserted that they could not: reaching the World Cup final on Sunday.
"I kept my way, instead of succumbing to people who don't deserve the freedom to criticize," Parreira said today. "The important thing is for Sacchi and myself to believe in what we are doing and follow that road until the end. I'm happy our way was shown to be the correct way."
Both Parreira and Sacchi are curious, engaging men, and unlike many American football coaches, they have lives outside their sport. Parreira is a painter. Sacchi is an avid reader of politics and economics and of the novels of Faulkner and Steinbeck.
For each of the last three years, Sacchi has spent a month in the United States, getting to know its customs and traditions in anticipation of the World Cup. The son of a shoemaker, Sacchi was never a great player; he rode a slow elevator from the basement of the lowliest Italian division to the penthouse as coach of the national team.
"I am accustomed to suffering and accusations and criticism, to people saying, 'You can't do this, it can't happen,' " Sacchi said in an interview in his apartment in Milan in late April. "I've always been a dreamer."
 
Experimentation With 73 Players
 There were many who accused Sacchi of slipping beyond dreams into delusion. He called 73 players up to the national team in his three years as coach. What he called experimentation, others labeled as bumbling indecision. Last fall, Guerin Sportivo, an Italian soccer magazine, ran photos of all 73 and tossed in other shots of Pope John Paul II, Robin Williams as Popeye and Sylvester Stallone as Rambo to ridicule Sacchi's uncertainty, asking in a mocking headline, "Arrigo, Have You Forgotten Anyone?"
When the Azzurri lost by 2-1 in a spring exhibition against Pontedera, a team in Italy's fourth division, American Oggi, an Italian-language newspaper published in New Jersey, demanded that Sacchi be fired "before it's too late." There was no way he could employ his attacking, pressing style in any coherent manner with only a month's preparation with the national team. Or so the skeptics believed. Clearly, they were wrong.
His glasses forever perched on his balding head, Sacchi had proceeded during the World Cup like some obsessive chemist, his lineups resembling exotic test-tube concoctions. By the semifinals, Sacchi had already used 20 of his 22 players in different starting arrangements. Then he shifted the midfield again for Bulgaria. Sometimes, he has simply relied on audacious spontaneity.
When goalkeeper Gianluca Pagliuca received a red card against Norway, and Italy was forced to yank a player, Sacchi benched none other than Roberto Baggio, voted the world's best player in 1993. Against Mexico, he brought on forward Daniele Massaro at halftime, and almost immediately Massaro delivered a goal. Against Spain, Sacchi did not start Giuseppe Signori, the leading scorer in the Italian league; Signori came on in the second half, though, and made the pass in the 88th minute that sprung Baggio for the winning goal.
 
Similar Pressure on Parreira
 Parreira, too, has followed his own instinct to great accomplishment, despite relentless criticism. In Brazil, there is an almost magnetic attraction-repulsion relationship between the national team coach and the ravenous news media. In fact, one journalist, Joao Saldanha, was actually named head coach as Brazil prepared for the 1970 World Cup.
"He was such a critic that they decided to make him coach," said Francisco Marcos, the Brazilian team liaison.
Saldanha's tenure came to an abrupt halt when he threatened to leave Pele off the World Cup team, but the point is this: journalists think they know as much about soccer as the coach. And they are not shy in expressing their opinions and demanding changes. Parreira has described his job as national coach of Brazil as a "a compromise, a commitment, a death sentence sometimes."
Parreira, a native of Brazil who previously coached Kuwait in the 1982 World Cup and the United Arab Emirates in the 1990 World Cup, said: "Being Brazil's coach in the World Cup, this is no fun. There's a great deal of responsibility, but no joy at all until you win."
Only two weeks ago, when Brazil drew 1-1 against Sweden, the tie was derided as a "national tragedy" by the Brazilian news media. Pele and Brazil President Itamar Franco suggested lineup changes. Parreira's mother asked him to use Ronaldo, the precocious 17-year-old forward. Parreira suggested that six Brazilian teams be allowed to play in the World Cup. Such an arrangement, he said, "might please half of the people."
 
First-Ever Qualifying Loss
 Parreira suffered the indignity of Brazil's first-ever loss during World Cup qualifying -- a 2-0 loss to Bolivia in La Paz. But, except for benching the enigmatic midfielder Rai -- something the news media had been urging -- he has ignored the critics' howling.
He made the unpopular choice of including defender Branco on the World Cup roster, and Branco scored the winning goal against the Netherlands in the quarterfinals. When Romario became a disciplinary problem, Parreira kept him off the national team for nine months until last fall. He also ignored Romario's calls that his friend Edmundo be included on the roster at forward instead of Muller. Since then, Romario has quit complaining.
"We Brazilians have not recognized the honest work done by Parreira," Romario said on Tuesday. "The Brazilian media should be thankful for Parreira. To put up with what he has put up with, someone like me, I wouldn't put up with it."
Imagine that. A compliment.

HEADLINE: Nigerian Democracy, Under Arrest

 BODY:
Nigeria can be described as a giant-size country under pint-size military rule. A year ago, Nigeria's generals decided to allow their people a whiff of democracy under highly controlled circumstances. Two political parties were formed under military tutelage; two carefully screened candidates were allowed to contest the presidency. Even so, when voters failed to approve the regime's first choice, the military ruler broke his promises, annulled the election and robbed the presumed winner, Moshood Abiola, of victory.
The result has been a grass-roots pro-democratic uprising that the current military clique has been unable to quell. The crisis deepened a few weeks ago when Mr. Abiola, a Muslim and millionaire with a following in Nigeria's non-Muslim south, proclaimed himself President on the first anniversary of the canceled election. For that he was charged with treason, held incommunicado and threatened with a life sentence. When a federal high court judge twice ordered the military to produce Mr. Abiola in open court, the junta ignored the order. 
 Predictably, the effect has been to widen the rebellion. Nigeria's biggest city, Lagos, was shut down yesterday by demonstrations, a work boycott and a strike, now in its 11th day, by the powerful oil workers' union. All this has placed the ruling cabal in a wholly untenable position. The demonstrators ask only for what they have been repeatedly promised: a return to civilian rule.
Nigeria is Africa's most populous country and the world's sixth-largest oil exporter. Yet years of misrule have made Nigeria a byword for chaos and cupidity. A once-outspoken press is now stifled, the narcotics traffic in Lagos is brazenly open and a potentially prosperous economy is wasted by a huge foreign debt, bribes and incompetence. The country's best-known author, the Nobel laureate Wole Soyinka, even fears that "Nigeria will not survive as a nation" unless the current junta steps down and permits Mr. Abiola to assume office.
All this has been noted and deplored in Washington, but without sufficient urgency and passion. This is an occasion for vigorous preventive diplomacy. Americans have the right to warn and to shame, especially given the dramatic democratic transformation in South Africa. If Pretoria's white minority rulers can honor their promise to hold elections and inaugurate President Nelson Mandela, by what reasoning does Nigeria's cabal flout the same principle?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Save F.H.A. Loans for Needy Families

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is backing legislation that would give more families Government-guaranteed mortgages. Put that way, the policy sounds enlightened. Why then do prominent community housing groups and consumer advocates oppose the legislation?
Their objections flow from a less flattering interpretation of the House and Senate bills: they authorize the Federal Housing Administration to help relatively high-income families. That would help mortgage lenders, whose loans to those families would become risk-free. But it would siphon mortgages from low-income home buyers whom the F.H.A. is supposed to protect. 
 Under the House bill, the F.H.A. would be allowed to provide Government-backed insurance to lenders who provide mortgages up to $101,575; the current limit is $67,500. In high-cost areas like New York City, the limit would be raised to $172,675.
But families would need to earn $70,000 a year or more to afford such mortgages. Most of these families already own houses and do not need help from the F.H.A., whose primary mission is to make a family's first house affordable.
Community housing groups note that raising the F.H.A.'s limits does nothing to make a family's monthly mortgage payments more affordable. And the higher limits will steer lenders away from the less-profitable smaller mortgages that go to low-income families. The bill's sponsors counter by arguing that if the F.H.A. is permitted to cater to richer families, it will cut down defaults and generate profit that could be used to help the poor.
This proposition is dubious. True, the current default rate is high. Lenders of F.H.A.-backed mortgages, protected from default, provide loans with very low down payments. Low down payments invite foreclosure -- and losses for the F.H.A. -- because the families have little equity at stake and the lenders have little incentive to monitor their customers. Indeed, last year over 80,000 families with F.H.A.-backed mortgages defaulted; in some areas, F.H.A. foreclosure rates reach nearly 30 percent.
But if legislation steers families into larger mortgages, it is likely to attract credit-risky families and trigger more foreclosures -- dealing another blow to neighborhood economic revival.
Despite high default rates, F.H.A.-backed mortgages are an important tool for moving financially strapped families into their first homes. For Congress to steer lenders of these mortgages from the needy toward upper-income families serves no public purpose.

To the Editor:
Assuming that Congress and the Administration can agree on a health care reform package, there will still be the problem of paying for it.
Cigarettes are already one of the most highly taxed commodities but provide far less revenue than would a tax on gasoline, which might also help to reduce health care costs by reducing the risk of another oil-related recession.

HEADLINE: U.S. MAKING MOVES FOR HAITI ACTION

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
While insisting again that a United States invasion of Haiti is not imminent, the Clinton Administration continued today to lay the groundwork for such an action.
Elite Army paratroopers who would probably lead an invasion of Haiti stepped up night training exercises at Fort Bragg, N.C. The Administration announced that 15 countries had signaled a willingness to join a multinational force that would maintain order and retrain Haiti's security forces after the current military government leaves. 
 The exiled Haitian President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, also issued a statement today calling for "swift and definitive" action by the international community to oust Haiti's leaders.
In making known recent military exercises but insisting no invasion is imminent, the Administration seemed to be pressing the Haitian military leaders to leave and also trying to silence critics in Congress who say that the White House is moving precipitately to use force.
A day after the Administration's senior foreign policy advisers briefed Congressional leaders on Haiti policy, Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is an influential voice on military matters, warned the White House to consider any invasion plans "very carefully," and said Haiti is not a "vital" American interest.
At the same time, the Senate today rejected, by a vote of 57 to 42, a proposal by the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole, to head off military action by creating a bipartisan commission to study the Haitian crisis, which opponents said would tie President Clinton's hands for months.
The Administration's actions were seen by many in Washington as a final effort to persuade Haiti's military leaders to leave voluntarily so the United States would not have to send troops, a step President Clinton has said he wants to avoid but will not rule out.
The White House continued to insist that it would still rely on strict economic sanctions to drive out Haiti's military leaders. But even as it maintained that position, some 2,000 paratroopers from the elite 82d Airborne Division, which would be in the vanguard of an American military action, held one of the largest rehearsals of an air assault that the unit has had in two years, Army officials said.
The paratroopers are practicing jumping from C-141 and C-130 transport planes, and securing landing zones for troops and equipment that would be flown in later -- the same task the troops would undertake in an invasion of Haiti.
Military officials in Washington and at Fort Bragg, where the 82d Airborne is based, described the two-night exercise as routine training that had been scheduled for two months.
"Honest to goodness, this isn't related to Haiti or any specific scenario," said Maj. Jim Hinnant, a spokesman for the 82d Airborne.
But one Pentagon-based general said that field commanders are now using long-scheduled exercises "to focus on things we need to get down if we invade Haiti."
 
Marines Stage Evacuation
 In addition, more than 4,000 marines staged a mock evacuation for the second day on Great Inagua Island in the Bahamas, about 80 miles northwest of Haiti. They are part of a force of some 2,860 marines posted on Navy ships near Haiti.
"We don't want to comment on the direct purpose of any training that would be going on," the Pentagon spokeswoman, Kathleen deLaski, said. "Some of the things you see going on are related to training that could be used to execute a military option."
Tensions in Haiti and in Washington have risen following the departure from Haiti on Wednesday of 89 international human rights observers who were declared unwelcome by Haiti's military rulers and given 48 hours to leave the country.
In light of these tensions and reports of the military preparations, Father Aristide's statement, while similar to others he has made in the past, seemed to add to expectations of an invasion. The latest comments seemed to contradict those made in an interview with National Public Radio in June, when he had said, "Never, never, never would I agree to be restored to power by an invasion."
 
15 Nations to Help
 The White House said that as many as 15 nations have signaled that they would participate in a multinational force to maintain security in Haiti after the military leaders leave. But the United Nations must still negotiate with those countries to work out specific details of their involvement.
The chief United States delegate to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, said at a luncheon speech here that countries indicating a willingness to join a post-restoration force include Argentina, Chile, Brazil, Barbados, Jamaica, Trinidad and Tobago, Guyana, Surinam, Belize, El Salvador and Honduras. Ms. Albright said the countries have tentatively committed 2,000 to 4,000 police and trainers.
"They would be there to help with the training of the military and police force, to watch the situation on the ground and to be on hand to make sure that there isn't some upsurge in violence," said the White House spokeswoman, Dee Dee Myers.
Administration officials also said today that Surinam has agreed to join Dominica, Grenada and Antigua in offering safe haven to Haitians fleeing their homeland. Surinam said it could accommodate between 2,000 and 2,500 Haitians.
 
Broadcasts to Haiti
 The State Department announced today that broadcasts, called Radio Democracy, will begin on Friday and will be scheduled for two hours a day -- from 6:30 P.M. to 7:30 P.M., then again from 8 P.M. to 9 P.M. -- on AM 1035 and FM 91.9.
Broadcasts will include messages of reconciliation from Father Aristide and other Haitians, but they will not include appeals for Haitians to halt their attempts to flee in rickety boats, a condition Father Aristide refused to accept.
Administration officials cited what they called encouraging signs that the number of Haitians trying to flee by boat may be dropping.
The State Department spokesman, Michael McCurry, said that about 2,300, or 30 percent, of the 7,600 Haitians being processed at Guantanamo Bay have chosen to return home. The remainder will be sent to third countries until the Haitian military government is replaced.
 
Warnings From Nunn
 Administration officials said the apparent reduction in the number of Haitians fleeing by boat has given the White House some "breathing space" to decide its next steps. But Congressional officials cautioned Mr. Clinton and his advisers not to act rashly.
"When we're thinking of Haiti, we also have to think of other spots in the world where we have potential problems," Senator Nunn said on NBC's "Today" Show. "Korea is a place where we have a vital interest, and that has to be our first top priority. Bosnia is also important and Haiti is important, but neither Bosnia nor Haiti are vital."
Senator Nunn said that calculation would change quickly if Americans come under attack in Haiti. "Right now, they're not under threat," Mr. Nunn said. "If they come under threat, we have to be prepared to move very rapidly."
Ms. Myers said there were no known threats against the more than 4,000 Americans in Haiti, but she added, "The situation is deteriorating, and I think that makes things more difficult for everyone there."

HEADLINE: How the Chengs Finessed Trump

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONG KONG, July 14

 BODY:
It may be one of the last big real estate deals in New York City, but to Henry Cheng, Riverside South, the multibillion-dollar joint venture that could transform Manhattan's largest buildable waterfront land into a community of 16 largely upscale apartment towers along with shops and parks, is just another development.
 "In Hong Kong, China, we've done bigger projects than this, much bigger," said Mr. Cheng, a man parsimonious with words. He and his father, Cheng Yu-tong, have built one of Hong Kong's biggest global property and project development conglomerates, with substantial holdings stretching across Asia and into the United States. 
For the Chengs, Donald J. Trump was not a rival but merely a target of opportunity. Mr. Trump first sketched out the plan for developing the 75-acre site along the Hudson River, blocks from Lincoln Center, but his recent financial problems allowed the Hong Kong group to buy his $250 million debt on the land for a bargain price of some $90 million and take over Riverside South.
 Construction could start within a year, and Mr. Trump will share in the profits. But people familiar with the Chengs' operations agree that they, not Mr. Trump, will call the shots.
 For the Chengs, one of Hong Kong's richest families, with a net worth reportedly about $3.3 billion, the Manhattan project is a minuscule part of their investments, but it is attractive.
 "We think it is a very good investment opportunity," the 47-year-old Mr. Cheng said in an interview in his unostentatious office here. "We think the United States economy has started to pick up."
 "New York is a very slow growth market," he added. "But we believe it has already bottomed out, so we are happy about the existing market. New York is still one of the major cities in the world."
 With land here virtually exhausted, and with extensive interests across Asia, including China, the Chengs have been on the lookout for opportunities in the United States for some time, according to Paul Y. L. Tong, the general manager of the New World Development Company, the centerpiece of the Cheng empire.
 "Previously we have been buying bricks and mortar," Mr. Tong said, referring to the group's vast chain of hotels and residential apartments in the United States, including the upscale Renaissance hotels. "We feel that perhaps this is the right time to do development. We had to look for a partner because we don't know the local situation."
 Because New World does not invest directly in real estate outside Asia, Henry Cheng assembled a consortium of investors to complete the Riverside South deal. "The shareholders are a group of our good friends that got together," Mr. Cheng said. "We bought the debt at a discount." The group also bought the company that owns title to the site.
 "A project of that size is really pin money for these guys," said David Faulkner, a partner at Brooke Hillier Parker, an international property concern with offices here.
 How Henry Cheng's father, Cheng Yu-tong, ascended to the pinnacle of economic power is a familiar tale among the colony's wealthiest families. From his first job, as an apprentice in the Chow Tai Fook jewelry store at the age of 14, he rose quickly to build the largest jewelry chain in Hong Kong. Then he assembleda diversified empire of land, hotels, telecommunications, power projects and roads that branched in stages into China and the rest of Asia.
 
$5.8 Billion Capitalization
 Today, New World, a publicly traded company which the elder Mr. Cheng controls with 35 percent of the stock, has a market capitalization of about $5.8 billion, making it one of Hong Kong's blue chip companies. CTF, as the Chow Tai Fook chain is known, functions as his wholly owned company, and holds his 35 percent share in New World.
 Now 69, Mr. Cheng has built a reputation for hard work and disciplined deal-making. He and his son share adjoining offices in an undistinguished office tower in the central business district, offices that are notable for the lack of opulence so central to Mr. Trump's public image.
 Ever the businessman, Mr. Cheng moved swiftly to build his company's holdings in China in the wake of the June 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre, at a time when many investors held back, hurting China's world trade.
He went to school with Li Ziliu, now the mayor of Guangzhou, where New World has major projects. But Mr. Cheng insists that he has never exploited valuable friendships. "Everything must follow the right way," he told The South China Morning Post last year in one of his rare interviews. "I don't like doing things through the back door."
 
Owner of Ramada Hotels
 New World is perhaps the biggest hotel operator in Hong Kong, with two of the colony's best, the Regent and the Grand Hyatt. The company also owns Ramada International Hotels and Resorts in the United States, a concern that includes 45 Renaissance hotels, with one in New York City, and the Stouffer hotel chain. New World also owns hotels in China, Macao, Australia and the Bahamas, and over the next few years is planning new hotels in Taipei, Bangkok, Phuket, Kuala Lumpur, Kota Kinabalu, Manila and Ho Chi Minh City.
 According to Mr. Faulkner, New World's diversification represents much of its strength. New World has major stakes in container terminals and tunnels, owns one of Hong Kong's four fixed-line telephone licenses and is developing road projects in the New Territories, the stretch of the colony that runs to the border with China. The company also has interests in infrastructure projects in China, including power, water plants and the ring road in Guangzhou.
 Central to the Chengs' investment strategy has been the building up of New World's land banks. While his start in the property business focused on Hong Kong, where he controls about 12 million square feet, he has in recent years acquired far more property in China, where New World owns around 20 million square feet of space, analysts here say.
 "China of course is the flavor of the month, but they're not putting all their eggs in the China basket, particularly because the economy there is having a bumpy landing," Mr. Faulkner said. "The very large groups have outgrown Hong Kong."
 Still, Henry Cheng said that New World intended to put about one-quarter of its assets in China. "We believe in China in the long term," he said. Among the group's recent projects is a $580 million coal-fired power plant in neighboring Guangdong Province.
 
High-Tech Buildings
 Joining Mr. Cheng in the Riverside South project is Vincent Lo, the chairman of the Shui On Group, one of the territory's largest construction concerns. Mr. Lo's group is best known for its modern buildings, particularly Citibank Plaza. With its advanced equipment for teleconferences, sophisticated power management and elevators that never leave patrons waiting more than 15 seconds, Citibank Plaza is considered the most high-tech building in Hong Kong.
 Franklin Lam, a property analyst at Salomon Brothers, said it was also outstanding for what is known in Chinese as Feng-shui -- a traditional practice of determining a building's auspicious setting, orientation and furnishing. Feng-shui is important even to very Westernized Hong Kong builders.
 Mr. Trump first came to the attention of the Chengs through their American investment arm, Polylinks International Ltd., Mr. Tong said. "Then three months ago, we knew that the bank was prepared to sell his paper," he said, referring to the $250 million held by Chase Manhattan Bank. "Through a couple of agents, we started looking seriously."
 Neither Mr. Tong nor Henry Cheng would discuss details of the Chengs' arrangement with Mr. Trump, or describe the elder Mr. Cheng's involvment. But, as to the latter, analysts here have no doubts.
 "Cheng Yu-tung is a much richer man than Donald Trump ever was," said Clive Wheedon, a director at Asia Equity Ltd. "I don't believe any of these guys would ever allow a Westerner to drive one of these deals. Most of them regard the Western entrepreneurs as being pretty sleepy. They're not wrong about that."

Although the arti cle said the Chengs were able to ac quire Mr. Trump's $250 million debt on the Riverside South land at a deep discount, the headline exceeded the facts and emphasis of the article, which was mainly a portrait of the family and its involvement in the project.
