HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Big Charge To Be Taken By Digital

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MAYNARD, Mass., July 14

 BODY:
The Digital Equipment Corporation announced today that it would take a $1.2 billion charge for the fourth quarter to cover the elimination of 20,000 jobs and the reduction of 10 million square feet of office and manufacturing space.
The company, which had announced the job reductions earlier, said the cuts would be accelerated and take place over 12 months rather than two years, as had been previously announced. 
 Robert B. Palmer, Digital's president and chief executive, also announced the end of the company's longtime approach to management. "Matrix management at our company is dead," Mr. Palmer said in a conference call with reporters. "For Digital, that statement is monumental."
 
Novel Management System
 Digital's matrix management structure, which became the focus of business school case studies and organizational management books, was an often chaotic and frustrating environment, where decisions were debated endlessly across departments and business units. It fostered internal competition and resulted in many ground-breaking computer systems like the PDP and VAX lines.
The approach, created by Digital's founder and former president, Kenneth H. Olsen, fueled tremendous growth in the 1960's to the mid-1980's.
But Mr. Palmer said such a strategy no longer worked. "That management approach may have been right when Digital was an emerging company, but it has proved to be unaffordable in the marketplace of the 1990's," he said.
Mr. Palmer announced the formation of two new divisions, the computer systems division, to be run by Enrico Pesatori, and the components division, under Charles F. Christ. An advanced technology group under the company's chief technical officer, William D. Strecker, was also established.
Three other business units, including multi-vendor customer services, Digital consulting and semiconductor operations, will be established. In the new organization, Digital will place engineering, manufacturing, marketing and sales responsibilities under each business unit manager.
"These are good moves," said George Colony, president of Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. "He's doing the right thing. He's just a year and a half late. He should have done this when he took over."
Some analysts were skeptical about the value of another reorganization at Digital, where at least three such make-overs have been instituted in the last 12 months.
"I don't think the underlying problems in a computer company can be solved by shifting boxes on an organizational chart," said William J. Milton, an analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman & Company.
Shares of Digital fell $1.25 today, to $20.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., is expected to announce a huge loss on July 25 for the fourth quarter, which ended July 2. The company will take the $1.2 billion charge against that quarter. Analysts had expected the charge to be around $1 billion.
When the job cuts are completed, the company will have a work force of 65,000 people. Digital plans to reduce its office and manufacturing space worldwide to 22 million square feet within two years.
The company is also expected to absorb a noncash expense of $350 million to $400 million associated with intangible assets and other write-offs during the quarter.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE EMPLOYER MANDATE;
Pizza Chain Blocks Critical Commercial

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
A sharp battle broke out today over workers' health insurance, pitting Pizza Hut against Senator Edward M. Kennedy and a coalition supporting President Clinton's proposal for universal health insurance.
The Health Care Reform Project, a coalition of unions and other groups that would require employers to help pay for insurance, held a news conference here to release a report and show a television commercial accusing the company of hypocrisy on health care. The report said Pizza Hut and McDonald's paid for workers' coverage abroad while fighting legislation that would make them do the same in the United States. 
 But the commercial, which discussed only Pizza Hut, a division of Pepsico, will not be shown outside the Congressional hearing room where the news conference was held because Pizza Hut persuaded four Washington television stations not to broadcast it.
The ad shows a young man bicycling toward the nation's Capitol to deliver a pizza. It says that Pizza Hut pays for health insurance for Japanese and German workers, "but for many workers in America Pizza Hut pays no health insurance. Zero."
 
Aggressive Turn in Debate
 The release of the report and the commercial marked an increasingly aggressive turn taken by those who support Mr. Clinton's proposal that employers be required to buy insurance for their workers -- an issue that that remains the central battleground of the health care debate.
The President and allies like Mr. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who heads the Senate Labor and Human Resource Committee, contend that without some version of this requirement, an "employer mandate," it will be impossible to achieve health insurance coverage for all Americans.
Much of the opposition has come from small-business organizations, but today's challenge was intended to show that some big companies that have many low-wage workers were also fighting the idea.
"What do they have against American workers?" Mr. Kennedy asked at the news conference today. "Why do they want to to treat Japanese workers, German workers, Belgian workers, Netherlands workers, better than they treat American workers here at home?"
The Labor and Human Resources Committee, responding to the small-business complaints, produced a bill last month with even smaller payment requirements for small businesses than Mr. Clinton had proposed. For businesses with 15 or fewer workers, like many fast-food franchises that are independently owned, employers would have to pay no more than 4.2 percent of a worker's wages for insurance, with additional insurance costs paid by Government subsidies. For someone who worked 40 hours a week for 52 weeks a year at the minimum wage of $4.25 an hour, the required employer contribution would be $371 a year.
Branches of a chain like Pizza Hut that were owned by a central company, and thus part of a large corporation, would pay more but would still receive subsidies for low-wage workers.
The two Senators from Kansas, Bob Dole and Nancy Landon Kassebaum, both Republicans, sharply rebuked the advertising effort. Senator Kassebaum said the ad showed that the Administration was "desperate." Senator Dole said pizza prices would go to $20 if employers had to buy insurance, far more than either the 10 percent Pizza Hut itself estimated or the 2 percent increase the Health Care Reform Project estimated.
But Pizza Hut, whose headquarters are in Wichita, Kan., thwarted the effort to put the advertising on television in Washington.
 
An Ingredient of Libel
 Rob Doughty, vice president for communications of Pizza Hut, said of the ad, "We regard it as libelous." When asked what part of the commercial was false, an essential ingredient of a libel case, he said he would check with company lawyers.
Later he refused to say whether the ad shown to reporters was libelous. But he said it must have been changed because Pizza Hut had been shown a version that "said we did not offer insurance or pay for insurance for any of our employees."
Mark Johnson, a spokesman for the Health Care Reform Project, said that was not true. "The television ad that was released today is the same ad that we tried to place over the past couple of weeks," he said. "It has not changed at all. There is only one script."
Robert A. Chlopak, a consultant to the coalition who developed the reports and the material for the ad, said the group would buy full-page ads in The New York Times and The Washington Post on Sunday, making the same points in greater detail. The newspapers accepted the ads.
Mr. Doughty did not dispute the statements contained in the organization's report, but he argued that when considered as a whole, the case was "bogus." He acknowledged that Pizza Hut does not contribute to health insurance for hourly employees in their first six months on the job.
He also said that if workers buy a basic plan costing single employees $11 a week, for a period of six months, then the company would make a small added contribution that increases the benefits that hourly workers receive. Salaried workers have a more generous plan to which the company contributes.
In countries like Germany, where insurance is required by law, the company pays but the pizzas cost more, Mr. Doughty said.
He insisted that "the issue for us is employer mandates," and added: "We have been vocal on employer mandates. We are in 87 countries. We have a lot of experience with employer mandates. Employer mandates do not work. All they result in is higher costs to the consumer."
He said a pizza that sells for $11 in the United States costs $19 in Germany and $25 in Japan. But he added that he could not say how much of the increase came from the cost of providing health insurance.
In Germany and Japan, Mr. Doughty said, Pizza Hut restaurants are in high-rent areas, unlike most of those in the United States. And the need to import ingredients like tomato sauce and cheese also contributed to higher costs, he said.
When Mr. Doughty was asked how much he thought the Clinton plan would add to the cost of a pizza, he replied: "In the first year about 10 percent. But in later years it would go up substantially more. So God knows what's the cost."
But Eric Sklar, who runs a chain here called Burrito's, appeared at the Health Care Reform Project news conference and said it was unlikely that any legislation would raise prices by more than 2 percent. Matching the plan Mr. Clinton proposed, he said, would probably force him to add 7 or 8 cents to the cost of a $4 burrito.
Mr. Sklar also said he would like to insure his workers fully, but added, "I have to compete with Taco Bell," which, like Pizza Hut, is owned by Pepsico. "If I insure my employees," he said, "I am at a competitive disadvantage."
A spokesman for the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee also said he doubted the Pizza Hut estimate. Under legislation approved last month by the committee, employers of low-wage workers would not have to pay the full cost of their health insurance.
Under that bill, a large company like Pizza Hut would have to pay no more than 12 percent of a worker's wages for insurance premiums. For a minimum wage, 40-hour employee, that would come to $1,061 a year. But labor is only one of Pizza Hut's costs, and so the impact on its prices would not have to be that great.
Pizza Hut owns the majority of its outlets in the United States. It owns 4,720, where it would have to pay 12 percent for insurance under the bill. An additional 2,715 Pizza Hut stores are franchises, where lower rates, down to 4.2 percent, would prevail, as would be the case in a number of the 535 licensee operations.
 
What the Workers Think
 Interviews around the country with fast-food workers -- when Pizza Hut managers did not chase reporters away -- showed a widespead desire for insurance coverage.
Rosie Rodriguez, who makes $2.90 an hour plus tips, was interviewed at a Pizza Hut on Atlantic Avenue in the New York City borough of Queens. She said she had no health insurance and thought it was unfair that the company covered employers abroad but not at home
"That's messed up," she said. "They should be doing it here, too. They don't care about people here, I guess. If I get sick I have to pay, and I can't afford it."
In Los Angeles, a waitress who gave her name only as Jannette said: "Of course we should have the right to health insurance. As years go by, everything is more expensive, so for the sake of our health, maybe they should increase the prices."
In Houston, a 37-year-old Pizza Hut employee with three children who gave only his initials, M.G., said, "Pizza Hut can afford to give insurance to its people." He had no insurance, but said he had occasionally received free medical care from a doctor to whom he delivers pizza.
No employees at McDonald's were permitted to give interviews, and the company itself was similarly uncommunicative. Requests for comment on the Health Care Reform Project report's charge that "McDonald's can well afford to pay for health insurance for their American workers," were answered with only a generalized statement.
It said, "It's unrealistic and misleading to single out any one benefit or program without considering the entire economic and social environment of each country."
The Health Care Reform Project sought to show the ad on four Washington stations. At WUSA-TV, Barbara Ware, manager of press and publciity said she had no comment when asked why the ad had not been shown. At WTTG-TV and WJLA-TV, spokesmen promised to call back but did not despite repeated requests. AT WRC-TV no one would comment.
The Health Care Reform Project released correspondence between the group and Michael S. Horne, a lawyer with Covington & Burling here who represented Pizza Hut. Mr. Horne sent a copy of his letter, accusing them of producing a commercial "that states or implies that Pizza Hut offers no health insurance program for its employees in the United States. That statement is false."
He concluded by warning that "if you cause to be broadcast any statement to the effect that Pizza Hut does not offer health care coverage for its employees in the United States, the company will regard that false broadcast as having been made with knowledge of falsity or in reckless disregard of falsity."
The falsity language comes from decisions on what constitutes libel, although Mr. Horne did not use the word "libel."
He sent copies of his letter to the four television stations and to two others that the Health Care Reform Project was not dealing with. WUSA-TV sent a copy of the letter to the health care group with a note saying, "Until some resolution is made relative to the counterstatements in this letter, WUSA will not go forward and air the spot."

Companies
 
Microsoft reached an agreement with the Justice Department under which the company will change some of its business practices to end a four-year antitrust battle on charges that it unfairly tried to stifle competition. [Page 1.]

A key to the Federated Department Stores bid to merge with R. H. Macy was the work of Ronald W. Tysoe, Federated's vice chairman and chief financial officer, who spearheaded the deal that will form the country's largest department-store chain. [37.]
 
Investors fled the stocks of computer chip makers after Texas Instruments predicted that the runaway growth in chip sales in the first half of the year would slow. [37.]
 
Hallmark Cards plans to market its Shoebox unit's characters to outside manufacturers, hoping the characters will adorn men's ties, boxer shorts, barbecue aprons, watches and clocks, and also star in a comic strip and an animated television series. [37.]
 
U S West plans to pay $1.2 billion to acquire Wometco Cable and Georgia Cable Television, which together control 65 percent of the market in metropolitan Atlanta. [39.]
 
Shares of Litton Industries rose after the company agreed to pay $83 million to settle a lawsuit that contended it had overcharged the Government for computer services. [39.]
 
Pacific Bell hopes to begin building a customer base for a new wireless service by seeking regulatory approval to resell cellular phone service delivered by other companies. [39.]
 
Pizza Hut persuaded some TV stations not to run an ad that contends it was hypocritical for paying for workers' health insurance abroad while opposing U.S. employer mandates. [9.]

Markets
 
Nasdaq's huge computer system passed out. Before frantic engineers could revive the system and steady its pulse, more than two and a half hours had elapsed. [37.]
 
The stock market moved mostly higher in a sluggish session highlighted by options-related trading and a sharp selloff in semiconductor shares. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 14.56 points, to close at 3,757.81. [38.]
 
The bond market failed to extend Thursday's strong rally, ending the day with little change after giving up its early gains. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond edged up to 7.54 percent, from 7.53 percent on Thursday. [42.]
 
The dollar fell against the Japanese yen, ending a two-day rally, after Japan said its trade surplus with the United States had surged 43 percent in June. [43.]
 
Cocoa jumped to its highest price in four years and coffee resumed its climb. [43.]
 
The Economy
 
Industrial production rose 0.5 percent in June, as hot weather forced a surge in utility output, the Government said. In another report, the Commerce Department said business inventories rose 1.1 percent in May, the largest increase in nearly seven years. [42.]
 
Your Money
 
Money managers and analysts are raising caution flags about real estate investment trusts amid a flood of new issues. [35.]
 
Swindlers are prowling on-line computer systems and the Internet, hunting for unwary investors. [35.]
 
The new I.R.S. rules on donations to charities pose some tricky issues. [35.]
 
The financial services group of equity funds eked out a gain during the first half of 1994, despite rising interest rates. [35.]
 
More companies are trying to capture the elderly market by offering discounts and special deals to older people. [36.]

HEADLINE: Aristide Calls for Reconciliation on His Own Radio Station

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 15

 BODY:
Speaking to his countrymen via a new radio station set up specifically for his use by the Clinton Administration, Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, tonight called for "reconciliation, justice and democracy" in his homeland and forswore revenge against the soldiers who removed him from office.
Vowing to return to Haiti soon, Father Aristide promised that "there will be no violence" when he comes back. "I will not accept any vengeance," he said. 
 The deposed President avoided any mention of Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, who led the coup that ousted him in September 1991. But he assured the "little soldiers who are the backbone of the army" that he did not want to punish them.
"You the soldier, you don't have to be scared," Father Aristide said.
He also sought to calm businessmen who view him as a radical, saying that he respected the Haitian Constitution and the right to make a profit.
"The Constitution is as clear as coconut water," he said. "Everybody is equal," he later added. "Everybody must respect the law."
Father Aristide's 50-minute address was the first item broadcast by the new American-sponsored radio station, called Radio Democracy. The speech was beamed to listeners on both AM and FM frequencies by two American C-130 aircraft flying above Haiti. It will be followed by daily radio programs featuring Father Aristide, his supporters and spokesmen for United States foreign policy.
 
An Indefinite Period
 Stanley Schrager, a spokesman for the United States Embassy here, said the broadcasts would continue for an indefinite period.
The idea of setting up a radio station for Father Aristide's use was first made public last month, but the launching of Radio Democracy was delayed because Father Aristide proved unwilling to urge Haitians not to flee their country in small and rickety boats, a proposal Washington had been hoping he would endorse.
Since then, the United States has tightened economic sanctions against Haiti and more than 20,000 would-be refugees have taken to the seas and been intercepted by American Coast Guard vessels. On July 5, the United States announced it would not resettle such Haitians in the United States, but would send them to safe havens in third countries.
Father Aristide's initial speech on Radio Democracy was awaited with great curiosity and anticipation here, since his position on basic aspects of the Haitian crisis has varied greatly in recent months. After saying in January that he would support a surgical strike by an international force to oust the military regime now in power, he reversed himself last month, saying, "Never, never, never would I agree to be restored to power in an invasion." This week, however, he demanded "swift and definitive action" against those who ousted him.
Though Father Aristide went into exile after his overthrow, his comments on events here still are sometimes broadcast on Haitian radio stations, as well as by the Voice of America's Creole-language short-wave service. Mr. Schrager said Radio Democracy offers the deposed President an advantage over that arrangement because his remarks will not be "subject to de facto control or censorship" by local authorities.
Mr. Schrager said that American officials would not exercise "direct censorship" of Father Aristide's broadcasts, which will be made in Creole. However, scripts will "be screened by the United States before they go on the air," he said.
Following Father Aristide's refusal to urge Haitians not to flee their country, the United States set up a radio station of its own to point out the dangers of boat trips and to explain American policy toward Haitians rescued at sea. That station is already on the air two and a half hours a day, broadcasting on an AM frequency from planes flying above the neighboring Dominican Republic.
The Haitian Government did not appear to have jammed Father Aristide's broadcast, and had no immediate comment about his appeal to soldiers and businessmen. Reception of large parts of the speech was weak and unclear, especially on the FM band, where the frequency chosen is sandwiched between one station playing pop music and another with religious programming in English.

HEADLINE: Dow Advances by 14.56, But Chip Stocks Sell Off

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The stock market moved mostly higher yesterday in a sluggish session highlighted by options-related trading and a sharp selloff in semiconductor shares.
Most of the rise in prices came late in the day, and was tied to expiring options contracts. Earlier in the session the market was up only modestly, despite a set of economic reports that were generally well received in the bond market. 
 "It was a fairly dreary summer Friday," said David Shulman, chief equity strategist for Salomon Brothers. "Basically, everybody who needed to get things done got them done on Thursday."
On the New York Stock Exchange, the Dow Jones industrial average, which rose by more than 34 points on Thursday, gained 14.56 yesterday, and closed at 3,753.81. For the week, the blue-chip index gained 44.67 points. Big Board volume was 275.9 million shares, down sharply from the 322.3 million shares traded on Thursday.
 
Broader Index Gains
 Broader indexes eked out smaller gains. The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose by just 0.75, to 454.16. The American Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.51, to 431.55. But the Nasdaq system's composite index dipped by 0.20, to 721.36.
Computer problems shut down the Nasdaq system until almost noon yesterday, and the delay created some problems for stock index traders who were trying to square positions ahead of the options expiration.
But the day's biggest shock was in semiconductor stocks, which fell sharply after an executive at Texas Instruments suggested that demand for computer chips might not be as strong in the second half of the year as it was in the first.
The comments from William A. Aylesworth, the company's chief financial officer, accompanied the release of Texas Instruments' second-quarter earnings, which were up 64 percent, a bigger increase than analysts had expected.
Traders were much more interested in Mr. Aylesworth's suggestion that while evidence of slowing demand had not turned up yet, given the strong first half, it was "mathematically" likely that the second half would see growth slip.
After Mr. Aylesworth's comments became public, shares of Texas Instruments started to tumble. The stock closed at 80 1/4, down 6 1/8, on heavy volume.
Concerns about Texas Instruments' as yet unseen problems still managed to drag down other semiconductor stocks.
Motorola, which earlier this week reported big gains in its second-quarter earnings, fell 1 3/8, to 48 7/8. Intel lost 2, to 59 1/2. Micron Technology dropped 1 7/8, to 36 1/4. And the Altera Corporation, which said it expected its revenue growth in the second and third quarters to be roughly half what it was a year ago, lost 6 1/2, to 25 1/2.
"The fact that the market reacted the way it did to what Texas Instruments said shows that some people are still nervous," said Laszlo Birinyi, head of Birinyi Associates, a market research company in Greenwich, Conn.
 
'Treading Water'
 Still, Mr. Birinyi said he thought the market was "O.K."
"What you are seeing is some consolidation and treading water after a fairly significant correction in the first part of the year," he said. "But the fact that the market didn't sell off on a summer Friday following a very good day is a good sign."
Among the day's big gainers were chemical stocks, which moved higher in anticipation of stronger earnings. Du Pont gained 1 1/4, to 60 1/8; Dow Chemical was up 7/8, to 67 3/8, and Eastman Chemical rose 1, to 49 1/4.
Oil stocks also posted good gains. Chevron was up 7/8, to 44 7/8; Amoco added 3/8, to 60 5/8, and Texaco gained 3/8, to 63 1/8.
In Tokyo yesterday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 52.11 points, or a quarter of 1 percent, at 20,770.15. On Thursday, the Nikkei rose 177.63 points.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE CAMPAIGN;
Clinton, on the Stump, Opens a Final Health Care Push

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GREENSBURG, Pa., July 15

 BODY:
President Clinton today began a vigorous and probably final crusade to sell his national health insurance program to voters and Congress, flying to rural Pennsylvania to assert that the program would be a boon to the middle class and that its critics were all but liars.
Standing in shirt sleeves, flushed in the vapory heat, Mr. Clinton punched the air and pounded his lectern as he argued, again and again, that working people were the only ones who would suffer if his plan to guarantee health insurance to everyone did not become law. 
 "The politicians have it," he said of guaranteed insurance. "The wealthy have it. The poor have it. If you go to jail, you have it. Only the middle class doesn't have it, and I don't think that makes much sense."
He alternated that populist appeal with attacks on supporters of rival plans like that of the Senate minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, that would fall short of covering everyone. "Let's not burn the middle class," Mr. Clinton exhorted the crowd. "Let's cover everyone and make America work."
 
Monthlong Drive Begins
 His speech, to a throng of several thousand people next to the old courthouse in this hilly county seat outside Pittsburgh, opened what is certain to be a frenzied month of health care campaigning by Mr. Clinton, his wife, Hillary, and virtually every top official in the Administration.
Most officials in Washington say that the House and the Senate must pass health care legislation before their four-week recess begins in mid-August if any plan at all is to become law this year. And Mr. Clinton's chances of enacting the sort of plan he favors, everyone agrees, will diminish after November's elections, in which Republicans are expected to gain Congressional seats.
Mr. Clinton will take up health care again next week in speeches to the National Governors Association in Boston and to the Hispanic group La Raza in Miami. Mrs. Clinton is expected next week to inaugurate a nationwide caravan of buses that will converge on Washington in August, carrying advocates of universal insurance coverage. Cabinet officials are besieging the editorial writers of most major newspapers this week, and the Democratic National Committee has begun a $4 million advertising campaign to generate support for the President's proposal.
The Administration is hampered because it lacks, as yet, any paper-and-ink legislation that it can hand the public. Competing and contradictory bills have emerged from four Congressional committees, and Democratic leaders in both houses are trying to write a single plan that would insure everyone, as Mr. Clinton demands, without driving away lawmakers who fear that guaranteed insurance would simply cost too much.
 
Pitch to the Middle Class
 Everyone agrees that no plan can cover all Americans unless the Government raises taxes, forces employers to pay much of the cost of insurance for all their workers and those workers' dependents, or requires individuals to buy it themselves. Mr. Clinton favors requiring payments by employers -- the so-called employer mandate -- but the idea is anathema to most Republicans and not a small number of Democrats.
The White House's strategists have decided that the best way to flip those lawmakers to the Administration's side is to convince the sea of voters who regard themselves as middle class that universal insurance coverage would save them worry and money. And that was the theme that the President underscored today.
His speech, like those in coming weeks, had two aims. One was to convince middle-class crowds that this was their chance to benefit from a Government program. The other was to defuse opponents' increasingly effective contention that Mr. Clinton's ideas would limit Americans' medical care options and hurt the economy.
So Mr. Clinton, the champion of the very poorest during his days as Governor of Arkansas, worked unusually hard today to suggest that the poor had received their share, mostly at the expense of his audience, and that it was time for the middle class to reap some Federal rewards.
He was preceded to a dais of pine two-by-eights, covered in blue bunting, by two women whose stories were tailored to his argument. One was a 62-year-old farmer, Louise Mastowski, who said she could no longer afford insurance and feared that she would fall ill before becoming eligible for Medicare.
The second, Lynn Hicks, is a mother of five children who lost her insurance after her husband had lost his job. She later fell ill with breast cancer and had to quit her own job and join the welfare rolls to receive medical care.
"Now, they've worked all their lives, they've paid for their health insurance," Mr. Clinton said of those women and other cases he cited. "They haven't done anything wrong. There are 600,000 people in Pennsylvania alone in the same boat."
 
Attacks Fear of Rationing
 Similarly he battered away at fears that guaranteed insurance would force the health care system to hold down costs by rationing medical services. For people like Ms. Hicks, he noted, medical care is already limited.
Mr. Clinton also mocked accusations that his plan would turn the medical system over to the Government -- in fact, he argued, his proposal is less intrusive than the existing Medicare system -- and that it would cripple small businesses by raising their insurance costs.
In Hawaii, which has long used an insurance system like the one the White House favors, insurance rates for small business are 30 percent lower than in the rest of the nation, Mr. Clinton said.
The crowd of a few thousand who heard him today, along with the several thousand who lined the eight-mile route from the local airport to Greensburg, seemed almost wholly receptive to Mr. Clinton. This is heavily Democratic territory in a state whose one Democratic Senator, Harris Wofford, swept to victory in 1991 on a wave of unhappiness with Republican diffidence toward health care reform.
But at the airport, where Mr. Clinton spent 18 minutes shaking hands and signing autographs, there was some suggestion that he still needed to convert even the faithful to his health care crusade.
As Mr. Clinton worked a fence row of cheering onlookers, one of them, 39-year-old Jim Kuhn, grabbed the President's hand and told him to "just keep pushing." Later, Mr. Kuhn said he lost his steady sales job about a year ago, received no coverage from his current work and had to buy "awfully expensive" insurance on his own while he looked for a better job.
Mr. Kuhn said the President had told him that the Administration had created four million jobs so far. But "my concern is with his health care plan," he said. "I don't know if there are going to be four million new jobs available if they pass this. With this employer mandate, it's going to close a lot of jobs down."

HEADLINE: Japan's Trade Surplus Up

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 15

 BODY:
Robust exports to the United States and Asia helped to raise Japan's trade surplus by nearly 15 percent in June, the Government said today. That is higher than most economists had forecast.
 The Finance Ministry said the overall surplus rose to $11.35 billion from $9.88 billion in June 1993. Japan's surplus with the United States widened to an unadjusted $4.73 billion from $3.30 billion a year earlier. 
 In the first six months of 1994, the total surplus widened to $60.01 billion from $57.12 billion a year earlier. The surplus with the United States rose to $24.56 billion from $21.56 billion in the first half of 1993.
 A strong United States economic recovery and dynamic growth in Asia helped exports to grow 10.4 percent over all in June to $33.67 billion. Export volume also rose 6.3 percent after declining from February through May, economists noted.

HEADLINE: How a County Buried $52 Million;
A Landfill Site Falls Afoul of Environmental Concerns

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GOSHEN, N.Y.

 BODY:
For $52 million, Orange County has constructed a garbage landfill that will never be soiled by garbage. Indeed, in the decade since the project was proposed, taxpayer money is the only thing that has been poured into the 34-acre site.
The state permits required to operate the would-be landfill expired in early July, and the County Executive, Joseph G. Rampe, has announced that he will abandon the project entirely. Mr. Rampe, who took office in January, says that to operate the landfill now would only mean throwing good money after bad. 
 Depending on whom you ask, this is either the story of a county caught between onerous state and Federal wetland regulations or a victory tale for the environmental movement.
Either way, the story has an expensive ending for the nearly 300,000 people who live in this county of graceful farms and struggling cities. Their taxes have gone to pay for a garbage landfill they will never use.
"Right along, it seemed that the right hand did not know what the left hand was doing in terms of our environmental laws," said Robert Weinberger, president of the Goshen Taxpayers Association and a former mayor of this county seat. "It has been a series of poor decisions that led us down a path of waste of the taxpayers' money."
A long, winding path it has been.
In the days when garbage was dumped in a hole in the ground, covered with dirt and forgot about, the county bought 300 acres of land from the state and was given a permit to use 245 of those acres for garbage. That was in 1973. The county cleared its first 75-acre portion and began filling it with garbage.
By 1984, when space began running out in the first section, the laws had changed and the county had to reapply to the State Conservation Department for permission to expand. Among the state's changes were tighter restrictions on landfills, like Orange County's, that sit over an aquifer. The regulations are intended to protect ground water from contamination.
It took four years and several design proposals, but in 1988 the state approved a temporary 34-acre landfill expansion plan. The state allowed the county to use the 34 acres for garbage until July 7 of this year, giving time to find a permanent, and drier, home for solid waste.
The county went ahead and spent $36 million building a double-composite, double-lined landfill, and agreed to pay an additional $16 million in interest on the bonds that financed it.
But there was another fly in the ointment -- Federal regulations for wetlands -- and this, county officials contend, was something state officials had never mentioned when they approved the building of the temporary landfill. The property is covered with cattails and other wetland plants that qualify it as a wetland under Federal regulations, though not state regulations. The state regulates patches of wetland larger than 12.4 acres. The Federal Government regulates any wetland larger than an acre.
"It could have taken one simple phone call from the Department of Environmental Conservation to explain the Federal process to the county," said Scott Thornton, an apple farmer turned lawyer who was the one who discovered the suspected violations of Federal law and sued Orange County in Federal court. "But no, the state says: 'We don't get involved in that. Those are Federal laws.' "
 
Went to Law School
 Mr. Thornton went to law school to fight the landfill, which was just across the Wallkill River from his in-laws' apple orchard. It was in class that he found out about the Federal Government's wetland regulations.
"I knew those were wetlands being filled in because the apple orchard started getting flooded along the river and that hadn't happened before," Mr. Thornton said. "I went to the state, but they said the property wasn't on their wetlands map."
In December 1991, Mr. Thornton, as a member of a community group, Orange Environment Inc., sued the county in Federal court, saying it needed a permit from the Army Corps of Engineers to fill in Federal wetlands. In January 1993, a Federal judge agreed that they needed Army corps permits.
Rather than start again from scratch, Mr. Rampe, the County Executive, wants to bury the landfill issue and concentrate on putting together long-range plans for getting rid of the garbage that it is now shipping out of state.
 
New Requirements
 For one thing, Mr. Rampe says, there is a hefty new set of Federal requirements to meet, and the time limits on the state's operating permits have expired. But the main reason for Mr. Rampe's pessimism is purely economic.
Without even counting the initial $52 million cost, he says the landfill would still be a financial loser.
He estimates that the landfill could generate, at most, $40 million in landfill revenue but could cost more than $41 million to run. The costs include completing the landfill and operating, capping and monitoring it. The cost of seeking Federal wetlands permits and new state operating permits, both of which would probably face legal challenges, would only add to the losses.
Even many taxpayers seem resigned to accept the expensive hole in the ground.
"Wisdom would suggest that they don't pursue it any further," said Edward P. Scharfenberger, a retired lawyer and president of the Orange County Coalition of Taxpayers. "Right now, I'm interested in long-term solutions to the solid-waste problem."

Scott Thornton, right, who led the fight against the project, stood in front of the site. (Dan Cronin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Flood Threatens to Wash Away Dreams

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Ga., July 14

 BODY:
Almost every black person here over 40 remembers the fervor and exultation, the hymns and protest songs, the sense of a new world just over the horizon that suffused this river city more than 30 years ago, when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. preached the gospel of freedom at the old Mount Zion Baptist Church.
But when the flood came this week, when the chocolate-colored water poured over the largely black river-bottom neighborhoods of low-slung cinder-block duplexes, dirt yards and old wooden houses in faded greens and blues, it was a bitter reminder of how fleeting that long-ago moment was. 
 It was black neighborhoods that were hit hardest by the historic flooding that washed over east and south Albany, many of them full of people who had taken only the first steps out of rural poverty here in the pecan and peanut country of southwest Georgia. And as the waters began to recede, many blacks in this city, where their per capita income is about a third that of whites, were wondering if they were about to be slammed right back down to where they began.
"I had a nice apartment, I had running water, I had it all," said Kimberly Jones, who remembers the buckets of water used for toilets and sinks at the home where she grew up near the small town of Camilla, not far from Albany. At 21, Ms. Jones was trying to rear her three children in a neat little apartment 16 feet from the Flint River and hoping to go back to school to study nursing. Now, with the apartment inundated, "I feel like I'm standing on the bottom of a deep hole, looking up at the sky."
 
One-Fourth in Poverty
 Albany, founded in 1836 by a Quaker from New Jersey who named it for Albany, N.Y., has about 80,000 people, about 55 percent of them black. A quarter of the population lives in poverty, and the murder rate is one of the highest in the nation.
The population of the metropolitan area, which includes rapidly growing, largely white suburbs in nearby Lee County, is about 120,000, and the flooding forced as many as 20 percent of them to evacuate. With the water only now receding, the extent of the damage is still unclear.
For blacks here, much has changed for the better since the days of the Albany Movement, the crusade to integrate the city in the early days of the civil rights struggle.
The Police Chief is black, and so is the Fire Chief. During the flood, one of the busiest people in town has been the young black assistant city manager, Janice Allen. There are blacks scattered across the white neighborhoods on the west side of town, and blacks serve on the boards of the local banks.
These days, class can mean at least as much as race here.
Henry Mathis, a black former city commissioner who was active in the Albany Movement as a child, said the city had at least four distinct classes.
"You have the Doublegate whites," he said, referring to a wealthy white neighborhood on the west side. "You have the Albany State College blacks. Then you have the industrial workers, and then you have the poor whites and poor blacks."
 
A City of Delineations
 But whites still hold the balance of political power on both the City Council and the County Commission, and they hold almost all the economic power. Those at the bottom tend to be overwhelmingly black. Median household income for whites is $30,943; for blacks it is $13,252. Per capita income for whites is $16,157, for blacks $5,904.
At Red Cross shelters jammed with poor blacks this week, like the one at Dougherty High School on the hard-hit east side or the one at Albany High School on the west, the city's social and economic delineations were plain to see.
There were welfare mothers from the flooded-out Washington Homes project, the working poor and those clinging to a ledge near the low end of the lower middle class.
Ronnie Soilberry was earning $147 a week as a maintenance worker before the flood waters inundated his home. It wasn't luxury, but it was a lot better than his parents' generation had known.
"I'm not slopping hogs, picking cotton, chopping timber, hauling wood," he said. "I think I'm doing pretty good. Or I was, before this hit."
 
Help From Government
 There are many others, now staying at local motels or with relatives and friends, who have come a long way, to jobs at hospitals, government offices or the Procter & Gamble or Miller Brewing plants. At 72, Rosa Rogers remembers the days of outhouses and kerosene lanterns; her life then is a long way from her daughter Emma's now.
Mrs. Rogers is retired from a candy factory, and her husband, now dead, owned a shoe repair business. Her daughter is a blood technician at a local hospital, and her son-in-law is a custodian at Dougherty High School. The three lived together in a three-bedroom brick house that was inundated, and they should be eligible for some of the $65.5 million in Federal aid available to the victims of the recent Southeast flooding. The Government will provide low-interest loans of up to $200,000 for real estate damage and $40,000 for personal property damage, and grants of up to $13,200 to flood victims who cannot repay loans.
Husher B. Smith Jr. earns $34,000 a year driving a truck for a local chemical company. His wife is a beautician. Their income is enough to make payments on a $42,000 house and to own three cars. The house and two of the cars were flooded, but he is already thinking of how to use Federal relief money to get back to where he was and perhaps buy a rental unit as well.
"Most people here got no plan," he said, surveying the crowd at a Red Cross shelter. "They'll take whatever money they get, buy a car or party and be back worse than they were. My idea may be as wrong as 1, 2, 3, but at least I got a plan to get back on my feet, so I'm not worried about getting there."
 
'The Lord Is Angry'
 You can hear lots of explanations for why things have not progressed further here.
"I think the Lord is angry," said Linda Luster, flooded out and worn out, at a Red Cross shelter at a middle school. "Everyone is doing wrong, and He's tired of it. Blacks are doing it to survive. Whites are doing it just because they can do it. He's tired of it. He's just tired."
Everyone talks about the devastating toll of drugs. Many see a culture of dependence, from the fields to welfare, that has left many blacks so accustomed to life on the bottom that they have trouble imagining anything else.
Otis Boyd, who has had various jobs over the years and now earns $10,000 a year as a custodian at Albany State College, blames employers who use temporary instead of full-time workers to avoid providing benefits.
Black businessmen say banks remain reluctant to lend money to them.
"A black is always going to be on the bottom, because he's never going to be able to go and secure a loan to start his business completely," said Nick Walker, who used $1,500 in savings from his full-time job to start his own window-tinting business seven years ago. "It can wear you out. But I still wouldn't give two blocks of Albany for any town. We have our racial problems and our personal problems, but we can clear it up."
If there is a comfort, to many it is the knowledge that they have always made do, even in the face of adversity.
There is Charlotte Hendricks, who came South from Newark because she did not want to rear her son there. She has worked two or three jobs at a time and expects to do so again.
"I've been up, down, up, down, up, down so much, I figure I can get back up again," she said, a thin woman in a pink top and blue jeans, smoking a cigarette after getting off work at a pecan shelling plant. "When I left New Jersey I had nothing but my children and my clothes, and I worked two jobs until I got something. I don't want to sound cocky or anything, but I'm a survivor. If I have to get two jobs or two and a half, I'll do it, and be O.K."
If the dreams of the Albany Movement seem a thing of the past, the individual dreams, tattered and waterlogged as they may be, live on.
"This will pass," said Mr. Soilberry, sitting on a cot in the gym at Albany High School. "I'm going to have everything I want. Plenty of money. My kids are going to go to college. I'm 33 years old, but I have a dream. I'm not going to stop hoping. I'm going all the way to the top."

HEADLINE: Bonds Fail To Extend Their Rally

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The bond market failed yesterday to extend Thursday's strong rally, ending the day with little change after giving up its early gains.
"The market has trouble holding the gains," said James Kenney, head trader at Prudential Securities. "I will continue to treat it as a rally in a bear market." 
 The Treasury's 30-year bond fell 4/32 of a point, after trading up as much as 18/32 of a point in the morning. Its yield, which moved in the opposite direction of its price, edged up to 7.54 percent from 7.53 percent. On Thursday, the long bond's yield fell 14 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, its biggest decline since May.
Prices of shorter- and intermediate-term Treasury securities also slipped.
 
Commodities Prices Up
 The bond market was once again unsettled around midday by rising commodities prices, considered by some analysts to be a leading indicator of inflation. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodity prices rose 1.77 points, to 233.50.
It seemed to ignore comments by the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, that inflation appeared to be under control. "The U.S. economy has recently been experiencing the ideal combination of rising activity, falling unemployment and slowing inflation," Mr. Greenspan told a Congressional panel.
 
Favorable Economic Reports
 Earlier in the day, the bond market had reacted favorably to a Government report showing a five-tenths of 1 percent rise in June industrial production, reinforcing earlier reports demonstrating moderate economic growth and almost nonexistent inflation.
So far this year, the Consumer Price Index has shown an annual inflation rate of 2.5 percent, down from 2.8 percent for the first six months of 1993 and 2.7 percent for all of last year.
"I don't really see any whiff of inflation," said Anthony Chan, senior economist at the BancOne Investment Advisors Corporation, which has about $8 billion in fixed-income investments.
The Fed also said the nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 83.9 percent of capacity in June, slightly above expectations. Even though economists associate a rate of 84 percent or 85 percent with more inflation, low inflation so far this year means that "we can tolerate a slightly higher level of capacity utilization," Mr. Chan said.
 
Utilities' Role Discounted
 The gain in the Fed's production survey did not set off inflation alarms because much of it came from utilities, which produce more electricity during the summer, analysts said.
The production number "might look a little scary, but the fact that it was mostly utilities should soften the blow considerably," said James Hale, senior fixed-income strategist at MMS International in San Francisco. "Because of the much warmer weather, everybody turned their air- conditioners on."
Still, some traders were not surprised that the bond market's rally stalled.
Thursday's "performance was impressive, but so many times in the past we've seen that, spending a day or two days grinding higher, only to give it back in a heartbeat," said Chris Madell, a trader at First Chicago Capital Markets.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Texas Instruments: Net Up, Outlook Down

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DALLAS, July 15

 BODY:
Despite record revenues and earnings at Texas Instruments Inc., the company's forecast today that the runaway growth in chip sales in the first half of the year would slow caused investors to flee the stocks of chip makers.
Earlier this week, the semiconductor industry reported its first monthly decline in orders since September, amid signs that corporate demand for personal computers that use the chips was beginning to slacken. 
 Texas Instruments executives and industry officials said, with some annoyance, that they saw continued strong growth. But some analysts said the latest reports were a sign that the chip boom had crested.
"It's pretty much assumed there will be a slowdown in the second half of the year,' said Wendy Abramowitz, an analyst for Argus Research. "But the market hasn't valued this into the stocks.'
At least not until today. Texas Instruments, the bearer of sobering news, fell $6.125, or 7 percent, to $80.25. Other chip makers suffered, but somewhat less.
Texas Instruments executives said they expected the year's worldwide chip demand to grow by a few percentage points more than the 21 percent increase they initially predicted. But after 25 to 30 percent growth in the first half of the year, they said, the second half would inevitably be slower.
The chief financial officer of Texas Instruments, William A. Aylesworth, was not about to panic or jump out of a window. "I'm doing fine -- I can assure you of that," he said. "My office is on the first floor.'
Texas Instruments said its earnings from operations for the second quarter were $292 million, up 69 percent from $173 million in the comparable period last year. Sales rose 19 percent, to $2.51 billion. Earnings per share of $1.93 were higher than the analysts' consensus by about 5 cents.
These records came primarily as a result of the company's chip making, about 60 percent of a business that also includes military electronics, calculators and laptop computers.
"It was a superb earnings report," said Rajiv Chaudhri, an analyst for Goldman, Sachs. "Squeaky clean.'
Mr. Aylesworth noted other encouraging signs, including lower chip inventories at its customers and especially strong demand from Pacific Asian markets outside Japan. "The forces driving longer-term growth remain intact," he said.
As for the United States, he said he saw moderating economic growth, and less likelihood that PC demand, especially from corporations, would continue its rapid growth.
A corporate shopping spree for technology has helped propel efficiency and economic growth higher during the last two years. But many businesses, courted with round after round of price cuts, have almost all the computers they can use. Some analysts said corporate buyers had also slowed their rush to upgrade their machines.
But a spokesman for the Intel Corporation, another leading chip maker, said its sales to computer makers continued to outstrip its expectations. The company is scheduled to report its earnings on Monday.
Earlier this week, the Semiconductor Industry Association reported that chip orders fell 2 percent and the book-to-bill ratio fell 4 percent in June from the month before. The ratio compares orders booked with those shipped and billed, and a declining ratio indicates slower growth.
Doug Andrey, the group's chief statistics keeper, said he saw only a seasonal pattern, noting that the ratio usually declined in June.

HEADLINE: Greenspan View of Deficit

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said today that the United States was experiencing ideal economic times but warned that future prosperity was jeopardized by the nation's giant budget deficit.
"The U.S. economy has recently been experiencing the ideal combination of rising activity, falling unemployment and slowing inflation," Mr. Greenspan told a bipartisan commission on Government spending and tax reform. 
 But he made clear that the nation must not let good economic times create an atmosphere in which policy makers take a view that the deficit, despite improvement, is no longer a critical problem. "We cannot let this good behavior lull us into neglecting the underlying problems of our economy," Mr. Greenspan said.
He said the impact of the deficit was pervasive and continued to keep long-term interest rates high, making it more costly to finance the red ink.
"Long-term interest rates are higher now because markets are anticipating rising deficits in the next century," he said.
At the same, he said he detected a sharp shift in the public's attitude toward the deficit and a willingness to make hard choices to bring the economy into better balance.
"I hope and really do believe" progress will be made, Mr. Greenspan said, adding that improvement would show up in interest rate levels.

HEADLINE: DISCOUNTS;
Deals for Older People If They Will Just Ask

BYLINE: By Andree Brooks 

 BODY:
GROWING older has an upside for those who aren't shy about discussing their age.
More and more companies are trying to capture the elderly market by offering discounts and special deals to older people. The topic may bring early-bird dinner specials and movie discounts to mind, but much bigger returns are available. Financial services companies and even the Internal Revenue Service offer tax breaks based on age. 
 Many of the discounts go unclaimed because eligible people fail to speak up. "A ticket agent isn't going to ask, 'How old are you?' Neither is your insurance agent," said Joan Rattner Heilman, author of "Unbelievably Good Deals and Great Adventures That You Absolutely Can't Get Unless You Are Over 50" (Contemporary Books, 1994, $7.95). Reticence about telling your age is likely to hurt your purse more than your image, Ms. Heilman added, because the definition of older people keeps expanding to include younger people. No longer tied to the Social Security benchmark of 62 years, discounts for older people are often available at age 50.
Consider Thrifty Car Rentals. It used to limit its 10 percent discount to members of the American Association of Retired Persons. In March, it began offering the discount to anyone over 55.
Geico Insurance of Washington goes a step further. Policyholders over 50 who are retired receive a discount of 5 to 25 percent on homeowner and automobile insurance premiums, depending on the policy. Retirees are loosely defined as people working fewer than 20 hours a week.
An additional 10 percent off auto premiums is given to older people willing to take an accredited defensive driving training course (offered in many communities by the American Automobile Association). All of Geico's auto discounts end at age 74.
A veritable bonanza of deals can be found in the travel industry. The most widely known are the airline programs. Coupon programs for older travelers have been expanding as rapidly as frequent flier programs did in the early 1980's. "It's one of the really great deals," said Ed Perkins, editor of Consumer Reports Travel Letter.
Once confined to a handful of major carriers, coupons are now available from smaller airlines, like Kiwi. Older people can buy books of 4, 8 or 10 coupons in advance, good for travel anywhere in the continental United States. On average, the cost works out to $270 for each round-trip flight, generally lower than promotional fares, Mr. Perkins said.
Though travel may be limited to weekdays and advance booking may be requried (or waived for anyone willing to fly standby), the fares do not require a Saturday night stay, the mainstay of most promotions.
In a new offer, Continental Airlines announced this week that it would give people over age 62 up to 75 percent off full-price coach fares. Under the program, those eligible will pay $314 for a one-way trip from New York to Los Angeles, versus $693 for a younger traveler. Other airlines offer flat discounts of 10 percent for people of a certain age.
 The Internal Revenue Service gives the elderly a break, too. In 1993, the standard deduction for a single taxpayer over 65 was $4,600, compared with $3,700 for others. Married couples over 65 who filed jointly were allowed a standard deduction of $7,600, instead of $6,200. If one spouse was younger than 65, the deduction fell to $6,900.
Figures for the 1994 tax year are not yet available, because they are adjusted for inflation at the end of the year. Taxpayers who itemize are simply out of luck.
Some states have gotten on the bandwagon. New Jersey, for example, permits any taxpayer over 65 to determine taxable income and then subtract $1,000 before calculating taxes owed. (New York and Connecticut do not offer elderly discounts.)
Credit card issuers, including American Express, reduce annual fees; municipalities cut fees for recreational use; hotels discount rooms; colleges lower tuition. Considering the wide range of discounts, it may be worth making it a practice to ask about age breaks. For people who may be embarrassed, the extra money in the bank may ease the sting.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

I.R.A. Beneficiary
Q. When a spouse is the beneficiary of an I.R.A., can the spouse add a child as beneficiary after the account owner dies?
MILTON GREENWOOD, Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.
 
A. As the beneficiary of an individual retirement account, a spouse can either receive distributions or roll over the account into another I.R.A.
If the account is rolled over into the name of the surviving spouse, it is considered a new I.R.A. The spouse can then name a beneficiary, which may be a child or grandchild.
If a younger person is named as beneficiary, minimum distributions can be stretched out by using the combined life expectancies of the account holder and the beneficiary.
"During the surviving spouse's lifetime, there is a special rule that limits to a maximum of 10 years the age difference that may be taken into account in the joint and last survivor life expectancy calculation," said Jeffrey L. Keyser of Deloitte & Touche. "So if the surviving spouse is age 70 1/2 and the designated beneficiary is age 40, the lives for purposes of determining minimum distributions would be 70 1/2 and 60 1/2."

Evaluating Annuities
Q. What sources evaluate variable annuities?
JOYCE FISCHMAN, Norwalk, Conn.
 
A. There are almost 300 variable annuities and a much larger number of fund subaccounts, or possible investments, from which investors can choose. Information is provided by Morningstar, Lipper Analytical Services and the Variable Annuity Research and Data Service, among others. Performance data and fee comparisons are also published periodically in some newspapers and magazines.
"Investors should look significantly beyond performance data when considering variable annuity products," cautioned Kurt Cerulli, a Boston consultant. "Consider whether the contract has a guaranteed death benefit, the ease of moving money among subaccounts, minimum guarantees on fixed accounts and withdrawal waiting periods."

Price-Earnings Ratio
Q. What is a price-earnings ratio?
JOHN J. HOWLEY, Rockaway Park, Queens
 
A. A price-earnings ratio, or P/E, gauges how
expensive a stock price is relative to a company's earnings per share. In general, lower P/E ratios are considered better than high ratios.
The traditional way to calculate P/E ratios, the one used in newspaper stock tables, is the trailing earnings method, in which the current price of one share of stock is divided by the company's earnings per share over the last four quarters. The alternative method is to divide the price by the earnings per share projected by analysts for the next four quarters.
"The ironic thing regarding P/E ratios is that the trailing earnings method actually works quite well," said Richard Bernstein of Merrill Lynch. "Stock-picking methods based on P/E ratios tend to underperform during recessions, because out-of-favor stocks usually become even more out-of-favor during bad economic times."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against Yen, But Holds Firm Elsewhere

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the Japanese yen yesterday, ending a two-day rally, after Japan said its trade surplus with the United States had surged 43 percent in June.
But the dollar remained steady against the German mark and other currencies as Treasury bonds held onto recent gains. 
 "The trade numbers reminded people that many of the reasons for the dollar's decline are still around," said Michael Faust, portfolio manager at Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser, a San Mateo, Calif., money-management firm with $1 billion of assets.
A swelling Japanese trade surplus means Japanese exporters have more dollars to sell for yen when they return revenue to Japan. Also, it adds to traders' fears that the Clinton Administration will prefer to keep the dollar weak in order to make American exports cheaper overseas.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 97.86 yen, down from 98.60 yen on Thursday. It had been rebounding after hitting a record low of 96.60 yen on Tuesday, but traders said the trade figures unnerved dollar buyers.
 
'Surplus Continues to Grow'
 "The trade numbers were horrible," said David De Rosa, director of foreign exchange at the Swiss Bank Corporation.
Japan's trade surplus with the United States rose to $4.73 billion in June from $3.3 billion a year earlier.
Many traders say the dollar will remain weak against the yen until the United States succeeds in narrowing the trade gap with Japan.
"I'm not buying the rhetoric that the dollar has fallen to its lows for the year," said Steve Flanagan, a currency trader at Paine Webber Inc. "The trade figures show Japan's trade surplus continues to grow."
Meanwhile, the dollar was little changed at 1.554 marks as Treasury bonds held on to most of the gains they made Thursday. Currency traders watch the performance of Treasury bonds closely for clues of whether international investors are returning to dollar-denominated investments after dumping them earlier this year.
The dollar traded at the week's high of 1.5615 marks at midday as bonds rallied on further signs that the economy was not growing fast enough to generate inflation.
But the dollar later retreated after Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, told a Congressional panel that inflation was slowing and gave no indication that interest rates would be pushed up soon. Some currency traders had been looking for a rate increase to support the dollar.
Elsewhere, the British pound rose to $1.5613, from $1.5602 on Thursday. The dollar fell to 5.3280 French francs from 5.3310 francs, but it rose to 1,550 Italian lire from 1,549 lire. And the Canadian dollar rose to 72.60 United States cents from 72.36 cents.

HEADLINE: Industrial Production Jumps 0.5%

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
Industrial production rose five-tenths of 1 percent in June as unusually hot weather forced a big surge in utility output, the Government said today.
The Federal Reserve said that without the higher utility use, production rose only one-tenth of 1 percent last month, matching the overall increase for May. Production at factories, mines and utilities has risen for 13 consecutive months. 
 In another report, the Commerce Department said business inventories rose 1.1 percent in May, the largest increase in nearly seven years. The gain, which was larger than expected, was the fourth advance in the first five months of the year and the biggest since inventories rose 1.3 percent in October 1987, the department said.
 
Operating Rate Soars
 Plants were operating at 83.9 percent of capacity in June, up three-tenths of 1 percent, after declining one-tenth of 1 percent in each of the two preceding months. The operating rate for June was the highest in five years, but the Fed noted that the stepped-up output at utilities more than accounted for the gain.
The Fed watches the figures for signs of inflationary pressure. The increases in output and operating capacity were larger than expected, but because they were related to the weather, did not appear to signal that the economy was growing rapidly enough to feed inflation fears.
Still, most economists have predicted that the Fed will raise short-term interest rates for the fifth time this year no later than Aug. 16, when the Fed's policy makers are scheduled to hold their next meeting.
The operating rate matched a peak set in June 1989. A high rate could mean that production limits are being reached and that shortages will result, leading to higher prices and wages.
The most recent data suggest that the economy is in a period of moderate growth after a strong expansion in the final months of last year.
The Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making body of the Fed, declined to increase interest rates when it met last week despite concern about the declining value of the dollar on currency markets. The dollar has stabilized since then.
 
Annual Pace Slows
 The Fed said industrial production in June was 5.8 percent higher than it was a year ago, and output grew at an annual rate of 4.4 percent in the second quarter, down from a rate of 8.3 percent in the first quarter.
The slowdown was mainly a result of slower car and truck production, the Fed said.
The output of consumer goods rose six-tenths of 1 percent in June, after slipping one-tenth in May. Business equipment was up five-tenths of 1 percent, after a rise of six-tenths. Construction supplies rose two-tenths of 1 percent, after a May advance of four-tenths.
Utility production soared 5.4 percent in June, after gaining nine-tenths of 1 percent in May. That more than offset a drop of five-tenths of 1 percent in mining, which had fallen 1.2 percent in May. At factories, production rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, after slipping a tenth in May.

HEADLINE: A Confidence Index Falls Confidence Index Falls

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The University of Michigan's preliminary index of consumer sentiment for July fell to 88.9 from 91.2 in June, people with access to the report said yesterday.
"While a drop was expected, the extent of the fall was a surprise," said Dana Sorrentino, an economist at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates. "We assume it reflects the turmoil in the stock and bond markets in early July." 
 Also helping to fuel concern was speculation that the Federal Reserve would soon raise interest rates to head off inflation, Mr. Sorrentino said. The Fed has raised the Federal funds rate -- what banks charge each other for overnight loans -- four times this year, to 4 1/4 percent.
The consumer confidence index is based on 100, set in 1966. When the monthly reading increases, consumers are becoming more optimistic about the economy. Since 1966, the record high for the sentiment index is 101, set in March 1984. The record low is 51.7, set in April 1980.
The university also said its July index of current economic conditions rose to 106.0 from 104.5 in June.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Good Job, But Good Riddance

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON 

 BODY:
ONLY one month and one day after Mike Keenan held the Stanley Cup aloft, he put a dent in it. And in his credibility.
Insisting he was a "free agent" because the Rangers "failed to honor the obligations of my contract," the only Ranger coach to kiss the Stanley Cup since 1940 kissed the franchise goodbye yesterday. The kiss was not returned. 
 As a coach, Mike Keenan deserves to be hailed for having done a good job. As a man, he deserves good riddance.
Look now for the Ranger lawyers to challenge Keenan's self-described free agency. In court, if necessary.
According to a Madison Square Garden statement, the Rangers were one day late in paying Keenan's playoff bonus. Keenan seemed to be using that as an excuse to leave, possibly to join the Detroit Red Wings as coach or general manager, if not both -- a deal he repeatedly denied despite persistent reports during the last week of the Stanley Cup final.
The night the Rangers won the cup, Keenan was asked again about the Detroit deal.
"As I said yesterday and as I said three days ago," he insisted, "it's nonsense."
Not everybody believed him. When the Rangers gathered two days later for their formal Stanley Cup photo, Bob Gutkowski, the president of the Garden, disclosed that he had alerted Commissioner Gary Bettman that if Keenan were to join the Red Wings, the National Hockey League should investigate.
Keenan, after all, joined the Rangers a year ago for a five-year contract reportedly worth $5 million. But he has always been the restless type.
 Despite his Ranger contract, Keenan talked vaguely every so often during the season about his interest in "new challenges." He also talked mysteriously about having spurned a firm offer from another N.H.L. club a year ago in order to join the Rangers.
In retrospect, was that offer from the Red Wings? And when the whispers about the Red Wings first surfaced, he issued what was known in the Nixon administration as a nondenial denial. He later hardened his denials.
Another factor added credence to the Red Wing deal: Keenan and Neil Smith, the Rangers' general manager, had a tense, strained relationship.
Gutkowski's putting Commissioner Bettman on alert was important. If the Red Wings are eventually found to have tampered with Keenan, especially with a Stanley Cup-winning coach, the Rangers would deserve quality compensation in players, draft choices or cash, if not all three.
But if Keenan could prove a breach of contract, he could slide into hockey's unemployment line for a few weeks or a few months, then join the Red Wings.
"I'm open to anything that might be out there in the N.H.L.," he said yesterday at his news conference in The Sports Network television offices in Toronto. "I'm on the open market and I'd like to coach in the N.H.L. again."
In choreographing his departure, maybe Keenan knew he could never top what he accomplished here: winning the Stanley Cup in his only season as the Rangers' coach.
In the four remaining seasons of his Ranger contract, anything less than winning the cup would be considered a failure. His reputation could only melt like so much ice. And with several aging players, maybe he thought the Rangers would not be able to win again next year. But a "new challenge" elsewhere would give him time to win.
Keep in mind that the Red Wings, stunned by the San Jose Sharks in the recent playoffs, are what the Rangers were a year ago: a talented team that needs only another player or two to win the cup.
Say this for Keenan: He's a good coach. Mark Messier has called him "the best coach I've ever played for," high praise considering how long Messier played for Glen Sather in the Edmonton Oilers' dynasty.
In the Rangers' only season with Keenan behind their bench, the players responded to his hard, demanding style. They finished first over all and won the cup. But would they respond so obediently now that they have won it?
And for Keenan, a "new challenge" would exist in Detroit. Of the six N.H.L. franchises before expansion nearly nearly three decades ago, the Red Wings, who last won the Stanley Cup in 1955, now have replaced the Rangers as the team that has endured the longest drought without champagne in hockey's silver punch bowl.
As the Red Wings' coach, Mike Keenan would have the opportunity to be a savior in Detroit just as he was a savior here. At least for one month and one day. But with his machinations, Mike Keenan must now be considered a deserter.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
NASA SELECTS SUPERSONIC AIRCRAFT DEVELOPERS

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
The Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation have been selected by NASA to lead a team developing technologies for the next generation of supersonic transport aircraft. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said the contract was valued at $880 million. Seattle-based Boeing said the contract was for a planned eight-year second phase of NASA's high-speed research program, intended to develop key technologies required for a new high-speed transport. Boeing said studies had shown that supersonic travel could be economically feasible and that demand existed for transportation that could cut flying time between New York and Paris or Los Angeles and Tokyo in half.

HEADLINE: Bennington Redesign Returns to Roots

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re 'How Downsizing Diminishes Bennington" (letter, July 5) by Debra Hecht and Anaheed Alani, Bennington College graduates: Literature, foreign languages and musical instruments will continue to be taught at Bennington and in ways that offer greater breadth and depth. 
 In keeping with a shift to a faculty composed of teacher-practitioners, literature will be taught by poets, writers of fiction, essayists and playwrights, a change that signals a return to the times when W. H. Auden, Howard Nemerov, Bernard Malamud and John Gardner taught the great works at Bennington.
All foreign language learning will be relocated out of the college into a new regional language learning center; languages taught will include Chinese, French, German, Japanese, Russian and Spanish (two more than were previously offered).
Music will be taught by professionally active composers, and the teaching of musical instruments beyond those provided by composers will be supplemented by the abundant resources of the Bennington community -- a community that may not be considered cosmopolitan by some standards, but one that offers an impressive roster of professional musicians and even its own symphony.
Art history, sociology, politics and economics have been eliminated as distinct areas of study, but all continue to be part of Bennington's curriculum; they will now be taught as a part of the study of art, history, philosophy, anthropology and psychology.
Bennington's redesign includes the dissolution of the traditional departmental structure; the prospective abolishment of presumptive tenure; a tuition-linked fund to encourage faculty innovation, and collaborative, cross-disciplinary faculty program groups as the primary academic structure. This dramatic redesign has received major support from foundations and alumni.
The human costs of such change are indeed great.
During the 1993-94 academic year, the faculty numbered approximately 80 full- and part-time teachers, a number that translates to a full-time equivalent of 61.5. The changes displaced 20 of those 80, although some will continue to teach at the college for 1994-95. When the 1995-96 academic year begins, the college expects to have a full-time equivalent of 50 faculty members, or 11.5 fewer than during 1993-94.
A college is indeed an "intricate institution, whose character derives from history"; the board of trustees evidenced that belief in making the difficult choices that led to the college's redesign -- a redesign that not only returns Bennington to the principles of its founding and its place as a leader in innovative education, but also offers students the richest possible academic experience at a cost that aims to go down in the foreseeable future.
 
NORMAN DERBY
Dean, Bennington College
Bennington, Vt., July 7, 1994
