HEADLINE: For a Troubled Building, a New Twist

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
DONALD J. TRUMP likes to boast that Trump Palace on Third Avenue is a fast-moving condominium. This is not a distinction he seeks for his next project, Trump International Tower and Hotel
Trump International Tower is what most New Yorkers know today as the old Gulf and Western Building on Columbus Circle. They also know that the 579-foot skyscraper twists perceptibly in high winds. 
 Such movement will simply not do for an apartment house and hotel, which is what the 24-year-old building is to become after Paramount Communications (the successor to Gulf and Western) moves out. Its lease expires next April. As part of the two-year, $230 million reconstruction, trusses and columns are to be added to make the tower more rigid.
Too small to satisfy the demands of commercial tenants, the building's 13,000-square-foot floors strongly suggested the conversion, as did the panoramic views it would afford. "The floor plate of the building is ideally suited for residential," said Bruce L. Warwick, executive vice president of the Galbreath Company, a real estate concern associated in this project with Mr. Trump and with an affiliate of the General Electric Pension Trust, which owns the building.
From the outside, the contrast between old and new will be dramatic. Under plans by Philip Johnson, the zebra-like black-and-silver facade will be replaced by a dazzling, beveled, multifaceted skin. The columns and horizontal spandrels are to be reclad in Champagne-colored mirrored glass. The windows, tinted a light bronze, will form three-sided bays among the angular columns.
"Philip thinks it's the best building he's ever done," Mr. Trump said the other day, lightheartedly, before double-checking with the architect whether the quote fairly represented Mr. Johnson's opinion.
"I'll allow you to use it," Mr. Johnson told Mr. Trump. Then he turned to a reporter and added, "But give him credit for saying it."
New Yorkers can be counted on to form strong opinions of their own about this design, particularly since the 45-story building commands such a vital site, gateway both to Central Park and the Upper West Side.
In some ways, however, the key is not what is added to the facade but what is added underneath. The tower must be made more stable. Motion that might merely discomfit an office worker would be intolerable for a resident, particularly one who had paid, say, $900,000 for a one-bedroom apartment.
"Our largest concern was that issue," Mr. Warwick said. "When the building was built, the degree of sophistication about high-rise structures was nowhere near what it is today. It's basically a safe building but the allowance for sway was much greater. In a heavy wind condition, it was not unsafe -- but it was uncomfortable."
The job of making the tower more rigid falls mainly to Ysrael A. Seinuk, the 62-year-old chief executive officer of the Cantor/ Seinuk Group, a 100-person engineering concern in Manhattan.
He first worked with Mr. Johnson in 1957 on a hotel project in Havana that was never built. Some of the firm's notable recent jobs includes a research building for the Rockefeller University that spans the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive and 450 Lexington Avenue, a tower that rises through an old post office from a base in the subsurface rail yards of Grand Central Terminal.
"There is nothing wrong about the building," Mr. Seinuk said about the Gulf and Western tower. "The engineers designed it according to code as it was then. There is nothing over-stressed about it. I'd live in the building today with no worry." He would, however, see the chandeliers swing a bit from time to time and hear the walls creaking as the structure shifted.
"It moves about two-and-a-half feet, very quickly, at the top," Mr. Seinuk said. "If it was just swaying two-and-a-half feet slowly, people would not feel it. The problem is that it twists. And that acceleration is what people feel and what makes them uncomfortable."
WHY are other tall buildings in New York not plagued with such a troublesome reputation? Because, Mr. Seinuk said, they are usually clustered with other high-rise towers in mid-Manhattan or downtown. The Gulf and Western Building, by contrast, stands in isolation.
"Most other buildings built at that time are shielded," Mr. Seinuk said. "This building is totally exposed."
"Which," Mr. Trump jumped in to say, "is a great asset for views."
Heavy winds from the northwest run freely down Broadway, Mr. Seinuk said, but are partly blocked by tall buildings along Central Park West. As a result, the wind moves faster across the west side of the Gulf and Western tower than the east side. This turns the structure into a kind of airfoil, not unlike the wing of an airplane, creating vibrations.
Working under professional review by another engineering concern, Leslie E. Robertson Associates, Mr. Seinuk devised several methods to reduce the movement by more than half and control vibration.
In the hotel, running from the base to the 14th floor, diagonal steel truss members will be added behind the interior walls that ring the core of the building, making the center of the structure more rigid.
Because the 15th and 16th floors are used for mechanical equipment, much larger trusses can be built without concern that the diagonal elements will slice through a prime view or poke through a spacious living room.
At this level, two-story outrigger trusses will be built to tie the core of the building to the exterior frame. Also, a two-story belt truss will be run around the perimeter of the tower to discipline the response of the whole structure to wind forces.
From the tops of the inverted V's formed by this belt truss will emerge new columns, interspersed among the existing columns, reducing the column-to-column distance from 26 feet to 13 feet, further rigidifying the periphery of the building.
Given all of this effort and expense, one wonders why the developers did not simply raze the building and start over again.
"The reason we're leaving the steel is that we have a mass that would never, ever be allowed again," Mr. Trump said. With 610,000 square feet of floor space on a 34,000-square-foot lot, the floor-area ratio is about 18. Zoning rules would not permit a residential building with a ratio of more than 12.
"We would have to reduce the building by 10 to 12 stories," said Scott C. Coopchik, executive managing director of Galbreath.
Even with the larger building, however, the developers said they are bound by the lower residential density, meaning that only two-thirds of the tower can be set aside for apartments, of which there will be about 200.
The bottom of the building is to be the Trump International Hotel, with some 200 suites that will be sold as condominium units to investors. Under zoning rules, these must be used "primarily for transient occupancy and may be rented on a daily basis." Hotel services will also be available to permanent residents upstairs, Mr. Trump said.
"Value is added to Trump Tower apartments by having an atrium," Mr. Trump said. "Likewise, I think that great value will be added by having a hotel section."
Mr. Trump also said he was negotiating with restaurants like the Four Seasons, Bouley, Le Bernardin and Le Cirque to operate the dining area at the top of the building.
Besides a sky-high restaurant space, the tower comes with other built-in advantages. Because it was designed for office use, its floor slabs are 12 feet apart. That allows for finished ceilings 10 feet or higher, about a foot or two more than typical in a modern apartment building, including Trump Palace.
But the redevelopment team was also constrained by the shape of the box. Since it already exceeds current zoning rules, there was no room for the pediments or pinnacles or mansards or gables that Mr. Johnson has been known to employ. "You couldn't do any modern architectural whizbangs," he said.
For Trump International Tower, Mr. Johnson said the choice of material was virtually a foregone conclusion. "I'm a great glass man," he said. "We didn't want to load down the building with sheets of granite."
"We're distilling everything we've learned about glass over the years," he said.
Working with Mr. Johnson on the Columbus Circle project is Costas Kondylis. The two architects are also associated in the design of buildings for Mr. Trump's Riverside South project on the Hudson River.
TWO months ago, when speaking of the new facade for the Gulf and Western Building, Mr. Trump conjured images of the Seagram Building, on which Mr. Johnson worked with Ludwig Mies van der Rohe.
In the event, the design turned out to be much more like PPG Corporate Headquarters in Pittsburgh, which was completed in 1984 to designs by Mr. Johnson and John Burgee. Like the PPG building, Trump International Tower has a pleated facade, with angular columns and mirrored glass.
"By doing that," Mr. Johnson said, "we take the curse of the glass box away. We make it shimmer in the light."
Unlike the PPG building, the windows in Trump International Tower will not be reflective, since a mirrored surface cuts down on transparency and views will be strongest selling point of the new apartments.
At first, the design called for flat window expanses between the columns. Then, the architects designed a two-sided projecting bay. But they finally settled on a more traditional three-sided bay. "Everybody likes that," Mr. Johnson said. "You get a sense of having a promontory room."
On the matter of whether the projecting bays add floor area to the building, Mr. Johnson and his colleagues met Wednesday with Buildings Department officials. A spokesman, Vahe Tiryakian, said the buildings agency is reviewing the floor-area issue, and the reinforcement and recladding plans.
Other key issues yet to be resolved include redesigning the entrance to the Columbus Circle subway station at the southern end of the plaza on which the tower sits. The station is now reached through a dank, barren pit.
There is also a 532-seat subterranean movie theater, once called the Paramount and now Loews Columbus Circle. That will close next year but Mr. Trump said he was not ready to announce what would go in its place.
The redevelopment team is also exploring the project's eligibility for tax benefits. Mr. Trump said one possibility was the Section 421-a program, which offers abatements on residential construction. There is also the J-51 program, for residential conversions, and the Industrial and Commercial Incentive Program, which might apply to the hotel.
Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge, a Democrat who represents the area, criticized the impending construction of "luxury apartments that we don't need more of," adding, "I only hope they're fully tax-paying, because we could use some of the revenues."
As to whether there are buyers, the answer is yes -- in Hong Kong, Taiwan and China -- said Barbara Corcoran, president of the Corcoran Group. She is directing sales and marketing for Trump International Tower, with Louise Sunshine of the Sunshine Group.
Overseas purchasers who would not have considered the West Side a few years ago are now moving into the Lincoln Center area, Ms. Corcoran said. They have, for instance, bought many of the apartments in the Three Lincoln Center tower.
Trump International Tower "is not a West Side building per se," said Andrew Weiss, executive vice president of the Trump Organization. "This is a Central Park-Midtown building with incredible views."
APARTMENTS will range from about 900 to 4,000 square feet. Ms. Corcoran envisions Asian purchasers buying units for their own use or as long-term investments. "They spend quickly," she said. "They spend a lot. They love newness. And they're crazy about views."
It remains to be seen whether prices can reach as high as Mr. Trump would like. "There are larger units in condominiums selling already for $1,000 a square foot," Ms. Corcoran said. "But it's not the norm."
Some people who live in the neighborhood cannot imagine it will ever be the case. "I just don't think, in this market, that kind of thing is going to fly any more," said Madeleine Polayes, president of the Coalition for a Livable West Side, which fights what it sees as overdevelopment of the area.
Ms. Polayes dismissed this and other recent announcements by Mr. Trump -- obtaining financing for Riverside South, becoming a partner in the ownership of the Empire State Building -- as gambits to improve his standing in the eyes of current and prospective Asian investors. "He needs this to show the Hong Kong people how vibrant he is," she said. "It's all hype and P.R. No one is talking about his debts and lawsuits."
But Ms. Corcoran said Mr. Trump's involvement had a definite economic value.
"What was important in the name was that it had 'Trump' in it," she said. "I'd say that whether Donald was in the room or not." (As it happens, he was at the time.)
"When people come from out of town," she said, "we can show them a smaller product at a higher price if it has the Trump name. Customers are predisposed to paying more. The name says glamour."

HEADLINE: Using a Mortgage Broker

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS 

 BODY:
WORKING with a mortgage broker is something relatively new. It's only in the last seven years that they have become popular, largely because prospective borrowers seem too busy these days to shop for themselves and some prefer to let a more qualified person find the best rate and terms.
Mortgage brokers have also gained an excellent reputation for helping marginal borrowers who cannot negotiate a loan on their own. Moreover, they can help the novice borrower collect the necessary documents and fill out the forms. A good mortgage broker will even make a prior credit check and help the borrower clear up any problem areas before the credit record is seen by a lender. 
 Little wonder that about a half of all home loans now originate through a mortgage broker. Yet with only a scant history to fall back on, many people aren't even sure of the questions they should be asking before selecting a broker or how to recognize honesty from sleaze. But it can be done.
"We just went with our instincts," said Jerry Weist, an appraiser of antique comic books who with his wife, Dana Hawkes, recently bought a rowhouse in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. But relying on instinct alone is taking a big chance.
First, a definition. Mortgage brokers do not originate loans. Rather, they scour the marketplace for the best possible deal among a basketful of lenders with whom they deal on a regular basis.
They are paid by the lender -- not the borrower -- for bringing in a client. (Of course, the borrower still pays an application fee, typically no more than a bank would charge.)
Say, for instance, the lender has a published charge of 2 points on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage for a borrower who walks through the door. When a mortgage broker makes a referral the points charge is split between broker and lender. On a no-points mortgage the lender will normally split part of the higher interest rate charged in lieu of points, based on a predetermined negotiated formula. So it should not cost a borrower more to use a mortgage broker than to go directly to a bank, another reason for their rising popularity.
But even this broad definition leaves a lot out. For example, some loans never go through a mortgage broker. These include certain state-sponsored mortgages offered with uncommonly low down payments or at discounted interest rates to moderate-income buyers.
"We aren't permitted to offer them," said Bernard J. Senderak, president of The Source Mortgage, a mortgage broker in Fairfield, Conn.
So even the best mortgage broker can never provide access to a truly comprehensive universe of lending. But the more reputable ones will explain how to apply directly when they are aware of a mortgage, unavailable through them, that might work better.
It is equally important to understand exactly how mortgage brokers negotiate their commissions with lenders, since these deals can lure even the most honest broker into temptation.
Thomas Hylinski, senior vice president at People's Bank of Bridgeport, Conn., said lenders generally negotiated separately with each broker. And some lenders cut highly favorable deals with certain brokers to encourage them to send the business their way, even though that lender might be charging more than the competition.
At other times, warned Vicky Papson, a mortgage consultant with Emigrant Mortgage Company of Darien, Conn., the broker may add a quarter point or so to the advertised interest rate whenever he or she thinks the borrower isn't going to find out.
"Never brag that you're too busy to check things out yourself," said Ms. Papson, who used to work as a mortgage broker, "or tell him you think you're going to have trouble getting any sort of loan."
Both are tip-offs that tempt the broker to incorporate excess charges, she said. And they can be difficult to detect even though regulations require all fees to be disclosed.
Instead, say these experts, suggest that you're closely following the latest promotions. Also, that you will question every one of the broker's recommendations.
Another protection is to call the institution where the broker intends to place the loan to make sure the rate is no higher than if you had applied directly.
Michael Hoogendyk, executive vice president of the National Association of Mortgage Brokers, warned against using a broker who demands an upfront fee before providing specifics on the total cost to the borrower for the loan and the terms of the loan.
And be thorough with the search. Say a real estate agent has recommended two brokers and your lawyer has offered yet another name. "Question each one carefully on the phone," said Alan Trachtman, president of National Money Merchants, mortgage brokers of Park Slope, Brooklyn. "Ask about their plans. Ask for a list of lenders they use."
During that interview, said Mr. Hylinski, the banker, the borrowers should seek references. They should ask for the names and phone numbers of two or three other borrowers who have recently used that broker and referrals to a couple of lenders the broker regularly uses.
Borrowers should also decide initially what they most want from a mortgage broker and base their questions on those needs, too.
For example, if they anticipate credit problems, can the broker guide them through a prior credit clearance and the complexities of the paperwork? If the borrowers are busy, can the broker return their calls on evenings and weekends and even make house calls?
Mr. Weist, for one, needed to work with someone who could rush the loan through so he would not overstep an imminent capital-gains deadline.
Others may prefer to work with a broker who may be willing to negootiate the fee. This is indeed a point worth raising, especially when seeking a jumbo loan (anything over $200,000) since the fee will be proportionately larger even though it may not require extra time to process.
For example, the broker may be willing to charge the borrower only 1.5 points instead of the normal 2, taking a half-point cut in his own commission. It's an excellent way to get an even better deal than going through a lender directly.
As the process moves forward, a broker should not be asking for a second application fee if the loan is rejected by one lender and another has to be approached, said Mr. Hoogendyk. Nor should a broker be promising, in advance, specific rates or terms, since these are dependent on the lender and change rapidly.
Finally, it is crucial to check the progress of the application. Mortgage brokers are sometimes criticized for not submitting paperwork in a timely fashion.
Delays may be prevented by calling in every week or so. "But don't wait a month before asking for a progress report," said Ms. Papson. "Two weeks is long enough."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New York Room Tax;
Surcharge End Delights Hotels

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
IT took New York's travel industry four years to get the state to repeal the hated 5 percent surcharge on hotel rooms renting for more than $100. It took New York City hotel managers probably four minutes to start marketing the fact that as of Sept. 1, that tax will be history -- and that three months later, the city will shave an additional percentage point off the tax as well.
"We're getting the message out that New York is visitor-friendly once again," said an ebullient Joseph E. Spinnato, president of the Hotel Association of New York City, which rushed out a four-page newsletter celebrating the repeal. 
 Indeed, almost immediately after the state tax repeal was announced on June 8, the Convention and Visitors Bureau and the hotels issued news releases heralding the impending new "low" room tax of 13.25 percent plus $2. They put stickers highlighting the tax repeal on their old sales brochures, and designed new ones that stress the new tax. And they put every available salesperson on the phone to convention managers to spread the good news.
"We called every single person who ever cited the tax as a reason they would not hold a meeting in New York," said Jean M. Spaulding, director of sales and marketing for Sheraton's two New York hotels.
The repeal's timing couldn't have been better. Hotel sales people made it a major topic at the Travel Industry Association of America's convention in Miami last month, and will probably do so again at next month's meeting of the American Society of Association Executives in San Francisco.
The Marriott chain just held a long-scheduled three-day meeting in San Diego for 225 of its best corporate customers, and the Marriott Marquis decorated a booth with bogus newspapers making the repeal page one news. Genuine headlines abounded as well -- numerous trade magazines and journals put the repeal on their front pages.
Stephen J. Morello, head of the convention bureau, heard about the repeal while he was in Chicago, pitching New York to various meeting planners there.
"I announced it to a group of association representatives, and they gave me a standing ovation," Mr. Morello said.
But will the tax repeal actually bring tourists and conventions back to New York City?
It's too soon to tell for sure. Hotel statistics show that 40 percent of room nights are booked two years in advance. Conventions are booked at least three years in advance.
Moreover, all of the hoopla about the tax has tended to obscure the many other reasons that travelers and conventioneers might shun New York. Many complain of high food, parking and room costs, of filth, of fears about crime and of traffic congestion. They cite the Javits Convention Center's problematic 11th Avenue location and layout, and the continual battle with unions over work rules.
"A lot of people promised to put New York back into the rotation of cities they consider each year, but no one will give a guarantee," said Ms. Spaulding of Sheraton.
That does not surprise Jeffrey W. Wood, director of conference planning for the Direct Marketing Association. His group is headquartered in New York and has many members within driving distance of the city, yet even he is not planning to hold his annual conference in New York any time soon.
"The tax was never the only reason I went elsewhere," he said.
Nor is Fabian G. Palomino, the Javits Center's president, surprised by continued hesitancy. He concedes that his meeting rooms are small, and that the column spacing on exhibit floors is more conducive to trade shows than to conventions. He is seeking approval to double the center's size, and to offer inexpensive parking. And he is trying to persuade exhibitors and their contractors to take a firmer stance with the unions.
"I wouldn't agree to some of the overtime rates or crew sizes that they accept," he said.
NEW YORK'S boosters stress that competing cities have strikes against them, too. They note that Seattle is perceived as rainy, New Orleans as hot, Las Vegas as too glitzy.
"New York is not the destination for everyone, but neither is Lake of the Ozarks, Mo., and that's cheap," said John Kalinski, director of marketing for the Marriott Marquis.
Still, New York has a herculean marketing task to repair the damage that has been done since the 5 percent surcharge was imposed on June 1, 1990. That day, New York's combined city and state taxes on hotel rooms went to 19.25 percent plus $2 -- effectively, 21.25 percent on a $100 room, compared with a national average last year of 11.68 percent.
According to the American Economics Group, a research organization, last year New York City hotel guests paid an average $24.47 a night in taxes, calculated on an average hotel room rate of $116.75. The average nightly tax in Washington, Atlanta, Las Vegas and other cities that New York competes with for conventions came to only $8.06.
Only four other cities -- New Orleans, Chicago, San Francisco and Washington -- even hit double digit figures on average taxes. New Orleans, the second most heavily taxed major metropolitan area, came in at a paltry-by-comparison $12.02, less than half New York's rates.
Convention managers had reacted to the surcharge with fury. Indeed, the Professional Convention Management Association recommended to its members that they avoid New York City as long as the tax existed.
"Lots of people think of New York as terribly expensive to begin with," Mr. Morello said. "To them, the tax was the icing on a very distasteful cake."
It was also a psychological affront, said Arthur A. Surin, senior vice president of the New York Hilton. "Convention managers said it was against their philosophy to let themselves be fleeced, and that even if we lowered our base rate to compensate they would still feel taken advantage of," he said.
Even hotels with room rates below the $100 at which the tax kicked in hated the levy. "As the more expensive hotels lost convention business, they started going after our airline or tourist business with lower rates," said Kenneth I. Walles, general manager of the Hotel Pennsylvania, a mid-priced hotel.
Not surprisingly, the hotels and the convention bureau spent four years trying to drive the impact of the tax home to state legislators. The hotel association hired the American Economics Group to gather economically damning data that they could use to lobby Albany.
The group came up with a formidable list of fiscal hurts. It noted that hotel employment was down 15.2 percent from the pre-tax peak; that convention-related hotel business was down to about 1 million delegates, just two-thirds of the 1.5 million that came here in 1989; and that the number of conventions that are comprised primarily of out-of-town delegates was down precipitously as well, from 640 in 1990 to 405 last year.
Actually, the dire numbers probably overstated the case, in that the hotel tax hit New York at about the same time as did the recession. Employment, tourism, business travel and convention attendance traditionally drop during any economic downtown.
And no one knows for sure if the tax has affected the length of stay of people who do come to New York, or the number of times business travelers will bring spouses.
"You get a non-expense account family of four visiting, and the tax might mean they forgo a set of theater tickets, or shave a night off their stay," Mr. Surin said.
But the muddiness of the figures did not stop the hotel association from capitalizing on them. It organized a Repeal the Hotel Tax rally on March 15, 1993, at Madison Square Garden. And it organized a campaign that deluged state legislators with thousands of letters decrying the tax.
Now, the industry is mobilizing its internal publicity machine to capitalize on the repeal. Many hotels sent faxes and E-mail and memos marked "urgent" to their international sales and reservations offices, to help them sell New York as a reduced-in-price destination. The Marriott Marquis even sent out a video of its sales people toasting the repeal with champagne.
But there is one aspect of the tax cut that the industry is decidedly playing down: The 1 percent city tax that is disappearing was a so-called dedicated tax, used exclusively to finance the convention bureau. Hotel executives worry about that because many convention customers count on a strong bureau to arrange transportation, provide greeters at airports, and to smooth relations with the convention center and the hotels.
"I'm not publicizing the 1 percent repeal until I'm sure it doesn't kill the convention bureau's funding," Mr. Kalinski of the Marriott Marquis said.
Mr. Morello says that city officials have assured him that his budget will not be slashed drastically. But, he concedes, he will have to redouble efforts to "make sure that the city continues to recognize that its investment in us is getting a strong return."

HEADLINE: The New Britain-Wroclaw Connection

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
WHEN the Iron Curtain collapsed of its own weight in Europe in the late 1980's, no group rejoiced more than the Polish-Americans of New Britain.
For decades, New Britain's Poles -- the major ethnic group in the city for most of the century -- had been agonizing over the fate of relatives and friends in Poland. Now Poland would be free at last, free at last. 
 Jubilation over the breakup of the Soviet Union was quickly followed however by some sobering questions. What would the new freedom really mean to Poland? How could the country survive in an outside world of which it really knew little after half a century of virtual isolation?
 
Adjusting After Communism
 Leaders of the Polish community sought the advice of leaders of Central Connecticut State University, which had started a Polish studies program several years ago because of the city's large Polish population. Together, they decided that the best way, perhaps the only way, to really help the new Poland was to teach its people how a free-market economy works and how to adjust to it from a Communist system.
Some $25,000 in seed money to get the venture started was quickly raised by the local General Jozef Haller Post, Polish Army Veterans Association, supplemented soon after by a $50,000 grant from the Rockefeller Brothers Fund.
Thus was established what is known officially as the Institute for Business Studies at Central Connecticut State University, but which unofficially might be known as the New Britain-Wroclaw connection.
Over the past five years, in a quiet and generally unpublicized way, Connecticut business people and educators, more than 50 in all, have shuttled back and forth to the Technical University of Wroclaw in Poland. There they have explained the facets of a free-market economy to faculty members and city officials, remaining for periods ranging from about a week to full semesters. Unpaid volunteers have included Stanley A. Twardy Jr., formerly United States Attorney General for Connecticut and formerly chief of staff for Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., and Sandra K. Hamer, president of a Farmington public relations firm.
In turn, educators from Wroclaw have visited Central Connecticut State to monitor classes, to talk about American business practices and to decide how best to make them work in a country that has marched to an entirely different drummer for half a century.
Exchange programs between educators are far from new. But Central's president, John W. Shumaker, said it was decided early on that the Connecticut-Poland program "should not be an educational exercise but should deal in reality," by providing expertise and training specifically to help get Poland into a market system.
"We didn't go to Poland to study Poles," he said. "We went to help."
 
Why Not Warsaw?
 The decision to hold the program in Wroclaw was part of that philosophy, he added. It would have been much easier to do it in Warsaw, a relatively modern and sophisticated city, but Wroclaw was chosen because "it really needed help."
Wroclaw (pronounced VROOTZ laff) is an old, remote industrial city of 650,000 in Lower Silesia near the German border. The city, its Polish leaders say, has always been a Polish city more than a German city even though before World War II it was part of Germany and known as Breslau.
One of the chief players in the Wroclaw-New Britain program is Henry S. Enck, executive assistant to the president for international development at Central Connecticut.
Until June of 1990, Mr. Enck had never been to Poland and his first visit to Wroclaw was a real revelation. He discovered that after 50 years of Communism, the leaders and educators of the city knew virtually nothing about a free-market economy. Even such simple terms as balance sheet or rates of interest were nonexistent or misunderstood.
"I saw the shambles of the Communist system," said Mr. Enck.
What was needed in Wroclaw, he said, was a quickly implemented system of getting information to college professors and high school teachers so that they could pass it along quickly. Central has been able to continue the program through more than $3 million in grants, mostly from the United States Agency for International Development -- this in an era when such money is progressively harder to come by.
Since his initial visit, Mr. Enck has been back to Wroclaw 11 times, arranging new programs and checking on progress. A Polish/English dictionary of economic terms prepared by Central is now being used by high school teachers in the Wroclaw area. Free-market business principles and practices and banking are taught at the technical college. A center has been established to encourage development of small businesses.
 
What's Communications?
 "We're also starting the first school of communications in Eastern Europe," Mr. Enck said. Eventually, he said, it will be jointly managed by the Technical University of Wroclaw and the University of Wroclaw.
Actually, simply explaining what a school of communications teaches has been difficult in Poland. There is no one word in the Polish language that means communication, in the sense of transmitting information.
"To us, communications was trains or planes," Zdzislaw B. Kremens, an official of the Technical University of Wroclaw, said recently on one of his visits to New Britain.
The one major irritant to people who have worked on the New Britain-Wroclaw connection is the seemingly endless red tape that continues unabated in Poland, no matter what the changes in government.
One person currently trying to deal with the red tape is Janusz S. Podlasek, a New Britain industrialist who, although a United States citizen, had been trapped as a child during World War II in Wloclawek, Poland, where his father had owned and operated a factory.
 
Improvements vs. Rent
 The factory has been run as a state venture since the war and currently produces radiators, said Mr. Podlasek, who is now 63. He said he has been attempting to regain the factory the past few years but keeps running into bureaucratic roadblocks.
"We have trouble agreeing on a price," he said. "They say they have made improvements to the factory. 'But you haven't paid rent in 50 years,' I say."
Despite the labyrinth of rules and regulations in Poland, Henry Enck said his university's program has been able to move forward not by ignoring them but by coping with them.
"We follow regulations to the letter but don't get strangled in them. We insist the bureaucracy respond in a timely manner," he said. "We ought to be a classic example of being suffocated by bureaucracy, but it hasn't turned out that way."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: From Paving to Lights and Trees;
Creating a Downtown Brooklyn 'Visual Identity'

 BODY:
"Brooklyn, you are the universe."
The words were those of the late novelist Bernard Malamud, who spent his childhood there, but they could describe the feelings of many Brooklyn residents, past and present. 
 Now the borough has a plan to make that universe, or at least its downtown, a little more attractive -- to tie together new developments in the area with the existing architectural fabric, improve the street environment, give the downtown a stronger identity and make more powerful Brooklyn's image as a borough of "green."
The plan, which involves both public and private funding, is called the "Downtown Brooklyn Streetscape Guidelines and Sign Program." It is the product of a study undertaken by the New York City Economic Development Corporation at the request of Brooklyn Borough President Howard Golden.
The result entails design recommendations for sidewalk paving, signs, curbs, corners, crosswalks, street lighting, trees and furniture. Gray-tinted concrete, for instance, is recommended as basic paving material for retail streets, major boulevards and commercial-institutional streets, while the bluestone paving around Borough Hall sets the precedent for all sidewalks of the Civic Center streets.
The plan also recommends narrow-shaped trees to allow better visibility for signs on retail streets; spreading trees to create a "delicate, generous canopy" on Civic Center streets and major boulevards and pyramidal trees for "green canopy without blocking views" on commercial-retail streets.
The sign program includes a "vehicular trail-blazer system" tied to a distinctive logo to guide drivers to such areas as the Civic Center, MetroTech, the Fulton Mall and the Brooklyn Academy of Music. A "pedestrian orientation system" is to feature directories keyed to a downtown map with arrows pointing to major destinations.
Greg Brooks, executive assistant to Mr. Golden, said the plan was "an opportunity to create a visual identity for downtown and to create a signage program in an area that sorely needed such a program."
Mr. Brooks said that the Borough President had appropriated about $500,000 for construction to complete the sign program and that "we would like to see this going forward in the next couple of months."
"We are working with the private sector to come up with a maintenance agreement," he said. "We will implement the plan, and the private sector will be responsible for maintenance." The entire plan, he said, "is an opportunity for public-private partnership."
"In this year's capital budget there is more than $1 million for roadway infrastructure," he said. "We will choose the targeted roadwork with the private sector, and they will fund the amenities, such as lights and trees."

GRAPHIC: Drawing: Brooklyn retail street envisioned in downtown plan. (New York City Economic Development Corporation)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1431 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: July 10-15

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Macy's? Federated? Bloomingdale's? It's All for One Now
At this rate, life will soon be elegantly simple. To shop, you'll just head for a single 20-square-block store sprawled across Midtown. Its name? Macy's-Federated-A&S-Bloomingdale's-Stern's-Etc.-Etc. Or, perhaps, simply Department Store Inc. Last week Macy's and Federated finished their long mating dance, as Macy's stopped battling to stay independent and agreed to a merger, giving birth to the nation's largest department-store company. Macy's bondholders do fairly well as the chain emerges from bankruptcy, but retail workers will probably lose out. New York-area department-store jobs have slid to 24,000 from 57,000 just 15 years ago, and more layoffs will certainly follow now. But you can't have jobs without stores: if, by joining forces, they're "better able to pay their bills," as Samuel Ehrenhalt of the Bureau of Labor Statistics put it, "it will be better for everyone." For shoppers, that remains to be seen. 

Odd Network Out
Let's see if we've got this soap-opera plot straight. After QVC got a richer offer from Comcast, CBS and QVC decided not to go off into the sunset together -- and QVC looked about for even higher offers. Then CBS, suddenly nervous that shareholders would forsake it in its hour of need, said it would buy back 3.5 million of its shares and split its stock 5-for-1. CBS quickly vowed to go in "new directions," but the cold fact is that CBS is again out of a lot of loops -- no cable interests, no merger partners, in an age of cable and mergers. And no Barry Diller. But will Disney, rumored to have an interest in CBS, star in the next episode?
 
Just What Kennedy Needs
Kennedy Airport is constantly under construction, constantly jammed. What it needs, of course, is more construction, a new terminal, more crowds. Sure enough, last week four foreign airlines -- Air France, Lufthansa, Japan Air Lines and Korean Air Lines -- said they'd build a terminal on the old Eastern site. It'll be the first totally new terminal since 1971. Demolition will last well into 1995, enhancing the perpetual in-the-works aura, with the new terminal to open in 1998. The foreign carriers will take financing responsibility. But will they get you a cab?
 
United Workers, Owners at Last
Employees bought United Airlines last week, and you'd be excused for thinking that has an awfully familiar ring to it. Employees have been about to buy, unable to buy, dying to buy United seemingly since the dawn of air travel. After seven years of false starts and failed deals, workers have taken over, swapping $4.9 billion in wage cuts and work-rule changes for 55 percent of the company, making United one of the nation's biggest employee-controlled companies. Will it have imitators? Probably. It's a sure way to cut costs without starting over. But will workers look out for themselves before the company? That worries some observers. "Somebody's crazy." said Lee Iacocca. "It can't work."
 
Surgical Costs: Pass the Scalpel
Anyone who's been in a hospital -- or a doctor's or dentist's office -- has seen it. An array of costly doodads are trotted out, sterilized and shrouded in plastic; then, with many unused, they're discarded or sent back to be sterilized anew. Such excess, though, has no place in health care's tightfisted future, and last week that future inched a scalpel's width closer. Baxter, the big hospital supplier, made a deal with Duke University Medical Center in which Baxter and Duke both have an incentive to cut surgical-supply costs. Baxter gets Duke's business for five years, and Duke probably saves money -- though doctors will have a bit less equipment available. "If we do this right," said Dr. Mark Rogers of Duke, "we believe it will be a national model."
 
Eli Lilly Grabs the Reins
What this world needs is more Prozac. A cheerier populace would rally around health reform, and everyone could go on Prozac. Sure enough, a deal cut last week "will help sell even more Prozac," said Randall Tobias, head of Eli Lilly. Lilly, you see, makes Prozac, and in this deal, Lilly will buy PCS, one of a new corporate breed. PCS buys vast quantities of drugs -- at a discount, of course -- on behalf of health plans, and drug companies want to wrest control of their market back from these middlepeople. It's the if-you-can't-lick-'em-buy-'em approach, the very one used by Merck when it bought Medco last year.
 
Please Fasten Your Collars
Airlines battle tirelessly to keep their planes on the move, whittling the time to whisk weary passengers out, fresh passengers in, to check the oil and kick the landing gear. But the oddest things can wreak riotous havoc with this precision, as Tower Air discovered last week. En route from New York to Los Angeles, a cat fled her cargo carrier and vanished into the innards of the Boeing 747. At first Tower kept the plane hopping, searching only on pit stops. But finally the cat's dogged owner, lawsuit in hand, brought the jet to a halt at Kennedy Airport until the cat was found -- which she was, after nine hours. What price cat freedom? Please don't ask.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
For Sale: An 80's Mistake
They'd make distinctive mega-stores -- worthy, even, of Macy's-Federated. Just add escalators and some smiling attack troops brandishing perfume, and you'd be in business. What are these prize sites? Half-finished nuclear reactors, of course. The Washington Public Power Supply System, which a decade ago defaulted on the bonds to finance two plants, can't afford to finish them, tear them down or even let them sit there, so it's trying to sell them. The price: $3.4 billion. (They'll take less.) One Congressman's idea: put up a plaque, call them a monument to stupidity. Another: burn plutonium from old nuclear weapons to generate electricity. But a cylindrical department store still sounds best.
 
The 'Best' Fund? Prove It
It's one thing for, say, a peanut butter to trumpet that it's the best. Your only risk: you buy it and say, Nah, it's not that great. But when you're told you're buying the "best" mutual fund, there's a bit more at stake. Of course, all funds would like to be the best -- and many have merged wish with fact, inventing "top" rankings in ads. But last week the S.E.C. clamped down, approving guidelines on the way rankings are used in ads and brochures. The rules require "prominent disclosure" of rankings, of the funds sharing the category, and the period in question. Now those proud claims may mean a bit more.
 
You Call That Inflation?
Maybe all the inflation talk is just part of the nostalgia craze. We haven't had real inflation for so long that some people, in the guise of solemn concern, are really hungering for it, to liven things up. Will they get it? A mixed message last week. First, producer prices came in flat, a sign that no inflation's in sight. But then came an 0.3 percent rise in consumer prices (helped by a hefty 0.6 percent rise in new-vehicle prices). That adds up to just a 2.5 percent quarterly pace, but some analysts still see inflation heading upward -- and expect the Federal Reserve to raise rates again soon. But they sure don't make inflation the way they did in the old days of the early 80's.
 
And the Rich Get Schools
It's easy for a state to make its economy work: let local districts educate their own, paying for it through property taxes, and may the fittest survive. That's fine, unless your district is not among the fit. Some states have rethought the formula, with Kansas taking control of school money and Michigan turning to sales taxes. And last week New Jersey edged toward state control as its Supreme Court ruled the existing system unconstitutional, because of a lingering rich-poor gap. The property-tax approach clearly doesn't work in Newark: the state pays 74 percent of the school bill.
 
World Cup Debris, at a Price
You'd think they were buying the Pope's toothbrush, or Elvis's Brylcream-stained pillow. People eagerly paid $20 last week for a square foot of Bermuda grass that had been torn up from a well-trampled New Jersey field. Why? Well, the field was the Meadowlands, site of some serious recent soccer games, and as one proud buyer put it, "Right here on this turf Baggio walked and scored and even spit" -- Roberto Baggio of Italy being the hero of the moment. It was all part of World Cup II: The Local Take. Officials said the games pumped $500 million into the regional economy, including $200 million for New York City. Give or take some old sod.

HEADLINE: Europe Inc. Has a Novel Idea: Cut Costs

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: AUGSBURG, Germany

 BODY:
SIGNS of change abound at Siemens Nixdorf's personal computer factory here.
The German technology company slashed the number of production workers to 1,000 from 1,300 earlier this year even as it added a third shift. Pay is being tied for the first time to meeting quality and volume goals. Engineers, who once focused on designing the most sophisticated possible product, now concentrate on making the assembly process more efficient. 
 For anyone at the plant who missed the message that Siemens Nixdorf is getting serious about cutting costs, improving productivity and abandoning the traditional German way of doing things as it struggles against rabid worldwide competition, there is also this: The employee cafeteria no longer serves beer.
"We have had to re-engineer more or less the whole company," said Hans-Dieter Wiedig, the chief executive of Siemens Nixdorf, which has been suffering heavy losses but hopes to break even next year. "In this kind of competitive environment, the only constant is change."
The words may be familiar, even hackneyed, to executives in most industries in the United States, who came to the same realization years ago and have been acting on it ever since.
But belated though it may be, what is happening here, some 50 miles northwest of Munich, is happening, with various degrees of urgency, throughout Western Europe at companies in nearly every industry.
Having seen its share of world markets eroding for years, European business is at last seeking to remake itself, conscious that it is in danger of being left hopelessly behind more efficient American and Asian competitors in the cutthroat worldwide race for sales, profits and survival.
 
Long List of Problems
 Whether Western European companies are moving fast enough and aggressively enough to catch up remains to be seen. But at the very least, corporate executives -- and to a lesser extent workers and political leaders -- are facing up to a list of problems that has grown long and familiar.
Employment levels remain bloated at many companies. Labor costs in Germany are the world's highest (an hourly average of $25.56 last year, including benefits), and are high in most other European nations as well. The cost of providing universal medical care, generous pensions and long vacations has become prohibitive. Energy, raw materials, even a phone call -- all are more expensive in Europe than in the United States or Japan.
Strong unions limit the kind of slash-and-burn cost-cutting that is common in the United States -- especially with unemployment already near or above 10 percent in most European countries. The high cost of hiring and firing workers discourages companies from doing either.
The ongoing transformation of Europe into a single market, which offered the promise of economies of scale, has not lived up to the expectations of most companies, which complain that trade remains inhibited by continuing legal, regulatory, tax and cultural differences among nations.
And there has been only tentative progress in addressing the issues on the national level. Spain, for example, recently made it easier for companies to hire part-time or temporary workers. And other European governments are spending more time studying Britain, where the Conservative Government over the last 15 years has swept away rigid labor laws, weakened the unions, dropped most trade barriers -- and seen foreign investment and productivity surge.
On a company-by-company basis, however, continental Europe has unquestionably become the scene of frenetic efforts to become more competitive with the United States and Japan -- arguably the region's biggest industrial challenge since rebuilding after World War II.
"The restoration of long-term economic growth in Europe is certainly feasible," said Sir Michael Perry, the chairman of Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer products company. "But it is heavily dependent on improved industrial and business competitiveness."
In industries like computers where there are few trade barriers to true global competition, and in those like automobiles where traditional trade protection is disappearing, European companies are moving rapidly. Mercedes-Benz has cut $1.4 billion from annual operating costs in the last two years, and is expected to return to profitability this year as auto sales rebound.
But progress has been slower in industries ranging from steelmaking to banking, and the process of shrinking to a realistic size and cost structure is just getting under way in nationalized sectors such as telecommunications and airlines. Many companies remain reliant on subsidies from their governments -- subsidies that shelter them from the need to take drastic action.
For example, Alitalia, the Italian airline, won agreement from its unions last week to eliminate 1,570 of its 20,000 jobs over the next several years. But the unions forced the airline to back down from plans to cut 2,000 more jobs. Analysts say the state-owned company will still be unable to survive without huge Government subsidies.
Many European companies are breathing easier now that the recession is ending and sales and profits are turning up. In Germany, Europe's economic powerhouse, the deleterious economic effects of unification with East Germany are fading. High unemployment and low inflation have allowed many European companies to hold down wage increases. At the same time, however, many business leaders say economic recovery will not carry away deep-rooted structural problems and that the process of corporate renewal will have to continue unabated if Europe is to make a comeback.
 
Ongoing 'Cost Crisis'
 "The cost crisis has in no way been overcome," Klaus Murmann, the president of the German employers federation, said at a news conference last month.
Moreover, Western Europe is starting out with so much ground to make up against the United States and Japan that even big steps forward have left European industry far behind.
A survey last year by McKinsey & Company of nine large manufacturing industries in Germany, the United States and Japan found that Germany was the productivity leader in not a single one. (Japan led in five, including auto parts and steel, and the United States in four, including computers and beer.)
European productivity is clearly improving. A recent study by Deutsche Bank calculated that productivity, after rising only slightly from 1989 to 1993, will jump sharply this year and next as cost-cutting programs and investment in new technology pay off. Measured by cash flow (earnings before depreciation, interest and taxes) per employee, European productivity will be up by 36.9 percent at the end of 1995 compared with 1989, according to the bank.
In that same period, however, productivity in the United States will have risen by 56.6 percent, the bank said, reflecting the all-out effort by American companies to improve their competitiveness since the start of the last recession.
Japanese productivity will actually have fallen during the six-year period in cash flow terms, in part because the strength of the yen has made its products more costly abroad, hurting sales and profits. But Japan will remain the productivity leader in absolute terms (85,653 German marks worth of cash flow per employee in 1995, or $55,260 at current exchange rates), with the United States (82,082 marks, or $52,956) just behind and Europe (38,455 marks, or $24,809) trailing badly.
Other measures of competitiveness vary in how far behind Europe stands, or in how much ground it is making up. But the bottom line is that for years Europe has been losing business to international competitors. Western Europe's share of world export markets fell from 23.7 percent in 1972 to 18.3 percent in 1992, the most recent year for which figures are available, according to a study by the Confederation of British Industry.
Against such a background, companies like Siemens Nixdorf are being forced to re-examine their entire method of doing business. The experience at Siemens Nixdorf suggests how far many European companies are going in their effort to remain in the race, but also how difficult it is for them to compete globally.
The changes are apparent from top to bottom at the company. Mr. Wiedig, the chief executive, is moving to another post within the parent company, Siemens A. G., in October, after spending years reassessing and modifying nearly every aspect of the company's business practices.
Breaking with long tradition, the company will bring in an outsider to replace him -- Gerhard Schulmeyer from ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd., the Zurich-based engineering and power generation equipment company that is Europe's standard-setter for lean management and production.
Under Mr. Wiedig, Siemens Nixdorf has been extremely aggressive by German standards in slashing employment and operating costs. The product of a 1990 merger of Siemens's computer businesses and Nixdorf, an innovative but financially troubled German technology company, Siemens Nixdorf has reduced its workforce to 38,000, from 53,000, over the last four years.
Because of the high costs of layoffs, retirements and transfers under German law, the process of shedding those jobs cost the company more than one billion marks -- or more than $43,000 per job -- an expense that many companies without Siemens's sound financial base would have been reluctant to take on.
By virtue of being in the computer business, Siemens Nixdorf has had to be even more aggressive in improving efficiency than its parent, which retains a reputation for being one of Germany's flabbiest big companies. Within Siemens Nixdorf, no division is under more cost pressure than the personal computer business, based here in Augsburg.
The PC industry is one of the world's most unrelentingly competitive, with Compaq, the leader, driving prices down as much as 20 percent a year. Given that it has also been working out the kinks from its merger, Siemens Nixdorf has by many measures made impressive progress in its PC operations.
Take its effort to streamline assembly of keyboards. Several years ago, the keyboard required assembly of 150 parts. Now, through advances in chip technology and with more components pre-assembled, only four parts need to be put together. The keyboards snap together rather than require screws.
The old keyboard took 32 minutes to assemble at a cost of 120 marks, or about $77 at current exchange rates. The new one takes 2 and a half minutes to produce at one-fourth the cost.
The company has made heavy investments in technology on the production line. A new testing machine, for example, takes only 1 minute to examine a circuit board, versus 2 and a half minutes for an older model.
Total production time for a PC has been cut in half, to 30 minutes. The line is now running at or near capacity, operating 22 hours a day to produce 2,000 PC's.
 
Aiming High
 If it all sounds very much like what Compaq has done to become the PC industry cost leader, it is no accident. "Best in class is the target for us," said Walter Rossler, general manager of Siemens's PC business.
Mr. Rossler said he is 90 percent of the way to reaching his manufacturing cost targets. Management consultants have never been popular among German companies, but Mr. Rossler recently hired McKinsey to examine the PC operation's costs.
The study found the costs out of line with global competitors only in non-production areas -- so-called selling, general and administrative costs, which at Compaq are about 12 to 15 percent of sales compared with more than 20 percent at Siemens, Mr. Rossler said.
But the PC business is a bit of an anomaly, even within Siemens Nixdorf, and certainly within the parent company and German industry generally. Labor costs amount to only 2 to 3 percent of total costs in the PC business, compared with 30 percent across all of Siemens Nixdorf, which sells a broad range of computers, software and integration services.
As important as reducing the workforce, Mr. Wiedig said, is changing the attitudes of those who remain. Engineers, for example, have had to learn that they can no longer design every part or assume that the company will build everything for itself -- the German tradition -- because it is often cheaper in the computer business to purchase components from suppliers, often in lower-cost nations.
Production workers remain among the best paid within the industry worldwide -- labor costs average 28 marks, or $18, an hour -- but a portion of total compensation now comes in the form of bonuses for meeting quality and volume targets. Employees said they are not totally happy that the old ways are coming to an end, but that they are well aware that the company's future rests largely with their willingness to be more flexible -- a real cultural change in the heavily unionized workforce.
"Costs could be a problem," said Petra Findeisen, a worker who was loading software onto hard disks at the PC factory here. "We have to be creative and remember that quality is No. 1."
For the PC business, the changes have had a payoff, at least in the short run. The company increased its share of the European PC market to 3.5 percent in the first quarter of this year, up from 2.5 percent in the same period last year and leaving it fourth behind Compaq, I.B.M. and Apple. Its goal next year is a 5 percent share. In Germany it is No. 3, with a 10.2 percent share, behind Compaq and Vobis, a German retailer and clone maker.
But Siemens Nixdorf clearly has a long way to go if it is to be anything more than a marginal player in the computer business. Prices in PC's are expected to continue falling at 20 percent or more a year, putting intense pressure on the operation to continue cutting costs, a prospect that it might find more difficult than larger rivals that enjoy greater economies of scale.
"The problem quite simply is costs," said Andrew Haskins, an analyst at James Capel in London. "An enormous amount of work still has to be done."
 
 
 
HOW AMERICAN COMPANIES COPE, OR DON'T
 EDGAR S. WOOLARD JR., the chairman of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the American chemicals giant, recently asked a group of European executives and government officials in Brussels a provocative question: "Would the chief executive of a multinational company with $1 billion to invest choose to invest in Europe in the next decade?"
Mr. Woolard, whose company has 30 manufacturing sites and $13 billion in annual sales in Europe, gave a downbeat answer: "Our observation is that right now many large companies are directing their discretionary investment to other parts of the world."
For American companies like Du Pont and for other foreign corporations, Europe is as difficult an operating environment as it is for Europeans. And that fact is clearly costing Europe new foreign investments and the jobs that come with them.
"Consider one example -- the issue of improving efficiency in the workplace," Mr. Woolard said. "Instead of engaging in a dialogue about institutional barriers to streamlining the production process, we have witnessed in Europe a long, unresolved debate about procedural mechanisms for consultation with workers. Meanwhile in other regions, new work systems are being experimented with, adopted and transformed to make companies more aggressive, customer-oriented and productive."
Western Europe suffers from many other problems, Mr. Woolard said. Besides high operating and labor costs, he said, there is evidence that it lags in developing new products in terms of speed and quality.
Certainly Europe can be troublesome for multinational companies trying to slim themselves down. When the Gillette Company announced plans in March to close a razor blade plant near Seville, Spain, and lay off 250 workers, the plant manager was threatened, presumably by disgruntled employees, and had to hire bodyguards. The regional government threatened a legal challenge. Nearly four months later, Gillette is still trying to reach a deal the way Spanish law says it must: through a negotiated settlement with the plant's unions.
Some American and Japanese manufacturers have found a happy home in Europe -- but more often than not in Britain. Attracted by the country's relatively low level of labor regulation, social welfare costs and union strength, all the major Japanese car companies have established their primary European production plants in Britain. And American computer companies, including I.B.M. and Compaq, have some of their most efficient plants in Scotland.

HEADLINE: The 'Moncton Miracle': Bilingual Phone Chat

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: MONCTON, New Brunswick

 BODY:
THE big blow to this community came in 1988 when the government-owned Canadian National Railways, closed its Moncton repair yard in a cost-cutting drive, idling 2,000 workers.
Many of the jobless spoke both English and French, like Louis Melanson, who was hired by the railroad after high school and labored at the Moncton yard for nine years, mostly behind his welder's blowtorch. 
 Today, Mr. Melanson is one of hundreds of bilingual workers who are transforming the former rail hub into the Omaha of Canada -- a telemarketing and customer-service telephone call-center capital.
Wearing the earphones that are the symbol of his new profession, the 34-year-old Mr. Melanson sits in an office cubicle in a big new building, around the corner from the Moncton railroad station.
He works for Purolator Courier of Canada, the nation's largest overnight courier service, which came to Moncton two years ago, attracted by the area's bilingual workers, a state-of-the-art phone system and lower wage rates than in the company's home province of Ontario. In addition, New Brunswick lifted its provincial sales tax on toll-free 800 numbers.
"We chose Moncton as one of the most cost-effective locations for telemarketing and corporate support offices in all of North America," says Fred Manske, Purolator's chief executive officer. (Canada's Purolator was once a subsidiary of the American company of the same name, but a group of investors bought the Canadian courier unit in 1987. American Purolator, a producer of oil filters, is no longer in the courier business.)
Mr. Melanson is among those hired to take calls about pickups and package-tracing from Quebec and other provinces seven days a week. He and his co-workers in neighboring cubicles field nearly 20,000 calls a day.
Others do data entry and billing operations. Altogether, Purolator accounts for 400 new Moncton jobs. It and other companies with similar operations have added nearly 2,000 jobs to the local economy, almost making up for those lost when the rail yard shut down in 1988.
Frank McKenna, New Brunswick's two-term premier is one of the policy architects of the economic rehabilitation that he likes to call the "Moncton Miracle." Bilingualism and the adaptation of new computer and communications technologies, he says, represent "our ticket on the uptown bus."
While repairing railcars, Mr. Melanson never realized his accentless English and French would be the key to a future job.
"It certainly has a lot of bearing now," he observes, adding with a grin. "No more heavy smoke and my hands stay clean."
His French is a carryover from the region's Acadian past. Nearly half the 106,000 people of Greater Moncton and many others in northern New Brunswick and Nova Scotia descend from the French farmers who settled here 200 to 300 years ago.
The Acadians' history, distinct from that of other French settlers in Quebec, was marked by a brutal deportation by the British between 1755 and 1763 -- recounted by Longfellow in his "Evangeline."
Yet because large numbers of English-speakers also settled in the two maritime provinces, New Brunswick and Nova Scotia, bilingualism is more widely practiced here than in Quebec, where a hard-line group of the population has long promoted not only French linguistic hegemony but physical separation from Canada as a French-speaking republic.
Eric M. Robichaud, president of the Greater Moncton Economic Commission, said the fading rail industry "forced us to realize we had a problem and then to recognize that the bilingualism of our work force that we had long taken for granted was a tool we could market."
To support the development effort, English- and French-speaking community colleges now even provide courses in telemarketing to eager bilingual students.
Moreover, Moncton has become the home of this nation's Telemarketing Industry Association (45 member companies ranging in size from one to 1,300 employees), whose mission is to promote Canadian call center operations as a "professional and leading edge industry."
Besides Purolator, the companies that have set up telemarketing or customer service operations here include Federal Express, the American courier service, Camco, a leading Canadian maker of household appliances, and Business-to-Business Telemarketing, which handles telemarketing for other companies on a contract basis. Last week, the Royal Bank of Canada, the nation's largest bank, announced that it plans to establish a big call center here.
New Brunswick isn't the only province trying to attract the new customer-service and telemarketing operations. Manitoba and Nova Scotia, also with French-speaking minorities, are pressing their case as well.
They, too, have lifted the provincial sales tax on 1-800 numbers. Manitoba offers favorable lending terms for capital equipment and software development. Nova Scotia also offers a range of incentives, which may have helped turn back an effort of New Brunswick to snatch a Sears Canada, Inc. operation away from Halifax.
Yet nowhere is the pool of bilingual workers greater than New Brunswick, although in annual operating costs, the three provinces are roughly on a par.
Helped by the weakening Canadian dollar, they all do well in comparisons with the United States. A study by Boyd Company Inc., location consultants of Princeton, N.J., showed that at the end of last year, the annual operating costs of a call center in Greater Monckton were below those of 24 sites in the United States. The closest American rivals were Panama City, Fla., Salt Lake City and Omaha.
"For communities to be successful in economic development, they must sell their core competencies," says Jim Gilligan, Toronto-based location consultant who for PHH Fantus Inc. "Clearly, in Moncton the people realize bilingualism is an asset and are running hard with it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Louis Melanson, a former welder, is one of the 800-number corps in Moncton. (Elisavietta Ritchie for The New York Times)
