HEADLINE: Blurred Images of North Korea's 'Junior'

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
Depending on who is doing the talking, Kim Jong Il is a depraved movie fan who abuses women and alcohol; a terrorist who masterminded the 1983 bombing of the South Korean Cabinet and the 1987 midair bombing of a South Korean airliner; an awkward, misunderstood technocrat who longs to be a statesman, or all, some or none of the above.
The sharply divergent views underscore the scarcity of reliable information about the portly 52-year-old who has begun to emerge as North Korea's new leader, a man American intelligence officials still refer to as "junior" or "the kid." 
 President Clinton sounded as baffled as everyone else when he was asked about Mr. Kim last Monday, three days after the death of his father, Kim Il Sung, the world's longest-ruling dictator. "I don't know the younger Kim," Mr. Clinton said. "And I think you have to be careful in judging people by what others say about them one way or the other."
Kim-watchers spun themselves into an analytical frenzy overnight when the funeral of the father, set for Sunday, was suddenly postponed. But by this morning, officials in Seoul suggested that the succession was on track. [Page 10.]
Mr. Kim's prospects, character and personal habits would hardly matter if the stakes were not so high for both Asia and the world. For he appears to be taking over what the Clinton Administration says is a rogue regime that may already have one or two nuclear bombs.
Few outsiders have ever met him, and he has rarely traveled outside the country. Much of what is said to be known about him is suspect because it comes from defectors whose views have been filtered through South Korean intelligence. When foreign visitors ask to meet him, as former President Jimmy Carter did during his recent trip, they are told he is out among the people in the countryside.
Both American and South Korean intelligence officials are so in the dark about Mr. Kim that they are reduced to analyzing frames from North Korean television of such seemingly minor details as changes in his weight, his elevator shoes, his pompadour hairdo and a sometimes drooping lower lip.
The information void has sparked a ferocious debate within the Administration -- both between the State Department and the Central Intelligence Agency and within the C.I.A. itself -- over who he is, what his intentions are and whether he will be able to fill the vast political vacuum left by his father's death.
The more benign view, shared by the State Department and some analysts in the C.I.A., is that while Mr. Kim may be eccentric, he has run the day-to-day operations of the country for some time, is now clearly in charge and may emerge eventually as a responsible leader.
The other view, shared by much of the C.I.A. and the Pentagon establishment, is that Mr. Kim is a Stalinist killer like his father. But because, unlike his father, he is not a national hero and does not have the respect of officials of the older generation or much of the military, he will be unable to make concessions on his country's nuclear program and lacks the charisma and standing to survive politically.
The backbiting has become so intense that different bureaus and agencies have inundated policymakers with hundreds of pages of often-contradictory analyses. "The situation we've gotten ourselves into can only be described as nutty," a longtime Korea watcher said.
 
A Gracious Host Open to the U.S.
 A few close-up, if isolated, snapshots of Mr. Kim exist.
An Italian businessman, Carlo Baeli, describes Mr. Kim as a gentle soul, solicitous of his guests, curious about business and politics, and eager to have good relations with the United States.
"The thing that struck me most about him was his simplicity," Mr. Baeli said of a five-hour encounter on the Korean's yacht in September 1992. "He was very simple in how he met me, simple through the meal we had, simple when he said goodbye. He's very versatile and has a good sense of humor. Once the world meets the man, they'll realize that he's not the man described up to now."
Mr. Baeli, 61, the president of a Rome-based exporting company, Compagnia Internationale Scambi con l'Estero, has a $120 million contract to sell finishing machinery for marble and gold to North Korea. He may not be the most objective witness, but he is one of the only ones.
Dining on fish antipasto and grilled shrimp, drinking Hennessy brandy and French wine aboard the yacht, the two men toasted their friendship and mused about the world as military and political aides stood by, Mr. Baeli said.
"He asked first about the Italian economy, how things were going in Italy," Mr. Baeli said this week in a telephone interview from Rome. "Since we also have a Moscow office, he asked of my impressions of Russia. His sentiments toward the United States seemed to be very good. He wanted to have direct ties to the United States and not ties through other countries.
"He said they, the North Koreans, were ready and open to collaborate with the United States, and that they were already collaborating on research into Americans who died during the Korean War. He said: 'We are men and sooner or later we should come to an understanding. There is no reason for us to be enemies of the United States.' "
At one point, Mr. Kim was concerned that his guest might be tired, so he asked an aide to bring them fishing rods and they fished off the side of the yacht. As the afternoon wore on, Mr. Baeli said, "We spoke of work, politics, music, theater.
"We spoke mainly of the shows put on in North Korea where up to 5,000 characters are on stage. Apparently Kim is the inspiration of these shows."
 
Self-Consciousness And Boyish Bravado
 Choe Eun Hee, a well-known South Korean actress, and her husband, Shin Sang Ok, a filmmaker, have a different view. The two, who say they were kidnapped and taken to North Korea on Mr. Kim's orders in 1978, describe Mr. Kim as a late-night partygoer who drank hard and terrified those around him.
Ms. Choe and Mr. Shin, who escaped into the care of the C.I.A. eight years after they arrived in the North, later wrote a book about Mr. Kim, which has been published in Korean and Japanese.
The C.I.A., which financially supported and physically protected the couple for three years after their defection, finds their tale believable; other Korean analysts inside and outside the Administration are skeptical. Both Mr. Shin and Ms. Choe were traveling and unavailable for comment, according to an assistant in their Los Angeles office.
In the book, "The True Story of Kim Jong Il," Mr. Kim is portrayed as a complicated, spoiled man obsessed with building up North Korea's film industry with their help, accustomed to getting his way and self-conscious about his height. "Well, Madame Choe, what do you think of my physique?" Mr. Kim asked Ms. Choe when they first met. "Small as a midget's dropping, aren't I?"
He terrified her by serving a special wine with a live snake inside the bottle, drove a motorboat at breakneck speed, enjoyed grown-up toys like a battery-operated car, summoned her to parties in the middle of the night, once ordered the circus to perform for them after midnight and surrounded himself with sycophants who leapt to their feet to act on his whims, she wrote.
Once, she told him he should play golf to get some exercise. "All right," he laughed. "I'll make some golf courses and from now on I'll play golf."
Mr. Shin related an incident in which a drunken Mr. Kim seemed disdainful of the personality cult around him. As a musical band of young women jumped and shouted "Long live the dear Comrade Leader," Mr. Kim said, "Mr. Shin, all that is bogus. It's all just pretense."
 
Imperial Upbringing In a Communist Era

This much is known about Mr. Kim. He was born on Feb. 16, 1942, in Siberia, although the official North Korean version is that he was born amid bright lights and double rainbows at the top of Mount Paektu, a sacred peak on the Korean border with China. His mother died when he was 7, and he was evacuated to Manchuria during the Korean War before being sent to a school for the children of the elite in Pyongyang.
After graduating with a degree in political economy from Kim Il Sung University, Mr. Kim worked in the headquarters of the Korean Workers Party, where he became a powerful figure.
In a move more imperial than Communist, Kim Il Sung began to groom his son as his successor in the early 1970's. The younger Kim moved to solidify his power base in 1972, when he created the "three main revolutionary squads" to instill loyalty among young college graduates.
Mr. Kim officially became his father's successor in 1980 and was given the title of Marshal of the Armed Forces in April 1992. He is married, with either two or four children.
He is believed to have operational responsibility for the country's nuclear program and is credited with masterminding the North's experiment with a free trade zone in a remote area near the Chinese and Russian borders. But in a speech disseminated in his name in January 1992, he called on North Korea's leaders to learn lessons from the failure of the Soviet system, calling the revival of capitalism "only a local and passing phenomenon."
Since the death of his father, the official media have referred to him as "the Great Successor," although he has not been formally been given his father's titles of head of the party, President or "Great Leader."
The death of the father has prompted analysts inside and outside the Administration to look anew at the son and the question of whether he can maintain his father's rigid control while somehow dealing with North Korea's worsening economic problems.
Robert M. Gates, the former Director of Central Intelligence, said of Mr. Kim, "He is not unstable or crazy, just weird."
"You've got to start from the premise that he grew up in the shadow of one of most brutal dictators in the post-war period," said Mr. Gates, "and there is nothing to suggest that his approach to power would be any different."
That view is still largely shared by analysts at the C.I.A. and the Defense Intelligence Agency, which in an unclassified report last December called Mr. Kim "paranoid, spoiled and suspicious." Although the report predicted that he would initially seize power, it added, "His limited personal ability, possible widespread opposition and the continuing poor economic and social conditions could lead to a coup."
But other analysts are convinced that Mr. Kim must be both judged as a man who has been waiting in the wings for too long and viewed with a fresh eye now that he is on stage. State Department officials who have met North Koreans for more than a year to discuss the country's nuclear program reported that after the father's death, their counterparts clearly acted as if the son were in charge and there would not be any surprises.
This view is shared by Mr. Baeli. "Few people know him and now the world will have to get to know him," he said. "If he becomes President, he will no longer simply speak, he has to act. And all your questions will have answers soon."

HEADLINE: TO THE MOON: 25 Years After Apollo;
25 Years Later, Moon Race in Eclipse

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

 BODY:
Two American astronauts landed and walked on the moon 25 years ago, taking the first human footsteps on another world. Bundled in oxygen cocoons, they hopped in low-gravity slow motion over the lifeless surface as in a dream that had to be seen in those grainy television images to be believed.
Their achievement was a spectacular American triumph in the cold war with the Soviet Union, culminating an eight-year, $25 billion mobilization of technology and talent, bringing together multitudes of scientists, engineers and technicians. 
 But the wonder now evoked by the lunar landing is that the United States so recently had the optimism to conceive such a grand undertaking and the will to see it through in a blink of history's eye -- and then so readily abandoned the enterprise. Perhaps that is why an air of melancholy, a dispiriting sense of unfulfilled promise, hangs over the Apollo 11 anniversary, and why even the space agency is doing little to celebrate its greatest moment.
Anniversaries speak in echoes of what was and what might have been.
Echoes in this case of the heavy thunder of the Saturn 5 rocket, which shook the Florida ground for miles around and lifted Neil A. Armstrong, Col. Buzz Aldrin and Col. Michael Collins on their way on July 16, 1969. Echoes of the heart-stopping lunar landing by Mr. Armstrong and Colonel Aldrin, with mere seconds of fuel remaining, on July 20. And echoes of the crackling radio link when Mr. Armstrong first stepped on the gray powdery surface of the Sea of Tranquillity and solemnly proclaimed, "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind."
In the euphoria of the moment, when the age-old symbol of the unattainable had been reached, people allowed themselves to ascribe transcendental significance to the historic event. This was sure to be the true opening of far-ranging human space travel. The species was no longer confined to its native planet. A few observers compared the achievement with the emergence of vertebrates from primordial waters, establishing life on land. In centuries to come, some historians predicted, the 20th century might be remembered for little else.
In sobering retrospect, no one can be so sure of the lasting meaning of the first lunar landing. The moon is only three days away, 240,000 miles, but no astronauts have made the journey in 22 years. It may be decades, or even longer, before anyone establishes lunar bases or sets out for Mars.
 
'A Few Tentative Steps'
 The Apollo experience reminds Dr. Carl Sagan, the Cornell University astronomer and author, of "a toddler who takes a few tentative steps outward and then, breathless, retreats to the safety of his mother's skirts."
This turn of events is frustrating to space scientists and engineers, especially those from the glory days of Apollo. Back when they could not reliably get a rocket off the ground, they were pressed by a fearful nation to spare no expense and beat the Soviet Union. Now that they have greater expertise and more elaborate technologies, they find themselves with little political or popular support. No one is asking them for the moon.
Historians, political scientists and other observers of the space endeavor offer explanations. As successful as Apollo was in meeting its immediate objective, the lunar landing, the project's limitations as a template for future space exploration became readily apparent. It was hugely expensive. It required unstinting effort and a commitment not easily sustained once the goal was achieved.
"It was a crash program, and countries can afford that only once in a while," said Dr. Alex Roland, a history professor at Duke University and former historian of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. "Apollo was a one-time event, not a pattern for some steady-state operation."
Dr. John M. Logsdon, director of the Space Policy Institute at George Washington University, said: "Apollo was a warlike mobilization undertaken in conditions of perceived crisis. We had a clear enemy, high confidence that it was technologically achievable and didn't have to modify human behavior. But once the crisis went away, space exploration on such a scale was not sustainable."
 
Driven by the Cold War
 Indeed, historians say, Apollo was the product of special circumstances not likely to recur any time soon, if ever. It was a bold American response in 1961 to ominous Soviet military and space challenges of the cold war. It was undertaken in the continuing flush of postwar prosperity, when American economic power was still undisputed. American self-confidence and a sense of destiny had yet to be shaken by assassinations, urban riots, rampant crime, the divisive Vietnam War and the paralyzing burden of debt.
President John F. Kennedy made the decision in May 1961. Ever since the Russians had launched the first spacecraft, Sputnik 1, in October 1957, Americans had been uneasy about Soviet power -- a launching vehicle can also be an intercontinental missile -- and concerned about their country's technological and military capabilities. More Soviet "space firsts" followed, including the flight of Yuri Gagarin, the first man to orbit Earth, on April 12, 1961. A few days later, Kennedy and the American people were further unsettled by the botched Bay of Pigs invasion, an effort to wrest Cuba from Fidel Castro.
That was when Kennedy asked Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson to consult with experts and high-ranking officials to determine if there was any space program that "promises dramatic results in which we could win."
For several years, the space agency had been developing plans for Earth-orbiting laboratories and trips to the moon. Dr. Wernher von Braun, the rocket scientist, wrote to Vice President Johnson: "We have a sporting chance of sending a three-man crew around the moon ahead of the Soviets." He added that the United States had "an excellent chance of beating the Soviets to the first landing of a crew on the moon (including return capability, of course)."
In a famous address to Congress on May 25, President Kennedy declared, "I believe that this nation should commit itself to achieving the goal, before this decade is out, of landing a man on the moon and returning him safely to Earth."
The project had its critics, who thought the money could be better spent on domestic needs or complained of its marginal scientific and military benefits. But Apollo was about politics and the cold war. It was to be a demonstration of American power and resolve. More than that, it was an expression of faith that people could still go forth and claim the future.
 
Steady Goals, but Changing Times
 By the time Apollo 11 landed, however, the spirit of 1961 was unrecognizable. The country had changed in eight years, drained of self-confidence in the Vietnam jungles and burning city streets. Six more missions followed Apollo 11, and five of them landed on the moon. The last of the 12 men to walk on the moon were the Apollo 17 astronauts, in December 1972. Three subsequent missions were canceled.
Looking beyond Apollo soon after the first lunar landing, a White House panel endorsed much of NASA's wish list when it proposed an ambitious program of bases on the moon, space stations circling it and even larger Earth-orbiting laboratories capable of supporting 50 to 100 people. The ringing encore would be a human expedition to Mars in the 1980's, at the earliest, or no later than the end of this century.
"That was NASA at its worst," said John E. Pike, a space policy analyst for the Federation of American Scientists in Washington. "It was all 'how' and no 'why.' "
But to most people, Apollo 11 had been an ending, not a beginning; the moon race was over, and there would be no more blank checks for space. All the proposals were quietly shelved, except for one to develop a reusable spacecraft, which President Richard M. Nixon approved in early 1972. But the space shuttles eventually developed were not fully reusable and have never lived up to extravagant forecasts that they would be flying 40 or 50 missions a year by the 1990's, instead of the current rate of seven or eight.
"People always talk about the 'Kennedy effect,' " said Dr. Walter A. McDougall, a University of Pennsylvania historian and author of the acclaimed political history of the space age, "The Heavens and the Earth" (Basic Books, 1986)."But once the moon race was won, people lost interest, and even a Kennedy probably could not have maintained a brighter post-Apollo program. Perhaps it's not unreasonable that the human race, once it had first mastered the art of rocket flight, would engage in a great burst of exploration, followed by a long pause to regroup and rethink the economics of space and then proceed in a more pragmatic fashion."
 
NASA Lowers Its Sights
 In any event, lower budgets, a lack of clearly defined goals and dwindling political support left the space agency adrift. Although President Ronald Reagan finally gave his approval in 1984, the space station program has taken two years more than it took to put the first Apollo on the moon, and the station is still not off the ground.
On the 20th anniversary of Apollo 11, President George Bush pledged that Mars would be the country's new space goal, with humans landing there by the year 2019, the golden anniversary of the first lunar landing. Nothing more was heard of this because Congress refused to finance it.
It is little wonder that sadness and a sense of betrayal creep into the recollections of Apollo participants. Dr. Robert C. Seamans Jr., NASA's deputy administrator during some of the Apollo years, recalled conversations he had with James E. Webb, the politically skilled leader of NASA in the 1960's, not long before Mr. Webb's death in 1992.
"We thought we were laying a foundation for future space exploration," Dr. Seamans said. "We thought after Apollo we wouldn't need to go back to the drawing board for whole new sets of vehicles. But that's what happened when they disbanded the whole Saturn-Apollo operation and hardware and chose to start all over again with the shuttle."
Mr. Pike of the Federation of American Scientists said, "The problem over the last 25 years was that we were not able to develop a compelling geopolitical rationale for any space program since Apollo that lasted long enough to get anything done."
 
New Role for Space Station
 A major civilian space program has now been identified with an important foreign policy objective, Mr. Pike noted, and the paradox is that this time it involves cooperation with the Russians, not confrontation. President Clinton won substantial support for the space station this year by bringing in the Russians, thus trying through cooperation in space to help insure the success of Russian democracy.
Dr. McDougall counseled patience. After all, he noted, it was 50 years after Magellan made the first crossing of the Pacific before the Spanish finally managed to go back in 1571 and establish a permanent base on the other side, at Manila. If the costs of rocket technology are substantially reduced, Dr. McDougall said, there could be a new rush to go to space, although the leader might not be the United States, but Japan.
Daniel S. Goldin, the current NASA Administrator, acknowledged that he had discouraged official Apollo retrospectives. "We can spend so much time reviewing history that we're not writing any more history," he said.
Another anniversary echo from the time of the lunar landing brings back the oft-repeated question, "If we can send men to the moon, why can't we . . ." cure cancer, rebuild the cities, or whatever. At first, the question was asked in earnest, an expression of impatience and hope. Now, if it is asked at all, the tone is one of despair and self-reproach. Apollo may have been a success, Dr. Logsdon of George Washington University said, but not as a model for attacking other concerns, not unless the goal can be as clearly defined, as amenable to a straightforward technological solution and as strongly supported.
In years to come, people may look back on Apollo as a historical anomaly -- a small step -- or as the inspired beginning of space travel and human life on other worlds -- truly a giant leap for mankind. Those who experienced the thrill of that beginning will never know the ultimate outcome.
 
Mystery of Absent 'A'
 Everyone expected Neil A. Armstrong to say something memorable at the moment of his first footstep on the moon, and he obliged. But something about the one small step/one giant leap quotation seemed to be missing.
The words heard and recorded at Mission Control in Houston were, "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind." But Mr. Armstrong said after the flight that he had intended to say, "small step for a man." The space agency left the impression that the missing article had been lost because of the radio static.
In an interview in 1971, the journalist Robert Sherrod asked Mr. Armstrong if the "a" had been lost in transmission or simply forgotten.
"We'll never know," the Apollo 11 commander replied, leaving one more enigma lingering about this very private astronaut.
 
Faded Spirit of Apollo
 Will there ever be another Apollo? In a catalog for a Library of Congress exhibit a decade after the first landing, the answer given is: probably not.
"We have changed as a people," the catalog noted in 1979. "No longer possessing the headiness and naivete of past times, we are spared the disappointments of risky ventures. Yet we also forgo the exuberance and elation of bold attempts. While still a vital people, we have been thrown off balance by a series of foreign and domestic disasters and disappointments, which, in the short run, have made us somewhat wary."
It added, "The face we present to the world appears indecisive."

HEADLINE: Despite Talk of Invasion, Haiti's Terror Continues

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 16

 BODY:
The United Nations observers had presented themselves at the airport in compliance with an expulsion order, but Haiti's military could not resist inflicting a few humiliations.
Before the group boarded the plane this week, soldiers acting as functionaries poked through their belongings and contemptuously questioned the validity of some of their passports. 
"The soldiers at the airport were acting as arrogant and cocky as I have ever seen them," said a diplomat who witnessed the departure of the 92-member mission, which had been monitoring human rights abuses here for more than a year. "They were looking very sure of themselves."
 
Facade of Fearlessness
 Haiti's military leaders may just be putting up a brave front for the rest of the world, but they continue to act as if they have no fear of a United States invasion. The order to expel the combined observer mission of the United Nations and the Organization of American States came hours after four American amphibious assault ships carrying 2,000 marines arrived in Haitian waters.
Immediately after the rights observers were expelled, a dozen men whose identities remain unknown were killed and secretly buried in a small town just west of here. Government officials describe the victims as car thieves who had been caught stripping United Nations vehicles and were killed in a gun battle with soldiers and police, but the American Embassy isn't buying the story.
"The motive was clearly political," an embassy spokesman, Stanley Schrager, said Friday. The embassy investigated the killings in the absence of the rights observers and concluded, he said, that the dead men had been "murdered by, or on behalf of Government security elements."
The leader of the armed forces, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, hardly has the air of a man who is cornered and is seeking a way out of his problems. Since the United Nations force was ordered to leave, he has become more visible and more expansive.
 
Conditions for Any Departure
 In two rare interviews with the foreign press this week, he said he planned to step down as commander-in-chief of the Haitian armed forces when his three-year term expires on Jan. 31, 1995, and would be willing to leave earlier only if other nations recognized Haiti's army-installed president, Emile Jonassaint.
"I think they still believe the United States is not going to invade, that it's all a bluff," a Haitian businessman with military ties said.
Backers of the military point to a statement by Senators Bob Dole and Sam Nunn and by others in Congress that Haiti is not of vital interest to the United States. "There are divisions in the military here, but there are also divisions in Washington," said the Haitian businessman, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Supporters of the military have also taken comfort in contradictory pronouncements by Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, and in his clashes with his backers in Washington.
The deposed President has the habit of "spitting in the rice," a Government official said, using a Haitian expression that describes an action intended to deliberately spoil a relationship, and has alienated many of his American sponsors.
Haiti's Information Ministry declined to comment today on a speech by Father Aristide that was broadcast to Haitians on Friday night via a new radio station set up for him by the United States.
Radio reception of the speech was weak in many sections of Port-au-Prince, making it hard for supporters in poor districts to hear the exiled President's message. Still, Gerard Joseph, an unemployed handyman, said he liked what he heard, "especially the promise to build schools and create jobs, because that is what we really need."
There are some signs that the economic sanctions against Haiti, including a freeze on Haitian assets imposed recently by the United States, are beginning to have an impact.
Employees at some Government ministries have complained that their paychecks are arriving late or, in some instances, not at all. In an action intended to enable the Government to meet those and other financial obligations, the Haitian Senate approved a proposal this week to eliminate a ceiling on the amount of money in circulation.
 
Bracing for Inflation
 An opposition member of the National Assembly called the measure, whose legality has been questioned but which was eagerly and immediately welcomed by Government officials, a "design by the coup makers to squander the coffers of the state before they pack their bags." But the main consequence of the flood of crisp new bills that are expected to begin appearing any day now will be to accelerate inflation.
With foreign trade blocked because of the United Nations embargo and large areas of domestic commerce crippled or driven underground, Mr. Jonassaint's de facto administration indeed has fewer and fewer sources of revenue. Desperate for hard currency, the Government has taken to charging the few foreigners arriving here $50 apiece to enter the country.
The military and its civilian allies are responding to the mounting economic pressure by invoking Haitian nationalism, always a potent force. A rally called on Thursday to protest the embargo was held under a statue of Henri Christophe, the President and king who committed suicide in 1820 after he lost control of his army.
The streets of the capital are festooned with banners proclaiming "Occupation, Invasion, Death: No!" or simply "No!" During broadcasts of World Cup soccer matches, slogans like "Haiti is small but won't be trampled!" or "No to occupation!" appeared on the screen.
Whether such appeals are finding their mark is an open question. Barely 1,000 people turned out for the Government-endorsed protest against the embargo, and many of them seemed more interested in the free T-shirts, food and rum drinks being distributed by organizers than in the speeches lambasting the United States and its allies.

(Andrew Lichtenstein/JB Pictures, for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Amid Uncertainty, Exploring Options for the Coliseum

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Over the nine years of Mortimer B. Zuckerman's effort to develop the site of the New York Coliseum, prospective tenants and partners came and went, plans were drawn and revised, the site itself was scaled back and the developer's down payment was reduced. One constant, at least in recent months, was acrimony.
Yesterday was no different. On the morning after the transaction unraveled, all sides were still insisting that their honest intent was to see a project go forward while charging one other with negotiating in bad faith. 
 "We were outraged at the actions of the M.T.A., which have prevented us from going forward," a statement by Mr. Zuckerman began.
Peter E. Stangl, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said any implication that the agency had tried to spoil the deal was "garbage."
The deal involved ambitious plans for one of New York's prime sites, at Columbus Circle, yet in the end the parties were quibbling over issues as mundane as parking spaces.
 
City Has Down Payment
 For the transportation authority, which owns the site, the collapse of the negotiations with Mr. Zuckerman offers a chance to start anew on a development plan.
The city, which sought the project for the jobs it was expected to produce, instead has Mr. Zuckerman's $17 million nonrefundable down payment, which will eventually be transferred to the M.T.A.'s capital budget for transit system improvements. And thanks to an agreement made by former Mayor David N. Dinkins in the final days of his administration, the city will have a equal say with the M.T.A. in any future development project at the Coliseum.
As for Mr. Zuckerman and his partner, Edward H. Linde, they are contemplating a lawsuit to recover either their money or their right to build at the Coliseum. But Mr. Linde did not completely rule out the possibility that if the Coliseum site were put on the market again, he and Mr. Zuckerman would be among the bidders.
The $17 million that Mr. Zuckerman has forfeited is only half what he stood to lose six weeks ago, when the terms were most recently revised and the project seemingly put back on track.
Until June, Mr. Zuckerman was under a 1989 contract with the M.T.A. to pay $338 million to develop the entire 3.4 acre Coliseum property. He stood to lose $33.8 million in a line of credit if he walked away from that deal.
 
Price Was Talked Down
 For months Mr. Zuckerman tried to negotiate a lower price, arguing that the decline in the real-estate market made developing the entire site in a single project too risky. In June the M.T.A. agreed to split the site in half and reduced its price to $100 million. With an agreement specified in a letter of intent, the parties tried to write a new contract.
There was one aspect of the failed negotiations on which all parties could agree: When the talks broke down hours before a Friday midnight deadline for a signing of the contract, several crucial issues remained unresolved.
"This was a very complex deal," said Robert Bergen, counsel for the transportation authority, "but it could have been done. But in the end we were not close."
 
Final Deal-Crusher
 Still unresolved were matters large and small, Mr. Bergen and others said. They included the division of the property; conditions for the separation of the Coliseum exhibition hall, which was to be demolished, from an office building, which was to remain in use; the number of parking spaces that could be created in the garage that the developer and the M.T.A. were to share, and who would be responsible for seeking the necessary approvals for additional spaces.
Another issue, which may have been the final deal-crusher, involved the personal liability of Mr. Zuckerman and Mr. Linde.
"We expected a guarantee of their responsibility for certain risks that we felt were well within the boundaries of the letter of intent," said Mr. Bergen.
For example, Mr. Bergen asked, who would be responsible if during demolition work a system in the office building, like air conditioning, failed? Who would pay the cost of relocating tenants?
"It would not be responsible as a public entity for us to take that risk," said Mr. Bergen. "If the development company lacks adequate assets to cover those risks, then the partners should assume the risk."
 
Personal Guarantees
 In the developer's view, such assurances sought by the M.T.A. were not consistent with the agreement.
"After paying $17 million in cash," said Mr. Linde, "we were being asked to pay an additional $63 million for the site and put up personal guarantees or letters of credit that would amount to more than $100 million. Anyone in the business world would tell you that those demands were overreaching the letter of intent."
Yesterday Mr. Stangl said the M.T.A. would join with the city to decide the best use for the Coliseum.
"The Coliseum is a very important site in terms of its location and potential," said Mr. Stangl. "It is appropriate now for us to look at all of the options whether that is an interim use of some sort or another development project."
When asked if Mr. Zuckerman might be among those bidding on a new development plan, Mr. Linde, his partner, said that the site's potential still appealed to them.
 
Loss of Appetite for Deal
 "We still think the Coliseum property presents an extraordinary opportunity," said Mr. Linde. "I did not spend the last 10 years of my life beating my head against a brick wall for a project we don't want do do. We would love to be involved in the future of the Coliseum. But unless there is a dramatic change in the leadership or methods at the M.T.A., it is highly unlikely."
While John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, blamed the M.T.A. for the negotiations' failure, he seemed to have no appetite for trying to revive the deal.
Once a letter of intent was signed on June 2 outlining what was to be signed on Friday, he said, it should have been easy to translate the agreement into a contract.
"Normally it's an administrative thing to do," said Mr. Dyson.
 
Determining the Future
 Mr. Dyson said lawyers for the city did not think that the personal guarantees the the M.T.A. was seeking were necessary.
"It's preposterous to expect men like them to guarantee anything with their personal fortunes," he said.
Mr. Dyson said that while he was disappointed, he believed the city was now in a better position to determine the future of the Coliseum site.
"You are better off taking $17 million in hard cold cash right now," he said. "On our side of the calculation, we could have lost the suit," he added, referring to the lawsuit that Mr. Zuckerman filed last May charging that his previous contract to build on the Coliseum property was not valid.
 
'Trying to Keep It Alive'
 Mr. Stangl insisted that the transportation authority had done everything it could to conclude a deal.
"I don't know how many times we have renegotiated this deal," he said, "and it has always been because we were trying to keep it alive and to get the project done."
Mr. Stangl said that when the agency agreed in June to a plan for Mr. Zuckerman to buy only half the site, at a reduced price, it had showed its good intentions to the developer and to the city.

HEADLINE: State Senator, A Democrat, Is Nominated For Governor

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 16

 BODY:
The president of the Connecticut Senate, John M. Larson, easily won the Democratic nomination for Governor at the party's state convention today but now faces a primary challenge from state Comptroller William E. Curry Jr., who won 35 percent of the delegates' votes.
Mr. Larson, a Senator from East Hartford since 1983, who was strongly supported by the party's leadership, said his economic plan to put Connecticut residents back to work and his ability to raise campaign funds would carry the party to victory in November. He won 65 percent of the votes. 
 "Of course we'd like to see party unity," said Mr. Larson. "Obviously we'd like to avoid a primary. If there is one, I'm confident we'll prevail."
After his nomination, Mr. Larson and party leaders immediately turned to the choice of a nominee for lieutenant governor, hoping to form a strong enough ticket to dissuade Mr. Curry from pursuing a primary. But hours later, just as Mr. Larson was deciding on the mayor of Bridgeport, Joseph Ganim, as his running mate, Mr. Curry emerged from his headquarters and announced that the primary was on.
 
Can't Wait
 "I thought long and hard today about the interests and well-being of the Democratic Party," Mr. Curry told a cheering crowd. "But even more I thought long and hard about the interests and well-being of this state."
"Because our cities cannot wait four more years," he said, "because the economy of this state needs to be turned around now, and not four or eight years from now, because our communities are not safe, because our children's lives depend so much on our bravery, I've decided to ask all of you to take a risk."
The primary will be held Sept. 13
Soon after Mr. Curry's announcement, Mr. Ganim was nominated for lieutenant governor and was approved by a quick voice vote called by the convention chairman, state Rep. Thomas Ritter of Hartford. "No's" and boos competed with the "yeah's."
 
Looking for Comeback
 Up to that point, unity was the overriding theme of this convention, as Democrats, the state's dominant party for 40 years, looked forward to recapturing the Governor's office after losing it to Lowell P. Weicker Jr., an independent, in 1990. Governor Weicker is not running for re-election.
The party faces a strong challenge in November from the expected Republican nominee, John Rowland, a former Congressman who outpolled the Democrats four years ago. And Eunice S. Groark, Mr. Weicker's lieutenant governor, is running for Governor on the A Connecticut Party ticket, again making it a three-way race.
But Mr. Curry, 42, a member of the Democrats' progressive wing, had said from the beginning that his goal was to qualify for a primary, and little changed immediately today even after a third candidate, state Sen. Richard Balducci, withdrew and most of his delegates went to Mr. Larson.
Mr. Larson, 45, overwhelmingly captured the state's cities, where the party organization is strongest. But Mr. Curry received 510 votes, or 35 percent of the convention total, mostly from suburbs and small towns.
The Democrats nominated United States Sen. Joseph I. Lieberman for a second term by acclamation Friday night, assuring the ticket of one popular candidate.
 
Blumenthal Named
 Today, as negotiations were under way over the nomination for lieutenant governor -- more important perhaps to the party, to satisfy various ethnic and personal interests, than to voters -- a second popular Democrat, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal, was nominated for a second term.
The negotiations intensified this morning when Mr. Balducci withdrew just before the nominating speeches were to begin and called for party unity.
Courted by the other candidates to be their lieutenant governor, Mr. Balducci had come under heavy pressure from party leaders to accept that post as his support began eroding below the 15 percent of delegates needed to qualify for a primary.

He was flanked by his wife, Leslie, right, and his sister Mary Lou Onidi. (Photographs by Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE CAMPAIGN;
Using TV to Create Skewed Window on Nation

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
Seldom have so many frowned so earnestly. Day after day here, to the accompaniment of tolling bells and morose soap opera music, typical Americans drive along small-town streets, gather in kitchens, offices and hospitals, knit their brows and fret over what Congress is going to do about health care.
These television images could be in Akron, Miami or Duluth. But the commercials that contain them are not. 
 They are intended not to move national opinion, but to change what Congress thinks that opinion is. So most are being televised in Washington, although some are being aired in Congressional districts with swing votes or on CNN.
And each day there are more.
On Thursday, the Democratic National Committee released new advertisements, attacking Republican recalcitrance, scheduled to run in Washington but also in Wisconsin, Nebraska and Nevada, where the committee thinks Democratic Senators need to be pulled into the President's camp. But the effort backfired, prompting Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, to complain that the advertisement was excessively partisan on an issue that will need bipartisan support.
 
At a Fraction of the Cost
 On Friday, the Health Care Reform Project, a coalition of unions and other groups that would require employers to help pay for insurance, released an advertisement intended for the Washington market that contained its toughest message yet. It charged that Pizza Hut helped pay for workers' health benefits in Germany and Japan but is lobbying hard to block the same coverage for Americans. Blocked from television stations after Pizza Hut executives called the advertisement libelous, the group now plans to get the message out in advertisements in The Washington Post and The New York Times.
The tempest is almost exclusively confined to Washington. The Democratic Party's "advertising blitz" costs only $400,000, a fraction of what a national media campaign might, and is designed to swing the nation's capital, not the nation.
"Washington is absolutely freaked out about ads that most people don't even know are out there," said Drew E. Altman, the president of the Kaiser Family Foundation, a private philanthropy that has both studied the health care advertising and contributed to the outpouring with its own commercials. "The policy makers turn on their TV's and they say, America is seeing this!"
Probably not. Although special interest groups, political parties and the health care industry have already spent at least $25 million to buy television, radio and newspaper advertising, most purchases have actually been small, tightly focused and relatively cheap. The most effective among them, like the "Harry and Louise" advertisement produced by the Health Insurance Association of America, a trade group, make news by either provoking a response from the White House or, in the case of the Democrats' advertisements, taking such an outrageous tone that news organizations cannot resist reporting on them.
 
Advertisements in News
 The $12 million Harry and Louise campaign ran in more markets than most of the advertisements reach. But an analysis done by the Kaiser Foundation showed that more people knew of that relatively expensive campaign through news accounts than from seeing the advertisement itself.
When the Democratic National Committee released a sardonic spoof showing their own Harry and Louise lying in bed in body casts and complaining about being out of work and out of insurance, almost every major news organization reported the advertisement. The Democratic committee spent only $250,000 to air the spot, but the news coverage reached a nationwide audience.
This strategy is being pursued by both sides. The Republican National Committee last March began a $500,000 campaign in Washington and Congressional districts in Milwaukee, Minneapolis, Omaha, Providence, R.I., and elsewhere where it ran with a tag line naming local Congressmen and urging viewers to call them.
Haley Barbour, the Republican chairman, said he decided to run the advertisement after discovering that the public thought Republicans opposed change of any kind. "We did not intend to enter the debate with a multimillion-dollar media campaign," he said. "But we did not want people to be misled into thinking their choice was either Clinton's health care reform or doing nothing." The districts chosen to receive it each represented a critical vote either of a fence-straddling legislator or members of the subcommittees that were moving bills through the system.
 
Mild and Pointed Appeals
 The Republican advertisements, like many early ones, were relatively mild, though vaguely filled with threats. Other groups have made more pointed appeals. "We go to very elementary messages," said Brent N. Bahler, the director of communications for the Citizens for a Sound Economy, a conservative political group that opposes expanded government initiatives. "Television is not really equipped to advance the debate," he said. "And yet it is actually easier to advertise around an issue than around a candidate because the candidate's ego is not involved."
Mr. Bahler's group has focused on fears that a national health insurance plan would mean red tape, arbitrary assignment of doctors, tax increases, long lines and, ultimately, health care rationing.
Supporters of revamping the health care system have a broad array of messages, too. The National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League aired one advertisement that took on a wide variety of women's health concerns from contraception to breast cancer and, of course, abortion rights.
"The key for us was defining our message early on," said James Wagoner, the group's executive vice president. "We have wanted to be sure that women aren't discriminated against by some plan that takes away care women already receive." The group's advertisement ran during CNN's morning news shows.
 
Conflicting Messages
 Robert A. Chlopak, a public policy communications expert working for the Health Care Reform Project, a consortium of 47 organizations supporting national health insurance, said that group's $4 million advertising campaign has refined its message at each step of the debate.
As the debate nears the floor, the group has developed the Pizza Hut advertisement and constantly hit away at the theme that the men and women of Congress may have better health coverage than average Americans.
The result for general viewers is a welter of conflicting messages. Those non-politicians who do catch the advertisements, either on CNN or on their local television stations, are faced with a wild array of conflicting messages and only the barest whiff of actual information. "People are incredibly confused and frustrated and cynical about what is happening in health care reform," said Mr. Altman, of the Kaiser Foundation. "And because of that they are throwing their hands up in despair, having no idea what is the truth any more."
 
Perception vs. Fact
 Mr. Bahler, too, acknowledges a cumulative danger. "We all come at it with different interests and different messages," he said. "What we end up with is an attack on a dozen or more fronts, not just all coming up over one cliff. And that makes it particularly dangerous."
It also, of course, leaves the debate right back where it began -- in the hands of the politicians, the spin doctors and the special interest groups. But there is a twist. Instead of just working in the bubble of the capital, legislators now work in the bubble with the perception that they know what is going on outside it.
That perception was particularly strong when the Health Insurance Association of America ran its first "Harry and Louise" advertisements. "Everyone on the Hill was convinced that H.I.A.A. was this hugely powerful juggernaut that had its hand on the pulse of America," Mr. Altman said.
That frightened a lot of politicians. And that, of course, was brilliant strategy.


GRAPHIC: Though most people around the country see few of them, advertisements for and against national health insurance have been filling the airwaves of Washington -- and selected states and Congressional districts -- as interest groups seek to mold opinion on Capitol Hill and convert fence-sitters in Congress. One of the hottest topics is whether a health care plan should be designed to cover every American. President Clinton says he will veto any legislation that does not include such universal coverage.
 
PRO: The American Association of Retired Persons.
Chart: "TRANSCRIPTS: Overhauling Health Care: Two Campaigns"
ON THE SCREEN -- The ad opens with a black screen with the words "One Family's Story," then shows a kitchen scene where a husband and wife and an older woman are sitting at a table, while a young teenager walks in the background.

As a result, it may preach more effectively to those already converted to the cause of national insurance than to those who oppose such a sweeping step.
WHERE IT IS SHOWN -- On CNN and in the Washington area.
 
CON: Citizens for a Sound Economy

But it closes on a strong point, appealing to viewers' pragmatism with a warning that Congress should just fix what is broken in the health care system instead of embarking on a top-to-bottom overhaul.
WHERE IT IS SHOWN -- Washington and selected states and districts. In Louisiana, for example, the advertisement ends by urging viewers to call Senator John B. Breaux, a Southern moderate who has at different times opposed or supported requiring employers to provide insurance for their workers. The ad urges viewers to "tell him that mandated universal coverage is not a universal cure -- and he should vote against it." The Senator's name and telephone number appear on the screen.

HEADLINE: WORLD CUP '94;
Two Stars Share Brilliance And Little Else

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TORRANCE, Calif., July 16

 BODY:
Player by player, the coach announced Italy's lineup in a hushed hotel ballroom this morning, but all the names were superfluous except for one. Roberto Baggio. A few days ago, his name meant emotional rescue in the World Cup. Now it was a gloomy password, signifying injury and uncertainty.
"There is still some question mark," Coach Arrigo Sacchi said, referring to Baggio's strained hamstring. "We will try in practice today and we will make a final decision tomorrow." 
 Tentatively, Baggio has been placed in the starting lineup for Sunday's World Cup final. Perhaps Sacchi will save him for the second half, knowing that Brazil has seldom scored in the first.
In any case, all the world -- save perhaps Brazil's defense -- hopes he can play. For it is Baggio and Romario of Brazil who have defined this tournament with their personalities, keen sense of drama and potent ability to score.
Romario is a cunning genius, Baggio a tortured savior. Their teams rely on them the way the Chicago Bulls depended on Michael Jordan. With them, anything is possible. Without them, victory seems remote, unattainable.
"If Brazil wins the final, Romario will be the player of the World Cup," said the former French star Michel Platini. "If Italy wins, it will be Baggio."
Their unrivaled success in the tournament has elicited wild devotion, throbbing national passion and the purplest of prose. At a hotel restaurant near Los Angeles International Airport the other night, a table of several dozen Brazilian fans broke into loud, rhythmic cheers of "Romario, Romario" at regular intervals. After his two goals provided Italy's 2-1 semifinal victory over Bulgaria, Baggio was pictured in a Milan newspaper surrounded by a penumbra of soccer balls and deified with the headline: "St. Baggio from N.Y."
"Baggianism," wrote Curzio Ma in La Stampa, a Turin newspaper, is "the only faith which unites Italians in the world."
Not to be outdone, Fernando Calazans of Rio's O Globo newspaper wrote that Romario "seems touched by the aura of champions. Blessed the breeze that blows in favor of Romario; it takes us, sweetly levitating, to the finals of the World Cup."
What the players have in common is transcendence in the same profession and little else. Where Baggio, who is 27, is humble, Romario, who is 28, is audacious. Where Baggio married quietly and took a villa next to his parents, Romario married on the penalty spot of a soccer stadium before a live television audience.
Where Baggio posed this spring for two friends who drove 125 miles to take his picture, Romario called a news conference to announce that he would not sit next to Bebeto on the team charter. When Pele said Romario should leave coaching to the coaches, Romario labeled him a "museum piece" and called him "mentally retarded." He believes there is a necessary egotism and selfishness to his job of scoring goals.
"I know I am a difficult guy," Romario said before the World Cup. "It's because I'm the real thing."
Both Romario and Baggio have scored five goals in the World Cup, but comparisons between them are necessarily awkward. They play different positions, employing contrasting styles. Romario is a pure striker, "king of the penalty area," as his coach, Carlos Alberto Parreira, calls him; Baggio is neither a pure forward or a midfielder but a hybrid called a withdrawn forward.
Romario has roamed to midfield during this tournament, but his singular skill is to root himself patiently in the penalty area, appearing inert and inattentive, then pouncing on any opportunity to score. He plays straight-ahead, bulling his way toward the goal with a muscular dribble and deceiving speed in short bursts. If this were American football, he would be a fullback brought in to punch the ball across the goal line.
"Romario is a specialist, not a player to compare to others who fight to get the ball, who run and move," said Pele, the greatest Brazilian player of them all. "When he gets the ball, he's very dangerous. He can give the pass if there is no space or he can make space for himself. He's quick with the ball. No doubt he's the best striker today in the World Cup."
Romario is squat and sturdy, Baggio is short and fragile. Baggio wears a braided ponytail and is known as Il Divino Codino, the divine pigtail. He is more of a playmaker than Romario and has an acute radar for placing shots into the net from impossible angles. His 60-yard bob-and-weave against Czechoslovakia was the most attractive goal of the 1990 World Cup.
"He's able to dribble through 11 players and score," said his teammate Antonio Conte.
 
Italian Player, Latin Style
 An indifferent student, Baggio said in an interview before the World Cup that as a kid he dreamed of scoring the winning goal in the 90th minute of the World Cup final. Today he may get his wish.
"Baggio is the only player in Italy who has the Latin style," Pele said, referring to his flair. "This is the player Carlos Parreira had better play very smart against. He can change a game in one second."
Baggio's World Cup, like his career, has been a real-life version of Mr. Toad's Wild Ride. Knee injuries cost him two seasons, bringing doubt and introspection; eventually, Baggio converted from Catholicism to Buddhism. He was benched for the start of the semifinals in the 1990 World Cup, which Italy lost in a penalty-kick shootout to Argentina. He played limply early in this tournament, was yanked from the Norway game for strategic reasons and was later called a "wet rabbit" by Gianni Agnelli, the Fiat car magnate who operates the Juventus club team for which Baggio plays in the Italian League.
"The criticism didn't bother him," said his teammate Nicola Berti. "Playing in the Italian League, you're used to being criticized every day."
By the round of 16, Baggio had returned to form. Italy was a minute from exiting when he tied Nigeria then won the game in overtime. Against Spain in the quarterfinals, he delivered the winning goal in the 88th minute. Against Bulgaria in the semifinals, Baggio produced two early goals before limping off with a balky hamstring.
Afterward, Baggio cried and said in operatic style, "This is my life; it is made of sweat and tears."
Romario has proceeded with less melodrama and more of a sense of inevitability. He has forecast that this would be "Romario's World Cup" with a seemingly bold accuracy. More than Baggio, Romario seems to have an undiluted sense of his place in his country's history, where success in soccer is a bandage that covers deep political and economic wounds. This week, he announced that he was starting a soccer school for children.
"We are aware that socially, politically, economically, Brazil is in bad shape," Romario said this week. "If we get out of here champions of the world, many things will be left behind. Soccer will take center stage. But these problems have to be solved. We've gone 24 years without winning, so we need to celebrate, but one week, two weeks later, we've got to end that and start living Brazil's life. The poor children have to be looked at. We can't forget about that."

PUB-DATE: July 17, 1994

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 509 words

HEADLINE: Look Again at Taiwan

 BODY:
If buying $8 billion worth of American products entitles China to flout President Clinton's human rights requirements and still win renewal of its trade privileges, buying twice that amount should entitle Taiwan to a little diplomatic respect.
Taiwan has one of Asia's most developed economies, best armed militaries and most vibrant democracies. Yet Taiwan's President is not allowed to stay overnight on American soil, Taiwanese officials are not allowed to meet their U.S. counterparts in government buildings and Taiwan's diplomatic offices in this country cannot use any name that would identify the country they represent. 
 This charade reflects the long-held position of both Taipei and Beijing that there is only one China and that it includes both the mainland and Taiwan. Washington abided by this fiction both before and after it switched U.S. recognition from Nationalist Taiwan to the Communist mainland in 1979.
But in reality two distinct societies, economies and political systems have grown up on either side of the Taiwan Straits. And despite its official "one China policy," Taipei now seeks diplomatic recognition as a separate political entity.
That has prompted the Clinton Administration to undertake a cautious review of U.S. policy. The resulting recommendations await White House approval. They would ease some of the more humiliating diplomatic restrictions now in force. Cabinet-level visits in both directions would be permitted. Meetings could take place on official premises. Taiwan's unofficial representative offices could be renamed. These are useful steps, meant to make it easier for Americans to do business with the country's fifth-largest trading partner.
But recognizing reality should not stop there. Taiwan is too important a factor in East Asian politics, economics and security to be left out of the new post-cold war order now taking shape. It belongs in the new World Trade Organization. It ought to be included in the Asean Regional Forum on security being launched in Bangkok later this month. And ideally, it should be admitted to the U.N.
The main obstacle to Taiwan's inclusion in such organizations is the bellicose opposition of mainland China, which openly asserts the right to invade and annex Taiwan if the Government there acts too independently. Beijing claims that its relations with Taiwan are an internal matter to be resolved by the two sides alone without outside involvement.
It is not in America's interest to provoke China on this score. But shutting Taiwan out of international forums also carries risks for the U.S. Under present arrangements, if China made good on its threats to attack, other Asian countries would look the other way while the United States, alone, would find itself caught in the middle of the fray.
Last year, Washington helped arrange a compromise formula that let Taiwan participate in the Asia-Pacific economic summit meetings in Seattle. Now it should begin exploring ways to involve Taiwan in the new regional security forum as well.
